Now there are four gutturals. They start with the ayin, which is followed by the chet.240The ayin is the hardest guttural to pronounce. Hence it is the first guttural. Next comes the chet, the second hardest guttural to pronounce (Weiser). Then comes the heh, followed by the alef. Do not consider all the letters that make up the name of a guttural in your definition of a guttural, as the additional letters are not made by the throat.241Only the first letter of a guttural spelled out is a guttural. The others are not. For example, ayin is spelled ayin, yod, nun. Only the ayin is a guttural. The yod and nun are not. We find this to be the case with all of the gutturals. It is best to refer to them as sounded with a pattach.242It is best to refer to the ayin and alef as the ah sounds, to the chet as the cha sound, and to the heh as the ha sound. In this way the guttural sound is fully enunciated. Now the ayin and chet are very hard to sound. A person who is not accustomed to pronouncing them in his youth will not be able to sound them properly. Thus the gentiles cannot sound them.243The reference is to the Christians. They cannot properly sound the ayin or chet, as there is no equivalent sound in the Latin alphabet. Hence only the alef and heh were chosen from among the gutturals to serve as ministering letters.244Since these gutturals are easy to pronounce they were chosen to serve as prefixes, suffixes, and prepositions. The medieval grammarians refer to letters which serve as prefixes, suffixes, and prepositions as me’sharitim, ministering letters. Ministering letters were also chosen from among the palatals, i.e., gimel, yod, kaf, kof, as the palate is next to the throat. The yod and kaf were chosen from the palatals to serve as ministering letters because they are the easiest palatals to pronounce. The gimel and kof are therefore only used as root letters.

The letters dalet, tet, lamed, nun, and tav are linguals. Two letters, the dalet and the tet, were chosen from the linguals to serve only as root letters. The others serve both as root letters and as ministering letters. The letters zayin, samekh, shin, resh, and tzadi are dentals. They are all hard to pronounce.245Hence, with the exception of the shin, they serve only as root letters. The shin is the easiest of the dentals to sound. Hence it was chosen as a ministering letter while the others were left to serve only as root letters. Therefore three letters were chosen from among the labials, namely, the bet, vav, mem, and peh, to serve as ministering letters.246Since half of the Hebrew alphabet serve as ministering letters and only one dental was chosen as a ministering letter. Three labials were chosen to complete the complement of 11 ministering letters. The peh was left to serve only as a root letter.

It is only right that the alphabet begin with a guttural, because the throat is the first organ in the framework of the human body to produce a sound.247The head is on top of the body. The throat, the top of which is connected to the head, is the first organ to produce speech. Hence the alphabet opens with a guttural (Krinsky). It does so from bottom to top.248It lies at the bottom of the head but its sound is heard in the mouth, which is above it. The alef comes before the heh because it is the easiest guttural to pronounce. Hence the alef heads all the other letters of the alphabet and is equivalent to the number one. It is fitting that the heh be the fifth number equivalent to the glorious number five.249The heh, the second most easily pronounced guttural, was chosen to represent the fifth letter of the alphabet, which serves as the number 5. This is so, as I.E. has previously explained, because the number 5 is a glorious number. A guttural was chosen to represent this number because the guttural was made by the “first” organ in the body. These two letters are the easiest to enunciate. Now since the first letter of the alphabet is a guttural the second letter in the alphabet was chosen from among the five labials, which are produced by the last of the body’s five organs of speech.250The order of the organs producing speech are: throat, palate, tongue, teeth, and lips. Now since the first letter of the alphabet is produced by the throat, I.E. believes it is only right that the second be produced by the lips, the last organ in the head to produce speech. Hence the bet follows the alef, the vav also follows the heh, and the peh the ayin.251Since a labial (the bet) follows the first guttural of the alphabet (the alef), a labial (a vav) follows the guttural heh and a labial (a peh) follows the guttural ayin. Now it was necessary to put in two letters between the bet and the heh. A palatal, the gimel, was chosen as the third letter and a lingual, the dalet, as the fourth letter.252The palate is the second organ of speech, the tongue the third, and the teeth the fourth. The master of the Hebrew language decided to follow the order of the organs of the body in choosing the first, third, fourth, and sixth letters. He did not follow this order for the second and fifth letters because of the reasons already noted by I.E. Hence a dental, namely, the zayin, follows the vav. The Hebrew grammarian now had to use the fourth of the implied letters253The yod. The implied letters are alef, heh, vav, and yod. for the tenth letter, which is equivalent to the number ten. He had already used the gutturals alef and heh whose great importance has previously been explained as the first and the fifth letters. He had similarly used the vav, which happens to be a very important and easily sounded labial. Now there are no root letters more easily pronounceable than the palatals. He chose from the palatals the yod and the kaf to serve as ministering letters. The more easily pronounceable of the two is the yod.254Hence the yod rather than the kaf was chosen as the tenth letter.

Four letters are fit to be implied letters.255The alef, heh, vav, and yod. The alef is silent in all vowels256The alef is present as a silent letter in each one of the vowels. because it is equivalent to the number one. We find the alef with the cholam in the word rosh (head);257Spelled resh, alef, shin. with the kamatz in roshim (heads);258Spelled resh, alef, shin, yod, mem. with the chirik in the word rishon (first); with the tzere in reshit (beginning of);259Spelled resh, alef, shin, yod, tav. with the shuruk in pura (boughs)260Spelled peh, alef, resh, heh. in Shall lop the boughs (Is. 10:33); with the pattach in chattat (purification)261Spelled chet, tet, alef, tav. in For purification and for sprinkling (Zech. 13:1); and with the segol in pele (wonders)262Spelled peh, lamed, alef. in doing wonders (Ex. 16:11). It serves as a first person imperfect prefix in the masculine and in the feminine because it is the first letter of the alphabet. Since the alef is never sounded when it comes at the end of a word, it does not serve as the sign of the feminine.263The heh serves this purpose. However, it occasionally takes the place of the heh, as in marah (bitter)264Spelled mem, resh, alef. The usual spelling is mem, resh, heh. in call me Marah (Ruth 1:20) and in gaveha (was exalted)265Spelled gimel, bet, heh, alef. The usual spelling would be gimel, bet, heh, heh. in its stature was exalted (Ezek. 31:5). The alef is also found employed as a superfluous letter at the end of a word, as in ve-attikeiha266The last letter in ve-attikeiha is an alef. The latter alef is superfluous. (and the galleries thereof) (Ezek. 41:15) and he-halekhu267The last letter of he-halekhu is an alef. The latter alef is superfluous. (that went) in that went with him (Joshua 10:24). It is also found as a sounded superfluous letter at the beginning of a word, as in etmol268The alef in etmol is superfluous. The basic word is temol. Compare, Ex. 5:8; I Sam. 15:20; 20:27. (yesterday) (II Sam. 5:2) and ve-ezro’i269The more usual form is zero’i. Hence the alef is superfluous. The text of I.E. reads, ezro’akha. However, the correct reading is ezro’i, as the word ezro’akha is not found in Scripture. (and my arm) (Job 31:22). It is similarly used in the middle of a word, as in ve-he’eznihu (shall become foul) in And the rivers shall become foul (Is. 19:6). The alef is also found unsounded at the end of a word, as in the word chet (sin)270Spelled chet, tet, alef. (Deut. 23:22). At times the silent alef is dropped, as in the word kes (throne)271Spelled kaf, samekh. The usual spelling is kaf, samekh, alef. in the throne of the Lord (Ex. 17:14). At times it interchanges with a heh or a yod, as in ha-amon272Spelled with an alef in place of a heh. The usual spelling is hamon. (the multitude) (Jer. 52:15), which is a variation of he-hamon (II Sam. 18:29); or tityammeru273Spelled with a yod in place of an alef, for the root of the word is alef, mem, resh. (shall ye revel) (Is. 61:6), which is a variation of yitammeru (Ps. 94:4). It is also found sounded with a vav, as in tomeru (say ye)274In place of the alef. Actually there is no vav in tomeru in II Sam. 19:22. Either I.E.’s edition of the Bible had a vav, or I.E. quoted from memory and erred, or I.E. considered the cholam equivalent to a vav. in And say ye to Amasa (II Sam. 19:14).

Now these three letters275The heh, vav, and yod, the letters that the alef interchanges with. are fit to serve as prefixes and suffixes. The letter yod, which is similar to the number one (the alef),276The yod (numerically equivalent to 10) is the first of the letters which serve as tens (kaf=20, lamed=30, mem=40, etc.). serves as a first person suffix both in the masculine and in the feminine. In the verbal forms we find shamarti (I have kept) (Ps. 17:4) and amarti (I have said) (Ex. 23:13); among the nouns we find shemi (my name) (Ex. 23:21). The yod is also employed as a third person masculine imperfect prefix, as the number ten is like the number one.277See note 276. The alef, which is numerically equivalent to one, serves as a first person imperfect prefix. The letter yod, which is similar to the number one, i.e., the alef, serves as a third person prefix. In the feminine it is oppositely positioned and serves as a suffix,278It serves as a second person feminine suffix. as in de’i (know), re’i (see) (I Sam. 28:17), and tizkeri (thou mayest remember) in that thou mayest remember (Ezek. 16:63). This yod also shows relationship279A yod at the end of a word sometimes indicates relationship, e.g., yisra’eli, an Israelite; shimoni, a Simeonite. because as a numeral it is similar to the number one.280See note 276. The yod is a sign of the plural construct connected to the third person, as in yede (hands of) in The hands of women full of compassion (Lam. 4:10) and yadai (my hands) in even My hands have stretched out the heavens (Is. 45:12) because the number ten281The yod is numerically equivalent to 10. includes all numbers in it.282See note 172. The yod is encountered as a silent letter when it follows a chirik, as in ragli (my foot) (Ps. 26:10); a tzere, as in ragle (the feet of) in He will keep the feet of his holy ones (I Sam. 2:9); or a kamatz, as in yadav (his hands) and raglav (his feet). The yod is found in place of a heh283Later on I.E. will offer an example of this. (it is also found in place of a vav),284The words in parentheses are not in the text. However, they have to be added to make sense of I.E.’s comments. Some suggest that “the yod is found in place of a heh” be emended to “the yod is found in place of a vav.” If the emendation is accepted then we do not have to add what is in parentheses. as in hoyah (is) (Ex. 9:3), which is a variation of the word hovah (wouldest be) in and thou wouldest be their king (Nehemiah 6:6).285The participle form of the root heh, yod, heh is hovah. In hoyah a yod has been substituted for a vav. The yod takes the place of a heh in the word yechesayun (take refuge) (Ps. 36:8), which comes from the root chet, samekh, heh.286The heh of the root is missing in yechesayun. A yod takes its place. It takes the place of an alef in yisharti (to be right)287Yisharti (spelled with a yod) is a variant of the word isharti (spelled with an alef). in all precepts…all things to be right (Ps. 119:128). The yod is found as a superfluous letter in the words yitzhar (oil)288The root of yitzhar is tzadi, heh, resh. The yod serves no purpose, and is therefore superfluous. (Num. 18:12), ha-yoshevi289The usual form is ha-yoshev. (that art enthroned) (Ps. 123:1), and rabbati290The usual form is rabbat. (great) (Lam. 1:1). The heh is also used to indicate the presence of a thing,291It is used in the sense of lo, behold, here is. for this is its meaning in he lakehem zera (Lo, here is seed for you) (Gen. 47:23). The heh is also sometimes used to introduce a question,292The heh ha-she’elah, the heh interrogative. as in ha-bemachanim (whether in camps) (Num. 13:19), and ha-niheyeh (whether there hath been) (Deut. 4:32); or as the sign of the definite article,293The heh ha-yedi’ah, the heh which indicates the definite article. as in ha-eved ha-ivri (the Hebrew servant) (Gen. 39:17) and ha-anashim (the men) (Gen. 19:5). The heh suffixed to a verb indicates a third person feminine perfect. It is similarly used with nouns.294A noun ending in a heh is feminine. The masculine form, on the other hand, was left without a sign.295Without a sign indicating gender. The point is that the heh is the sign of the feminine. The masculine form has no sign. Compare the word amar296The text reads, ameru. This is obviously a scribal error, for I.E. wants to contrast the third person perfect in the masculine and feminine. Ameru is a third person plural. See Krinsky. and the word amerah in saith Koheleth (Eccles. 7:27).297Kohelet is a feminine form, hence the word amerah, a third person feminine. The heh is also used as a sign of the feminine when the imperfect is combined with the pronoun, as in eshmerenah (I will watch her), yishmerennah (he will watch her),298Some versions have yivcharunnah (he will choose her). nishmerennah (we will watch her), tishmerennah (you will watch her), yishmeruha (they will watch her), shemarnuha (we watched her), and shimruha (watch her). The heh serves as the sign of the feminine noun, compare, na’arah be-tulah (a damsel that is a virgin) (Deut. 22:28). The heh is appended to the hifil299Literally, the heavy. A heh is added to the root in the hifil. and also to the hitpa’el300A heh is also added to the root in the hitpa’el. conjugations. The heh is also at times dropped, as in the word mazzeh301Mazzeh is made up of mah and zeh. In mazzeh a heh is dropped since the word is spelled mazzeh, not mahzeh. It should be noted that mazzeh is the ketiv. The kere is mah zeh. (what is that) in What is that in thy hand (Ex. 4:2). It is similar to the yod of etzarekha302The root of etzarekha is yod, tzadi, resh. The yod is dropped in etzarekaha. (I formed thee) in Before I formed thee (Jer. 1:4), and it is like the alef of va-abbedkha303The root of abbedkha is alef, bet, dalet. The root alef is dropped in abbedkha, as the alef in abbedkha is a first person prefix. (and I have destroyed thee) in and I have destroyed thee, O covering cherub (Ezek. 28:16). It is also superfluously appended to the end of a verb, as in eshme’ah (I will hear),304The usual form is eshma. or a noun as in laylah (night).305The basic word is layil. See I.E. on Gen. 1:5. It is silent when following the kamatz, tzere, segol, cholam, or shuruk. Compare the words asah (made)306Vocalized kamatz heh. and boneh (doth build)307Vocalized tzere heh. in the Lord doth build up Jerusalem (Ps. 147:2); boneh (build)308Vocalized segol heh. in And the house which I build (II Chron. 2:4); pera’oh (let them loose)309Vocalized cholam heh. in for Aaron had let them loose (Ex. 32:25), also shelomoh (Solomon)310Vocalized cholam heh. and yikrechu311It is vocalized with a kubbutz but I.E. refers to it as a shuruk. (they shall not make baldness) (Lev. 21:5).

The vav is used as a connective and is in such instances placed in front of the word because the vav sound is made by connecting the lips. The vav is used as a connective in the phrases avraham ve-yitzchak (Abraham and Isaac) (Gen. 48:16) and in mi fa’al ve-asah (who hath wrought and done it) (Is. 41:4). The vav is also employed as a masculine and feminine plural perfect suffix. It is also used as a masculine imperfect suffix. It is similarly employed at times as a feminine imperfect suffix, as in im timtze’u (if ye find) (Cant. 5:8) and im ta’iru (that ye awaken not (Cant., 7:2).312Timtze’u and ta’iru are masculine plural imperfects. However, they are used as feminines. The vav is found as a silent letter when employed with the shuruk and cholam vowels. It is used as a masculine pronominal suffix with words in the perfect, as in shemaro (he watched him); with a noun, as in yado (his hand), and with a verb in the imperfect, as in yirdefo (will pursue him). It is vocalized with a shuruk following a heh, or a nun with a dagesh, as in yishmerehu (preserve him) (Ps. 41:3) or yishmerennu be’alav (its owner hath…kept it in) (Ex. 21:36), because the heh is used as a feminine suffix.313In other words, the heh is a feminine suffix and the vav a masculine suffix. The vav is also used as a sign of the plural in verbs in the perfect and imperfect.314For example, katevu (they wrote); yichtevu (they will write).

I have shown that these four letters315The alef, heh, vav, and yod. are implied letters. Therefore the proper names316The divine names EHYH and YHVH. that are constructed from these four glorious letters are glorious names. Now the first of these divine names317EHYH. This term for God is found only in our verse. is only found here. It is not encountered elsewhere in Scripture. We know that when Moses spoke to Pharaoh he enunciated God’s name as written. He did not employ any substitute.318Moses sounded out YHVH when he referred to God. He did not refer to Him as Adonai. Moses acted thus because he was holy. However,319Literally, therefore. the ancients320The reference is to the sages of the Talmud. See notes 322 and 323. were forced to use a substitute name when referring to God.321The point is that Moses, being holy, was permitted to sound out God’s name. However, later generations not as holy were prohibited from sounding out God’s name and therefore had to substitute Adonai for YHVH. The meaning of and this is My memorial is the same as this is My name,322That is, My memorial means My name. I.E. takes issue with the Talmudic statement that the term My name refers to the way God’s name is written (YHVH) and My memorial to the way that God’s name is sounded (Adonai). Cf. Kiddushin 71a: “This is My name forever (le’olam); it is written le’alem (to be concealed; i.e., God’s name is not ordinarily to be sounded)…R. Abina raised the following contradiction: It is written, This is My name to be concealed (le’alem). Then it is written, This is my memorial (which indicates that God’s name is to be enunciated). The Holy One, blessed be He, said: Not as My name is written shall it be pronounced. It is written Yod Heh (Vav Heh), but is pronounced Alef Dalet (Nun Yod-Adonai).” I.E. believes that the latter is aggadic and is not the literal meaning of the text. as our text employs two words with one meaning. Our reading of the divine name as Elohim whenever it is connected to Adonai,323Whenever the text reads Adonai YHVH we read it as Adonai Elohim. Cf. Deut. 3:34; Hab. 3:19. If the original reading of YHVH was Adonai we would read Adonai YHVH as Adonai Adonai. the meaning of which is, He324YHVH. is Lord,325The term Adonai was chosen as a substitute for YHVH. This substitution indicates that YHVH is Lord. is proof of the above.326That Adonai is not the original pronunciation of YHVH. This word comes in the plural327Adonai is a plural. It literally means my Lords. out of deference to God328“It is considered a sign of dignity to employ the plural when speaking of a superior” (I.E. on Gen. 1:1). in the same way that Elohim does.329Elohim is a plural. For a full treatment of the use of a plural in reference to God, see I.E. on Gen. 1:1. Hence if someone addresses the Lord in the same way that he addresses a person and says Adoni (my Lord),330If someone addresses God as adoni (my lord) he errs, as he is addressing God the same way that he addresses a human master. as in adoni sha’al (My lord asked) (Gen. 44:19), he errs.

I will now explain the meaning.331Of our verse, i.e., why God revealed His name to Moses. Know that there are three worlds.332Cf. Husik, op. cit., p. 190. One of them, the lower world,333That is, our world, the sublunar world. consists of objects that are on various levels of importance.334The term used by I.E. is ma’alot. The word can mean levels, steps or virtues. However, they can be classified in three groups.335Medieval philosophy classified whatever is found on the earth in three groups: domam (dead matter), tzome’ach (plants), and chai (living beings). I.E. follows this classification. The first is the metals, which number seven336The seven metals are: gold, silver, mercury, copper, tin, lead, and iron. and correspond to the seven stars.337Literally, the seven ministers. The reference is to the moon, Mercury, Venus, the sun, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. At a higher level come the plants, which have many levels of value. Above them come living things, which have many levels of importance. Man alone is on the highest level in this lower world.338Man is the most noble creature on earth. Nothing on earth is as important as man. Change befalls him in his body. Also his soul changes with his thoughts.339By thinking noble thoughts man elevates his soul. By thinking base thoughts man debases his soul. Similarly, change befalls his occupation and his affairs.340Stability was considered by the medieval philosophers to be a sign of perfection. Change was a sign of imperfection. Cf. Maimonides on the nobility of unchangeable form and the baseness of changeable matter. The wise men have compared the genera which is the group that endures although the individuals which make it up perish.341To the shadow of a tree upon the ever-running water. See next line and the notes thereto. The wise men have compared the intransient species to the shadow of a tree upon the ever-running water.342This sentence is extremely verbose. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, “The wise men have compared the genera which are the group that endures [to a shadow] of a tree over running water.” This appears to be the original reading. Our text arose from the incorporation into it of various glosses that were written to explain I.E.’s somewhat vague sentence. His point is that the wise men compared the relationship of the eternal species, with regard to the transient individual, to the shadow that a tree casts upon moving water. The branch which casts the shadow remains, but the shadow keeps on changing because of the movement of the water.

The next world is the middle world. It too contains objects that are on various levels of importance. The five ministering stars343Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. They, in contradistinction to the sun and moon are unchangeable. are very important, as they are self-sufficient and do not die or diminish. Neither do their movements change, enlarge, or shrink. They do not ascend or descend. Howbeit, they do change greatly according to the arrangement.344According to the way the heavens are arranged. I.E. appears to be contradicting himself Only a few sentences above he wrote, “Neither does their movement change.” Here, however, he writes, “Howbeit, they do change greatly.” Weiser suggests that I.E. is referring to the forms of the ministering stars, the sun, and the moon. The forms of the latter change while that of the former never do. However, I.E. speaks of movements, not of forms. Rabbi Joseph Ha-Sephardi suggests that what I.E. means is that the motion of the sun and moon actually changes while that of the ministering stars only appears to change. What I.E. apparently is saying is that the movement of the five “ministers,” left to themselves, would not change. However, the heavens are so arranged that their movements do change. At times a given star345The reference is to one of the “ministering” stars. is seen in the line of the zodiac; at other times it is seen at a greater or nearer distance to the left,346That is, north of the zodiac (Weiser). or at a greater or nearer distance to the right.347That is, south of the zodiac. Sometimes it ascends in its epicycle, at other times in its large sphere,348Its eccentric sphere. The stars appear to make various movements in the sky. To explain these movements, spheres within spheres were posited. See note 27 to I.E.’s introduction to Genesis. What applies to the movement of the moon more or less applies to the movement of the stars. for the center of the latter is far from the center of the earth.349This sphere is so called because the earth is not its center. Sometimes its sphere ascends or descends. At other times it runs. Sometimes it tarries. At other times it stands in its place. Sometimes it goes backwards. All of this is vis-à-vis the earth.350In reality there is no change in the movements of these stars. These movements only seem to change because they are viewed from earth (Joseph ben Eliezer Ha-Sephardi). See Yesod Mora, Chap. 12. Sometimes it is seen. At other times it is hidden. Sometimes it is in the east, at other times in the west. Its relation to its companion,351The star to which it is paired (Weiser). and also to the hosts of heaven above and to the moon below, is indeterminately forever changing because it352The star under discussion (one of the seven fixed stars) may be in conjunction with one of the other fixed stars. is sometimes in conjunction with one of the seven fixed stars.353The moon, Mercury, Venus, the sun, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. Now there are one hundred and twenty conjunctions in each one of the three hundred and sixty degrees.354The heavens are circular. There are 360 degrees in a circle. It is due to these irregular movements that different things happen to man’s body and certainly to his fortune in this lower world. However, these stars themselves do not change. The moon is therefore on a lower level than they, because whatever happens to the stars happens to the moon, and even more. They355The five ministering stars. See note 343. have two spheres, neither of which has the earth as its center. Furthermore, the moon’s movement in its epicycle is opposite that of the great sphere.356The inclined sphere (galgal ha-noteh) and the all-encompassing sphere (galgal ha-domeh). See note 27 to I.E.’s introduction to Genesis. Additionally, the moon by herself has no light. Her light comes from the sun. This can be seen from the fact that when the moon is in conjunction with the sun357That is, a solar eclipse. in the head or tail of the dragon358The point at which orbits intersect is called “the dragon” by medieval astronomers. Maimonides writes, “The regular orbit of the moon is inclined toward the regular orbit of the sun; one half of it is inclined to the north and the other half to the south. But there are two points in it diametrically opposite each other, at which the two circular planes intersect each other…The point from which the moon begins to deviate to the north of the sun’s orbit is called the head, while the other point, from which the moon begins to deviate to the south of the moon’s orbit, is called the tail” (Mishneh Torah; Laws of the Sanctification of the New Moon, chap. 16:1, 2, Yale Judaica Series, Vol. XI). during the day, the sun cannot be seen,359And it is dark all over. If the moon had its own light, its light would be seen. and if it faces the sun in one of the above-noted places at night360A lunar eclipse. the moon is invisible.361If the moon had its own light, it would not be eclipsed when the earth comes between it and the sun.

Now the stars that make up the sphere of the constellations are a level above the “ministers.”362See note 337. They are fixed in one sphere and they do not move as the ministers do. Their distances and relationship to each other do not change. They have one motion; it neither increases nor decreases. Their relationship to the earth is always the same. They appear different according to the place on earth where they are seen and the movement of the sun. The highest world is the world of the holy angels who are incorporeal and, unlike the souls of men, do not inhabit bodies. Their importance is far and above the understanding of their insignificant counterparts.363Human beings. The latter are counterparts to the angels, as man is created in their image. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26. This entire world is glorious and unchanging. There is no change in its arrangement. This world is not self-sufficient364As great as this world is, it is not independent of God. but its existence is dependent upon God the glorious. Man’s soul is of this same kind.365As the inhabitants of this world, the angels. It receives power from above in accordance to the arrangement of the ministers, that is, the arrangement of each “minister” vis-à-vis the great hosts at the time of a person’s birth. If the soul grows wise it will share the secrets of the angels and will be able to receive great power from an upper power that received it from the light of the angels. The person will then cleave to God the glorious. This is precisely what Jacob meant when he vowed, then shall the Lord be my God (Gen. 28:21). Jacob vowed that he would dedicate his entire life to cleave unto God to the fullest of his might. Jacob therefore said, Put away the strange gods that are among you (Gen. 35:2). Jacob did not utter these words till this point, for it was only now that he was going to serve God according to his vow. So too, Jethro, who said, Now I know that the Lord is greater than all gods. (Ex. 18:11).366Hence when he said, Now I know that the Lord is greater than all gods, what he meant was that he was now going to cleave only to God. Jethro was a very wise man.367Jethro advised Moses on the question of judges (Ex. 18:17). Proof of the latter is, And they asked each other of their welfare (Ex. 18:7). Additionally, Scripture states, and bowed down (Ibid.), which implies that Jethro did not stand in awe of Moses.368Jethro is called Moses’ colleague, as is implied in the word le-re’ehu in Ex. 18:7. Furthermore, Moses bowed in front of Jethro (Ibid.).

When Adam realized that he would die he sired a son so that the human kind would be preserved.369See I.E. on Gen. 4:1. He received the power to preserve the human genus.370The power to preserve the kind. However, the individual would die. Hence Eve371Who concurred with Adam. exclaimed, I have gotten a man with the help of God372The power to preserve the human race came from God. (Gen. 4:1). Each one of the sons of the prophets373Students of the prophets (bene ha-nevi’im) mentioned in the prophets. used to isolate himself in the hope of being inspired from on high according to his ability. Now it is via this name374YHVH. that new signs and wonders come into this world. When this name was told to Pharaoh375Literally, to him. he asked for signs and wonders.376When Moses told Pharaoh that YHVH sent him, Pharaoh asked for a sign to see if this power could change nature. Therefore this name is not found in the book of Koheleth, as this book speaks of things concerning which nothing can be added nor anything taken away (Eccles. 3:4). It deals with those things concerning which there is nothing new under the sun (Eccles. 1:9). It deals with those things which are based on the wisdom that comes from on high.377The book of Ecclesiastes deals with natural law. However, the name YHVH changes natural law. Hence it would be misplaced in Ecclesiastes.

GO, AND GATHER. Scripture reads, the God of Abraham378The name God is not repeated in our verse with Isaac or with Jacob. because God made a covenant with Abraham to give him the land of Canaan.379Canaan was first promised to Abraham (Gen. 15:18). God then promised Isaac and Jacob that he would keep the promise made to Abraham (Gen. 26:3-5; 35:11, 12) (Weiser).

[I HAVE SURELY REMEMBERED YOU.] The meaning of pakod (remembered) is that the time of their visitation had come.380The root peh, kof, dalet means to visit (cf. Ex. 20:5). Hence I.E.’s comment that pakod pakadti (I have surely remembered) means that the time that I should visit you (and keep my promise) has come. See Gen. 21:1 and the use of the word pakad therein.

AND I HAVE SAID. I have previously said to your fathers that I will bring you up out of the affliction of Egypt, the reference being to and afterward shall they come out with great substance (Gen. 15:14), and to and I will also surely bring thee up again (Gen. 46:4). Or its meaning is, I have now decreed381Va-omar, usually translated as and I have said, here means: and I have decreed. that this382What follows, in the verse. shall come to pass, as in Thou shalt also decree a thing (Job 22:28).383Job 22:28 reads, ve-tigzar omer. What it means is: ve-tigzar ge-zerah. We thus see that the root alef, mem, resh sometimes means to decree. Hence va-omar may be rendered: and I have decreed, rather than, and I have said.

AND THEY SHALL HEARKEN. When the word shama (heard) is followed by a lamed or bet its meaning is not to hear a voice but rather to hear the message which a voice carries. The yod in the word ha-ivriyyim (the Hebrews) has a dagesh for euphonic purposes. It is there to emphasize the yod genitive. The yod in ha-ivrim (the Hebrews) that follows the resh with a chirik beneath it is, in accordance with Hebrew grammar, the sign of the plural.384Chirik yod mem is the sign of the plural (ivrim, yeladim, etc.). Chirik yod indicates membership in a group (compare, ivri, yehudi, yisra’eli). Now when the two yods come together the gentilic yod is usually dropped. In our verse not only do we have two yods, but one of them receives a dagesh (thus doubling it). The extra yod and the dagesh are in our word for euphonic purposes, i.e., to emphasize the gentilic yod (Filwarg).

HATH MET WITH US. Nikrah (hath met) means the same whether spelled with a heh or an alef.385Here the word is spelled with a heh. In Ex. 5:3 it is spelled with an alef. Compare, nikro nikreti386Nikro is spelled with an alef. Nikreti comes from the root kof, resh, heh, for the yod takes the place of the heh in a first person perfect. Compare, nikrah in our verse. (as I happened by chance) (II Sam. 1:6). I will now explain the meaning of nikrah.387In Ex. 5:3 I.E. explains that nikrah (met) means the same as pagah (fall upon). Its meaning is, lest he fall upon us (Ex. 5:3).388That is, nikrah means fall upon, as in lest he fall upon us (Netter).

AND I KNOW THAT THE KING OF EGYPT WILL NOT GIVE YOU. Leave.389The word leave or permission must be added to the text. Our verse literally reads: And I know that the king of Egypt will not give (yitten) you to go. Or the meaning of yitten (give you) is, let, as in Therefore suffered I thee not (netatikha) to touch her (Gen. 20:6).390In this case nothing is missing from the text. Our verse reads: And I know that the king of Egypt will not let (yitten) you go.

[EXCEPT BY A MIGHTY HAND.]391The text literally reads: and not by a mighty hand. Hence the two explanations which follow. Neither will he let you go because of his mighty hand.392Pharaoh’s hand is mighty and he therefore sees no reason to let you go. However, Saadiah explains it to mean: neither will he let you go if he is struck once with a mighty hand.393In other words, it will take more than one plague to get Pharaoh to change his mind.
AND I WILL PUT FORTH MY HAND. Against his394Pharaoh’s. hand.395God will show Pharaoh that His hand is mightier than Pharaoh’s hand.

AND I WILL GIVE. The Egyptians’ appeasing of the Israelites by imploring them to ask for jewels and raiments (which is the meaning of va-yashilum)396The word va-yashilum (so that they let them have what they asked) is found in Ex. 12:36. I.E. renders va-yashilum: they implored them to ask. was also a great wonder.397Not only the plagues were wondrous. This too was a wonder. This is the opposite of the behavior of the world’s inhabitants.398People don’t go around imploring others to ask them for things.

[EMPTY.] The mem of rekam (empty) is superfluous.399Its root is resh, yod, kof. The mem has no meaning and apparently serves no purpose. The word rekam is used in the plural as in our verse.400Our verse reads, lo telekhu rekam (ye shall not go empty). Telekhu is a masculine plural. Hence rekam too must be a masculine plural. I.E.’s point is that the Bible employs the term rekam with the masculine feminine and the plural. See I.E.’s comments on Gen. 31:42 and the notes thereto. It is also used as a feminine in Go not empty401Tavo’i (go) is a feminine singular. Hence rekam (empty) too must be a feminine singular. Cf. I.E. on Gen. 31:42 and the notes thereto. (Ruth 3:17). The word chinnam is similar.402See I.E. on Gen. 31:42 and the notes thereto.

BUT EVERY WOMEN SHALL ASK. Now elsewhere it is written with regard to both males and females, and let them ask (Ex. 11:2).403We thus see that both males and females did the asking. The question thus arises: Why did Scripture state here that every woman shall ask? Scripture mentions females here because women are more in the habit of asking their neighbors for jewelry of gold and silver to put on the necks of their sons and daughters. They are likewise in the habit of asking for ear rings, nose rings, bracelets, crescents, and anklets. This is the contemporary custom in Moslem countries. However, the inhabitants of the land of the uncircumcised404Christian countries. do not act in this manner. Scripture similarly speaks of a sorceress,405Ex. 22:17 states, Thou shalt not suffer a sorceress to live. The same applies to a sorcerer. as women are more involved in witchcraft than men.406Cf. Sanhedrin 67a, Yerushalmi Sanhedrin 7:3, and Rashi and I.E. on Ex. 22:17.

AND OF HER THAT SOJOURNETH IN HER HOUSE. For the Israelites owned land.407Hence they had rooms or houses to rent to Egyptians. See I.E. on Gen. 47:27.Some complain and say that our ancestors were thieves.408For they asked the Egyptians for goods and had no intention of returning them or paying for them. Can’t these murmurers see that this was a command from on high? There is no sense in asking why? God created everything. He gives riches to whom He desires to give it, and when He wishes to, He takes the very same riches away. There is no evil in this, as everything is His.

AND YE SHALL SPOIL. Ve-nitzaltem (and ye shall despoil) is like ve-dibbartem (and speak ye)409That is, ve-nitzaltem is a pi’el. (Num. 20:8), for it is possible that its form is that of the nifal conjugation.410The word also looks like a nifal. However, in this case ve-nitzaltem means and ye shall be despoiled, an impossible rendering, for it was Israel that was doing the despoiling. Hence I.E.’s note that ve-nitzaltem is a pi’el, i.e., active, not passive. Krinsky quotes a reading: It is not possible that its form is that of the nifal. Compare, ve-niggaftem (and ye shall be smitten) (Lev. 26:17).

AND MOSES ANSWERED. God indicated1Literally, told. to Moses that the elders would believe in him.2I.E. was bothered by the following: since God told Moses, And they shall hearken to thy voice (Ex. 3:18) why did Moses now say, But, behold, they will not believe me. However, He did not mention this explicitly. And they shall hearken to thy voice (Ex. 3:18) relates only to behavior and not to inner belief.3Thus God never actually told Moses that he would be believed. It should be noted that Nahmanides had a different reading of I.E. According to Nahmanides, I.E. offers two answers to the question raised (see note 2). God told Moses that the elders would believe. He did not tell him that the people would believe. And they shall hearken to thy voice only relates to behavior, not to inner belief.

AND THE LORD SAID. This sign4The staff becoming a serpent. was not given to Moses so that he would believe, because He had already given him the sign of the bush.5The burning bush convinced Moses of the truth of his mission. God performed this sign for Moses so that Moses would imitate it before the children of Israel. It is therefore written, that they may believe (v. 5), which means, thus shall you do before them. God gave Moses a sign via an object that was always with him, the staff, Moses’ walking stick, as is the custom with elders.6Moses was then 80 years old and walked with a staff (Krinsky). Moses would not appear as a shepherd before Pharaoh.7Thus the staff in his hand was not a shepherd’s staff but the staff of an elder.

AND HE SAID. Those versed in the sciences ask,8In Hebrew, chakhme ha-mechkar (philosophers professing materialistic principles) (Friedlander). how is this possible?9For a staff to be turned into a serpent by being cast upon the ground. They were forced10To conclude by their philosophic inquiries. to conclude that it was to remove the dryness.11The dry wood of the staff became moist by coming into contact with the ground. It was then fit for life to enter it (Zarza). This explanation of course appears ridiculous to a modern person. However, all their words are empty wind, as we are dealing with a wondrous event, one that did not occur according to the laws of nature.

Yefet says that this wonder was a hint,12About Pharaoh. It explained Pharaoh’s nature. as Pharaoh was at first soft13By soft, I.E. means an object not inherently evil. Pharaoh at first did not oppress the Israelites. like a staff and then turned into a serpent. It is written, Pharaoh King of Egypt, The great serpent14Hebrew tannim. J.P.S. translates it as dragon. However, Yefet rendered it as serpent. (Ezek. 29:3). At the end he ended up the way he started; he was like one that never existed.15Like the serpent which turned back to a staff. Pharaoh the serpent of the Nile was defanged and broken like a dry stick.

AND THE LORD SAID. The first sign was performed upon the staff that was found in Moses’ hand. The second one was executed on Moses’ very hand.16Which became leprous. This raises a question: Leprosy is usually a sign of punishment. (Cf. Num. 12:10; II Chron. 26:20.) This being the case, why was Moses punished? Yefet says that his hand became leprous because he suspected that the Israelites would not believe him.17So too the sages of the Talmud and Midrash. Cf. Sabbath 57a; Shemot Rabba 3:12. Similarly Rashi. It is hard to understand why I.E. would quote a Karaite when he had traditional sources at his disposal that said the same thing. However, if this were the case,18That Moses was being punished. this should have been the first sign.19First Moses should have been punished by having his hand turned leprous and then shown the sign of the staff turning into a serpent. Rabbi Joshua says that this was a hint20In other words, Moses was not being punished. about Israel, who at first were free and then God plagued them with Egyptian bondage, and that God would eventually heal them and that they would be free once again.

AND THE LORD SAID. Saadiah Gaon says that chek (bosom) refers to the sleeve of the arm. Similarly u-ve-cheko yissa (and carrieth them in his bosom) (Is. 40:11) and sa’ehu ve-chekekha (carry them in thy bosom) (Num. 11:12).21According to Saadiah Gaon ve-cheko means in his sleeve and ve-chekekha in your sleeve. Others say that it refers to a garment that lies close to the chest.

AND IT SHALL COME TO PASS. We know that God knew whether they would believe or not. Scripture, however, speaks with regard to Moses,22Moses did not know how many signs he would have to do before all the people would believe him. viz., if there will be some Israelites who will not believe the first sign, then they will believe the latter sign (ha’ot ha-acharon). Scripture speaks of the voice of the sign. Now a sign has no voice. The Torah, however, speaks in the language of man,23See I.E. on Gen. 1:26. as it does in Death and life are in the power of the tongue (Prov. 18:21). Scripture speaks of the latter sign24Scripture refers to the second sign as the latter sign (ha’ot ha-acharon). However, in view of the fact that there were three signs, Scripture should have referred to it as the second sign. even though there were three signs, because God now showed only two signs to Moses,25The second sign was thus the latter sign at that moment. as He was yet to perform the third sign.

AND IT SHALL COME TO PASS. If there shall still be a few Israelites that will not believe the last sign, then you will show them the third sign and they shall believe. Indeed, it is written, and (Moses) did the signs in the sight of the people (v. 30). This third sign, namely, and the water…shall become blood upon the dry land was part of the first of the ten plagues which were destined to come.

AND MOSES SAID. All the commentaries agree that bi (oh) is to be taken as a supplicatory expression.26It means please or pray. However, Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi says that bi is an abridgement. It is short for bi ani adoni he-avon (Upon me, my lord, upon me be the iniquity) (I Sam. 25:24), that is, punish me as you wish27I.E. explains avon (iniquity) to mean punishment. See his comments on Gen. 4:13 and 43:20. Thus bi ani adoni he-avon means upon me, my lord be, the punishment. but relieve me of this task and do not send me.28I.E.’s elaboration of the implication of bi ani adoni he-avon in the context in which it is used in this verse. Similarly bi adoni yedabber na avdekha davar (oh my lord, let thy servant, I pray thee, speak a word in my lord’s ears) (Gen. 44:18). Its meaning is, do to me as you wish but allow me to speak.

A MAN OF WORDS. A person who knows how to speak elegantly, that is, a person who does not halt or stutter or have difficulty in enunciating certain letters. It is the custom of the Hebrews when they went to compare two or three things to add the word gam (also) to the first object,29Our text reads, gam mi-temol gam mi-shilshom (neither heretofore), gam me-az dabberekha el avdekha (nor since Thou hast spoken unto Thy servant). Literally translated, it means: also from yesterday and also from the third day, also since Thou hast spoken unto Thy servant. The first “also” appears out of place hence I.E.’s comment. I.E. then goes on to explain what Scripture means by the third day. as in Rule over us, also you, also your son and also your son’s son (Jud. 8:22).30This is the literal rendition of the verse. J.P.S. translates somewhat differently.

[HERETOFORE.] The explanation of the word shilshom (third day)31J.P.S. heretofore. See note 29. is as follows. The word temol (yesterday)32J.P.S. heretofore. See note 29. refers to the day before the one in which the person is speaking. Shilshom thus refers to the third day from which the person is speaking.33Hence shilshom (the third day) means three days ago. The point is that the Bible uses temol and shilshom back to back. Since temol means yesterday the word shilshom must mean three says ago, not the third day to come. The mem in shilshom is the mem of the plural34The masculine pronominal plural suffix. as it refers to today and yesterday,35That is, shilshom means their third day, i.e., today’s and yesterday’s third day (Weiser). even though its shin is not vocalized with a kamatz as the rules of grammar require.36If the meaning of shilshom is their third day (shalosh she-lahem) the word should have read shilsham. On the other hand, it is possible that the mem is appended at the end of the word as it is to the beginning of the word.37That is, the mem of shilshom is not the mem of the plural. It is a form (or superfluous) letter and has no meaning. Compare, the word mishlosh (three)38The mem in mishlosh has no meaning. See I.E. on Gen. 35:24. in And it came to pass about three months after (Gen. 38:24).

NOR SINCE THOU HAST SPOKEN. Me-az dabberkha (since thou hast spoken)39The word az means then. Hence I.E.’s comment that me-az means from the time or since. is to be rendered, from the time that thou hast spoken. Me-az (since) in For since I came to Pharaoh to speak in Thy name (Ex. 5:23) is similar, as40The reason that Moses said what is recorded in our verse. the slowness of his speech was not removed41By God when He revealed Himself to Moses. but remained as it was. The one who says that Moses forgot Egyptian42This commentator explains that slowness of speech and tongue refers not to a speech impediment but rather to Moses’ inability to speak Egyptian. The latter interpretation is offered by Rashbam. is incorrect, because Moses mentioned two things, viz., slowness of speech and slowness of tongue.43If the reference was merely to difficulty in speaking Egyptian, Moses would have limited himself to slowness of speech. Furthermore, we can learn from God’s answer, Who hath made man’s mouth? or who maketh a man dumb? that Moses was not referring to the Egyptian language.44God appears to be addressing a complaint about a physical impediment rather than one dealing with a lack of knowledge. The upshot of this is that Moses was born with slowness of speech; i.e., he could not pronounce the labials or all of the linguals.45Slowness of speech indicates a problem with labials, for the Hebrew word for speech is safah (lips). Slowness of tongue indicates a problem with linguals. However, he was able to pronounce some of them with difficulty. This is the meaning of, and I will be with thy mouth, and teach thee what thou shalt speak; i.e., God told Moses that He would teach him to speak with words that do not contain letters that he had difficulty enunciating.

AND THE LORD SAID. We find46In our verse. dumb corresponding to the making of the mouth, blind corresponding to seeing, while the word deaf stands by itself; it has no counterpart. However, in reality the word pike’ach (seeing) corresponds both to blind and to deaf,47It comes from the root peh, kof, chet, which means to open. Thus pike’ach can refer to one who can either hear or see. as it is written, pako’ach oznayim (opening the ears) (Is. 42:20); li-feko’ach enayim ivrot (to open the blind eyes) (Is. 42:7).
Behold, God did not now48As our verse may be taken to imply. promise Moses that He would remove the slowness of his tongue. He only promised to teach him what to speak.49See verse 12.

AND HE SAID. I have already explained50Gen. 12:11. that the word na (I pray) always means now in Scripture.51Hence shlach na (send, I pray) means send now. See, Speak now (na) in the ears of the people (Ex. 11:2); Hear now (na), O Joshua the high priest (Zech. 3:8); Let this man, now (na)52Translated according to I.E. J.P.S. translates as, We pray thee. be put to death (Jer. 38:4); Woe now (na)53Translated according to I.E. J.P.S. translation reads, Woe unto us; i.e., it does not translates na. unto us! for we have sinned (Lam. 5:16).

WHOM THOU WILT SEND. The word asher (whom) has been omitted.54From the clause shelach na be-yad tishlach (send, I pray thee, by the hand of him whom Thou wilt send). Its literal meaning is: send, I pray Thee (or now) by the hand of Thou wilt send, hence I.E.’s comment that the word asher (whom, i.e., he whom) has to be added to the text. The word asher can mean which, that, who, or in order to. Our verse is to be read as if written be-yad asher tishlach.55Which means via the hand of him whom you were in the habit of sending, i.e., Aaron. Rashi interprets similarly. Im levavam shalem (whose heart is whole) (II Chron. 16:9) is similar.56The word asher has to be added to the clause which is to be read as if written, asher im levavam shalem (of them whose heart is whole). Its meaning is, send this message by the hand of Aaron my brother57Literally, Aaron his brother. who is a man of words, for he is not of slow speech and he is in the habit of prophesying to Israel. Indeed, it is written in the book of Ezekiel that God sent a prophet to Israel before he sent our master Moses.58See Ezek. 20:5. I.E. identifies this prophet with Aaron. Scripture also states, And the Lord said to Aaron: Go into the wilderness to meet Moses (Ex. 4:27).59Which shows that Aaron was a prophet, as God spoke to him. Furthermore, since Aaron was older than Moses, he might be angry if Moses was appointed God’s messenger to Pharaoh.60Hence Moses suggested that God appoint Aaron to this task. It is for this reason that God told Moses, and when he (Aaron) seeth thee, he will be glad in his heart (Ex. 4:14).61That is, Aaron is not angry that you, his younger brother, have been chosen as God’s messenger. Now Moses did not refuse to go.62As God’s messenger, as a superficial reading of verses 10-14 implies.

What happened was that Moses first replied, I am not a man of words (v. 10), and it is difficult for one who is slow of speech to speak before the king. Moses thought that God63In response to Moses’ reply, I am not a man of words. would miraculously remove his slowness of speech. However, when God answered him, and (I) will teach thee what thou shalt speak (v. 12), Moses knew that his slowness of speech would not be removed. Moses thus wondered why God did not send Aaron to Pharaoh. It is for this reason that he said, send, I pray Thee, by the hand of him whom Thou wilt send. All of this can be clearly derived from God’s answer, Is not Aaron thy brother… (v. 14).64Is not Aaron thy brother implies that Moses suggested that Aaron be chosen in his place. When he (Aaron) seeth thee, he will be glad in his heart implies that Aaron is not angry for not being chosen. He (Aaron) can speak well implies that Moses was concerned with not being able to speak before the king.

AND THE ANGER OF THE LORD WAS KINDLED. Heaven forbid that this be the meaning of the verse, that the Lord…sought to kill him (v. 24),65That is, God sought to slay Moses (v. 24) because he at first refused the Lord’s call to be His messenger. See Rashbam on verse 24. as he should have killed him now when he refused to go, not when he went, as others have interpreted. Why kill him when he went?66Verse 24 describes what happened to Moses on his way to Egypt as God’s messenger. Our case cannot be compared to that of Balaam.67Where God told Balaam that he may go to Balak (Num. 22:20) and then sent an angel with a drawn sword to stop him (Num. 22:22), for Balaam had evil intentions (Krinsky). Similarly, the incident with Jacob is different.68Gen. 32:25 tells us that an angel tried to kill Jacob. However, that incident too cannot be compared to that of Balaam, for that angel was not sent to punish Jacob. So Filwarg. For other interpretations see Krinsky and Weiser. However, their interpretations are forced. Should someone argue, where do we find a case where God’s anger did not cause harm,69That is, once the anger of the Lord was kindled against Moses punishment had to follow. The only punishment that conceivably followed was that the Lord sought to kill him. we will show him, And the anger of the Lord was kindled against them (Num. 12:9),70Against Aaron and Miriam. yet no harm befell Aaron.71Thus punishment does not always follow the kindling of God’s anger.Scripture refers to Aaron as the Levite, for this is the way the Levite prophet72That is, Aaron. was known in Israel since there were others who bore this name.73There were other people who bore the name Aaron. Hence people referred to the Aaron who was the prophet as Aaron the Levite. Now Aaron’s appointment as spokesman74Literally, this thing. did not entail Moses’ demotion. On the contrary, Moses’ status was thereby elevated. Aaron was merely an instrument, similar to the mouth which brings forth the words of the invisible soul which, like the angels, cannot be seen because they are incorporeal. Moses’ station was thus similar to the station of an angel.75Moses was the “soul” of the words produced by Aaron. The soul is angelic; hence Moses was angelic. This is the meaning of And thou shalt be to him in Elohim’s (God’s)76That is, you will be as an angel to Aaron.stead (v. 16). Now Elohim in Scripture does not refer to anything but God the glorious or His holy angels77As in verse 16. Also see I.E. on Gen. 1:1. or the holy ones below who execute God’s justice in the world.78Judges. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1. Whenever Scripture refers to an idol by the term elohim79Which seems to indicate that elohim also means an idol. However, I.E. has just stated that it refers only to God, angels, and judges. it does so in keeping with the beliefs of its worshippers.80Thus even when elohim refers to an idol it means a god. It is similar to unto the prophet Hananiah81Who was not a true prophet, yet was called one. (Jer. 28:5).

AND…THIS ROD. Scripture refers to the signs82Scripture speaks of this rod, wherewith thou shalt do the signs. However, up to now Scripture speaks of only one sign that was to be done with the rod, i.e., its being changed into a serpent. because the rod changed into a serpent before all of Israel and into a serpent before Pharaoh. The rod was also used to strike the Nile, to bring up frogs, to produce gnats, to bring down hail, to bring locusts, and to cause darkness.83Many other signs were to be done with the rod in the future. Hence Scripture speaks of the signs.

AND MOSES WENT…JETHER.84This is the Hebrew reading. J.P.S. translates it as Jethro. Jether and Jethro are one and the same. Similarly, Geshem (Neh. 6:2) and Gashmu85This is the Hebrew reading. J.P.S. translates it as Geshem. (Neh. 6:6) are one and the same, as are Salmah86This is the Hebrew reading. J.P.S. translates it as Salmon. (Ruth 4:20) and Salmon (Ruth 4:21). Moses told Jethro that he was going to see his brethren. He did not reveal the secret to him.87That he was going at God’s command to liberate them.

AND THE LORD SAID. The Torah is not88Always. in chronological order.89What is reported in verse 19 had to take place before what is recorded in verse 18. It is illogical for Moses to have told Jethro that he was going to Egypt before being informed by the Lord that Pharaoh was dead. The meaning of and the Lord said is, and the Lord had said.90For the reasons noted in note 89 we must translate verse 19 as: and the Lord had said to Moses in Midian (i.e., before Moses had taken leave of Jethro), Go return into Egypt. Similarly, And out of the ground made the Lord to grow91See I.E. on Gen. 2:9. (Gen. 2:9) and many other such instances. Now when Moses was handing over Jethro’s sheep to Jethro, God assured him that he could go to Egypt without trepidation because Pharaoh and his servants who knew about the incident of the Egyptian were dead. This is the meaning of that the king of Egypt died (Ex. 2:23); as long as Pharaoh lived it was improper for Moses to be a messenger to him.92The same Pharaoh who knew of the incident of the Egyptian.

AND MOSES TOOK. We do not know whether Gershom was born at the time that Moses was a young man, when he fled to Midian, or during his old age. Do not rely on The History of Moses,93A medieval work dealing with the life of Moses. as everything written in it is nonsense. Moses’ second son, namely, Eliezer, was born now, at the time that Moses started to prophesy. Moses planned to bring his wife and sons to Egypt so that they could leave Egypt together with all of Israel. However, this was not a good idea; he was going to bring the Israelites out of Egypt and they would see that he came with his wife and children to live there.94Hence the Israelites would have reason to doubt whether they were really going to be brought out of Egypt. Do not be surprised that a prophet should incorrectly assess practical events,95That is, do not be surprised that a prophet can err as Moses did in wanting to bring his family to Egypt. for indeed we find that David asked Nathan the prophet whether is was proper for him to build a temple to the Lord.96This is the import of II Sam. 7:2. Nathan then answered him, All that is in thy heart do, for the Lord is with thee.97I.E.’s slight paraphrase of II Sam. 7:3. However, in a prophetic vision of the night, Nathan was told to inform David that he should not build the temple.98II Sam. 7:5-13.The elders99Who translated the Pentateuch into Greek. See Megillah 9a. were forced to translate upon an ass as upon the man carrier, because it is demeaning that the wife of the prophet and her two sons should ride on one ass.100For this implies that Moses was impoverished. Yefet101See notes and comments on Ex. 3:3. says that ass is used as a collective noun,102Thus more than one ass was used by Moses’ family. Therefore the verse does not imply that Moses was impoverished. as in And I have an ox and an ass (Gen. 32:6).103The meaning of which is: And I have oxen and asses. However, Yefet is incorrect. This is not the place to use collective nouns.104One uses the collective noun when one speaks of many of a kind. Here, at most two asses were involved and the use of the collective is out of place. The term105Ass. thus must be taken literally.106It refers to one ass. Now the asses in Egypt are dearer and more precious than the mules.107Hence Moses chose an ass rather than a mule for his family to ride upon. There is nothing to wonder about108Why Moses employed one ass for his family. His wife rode holding their infant son Eliezer and their other son rode behind her as children are wont to do. if his son Gershom rode behind his mother. Perhaps he was small109Young. See the opening of I.E.’s comment. This would make the scenario more acceptable, and not be demeaning to Moses. and Eliezer was in her bosom for he was not yet circumcised.

[AND HE RETURNED TO THE LAND OF EGYPT.] Its meaning is that only Moses himself returned.110The verse reads, And Moses took his wife and his sons…and he returned to Egypt. Hence I.E’s comment. When God met Moses (v. 24) Eliezer was circumcised (v. 25). When Eliezer was healed, Zipporah and her children returned to her father. Moses left them and went on to Egypt.

Scripture refers to the staff as the rod of God because of the sign that was performed with it.111Ex. 4:1-4. The rod of God is the same as the rod of Moses and the rod of Aaron. It was in his112Aaron’s (Weiser). hand when he did the signs.113When Aaron performed signs he held the rod. Hence it is also referred to as the rod of Aaron. Now that the rod of God is mentioned Scripture backtracks and relates that God told Moses114In general terms. all the wonders that he was destined to do in Egypt.115Verse 21. He mentioned116That is, he specifically mentioned. to Moses the sign that would bring Israel out of Egypt, namely, the plague of the first-born.117Verse 23.

[AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE WAY AT THE LODGING-PLACE.] This should have been connected to And Moses took his wife and his sons (v. 20).118The sequence of events is: And Moses took his wife and his sons, and set them on an ass. And it came to pass on the way at the lodging place, etc. That which is between these verses is parenthetical. There are many such cases in the Pentateuch, an example being, he shall make restitution (Ex. 22:2). The latter is connected to he shall pay five oxen for an ox (Ex. 21:37).119And not that which immediately precedes it.

AND THE LORD SAID. This was told to Moses in Midian.120When God told Moses, Go return into Egypt (v. 19) (Krinsky). God informed Moses that He would harden Pharaoh’s heart and that Pharaoh would not let them go despite all of the wonders, including the last one,121The plague of the first-born. Even after this plague Pharaoh changed his mind and tried to re-enslave the Israelites. that He would show them.122Nahmanide’s version of I.E. had, “God informed Moses that he would harden Pharaoh’s heart and that Pharaoh would not let them go despite the wonders until He would show (them) the last wonder.”

AND THOU SHALT SAY. The meaning of Israel is My son, My first-born123And what follows, i.e., verse 23. is: the ancestors of this nation were the first to serve Me. I therefore take pity on this nation as a father pities a son who serves him. You took him for a perpetual slave. I will therefore kill your first-born son.

AND I HAVE SAID UNTO THEE. Behold, I have told you time and time again to let My son go, that he may serve Me by offering sacrifices to Me, and thou hast refused to let him go. I will therefore punish thee.124I.E.’s paraphrase of verse 23. The ignorant say that these words are directed at Moses.125Moses refused to go to Egypt to liberate God’s first-born son (Israel). God therefore threatened to kill Moses’ son. This explains the sequence which follows in verse 24. The latter is sheer madness. Furthermore, Eliezer126The son of Moses that God wanted to kill (v. 24). was not Moses’ first-born.127If God wanted to kill Moses’ first-born because Moses did not have pity on His first-born, then Gershom should have been threatened.

AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE WAY. They had a tradition that a child should not be circumcised on the eighth day if he was sick, or while traveling when it was not possible for his guardian to tarry and circumcise him. Now because Moses could not tarry in carrying out God’s mission he concluded that he should not circumcise his son, because the child would be in danger if he were taken along.128After circumcising him. God therefore sent an angel129This is the meaning of that the Lord met him. to tell Moses to put his decision aside130Not to circumcise Eliezer. and to circumcise the lad. The child would then remain with his mother until healed and Moses would continue on by himself.

[THAT THE LORD MET HIM.] Its meaning is that God sent an illness upon Moses because it did not occur to him.131To circumcise his son at that time. I.E. literally reads: Its meaning is, an illness came upon Moses from God that he did not think. This then is the meaning of and sought to slay him: God sought to slay Moses if he would not circumcise his son. Now because Moses was seized with trembling132He was shivering due to the illness. he could not circumcise his son. Zipporah circumcised him, for Moses revealed this secret to her.133That he was ill because he did not circumcise his son. Do not be surprised that it is written, That the Lord met him;134I.E. explains that God sent an angel to tell Moses to desist from his decision. However, the verse implies that it was God Himself who met Moses. the reference is to an angel of the Lord. And the Lord went before them (Ex. 13:21) is similar, and there it is written, And the angel of God…removed (Ex. 14:19). However, Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni135The last Gaon of Sura. He died in 1034 C.E. says: Perish the thought that God would seek to slay Moses who was on God’s mission to redeem His people. It was rather Eliezer whom the Lord sought to slay, and it is to Eliezer that the third person pronominal suffixes of va-yifgeshehu (met him) and hamito (slay him) refer. Scripture then goes on to explain that the reference is to Eliezer.136That is, to her son. The name Eliezer is not used in our passage. Scripture therefore states, and cut off the foreskin of her son. He is not at first mentioned137Scripture refers to Eliezer by the term him. However, before referring to a person in the third person, one has to first identify him. I.E. thus explains that Scripture does not identify the object of va-yifgeshehu and hamito because he did not yet have a name. because he did not as yet have a name. And it came to pass, when she travailed, that one put out a hand (Gen. 38:28) is similar.138Scripture does not identify the one that put out his hand because he was not yet named.

THEN ZIPPORAH TOOK A FLINT. A sharp instrument.139According to I.E. the word tsor (flint) is not to be translated as flint but as something sharp and hard as a flint, that is, a sharp instrument. Compare, Make thee knives of flint140Hebrew, tzurim. (Josh. 5:2) which refers to sharp knives. Yea, thou turnest back the flint (tzur) of his sword141J.P.S. translates as edge of his sword. (Ps. 89:44) is similar.

[AND CAST IT AT HIS FEET.] In my opinion the reference is to Moses’ feet. Our verse is like142That is, the placing of the bloody foreskin on Moses’ feet was similar to the placing of the blood on the side-posts and lintels of the Israelite homes; i.e., it prevented the destroyer from killing. and when He seeth the blood upon the lintel, and upon the side-posts, the Lord…will not suffer the destroyer to come in unto your houses to destroy you (Ex. 12:23). Therefore143Because of what Zipporah did. He let him, that is, Moses, alone; his illness and shivering ceased. However, Rabbi Samuel144Rabbi Samuel ben Hofni. says that his feet refers to Eliezer’s feet,145Rabbi Samuel’s comment is in keeping with his interpretation that it was Eliezer rather than Moses who took ill. and similarly He let him alone.146The reference is again to Eliezer. This being the case we can refute him by asking, “If the illness befell Eliezer how could Zipporah circumcise him, thereby adding pain to his pain?”147The idea is that it would be either dangerous or cruel.
[A BRIDEGROOM OF BLOOD.] It is the custom of women to refer to a child as a bridegroom when he is circumcised.
[BLOOD.] Its meaning is, surely thou art a man of blood to me,148Cf. II Sam. 16:8, because (surely) thou art a man of blood. Thus blood means bloody. for because of you my husband will die.

SO HE LET HIM ALONE. The word damim (blood) in Hebrew is used in two ways. One way is to indicate bloodshed, as in because thou art a man of blood to me (II Sam. 16:8).149“To me” is not found in the verse quoted. I.E., under the influence of his comment on the word blood, added the words to me to II Sam. 16:8. The person who says that damim refers to life150This commentary takes blood to mean life because a living person has blood flowing through him. According to this commentary, Surely a bridegroom of blood art thou to me means: Surely a live bridegroom are thou (Moses) to me; i.e., thou art alive because I circumcised Eliezer. Similarly the word blood in the next verse. It should be noted that in Ex. 22:2 Rashi explains dam (blood) as alive and I.E. takes issue with him there (Filwarg). is giving the word a meaning that it does not have. The second way151That the word damim is used. is as a plural referring to actual blood,152The singular being dam. as in be-damayikh chayi (in thy blood live) (Ezek. 16:6). Now when Zipporah saw that the illness left Moses she exclaimed, you my son are not a bridegroom of blood, blood referring to death,153That is, you are not a bloody bridegroom. but you are a bridegroom wallowing in the blood of circumcision. The word mulot (circumcision) is a noun. It is in the plural154Prima facie, the singular should have been used. because of damim (blood).155Damim which precedes mulot is in the plural; i.e., the word mulot is in the plural because it follows damim.

AND THE LORD SAID TO AARON. Aaron did not prophesy;156God told Aaron, Go into the wilderness to meet Moses. He did not tell him to prophesy before Pharaoh (Weiser). there was no need for him to do so157Henceforth. as Moses was the messenger sent to Pharaoh. It was rather the elders who spoke to them.

THEN THEY BOWED. Va-yikkedu (then they bowed) comes from a double root.164Its root is kof, dalet, dalet. It is like the word kodkod (skull).165The root of which is kof, dalet, dalet. Va-yikkedu follows the paradigm of va-yittemu (were ended)166From the root tav, mem, mem. in so the days of weeping in the mourning of Moses were ended (Deut. 34:8) and yiddemu (they are still)167From the root dalet, mem, mem. in they are as still as stone (Ex. 16:16). If only those who say that these words168That is, va-yikkedu, va-yittemu, and yiddemu. come from roots that begin with a nun169That is, that the root of yikkedu is nun, kof, dalet; of yittemu, nun, tav, mem; and of yiddemu, nun, dalet, mem. would be as still as stone. In order to explain the paradigm170The point is that the words yikkedu, yittemu, and yiddemu follow the paradigm of roots that begin with a nun. Compare, yippelu from the root nun, peh, lamed, and yittenu from the root nun, tet, nun. Hence they conclude that the former come from similar roots. See note 168. they add roots that are nonexistent in the holy tongue.171For they make peh nuns out of double roots. See note 168. Can they not see that the word redu (get you down)172From the root yod, resh, dalet. (Gen. 42:2) follows the paradigm of benu (build ye)173From the root bet, nun, heh. in Build ye (lakhem) houses (Jer. 29:5)174The word lakhem (ye) is not in Jeremiah. The reference might be Num. 32:24, which reads, Build you (lakhem) cities. In any case, if this is not a scribal error then I.E. quoted from memory and erred. although they are two different175The literal reading is: and they are roots. “Two different” is not in our text, but it is in Vat. Ebr. 38. In any case, it has to be inserted in order to make sense. roots.176We thus see that words from different root families can follow similar paradigms. THAT THEY MAY HOLD A FEAST (VE-YACHOGU) UNTO ME IN THE WILDERNESS. He merely asked, “Who is this God YHVH (the Lord)?” We learn this from Moses’ answer to Pharaoh, which follows.11Moses answered Pharaoh that YHVH is the God of the Hebrews. We deduce from this that Pharaoh had asked, “Who is this God YHVH?”

AND THEY SAID. This name12The Tetragrammaton. refers to the God of the Hebrews. The Hebrews were a group whom the Egyptians were familiar with.13Hence Moses identified YHVH as the God of the Hebrews. The term Hebrew refers to Abraham, who is called the Hebrew.14See Gen. 14:13. It likewise refers to Abraham’s son Isaac and to Jacob and his sons,15It thus applies to the Israelites, hence the term, “the God of the Hebrews.” I.E. explains that the term Hebrew refers to Israelites because there were some commentators who believed that it applied to non-Israelite descendants of Abraham. AND THEY SAID. The word nikra (hath met) is similar to nikro nikreti (as I happened by chance)16The Hebrew word for met comes from the root kof, resh, heh (karah). However, nikra (spelled with an alef) comes from the root kof, resh, alef. I.E. points out that the alef and the heh interchange. For nikro (spelled with an alef) comes from the root kof, resh, alef and means met, (happened by chance) while nikreti (I happened by chance), from the root kof, resh, heh (the heh changes to a yod in the perfect) has a similar meaning. We thus see that the word nikrah, whether spelled with an alef or a heh, means met. in As I happened by chance upon mount Gilboa (II Sam. 1:6). It means met. He explained to Pharaoh why they are obligated to offer sacrifices, i.e., lest a pestilence or sword come upon us.17I.E.’s paraphrase of lest He fall upon us with pestilence, or the sword.

LEST HE FALL UPON US. Upon us includes us Israelites, also you, Pharaoh, and all the Egyptians. When Pharaoh saw that swarms of animals came and devoured many Egyptians, as it is written, He sent among them swarms of animals, which devoured them18Translated according to I.E. (Ps. 78:45), he said, Go ye, sacrifice to your God in the land (Ex. 8:21).19In Egypt. However, Moses answered him, it is not meet so to do in the land20Of Egypt. (Ps. 8:22). It is furthermore written, and Moses24The word Moses is not in this part of the original verse. I.E. probably quoted from memory. builded an altar under the mount (Ex. 24:4). (Ex. 17:1), and it is there written, Behold, I will stand before thee there upon the rock in Horeb27Horeb is another name for Sinai. We thus see that Rephidim is very close to Sinai. (Ex. 17:6). AND THE KING OF EGYPT SAID. The word tafri’u (ye cause to break loose) means ye cause to disrupt.31That is, ye cause the people to spoil their work schedule (Krinsky). Cf.
