[AND THERE WERE GNATS UPON MAN, AND UPON BEAST.] Scripture notes this a second time because the plague was also upon the magicians.

THEN THE MAGICIANS SAID. When the magicians saw that unlike the changing of the rod into a serpent and the plague of blood and frogs where they were able to duplicate Aaron’s actions they were now unable to imitate what Aaron had done, they said to Pharaoh that this plague did not come to liberate Israel but was a disaster sent by God in keeping with the arrangements of the stars dealing with Egypt’s fortune. I have previously explained that Pharaoh did not deny the existence of a Creator.33See I.E. on Ex. 5:2. He only denied the existence of the God which Moses revealed to him. Our verse is explained by, it is not His hand that smote us; it was a chance that happened to us (I Sam. 6:9) from heaven. Hence Pharaoh’s heart was hardened. Our interpretation is supported by the fact that the magicians said, This is the finger of God, and not, this is the finger of the Lord, meaning the God of Israel, as Pharaoh did when he exclaimed, Entreat the Lord, with regard to the plague of frogs and then similarly used this term for God in the latter plagues.34When Pharaoh finally acknowledged that the plagues were sent by the God of Israel, he used the term Lord (Adonai) rather than Elohim (God) for the Deity. Adonai is the Lord’s proper name. Elohim is a generic name and in the Bible often refers to idols. Furthermore, Moses told Pharaoh that the Nile would be stricken before it was actually plagued, and he likewise informed him that the land would be inundated by frogs before they appeared. However, Moses did not inform Pharaoh that a plague of gnats was about to strike.35Hence the magicians could argue that the gnats were not sent by the Lord.
AND THE LORD SAID. It is the custom of kings to go out to the river in the morning, for it is good for the eyes to see water.
I WILL SEND. The word mashli’ach (I will send) is in the hifil. It is irregular.36The usual term for I will send, as used in our verse, is meshale’ach in the pi’el.

[SWARMS OF FLIES.] The word arov (swarms of flies) refers to a mixture of evil beasts such as lions, wolves, bears, and leopards.37The word arov, translated by J.P.S. as swarms of flies, comes from the root ayin, resh, bet, meaning to mingle. According to I.E. it means a mixture of wild animals.
[AND ALSO THE GROUND.] Uninhabited places.

AND I WILL SET APART. Some say that the word ve-hifleti (and I will set apart) is missing an alef.38It comes from the root peh, lamed, alef. There is no alef in ve-hifleti, hence I.E.’s comment. However, I believe that it comes from a root ending in a heh.39Its root is peh, lamed, heh. Hence there is no alef in ve-hifleti. The meaning of ve-hifleti is, and I will set apart. It is logical to assume that Pharaoh now started to lighten Israel’s burden. When he saw that the Lord put a division between Israel and Egypt he feared to harm them. He now saw the need to send them to offer sacrifices to the Lord, lest he fall upon us with pestilence (Ex. 5:3).40Lest he fall upon us with pestilence was first uttered by the Israelites. However, it also referred to Pharaoh. See I.E.’s comment on Ex. 5:3. Don’t you see that he now gave them permission to sacrifice to the Lord in the land of Egypt?41Which shows that Pharaoh now started to make concessions.

[THAT I AM THE LORD IN THE MIDST OF THE EARTH.] This is a metaphor. It is the manner of kings to establish their residences in the middle of their kingdoms so as to be equidistant to their borders. The Lord similarly placed the heart, which is “king” over man’s body, in the center of the human corporeal frame. Man’s spirit too is located in the center of the body, as it is written, And (the Lord) formed the spirit of man in the midst of him (Zech. 12:1).42I.E. believed that man’s soul is located in the heart, which is in the center of the body. He held that Zech. 12:1 supports this contention. There are many proofs from nature that this is so. Scripture states, Out of Zion, the perfection of beauty, God hath shined forth (Ps. 50:2) because Zion is in the center of the inhabited world and God’s presence is seen in the inhabited world.43See I.E. on Gen. 1:1.

AND I WILL PUT A DIVISION. The meaning of pedut is a division. The word pidyon (redemption) is always similar in meaning.44To be redeemed means to be separated from ones enemies. Both pedut and pidyon come from the root peh, dalet, heh.

AND THE LORD DID SO. On the morrow, as Moses had spoken.45I.E. assumes that the swarms came the day after Moses had warned Pharaoh of their coming. They did not come immediately because God wanted to give Pharaoh a chance to repent (Krinsky).

[AND THERE CAME GRIEVOUS SWARMS.] By themselves.46Moses threatened a swarm of beasts (or flies). The Pentateuch tells us that a grievous swarm came. Hence I.E. notes that the grievous swarm came of itself; i.e., it was worse than what Moses threatened (Krinsky). That is, they were more numerous and/or more harmful. This plague was worse than any of the previous plagues.
AND PHARAOH CALLED. It was now clear to Pharaoh that the plagues came because the children of Israel did not offer sacrifices unto the Lord.
[IN THE LAND.] In his kingdom and not in any other place.

AND MOSES SAID. Rabbi Joshua says that the clause the abomination of the Egyptians was written to disparage idol worship. What Moses actually said to Pharaoh was, “the god of the Egyptians.” Rabbi Joshua further states that the god of Egypt was shaped like a lamb because the Egyptians believed that the constellation of the lamb ruled over their land. It is because of this that the Egyptians did not eat meat. However, if the reason for the Egyptians not eating meat was their worship of the lamb why did they also abstain from ox and goat meat? I believe that the ancient Egyptians in the time of Moses had the same belief currently held by the people of India, who make up more than half of the world. All of them are descendants of Ham.47As are the Egyptians. They do not eat meat until this very day. These people also do not drink milk or blood or eat fish or eggs. In other words, they do not eat anything coming from a living creature. Furthermore, they abhor any person who eats any of the aforementioned. They consider shepherding to be an especially disgusting type of work. It is similarly written, for every shepherd is an abomination unto the Egyptians (Gen. 47:34). They also do not allow any meat-eating person in their country. If any of them goes to a foreign country he will flee from any place where flesh is eaten. They will not eat anything which a meat-eater has handled. They consider his very garments unclean. It is thus written, because the Egyptians might not eat bread with the Hebrews (Gen. 43:32). Behold, Potiphar placed everything with the exception of the food which he ate under the care of Joseph, who was then living in his house. Potiphar would not permit him to touch his food because Joseph was a Hebrew. There is no reason to ask, “If this is so, then why did the Egyptians keep cattle?”48The Pentateuch tells us that the Egyptians kept cattle. See Ex. 9:3 and many other verses in this chapter which relate the same. We find the same to be the case in contemporary India. Horses, asses, and camels were used to carry burdens and for riding. Cattle served to pull the plow and sheep were kept for their wool. I will yet speak on this when I discuss the Passover observed in Egypt.49Ex. 12:7. Yefet says that an interrogative heh is missing in the phrase ve-lo yiskelunu,50Ve-lo yiskelunu (will they not stone us) literally means: and they will not stone us. For the clause to mean “(and) will they not stone us” it should read: ve-ha-lo yiskelunu; i e., an interrogative heh should be placed before the word lo. for its meaning is, will they not stone us.51The context implies that it is to be so translated. However, I believe that the word hen (lo) in hen nizbach (lo, we sacrifice)52Hence there is no need to place an interrogative heh before the word hen (lo). J.P.S. translates: lo, if we sacrifice. has the same meaning as the interrogative heh. The meaning of our verse thus is: if we sacrifice (hen nizbach) the abomination of the Egyptians before their eyes, will they not stone us? The word hen in hen hayetah ka-zot (if there hath been such a thing) (Jer. 2:10) is identical.53There too hen is in place of the interrogative heh, for the meaning of hen hayetah is: if there had been, not lo, there had been. The word hen can mean lo, behold, or if.
WE WILL GO THREE DAYS’ JOURNEY INTO THE WILDERNESS. We must remove ourselves from the Egyptians.
[AS HE SHALL COMMAND US.] Regarding the type and number of animals to be selected as sacrificial victims.

AND PHARAOH SAID. The phrase entreat for me should have been placed at the beginning of the verse,54Rather than at the end of the verse. as the verse means entreat for me that this plague will be removed and I will let you go to sacrifice in the wilderness as you asked. However, this is on the condition that you go no further than three days’ journey into the desert.

AND MOSES SAID…ONLY LET NOT PHARAOH DEAL DECEITFULLY. The word hetel (deal deceitfully) is irregular. A dagesh should have been placed in the tav, for its heh is a root letter. It should have been vocalized like the word dabber (speak) in behold, I cannot speak (Jer. 1:6).55The word hetel is a pi’el. Hence it should follow the paradigm of dabber, which is a pi’el and should be vocalized hattel. Since the word is not so vocalized it is irregular. We find the same irregularity in hatel tehatellu vo (mock, will ye mock him) (Job 13:9).56I.E. has abridged the clause. Job 13:9 reads: Or as one mocketh a man, will ye mock Him? Cf. Krinsky. The correct vocalization of this word is found in the clause va-yehattel ba-hem eliyahu (that Elijah mocked them) (I Kings 18:27).57The word is there vocalized in the usual pi’el form va-yehattel. Compare, va-yedabber. Moses said, only let not Pharaoh deal deceitfully any more, because he had promised to let the people go during the plague of the frogs and then didn’t.

AND MOSES WENT OUT. There are words in Hebrew that have the same meaning in the kal and hifil. These words come in two forms with one meaning. Examples are: va-yetar (and entreated) in and entreated the Lord and ve-hatarti (and I will entreat) in and I will entreat the Lord (v. 25).58The same root in a variant conjugation usually has a different though related meaning, hence I.E.’s comment. Va-yetar is a kal; ve-hatarti is a hifil. Similarly moreh (shoot) and yarah (shot) in which I shoot and he shot an arrow (I Sam. 20:36).59Moreh is a hifil. Yarah is a kal. However, such words are rare.

AND THE LORD DID. The word va-yasar (and he removed) is grammatically irregular. Roots having a vav as their middle letter60The root of va-yasar is samekh, vav, resh. are vocalized with a kamatz beneath their first stem letter, i.e., va-yashav (and he returned)61The root of va-yashav is shin, vav, bet. and va-yakam (and he got up).62The root of va-yakam is kof, vav, mem. However, in cases where the last letter of the root cannot receive a dagesh, i.e., if it is a chet, ayin, or resh, then the first root letter is vocalized with a pattach,63Rather than a kamatz. as in va-yanach (and rested)64From the root nun, vav, chet. in and rested on the seventh day (Ex. 20:11); va-yana (was moved)65Its root is nun, vav, ayin. in and his heart was moved (Is. 7:2); va-yasar (and he turned) in And he turned in unto her (Jud. 4:18). All of the aforementioned applies to words in the kal, because in the hifil roots having a vav as their middle letter are vocalized with a segol beneath their first stem letters in cases where their roots do not end in the letters mentioned above.66A chet, ayin, or resh. An example of the aforementioned is va-yashev (and he brought back) in And he brought back all the goods (Gen. 14:16). Now and he removed is written va-yasar rather than va-yaser.67Even though it is a hifil. It is so written because its final root letter is a resh. Thus the hifil and the kal of this root are spelled in the same way, hence the grammatical irregularity of this root. It is like va-yasar (and he took off) in And he took off their chariot wheels (Ex. 14:25). However, it appears that va-yasar is a kal and that va-yasar he-arov (and He removed the swarms of flies) means: and the swarms of flies departed.68If we take va-yasar to be a hifil its meaning is, and he removed. If we interpret it as a kal its meaning is, and he (it) departed.
AND PHARAOH HARDENED HIS HEART. He hardened his heart as he did at the plague of the frogs wherein it is written: he hardened his heart (v. 11).

GO IN UNTO PHARAOH. To his palace. Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi says that two plagues were in the water: one, that it turned red and the fish died; two, that frogs arose from it.1The first two plagues came about through Egypt’s waters. Two plagues were on the earth:2The next two plagues came about via the earth. one of gnats and the second the swarms, which were an assortment of wild animals. And it is written, Let the earth bring forth the living creature (Gen. 1:24).3The plague of wild animals can thus be considered as a plague from the ground. There were likewise two plagues in the air.4The next two plagues came about through the air. Murrain5Or pestilence. I.E. did not know that germs are the cause of pestilence. is nothing but a change from the normal in the air’s heat or cold. This change causes an untold number to die in an instant, as the spirit of life which resides in the heart depends on the air.6See I.E. on Gen. 2:7. The second plague7To strike through the air. was the boils. Scripture refers to the firmament which is above their heads as the heaven.8When Scripture states, Take to you handfuls of soot…and let Moses throw it heavenward (Ex. 9:10) it means “and let Moses throw it up to the air,” as the air above is called the firmament. See I.E. on Gen. 1:6 where he writes, “The firmament is the air.” The seventh plague9The plague of hail. was a mixture of the sphere of the whirlwind10A layer of wind surrounding the earth. and the sphere of fire.11A layer of fire surrounding the earth. Medieval man believed in four elements: earth, water, air, and fire. I.E. explains that all the earthly elements plus some heavenly elements were involved in bringing about the plagues. That is, two blows came from the water, two from the earth, two from the air, one from a combination of air and fire, two more from the air (locusts and darkness), and one from the heavens. Earth is the heaviest element. We therefore would imagine that it would be the first element involved in the plague. However, I.E. notes in Gen. 1:6 that it is the nature of water to be below the earth. Hence the first plague came from the waters, and succeeding plagues moved upward to the heavens. It is thus written, and fire flashing up amidst the hail (v. 24). The eighth was the plague of locusts which the wind brought from afar. The ninth was a wonderful plague in that the light from the two great luminaries and the stars was absent from above the land of Egypt.12This too came about from the air, in that the air was clouded (Krinsky). See I.E on Ex. 10:22. The tenth was the descent of the destroyer from the spheres of the glory13Hebrew, galgale ha-kavod. I.E. refers to a large shining star as a kavod (a glory). See Y. Klatzkin, Otzar Ha-Munachim Ha-Filosfim, Vol. II, Berlin, 1928, p. 62. to kill the first-born.14I.E. apparently believes that an evil conjugation of the stars caused the first-born to die.

AND WILL HOLD THEM STILL. The word hand or something similar15Perhaps teeth (Weiser). has been omitted.16The word machazik (hold them) is a hifil, a causative. It literally means causes to hold. Hence, whenever this form is encountered, the word hand or something similar is implied although not always stated. Our phrase literally reads: and will still cause to hold them. I.E. interprets this to mean: and will still cause your hand (or something similar) to hold them (Filwarg). One that holdeth17Hebrew, machazik. J.P.S. translates as taketh. a dog by the ears (Prov. 26:17) is similar.18This too should be read as: one that causeth his hand to hold a dog by the ears. It literally reads: one that causeth to hold a dog by the ears.

BEHOLD, THE HAND OF THE LORD IS UPON. Observe, we find that a yod interchanges with a vav,19In our verse, in the word hoyah (is). as elsewhere we read, and thou wouldest be (hoveh) their king (Neh. 6:6).20Hoveh is the usual form. Hence in hoyah a yod has been interchanged with a vav. The opposite is the case with the vav of kovai (that wait for me)21From the root kof, vav, heh. in For they shall not be ashamed that wait for Me (Is. 49:23) which interchanges with a yod in the word ve-kove (but they that wait)22The word kove is spelled kof, vav, yod. This comment presents a problem. Prima facie, no yod has been interchanged for a vav in kove, because this is the normal construct form of the word. Compare, love (lamed, vav, heh) and shave (shin, vav, heh). We must assume that I.E. read koye rather than kove (same vocalization but different spelling). See Rabbi David Kimchi and S. Kraus, Sefer Yeshayahu, edited by A. Kahanah, on Is. 40:31. in But they that wait for the Lord shall renew their strength (Is. 40:31).

The word dever (murrain) is a collective noun.23For pestilence. It does not refer to any particular disease (Weiser). Its verbal form24Hebrew nouns have verbal forms. is found employed only once, in va-tedabber (she destroyed) in she arose and destroyed all the seed royal of the house of Judah (II Chron. 22:10). The book of Kings25II Kings 11:1 and II Chron. 22:10 relate the same events in slightly different words. reads, va-te’abed26Va-tedabber is parallel to va-te’abed. As va-te’abed means: and she destroyed, va-tedabber means: and she destroyed. (and she destroyed) (II Kings 11:1). This interpretation is far-fetched.27That is, that va- tedabber means and she destroyed. Perhaps it means she plotted against, or she waylaid, as in its Arabic cognate dabbra. However, we know of no better one.28We must accept the reading of the parallel verse as its meaning, i.e., that va-tedabber means the same as va-te’abed.

AND THE LORD SHALL MAKE A DIVISION…NOTHING. The word davar (nothing)29Literally, a thing. is used in reference to many words joined together, as in ha-davar (the word)30God spoke many words to Jeremiah. Thus Scripture should have read, ha-devarim, as in eleh ha-devarim (these are the words) (Deut. 1:1). Thus I.E. explains that davar can refer to many words. in The word that the Lord spoke to Jeremiah (Jer. 46:13). It is also used in reference to a thing, as in our verse. Davar in thou hast not lacked a thing is similar (Deut. 2:7).
AND THE LORD APPOINTED. He set a fixed time for the sign to begin.31So that the Egyptians would not think that the plague came about by accident (Krinsky).

AND THE LORD DID. The meaning of and all (kol) the cattle of Egypt died is, that most of the cattle of Egypt died. For behold, it is written,32With regard to the hail. Now therefore send, hasten in thy cattle (v. 19).33If all the cattle died from murrain, what cattle were left to be struck by the hail? We find the same with regard to the plague of hail.34That Scripture uses the term kol (all or every) but means most. Scripture reads, and the hail smote every herb of the field (v. 25). The plague of locusts concerning which it is written, and they shall eat the residue of that which is escaped, which remaineth unto you from the hail (Ex. 10:5) is proof of this.35If the hail destroyed every herb of the field, what was left for the locusts to eat?

SO MUCH AS ONE. Ad echad36Literally, until one. means, as I will explain in the song of Moses,37Cf. I.E. on Ex. 14:28. so much as one. The meaning of our verse is: even though Pharaoh sent agents and saw that God loves Israel and on their account smote his flocks,38While none of theirs perished. he was not so bothered by the death of the flocks during this plague as to let Israel go. Perhaps the plague did not last a long time.39Once the plague quickly passed he was no longer afraid and hence did not let Israel go. Similarly, he did not ask Moses to intercede for him as he had done in the case of the plague of the frogs. See Ex. 8:4.

AND IT SHALL BECOME. This was miraculous, that this small amount of soot turned into dust all over the land of Egypt. This plague did not separate out the Israelites.40See I.E.’s comments on Ex. 7:24.

BLAINS. The alef of avabu’ot (blains) is superfluous, as avabu’ot comes from the same root as tiveh (to boil)41Its root is bet, ayin, heh. in And the fire causeth the waters to boil (Is. 64:1). The word is doubled42The heh drops out and the bet and ayin are doubled, forming the apparently quadriliteral avabu’ot. like the words teshasha’u (shall be dandled)43Its root is shin, ayin, heh. However, the heh drops out and the shin and ayin are doubled, forming the apparently quadriliteral teshasha’u. (Is. 66:12) and tesagsegi44Its original root is sin, gimel, heh. However, the heh drops out and the sin and gimel are doubled, forming the quadriliteral root sin, gimel, sin, gimel (Krinsky). (thou didst make it to grow) (Is. 17:11).

AND THEY TOOK THE SOOT OF THE FURNACE. Each as earlier noted took handfuls of soot and Moses threw all of it heavenward.45As clearly stated in verse 8. Even though Aaron took a handful of soot it was Moses who threw the soot toward heaven. See also I.E. on Ex. 8:12. It is possible that the magicians were not smitten with the plague of frogs and swarms. Through their wisdom and their knowledge of natural law they searched for a way to gain a small respite.46And hence were not smitten by the frogs and swarms. However, their knowledge now failed them, as Scripture tells us.47The boils were upon the magicians (v. 11). Pharaoh did not ask Moses and Aaron to entreat the Lord48As he did in the case of the frogs (Ex. 8:4). because the plague did not last long. We cannot conclude from the plain meaning of the text that since the first plague lasted for seven days all the other plagues did so too. Additionally, we shall pursue the text of Scripture. It is known that the plague of murrain lasted for one hour49That is, a very short time, for death by pestilence is immediate. and the plague of darkness for three days. There is no way to ascertain in which month Moses came and the plagues commenced.50According to the rabbis the plagues lasted for an entire year. See Eduyot 2:10, “the judgment of the Egyptians endured twelve months.” Similarly Seder Olam, 3. Also, according to the rabbis, since Israel was delivered in Nisan and the plagues lasted a year they had to commence in Iyar (Seder Olam 3). It is possible to further interpret the rabbinic statement that the judgment of the Egyptians lasted for one year to mean that it lasted for one year from the time that Moses first appeared before Pharaoh. If we assume the aforementioned then Moses first appeared before Israel and Pharaoh in the month of Iyar. Furthermore, if we accept the fact that the judgment of the Egyptians lasted for a year then each of the ten plagues struck a little over a month apart (Tiferet Israel on Eduyot 3:10). Cf. Shemot Rabba 9:12, “Rabbi Judah and Rabbi Nehemiah: One says Moses warned them for 24 days before (he plague struck and the plague ravaged them for seven days. The other one says he warned them for seven days and the plague ravaged them for 24 days.” However, if our holy sages received this via tradition we accept and abide by it.51That is, that the plagues ravaged seven days, that a new one struck each month, that the plagues lasted for a year, and that Moses appeared in the month of Iyar. See note above.
AND THE LORD HARDENED THE HEART OF PHARAOH. He therefore did not request Moses to entreat the Lord.52As he did in the case of the frogs and swarms.

AND THE LORD SAID. Scripture does not here note that Pharaoh went out unto the water.53As it does in Ex. 7:15 with regard to the plague of blood and in Ex. 8:16 with regard to the swarms. Perhaps he had another reason for rising early.

FOR. Scripture reads, all My plagues because thunder, hail, rain, and fire combined in this plague. We do not find Pharaoh to be as afraid of all the passing plagues as he was of this one.54Because of the combination of thunder, hail, rain, and fire. He also said,55Due to his great fear of this plague. the Lord is righteous (v. 27).

[THAT THERE IS NONE LIKE ME IN ALL THE EARTH.] This was said56There is none like Me in all the earth implies that there are other gods but that they are weaker than the Lord. Hence I.E. comments that the Lord spoke in accordance with Egyptian belief that there are other gods. in accordance with Egyptian belief that their gods had the power to harm or to benefit.

AND SMITTEN. Va-akh (and smitten) is missing a nun. It is like the word ve-at (though I was offering) in Though I was offering them food (Hos. 11:4). They are both the same. Their roots are nun, tet, heh and nun, kaf, heh.

[PESTILENCE.] Scripture reads, ba-dever (with pestilence)57Rather than be-dever. Ba-dever is short for be-ha-dever (with the pestilence) and according to I.E. should be so translated, hence his comment. because it refers to the well-known pestilence. It means: I would have killed all of you along with your cattle with the pestilence with which I smote them.

BUT IN VERY DEED FOR THIS CAUSE58The word cause is not in the Hebrew text. The Hebrew reads: But in very deed for this have I made thee to stand. HAVE I MADE THEE TO STAND. Scripture goes on to explain the meaning of zot (this). It means to show thee My power.59The verse is to be understood as follows: But in very deed for this, i.e., to show thee My power, and that My name my be declared throughout all the worlds have I allowed thee to exist. And out of the midst thereof as the color of electrum, out of the midst of the fire (Ezek. 1:4) is similar. However, Yefet says that its meaning is, for this plague,60This is short for this plague. the reference being to the plague of hail.61The verse is to be understood as follows: But for this plague have I made thee to stand, etc.

[AND THAT MY NAME MAY BE DECLARED THROUGHOUT ALL THE EARTH.] This does not refer to Pharaoh.62The form sapper is used both for the imperative and the infinitive. If it is taken as an imperative then it is Pharaoh who is being addressed, and our verse should be interpreted as follows: and that thou shalt declare My name throughout all the earth. On the contrary, the word sapper (be declared) is an infinitive like the word kabbed (promote)63Kabbed, like sapper, is used for both the imperative and the infinitive. in for I will promote thee unto very great honor (Num. 22:17). Its meaning is not that Pharaoh will go all over the world to declare God’s glory, but rather that God’s name would be declared from generation to generation because of the signs which He performed.64I.E. takes issue with the Midrash and Targum Jonathan, which take sapper as an infinitive. Targum Jonathan translates, u-min bi-gelal de-tini shemi kadisha be-khol arah (and so that thou shall declare My holy name all over the earth). Also see the Mekhilta, Ex. 6, wherein we read:”…There remained not so much as one of them (Ex. 14:28)…Rabbi Nahman says, excluding Pharaoh, for concerning him it says, But in very deed for this cause, etc.” That is, that thou shalt declare My name all over the earth. Also Rashi on Ex. 12:29 interprets sapper as an imperative. Rashi comments, “Pharaoh too was a first-born but he remained alive out of all the first-born. Concerning him Scripture states, But in very deed for this cause, etc.”

AS YET EXALTEST THOU THYSELF AGAINST MY PEOPLE. Mistolel (exaltest) means praises. It comes from the same root as the word salseleha (extol her) in Extol her, and she will exalt thee (Prov. 4:8). Now even though its first root letter is doubled65The samekh, the first root letter, appears twice. Similarly the lamed, its second root letter. Thus the word appears to come from a quadriliteral root; i.e., its stem appears to be samekh, lamed, samekh, lamed, whereas the root of mistolel is samekh, lamed, lamed, it still belongs among the double roots.66It basic root is samekh, lamed, lamed even though it appears to have a quadriliteral root. See I.E. on verse 9 and the notes thereto. It67Salseleha. So I.E. on Prov. 4:8. is similar to the word solu (extol)68Which comes from the root samekh, lamed, lamed. in Extol him that rideth upon the skies (Ps. 68:5). Likewise ve-gilgaltikha (and roll thee down)69The root of ve-gilgaltikha appears to be gimel, lamed, gimel, lamed. However, its real root is gimel, lamed, lamed. (Jer. 51:25) is similar to mitgolel (wallowing) (II Sam. 20:12) and golu (roll). However, Rabbi Merinus says that the meaning of mistolel (exaltest) is strengthens and comes from the same root as mesillot in And the king made of the sandalwood pillars (mesillot)70J.P.S. renders paths. for the house of the Lord (II Chron. 9:11). Elsewhere it is written, And the king made of the sandalwood pillars (misad)71The point is that misad is parallel to mesillot. As misad means a support (from the root samekh, ayin, dalet) or something which gives strength, so does mesillot. for the house of the Lord (I Kings 10:12).

I WILL CAUSE IT TO RAIN. It is well known that even today neither rain nor hail comes down upon the land of Egypt. There is no need to explain why this is so.72This is not the place to go into it. The same is still true of many other places. It was because of this that the Egyptians were greatly afraid, for with the exception of something resembling dew, nothing73Neither rain nor hail. rains down there.
SEND HASTEN. The word ha-ez (hasten) means make to flee74To a safe place. or gather.75Into a safe place. He-izu (flee) in The inhabitants of Gebim flee to cover (Is. 10:31) is similar.
HE THAT FEARED…MADE FLEE. On that very day.

AND HE THAT REGARDED NOT. There is a meaning in Arabic for the vav of va-ya’azov (left).76Literally, and he left. Prima facie, this form is out of place. The proper form here is azav (left), hence I.E.’s comment. However, it is not in our power to translate it into another language.77Its meaning is identical to that of the Arabic fa. See I.E. on Gen. 1:1 and the notes thereto and Vol. 1, Foreword, p. xvi. Va-yissa (lifted up his eyes) in, On the third day Abraham lifted up his eyes (Gen. 22:4) is similar.78Here too the form va-yissa (literally, and he lifted up) is prima facie, out of place. The proper form is this case is nasa. There are many other similar instances.

AND THE LORD SAID. From a strictly logical point of view it appears that the stretching forth of his hand was with his rod.79That is, when God told Moses, Stretch forth thy hand, he meant stretch forth thy rod with thy hand (Krinsky). Behold, it is written afterwards, And Moses stretched forth his rod toward heaven,80It is thus perfectly logically to assume that when God told him, Stretch forth thy hand toward heaven, He meant stretch forth thy rod with thy hand toward heaven. that is, in the air above. In the open firmament of heaven (Gen. 1:20) is similar.81Heaven here is short for or refers to the firmament of heaven, which refers to the air and not to heaven per se (Weiser). See I.E. on Gen. 1:6 and 1:20 and the notes thereto.
AND FIRE RAN DOWN. Va-tihalakh (ran down) is a kal form. It expresses going.
UNTO THE EARTH. Contrary to its nature, which is to go up.82Fire rises upward.
AND FIRE FLASHING UP AMIDST THE HAIL. A miracle within a miracle.83For fire and water do not mix.

AND THE HAIL SMOTE. This was a very strong plague, for it killed man and beast and broke every tree of the field. However, God pitied them84The reference appears to be to Israel. God pitied Israel and their cattle and none of them died (Krinsky, Netter). Weiser suggests that the reference is to Egypt. God pitied the Egyptians and warned them to gather in their cattle and stay indoors. However, the remainder of I.E.’s comment does not seem to bear out Weiser’s contention. and their cattle. Moses did not mention this to Pharaoh85As he did in the case of the murrain. See verse 4. because he saw that Pharaoh sent agents and learned that there was not even one of the cattle of the Israelites dead, and yet did not take this to heart.86Verse 7.
AND CALLED. Pharaoh said, I have sinned, because he was greatly afraid that he, as was told to him, would be destroyed by the pestilence.87Verse 15.

ENTREAT THE LORD. Pharaoh made mention of the glorious name88YHVH, for Pharaoh said, Entreat YHVH (the Lord). and referred to kolot Elohim (noises from God) because he, as I have already noted, admitted to the existence of a Deity.89See I.E.’s comments on Ex. 6:2 and 8:15. Moses combined the proper and adjectival names and said, “the Lord God” (YHVH / Adonai Elohim) because Pharaoh did not employ the term kolot YHVH / Adonai.90But rather used the term kolot Elohim. Since Pharaoh referred to YHVH / Adonai and to Elohim, he, being a pagan, might have referred to two deities. Hence Moses used the term YHVH / Adonai Elohim (the Lord God), which means YHVH alone is God. The meaning of YHVH / Adonai Elohim is: the Lord alone is God. We never find Moses employing this phrase91YHVH / Adonai Elohim. Because Moses addressed Israelites, and they knew that YHVH / Adonai alone is God. in the entire Torah. The term Adonai Elohim in O Lord God, Thou hast begun (Deut. 3:24) does not refute the aforementioned, as Adonai is written there with an alef, dalet. 92Rather than YHVH. Hence it does not mean YHVH alone is God but rather O Lord God.

AND MOSES SAID UNTO HIM: AS SOON AS I AM GONE OUT OF THE CITY. The commentaries say that Moses was unable to spread forth his hands in Egypt because it was filled with idols.93See Mekhilta, Bo, chap. 1; Shemot Rabba 12:5, and Rashi.
THAT THE EARTH IS THE LORD’S. Not yours.

BUT AS FOR THEE. Rabbi Solomon94Rashi. says that the meaning of terem tire’un (ye will not yet fear) is: you do not fear.95According to Rashi terem means not yet. He renders terem tire’un as: you will not yet fear. However, I.E. quoted Rashi as saying that terem means no. Most of the commentaries avoid the issue. They apparently believe that I.E. was laconic in quoting Rashi. However, in his short commentary, I.E. quotes Rabbi Judah the grammarian as saying that terem means no. Weiser suggests that I.E. confused Rashi and Rabbi Judah in his long commentary. Since, as has been shown in Vol. 1 of this work, I.E. often quoted from memory and, as Birnbaum notes, did not always have time to edit his writings, it is quite possible that Weiser is right. He interprets terem yishkavu (but before they lay down) (Gen. 19:4) similarly.96Rashi on our verse interprets it as meaning: they did not as yet lie down. However, the meaning of this word is not as he imagined, as the subject always follows.97Not yet or no implies the end of a subject. However, terem is almost always followed by a subject. Hence I.E. interprets terem as meaning before. The problem with I.E.’s interpretation is that in our verse, unlike Gen. 19:4, the term seems to end the subject under conversation. It is to answer the latter that I.E. quotes Saadiah Gaon and then offers his own interpretation. Following terem yishkavu (but before they lay down) Scripture reads, the men of the city, even the men of Sodom, compassed the house round: its meaning is, at the time when they lay down they compassed the house round. The word terem (before) in before they call, I will answer (Is. 65:24) and terem (before) in Yea before the fat was made to smoke (I Sam. 2:15) are similar. The same applies to all times the word terem is used. Thus terem never has the meaning of no.98That is, of not yet. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon of blessed memory connected the whole subject.99According to Saadiah Gaon the meaning of terem is before. He connects verses 29-32. If he did not connect them, verse 30 would make no sense for it would end reading: I know before you fear the Lord God. He explained it as follows. Moses said to Pharaoh, I shall pray for the hail to be removed.100Verse 29. However, what it destroyed, it destroyed.101Verse 31.

The meaning of And the flax and the barley were smitten102Verse 31. is, the flax and barley shall not return103For they have already been destroyed, and what is destroyed is destroyed. and I shall not pray for their recovery.104However, I shall pray for the wheat and the spelt because they have not yet been smitten (v. 32). Behold, its meaning is,105The meaning of verse 30 and verse 31. before you fear God and confess and say the Lord is righteous,106Verse 30. the barley and flax shall already be smitten. This vav,107Verse 31 starts with a vav. This seems to indicate that, contra Saadiah Gaon, the verse introduces a new topic and is not dependent on verse 30. If it were, it should read, ki terem tire’un mepene Adonai Elohim ha-pishtah ve-hase’orah nu-katah (but before you will fear the Lord God, the flax and the barley will be smitten). The fact that it opens with ve-ha-pishtah (and the barley) shows that verse 31 is an independent verse. The same applies to the vav that opens verse 32. as I have noted, is correctly used according to the Arabic.108For the vav at the beginning of a verse does not always introduce an independent clause. See I.E. on verse 21 and the notes thereto. However, in my opinion109I.E. agrees with Saadiah Gaon that terem means before. However, he does not see any need to connect and interpret the verses as Saadiah does. a word110Actually two words, efrosh (I spread) kapai (my hands). has been omitted,111Adding these two words eliminates the problem of no appropriate subject following terem. its interpretation being: before I spread my hands you will fear the Lord, viz., you and your servants. Moses was being polite. Its implication is, when the plague is removed you will rebel. Therefore Scripture notes afterwards, and (Pharaoh) hardened his heart, he and his servants. We do not find this in any other place.112That Moses politely alluded to the fact that Pharaoh would change his mind as soon as the plague disappeared (Weiser).

AND THE FLAX AND THE BARLEY. Scripture relates what happened.113Contra Saadiah Gaon who believed that verse 31 is dependent on verse 30. I.E. holds that verse 31 is independent. He explains that it relates what happened next, not what Moses told Pharaoh about his limited fear of God. See I.E.’s comment on verse 30 and the notes thereto. It is clear from the word nukkatah (were smitten) and also from the word nukku (were smitten) (v. 32)114Nukkkatah and nukku are third person pu’als. Their root is nun, kaf, heh. In the verb makkeh, which is a hifil, the nun is missing. that the root of makkeh (smite) is nun, kaf, heh. It is similar to the words shuppu (corrode) and ru’u115Both are in the pu’al, as are nukku and nukkatah. Hence their nuns are not nifal form nuns but root letters (Krinsky). (unsightliness) in And his bones corrode to unsightliness (Job 33:21).

THEY RIPEN LATE. Afilot (ripen late) is an adjective. The word afel (darkness), as in, darkness, and not light, is close in meaning to it. It means that they were beneath the earth116Being beneath the earth is like being in a dark place. and unseen.

POURED. Nittakh (poured) is used in the same sense as ke-hittukh (as is melted) in117Or turns liquid. Similarly, nittakh in our verse refers to liquid. As silver is melted in the midst of the furnace (Ezek. 22:22). It is a nifal118Hence it means was poured. like the word niggash (drew near) in but Moses drew near unto the thick darkness (Ex. 20:18).

AND WHEN PHARAOH SAW. Scripture now mentions, he sinned yet more,119Which it never did before. because Pharaoh confessed and said, I have sinned this time (v. 27).120Scripture notes that he continued to sin even after he had confessed his transgression.
[AND HARDENED HIS HEART, HE AND HIS SERVANTS.] From this, Moses’ words, But as for thee and thy servants (v. 30), become clear.121That Moses was justified in saying what he did (Weiser).

AND THE HEART OF PHARAOH WAS HARDENED. Though he feared this plague more than the earlier ones.122Even though the plague of hail scared him more than any of the previous plagues, as soon as it passed Pharaoh hardened his heart.

GO IN UNTO PHARAOH. Go in unto him this time4This last time of your own accord; henceforth Pharaoh shall ask you to come to him (Weiser). and do not be astonished that he has hardened his heart until now,5Do not be discouraged by the fact that he has not as yet let Israel go. For I have hardened his heart, and the heart of his servants. God mentioned the heart of his servants because their hearts6Unlike Pharaoh’s heart. would mellow with the coming of the plague of the locusts.7See verse 7, And Pharaoh’s servants said unto him…Let the men go, that they may serve the Lord their God.

[FOR I HAVE HARDENED HIS HEART.] Its meaning is: I have hardened his heart that I might show these My signs in the midst of them. The Spanish scholars differ with regard to the word shiti (I might show).8Literally, I might put. Some say that shiti is similar to binu9The root of which is bet, yod, nun. (consider) (Deut. 32:7), simu (set)10The root of which is sin, yod, mem. (Gen. 43:21), and other such words.11Words having a yod as their middle root letter. In other words, shiti is a kal from the root shin, yod, tav. The same is the case12They are all kals having a yod as their middle root letter. with yashit (he will put), yasim (he will place), yavin (he will understand), and comparable words13Words similarly vocalized. in all of their14Conjugational forms. forms. Others hold that shiti is a hifil minus the sign of the form,15The heh. Because it is a hifil the word should read hashiti. because they found the words yasum16Yasum is a kal from the root sin, vav, mem. Now if shiti was a kal it should read yashut (like yasum), rather than yashit, in the third person imperfect form. Hence the form yashit must be a hifil. Similarly, if shiti were a kal it would read shuti. It should be noted that these grammarians assume that the root of shiti is shin, vav, tav (Weiser). (maketh) and la-sus (rejoice)17La-sus is a kal infinitive from the root sin, vav, sin. Here too we see that such roots are vocalized in the kal with a shuruk, not with a chirik as shiti is. Hence shiti cannot be a kal. The point of these grammarians is that when we come across forms such as yasis, yashit and the like, we are dealing with hifils having a vav as a middle root letter. When we come across forms such as yasus, yashut, we are dealing with kals having a vav as a middle root letter. Hence the word shiti must be a hifil (Weiser). in who maketh a man dumb (Ex. 4:11) and for the Lord will again rejoice over thee for good, as He rejoiced over thy fathers (Deut. 30:9), all of which are kals. Others say that yasis is similar to yasus (he will rejoice)18In other words, yasis is not a hifil; it is a kal. The reason it is pronounced yasis and not yasus is that yasis comes from the root sin, yod, sin, and yasus comes from the root yod, vav, sin (Weiser). and shiti to sumi (set).19There are two roots for the word set. One comes from the root sin, yod, mem, and one from the root sin, vav, mem. Compare, som tasim (thou shalt in any wise set) (Deut. 17:15). Som comes from the root sin, vav, mem, and tasim from the root sin, yod, mem. Both som and tasim are kals. It is the same with the words for put/set. One word comes from the root shin, vav, vav, and the other from the root shin, yod, tav. Shiti comes from the latter root, hence its vocalization. They are all kals. In Ex. 12:9 we find: “Behold, I the writer add to the words of this sage as I heard from his mouth.”

AND THAT THOU MAYEST TELL. God spoke to Moses, who is equivalent to all of Israel.20And that thy mayest tell doesn’t only refer to Moses, to whom God was speaking, but to all of Israel. The point is that Israel might tell their children and grandchildren all that God did to Egypt. Similarly, that ye may know that I am the Lord 21Which closes our verse. means that all Israel shall know the aforementioned. The Torah speaks in human terms when it says, I have wrought, for it pictures God as acting as a human being who arranges events in order to avenge himself upon another.

AND MOSES AND AARON WENT IN. We know that Moses would not come in unto Pharaoh unless Aaron was with him,22Hence what need is there for Scripture to mention Aaron? as Aaron was his spokesman.23Therefore Moses would not go to Pharaoh without Aaron. See I.E. on Ex. 4:30 and 7:2. Scripture here mentions Moses and Aaron because now, unlike any of the other instances of the plagues, they were both returned to and finally expelled from the presence of Pharaoh.
TO HUMBLE. Le’anot (to humble) is a nifal.24Its meaning thus is, to be humbled. It comes from the same root as ani (humble).25From the root ayin, nun, heh.

LOCUSTS. Arbeh (locusts) is the name of a type of locust.26Weiser. Perhaps it is so called because it is more numerous than other kinds of locusts.27It comes from the root resh, bet, heh, meaning numerous. Scripture states, That which the palmer-worm (gazam)28A type of locust. hath left hath the locust (arbeh) eaten (Joel 1:4).29Joel mentions four types of locusts: gazam, arbeh, yelek, and chasil. We thus see that arbeh is a type of locust. Concerning it, Scripture states, My great army which I sent among you (Joel 2:25). If this be the case then the alef of arbeh is superfluous.30It has no meaning.
AND THEY SHALL COVER. Metaphorically speaking.

THAT ONE SHALL NOT BE ABLE TO SEE.31Literally, that shall not be able to see, hence I.E.’s comment. The word ish (a man) has been omitted.32The verse should be understood as if read: that a man shall not be able to see. Yefet says that many days passed between the plague of hail and the plague of locusts, for Scripture states: which groweth for you out of the field.33Which indicates that the locusts ate new produce, as earlier the hail smote every herb of the field, and broke every tree of the land (Ex. 9:25).

SHALL BE FILLED. This word34Male’u (filled) is a third person kal perfect plural. The vav changes it into an imperfect. is irregularly used in the Hebrew language.35I.E. goes on to point out that it is both transitive and intransitive in the kal. The meaning of u-male’u (shall be filled) is that the houses were full of locusts.36In other words, here ma’le’u is intransitive. However, mile’u is transitive. Both are kal forms. However, we also find mile’u (fill) in Fill four jars with water (I Kings 18:34) wherein mile’u is a transitive verb. It is as if it were vocalized with a pattach beneath the mem and a dagesh in the lamed37Malle’u. and belonged to the conjugational form that receives a dagesh.38As if it were a pi’el. Pi’el is always transitive.

[AND HE TURNED.] Rabbi Joshua says that va-yifen (and he turned) refers to Moses, who paid his respects to the throne by facing the king39According to Rabbi Joshua va-yifen means: and he faced. Compare, panim (face). and walking out backwards.40Rather than turn his back to Pharaoh and leave. However, Yefet says that Moses finished his duties.41According to Yefet va-yifen means: and he was finished, i.e., finished his duties. Compare, panuy (unoccupied, disengaged). So too u-fanita (and thou shalt turn)42According to Yefet u-fanita means: and you will be finished. in and thou shalt turn in the morning (Deut. 16:7). However, what shall Yefet do with the word va-yifen (and he looked) in And he looked this way and that way (Ex. 2:12)?43Here the word cannot be taken to mean he was disengaged, for what sense is there to a clause that reads: and he was finished this way and that way? Va-yifen is to be explained as coming from the same root as panim (face).44Its root is peh, nun, heh. It should be noted that the same applies to the above interpretations. However, I.E. means that the word means to turn the face and look. According to I.E. the meaning of our verse is: and he looked (va-yifen); i.e., he turned his face and went out from Pharaoh. It has the same meaning as va-yar (and he saw). Now Moses left the presence of Pharaoh without his permission. Scripture notes this because Pharaoh asked that Moses and Aaron be brought back. After they were returned Pharaoh, in anger, commanded that they be driven out.45This time Pharaoh did not want to give Moses the chance to insult him by leaving on his own.

AND PHARAOH’S SERVANTS SAID. The meaning of ha-terem46According to I.E. terem means before. See I.E. on Ex. 10:30 and the notes thereto. teda (knowest thou not yet) is: do you first want it to become clear to you that Egypt is destroyed.

WERE BROUGHT AGAIN. The word et indicates the thing itself.47It is used for emphasis. I.E. goes on to explain the meaning of et because our text reads, va-yushav et moshe ve-et aharon, (and Moses and Aaron were brought again). Now whether one says ha-adam ohavi (the man loves me), in which the yod is a first person pronominal suffix, or he says ha-adam ohev oti (the man loves me),48Oti is a form of et. the reference being to my very self,49Oti refers to the very persona. the meaning is one and the same. Therefore, if someone says re’uven harag et shimon (Reuben killed Simeon) he is telling us that Simeon has been slain. However, the same is the case if he says, re’uven harag shimon (Reuben killed Simeon).50In other words, the et does not make a difference. Re’uven harag et shimon means the same as re’uven harag shimon. Ve-rav ya’avod tza’ir (and the elder shall serve the younger) (Gen. 25:23)51It has the same meaning as ve-rav ya’avod et ha-tza’ir. and asher bara Elohim adam (that God created man) (Deut. 4:32)52It has the same meaning as asher bara Elohim et ha-adam. are similar. Do not think that et indicates the direct object because it is often found to be so used.53It is so found most often in Scripture. It is also found before the subject, as in u-va ha-ari ve-et ha-dov (and when there came a lion, or a bear) (I Sam. 17:34)54Here it emphasizes the subject rather than the object. and many other similar cases. Rabbi Judah the grammarian says that Scripture reads, va-yushav (were brought again) rather than va-yushevu (were brought again)55Va-yushav is in the singular. Its literal meaning is, was brought again. Since Scripture speaks of Moses and Aaron we would expect the plural, va-yushevu. because of the word et.56Since va-yushav is connected to the word et, which does not take on a different form before a plural, it too does not take on a plural form (Filwarg). However, I believe that Scripture reads, va-yushav because Moses was the most important one. Scripture similarly reads, va-tedabber miriam ve-aharon57Va-tedabber is a feminine singular. Since Scripture speaks of Miriam and Aaron we would expect a plural masculine. (And Miriam and Aaron spoke) (Num. 12:1) because Miriam was the main speaker.

FOR WE MUST HOLD A FEAST UNTO THE LORD. All of us are obligated to sacrifice unto the Lord.58In other words, the term chag (feast) means a sacrifice, and our clause is to be translated: for we must sacrifice unto the Lord.
SO BE THE LORD WITH YOU. Whom you say is with you.59Pharaoh was not recognizing the Lord as God. What he was saying was: So be the Lord whom you claim as your God with you (Weiser).

[SEE YE THAT EVIL IS BEFORE YOUR FACE.] The evil is close to you and is before your face. This meaning is also to be connected to for that is what ye desire (v. 11).60For that is what ye desire refers to the evil mentioned in our verse; i.e., the clause is to be understood: for it is evil that you desire. Hence it is only right that I so act. At this point Pharaoh surmised that they wanted to flee.61Hence he threatened them with evil. Note that our Master Moses did not go so far as to lie and say that Israel would return. He merely said that they would travel a three days’ journey (Ex. 9:23). However, the Egyptians thought that they would return. Hence they let them have what they asked.62Jewels of silver, and jewels of gold, and raiment (Ex. 12:35). They would not have given these objects to Israel if they had not believed that Israel would return. Moses had another reason for acting in this manner.63Not telling Pharaoh that they would return. Had Pharaoh given Israel permission to go64That is, to leave Egypt permanently. and Israel did not return, Pharaoh would not have pursued them. However, God commanded Moses to act in this manner so that Pharaoh would chase after them and drown. Behold, this is clearly stated, that they turn back and encamp before Pi-hahiroth (Ex. 14:2).65Scripture goes on to say, And Pharaoh will say of the children of Israel: They are entangled in the land…and he shall follow after them (Ex. 14:3, 4). One should not question the acts of God,66Why did God mislead Pharaoh into thinking that Israel was lost in the desert so that he would pursue them? He could have drowned Pharaoh and his army in the Red Sea without employing military strategy. as He does everything with wisdom, though it be hidden from the eyes even of wise men. We find a similarity in the account of David, viz., And it shall be, when thou hearest the sound of marching in the tops of the mulberry-trees, that then thou shalt bestir thyself; for then is the Lord gone out before thee to smite the host of the Philistines (II Sam. 5:24).67David too was told by God to use strategy in fighting the Philistines. David inquired of the Lord how to attack the Philistines. The Lord answered him, Thou shalt not go up; make a circuit behind them, and come upon them over against the mulberry-trees. And it shall be, when thou hearest the sound of marching in the tops of the mulberry-trees, that then thou shalt bestir thyself; for then is the Lord gone out before thee to smite the host of the Philistines (II Sam. 5:23, 24). Here too God instructed David to lead the Philistines into a trap so that God would destroy them. The Lord acted in this manner even though He could have destroyed them without employing this strategy.
NOT SO; GO NOW YE THAT ARE MEN. The word gever (man), unlike the word adam (man),68Adam can refer to both a male or a female. Compare, Gen. 1:27. always refers to a man in Scripture.
FOR THAT IS WHAT YE DESIRE. The above-noted evil.69Mentioned in verse 10.

FOR THE LOCUSTS. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that ba-arbeh (for the locusts) indicates that Moses placed a locust on the rod.70Rabbi Moses takes the bet of ba-arbeh to mean with. Compare, the bet in be-tuppim u-vimcholot (with timbrels and with dances) (Jud. 11:34). Rabbi Moses interprets our verse as follows: Stretch out thy hand with the locust over the land of Egypt. However, this is incorrect. The correct interpretation of ba-arbeh is: so that the locusts would come.71In other words, the bet has the meaning of because. Compare, ish be-chet’o (each because of his own sin) (Deut. 24:16).

AN EAST WIND. Kadim (east) is an adjective, since kedemah mizrachah (the east side) is a noun.72In other words, kedemah is a noun and kadim an adjective. Kadim73Meaning be in front, before. is so called because it is the first of the sides74To see the sun. because the sun begins to shine there. Hence the west is termed achor (hinder side).75It is the last side to see the sun. Compare, Behold, I go forward (kedem), but He is not there, And backward (achor), but I cannot perceive Him (Job 23:8).
BROUGHT THE LOCUSTS. From its place and deposited them in all the kingdom of Egypt.
WENT UP. Neither after them shall be such was prophetically written.76The Torah prophesies that there will never be an exact duplication of this plague again.

FOR THEY COVERED THE FACE OF THE WHOLE EARTH. The meaning of so the land was darkened is that the locusts intervened between the sun and the land. The land is always dark.77The earth gets its light from the sun; hence without sunlight it is dark.
THEN PHARAOH CALLED FOR MOSES AND AARON IN HASTE. Via his messengers.78Pharaoh did not personally call them. Pharaoh added, I have sinned, because he drove them away from his presence in disgrace.

NOW THEREFORE FORGIVE, I PRAY THEE. I will explain the term sa na (forgive, I pray thee) in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.79See Ex. 34:4, where I.E. explains that the phrase has two meanings, to forgive or to bear sin. Here it means to forgive.

[ONLY THIS ONCE.] Because I will not sin again by rebelling against the Lord. Pharaoh did not promise to free the people because Moses was angry.80And Pharaoh did not want to engage him any further in conversation (Weiser). Moses went out of the city as was his wont81When he prayed. and prayed.82Moses could not pray within the city because of the idols therein. See I.E. on Ex. 9:29.

AND THE LORD TURNED AN EXCEEDING STRONG WEST WIND. West is termed yam83Sea. in the holy tongue because the great sea84The Mediterranean. Scripture refers to the sea which borders the Land of Israel on the west as the “great sea.” Cf. Num. 34:6; Jos. 1:4; 9:1. which goes out from Spain and passes by the land of Egypt and goes on to the Land of Israel lies in the west. This sea is not to be identified with the Atlantic Ocean because Israel did not inherit that much territory.85The Land of Israel was not that vast as to reach the Atlantic. The Spanish Sea is called the great sea because it is three hundred Persian miles wide, whereas none of the seas in the Land of Israel such as the Sea of Reeds, the Kineret, and the Salt Sea is even thirty Persian miles wide.
BUT THE LORD HARDENED. This is to be understood à la the words of our sages of blessed memory who said, “The door is opened for one who comes to defile himself.”86Sabbath 104a; Yoma 38b.
AND THE LORD SAID. We may logically assume although it is not so stated that Moses’ staff was in his hand.87When he stretched out his hand towards heaven. See I.E. on Ex. 9:22.

EVEN DARKNESS WHICH MAY BE FELT. Yefet says that ve-yamesh (which may be felt) is like ve-yamish (and it shall depart);88From the root mem, vav, shin, meaning to depart or remove. Compare, lo yamish amud he-anan, (the pillar of cloud by day departed not) (Ex. 13:22). its meaning is: that the darkness to which they have become accustomed shall depart and another type of darkness, thicker than it, shall come. Others say that ve-yamesh is missing an alef.89Cf. Rashi. According to Rashi ve-yamesh, spelled vav, yod, mem, shin, is a form of emesh. According to him ve-yamesh choshekh (even darkness which may be felt) means: and the darkness of the night shall be even more dark (Cohen). Now the word emesh in the holy tongue refers to the previous night, like emesh (yesternight) in spoke unto me yesternight (Gen. 31:29). It is the same case with the Arabic ams, as the shin and samekh interchange in most of the words.90That are cognate to Hebrew and Arabic. Now their interpretation makes no sense.91For emesh means yesternight. Thus ve-yamesh choshekh has to be translated: and yesterday shall be dark. This makes no sense. I believe that ve-yamesh comes from the same root as yemashesh (gropeth) (Deut. 28:29).92From the root mem, shin, shin, meaning to feel, to grope. One cannot argue that yemashesh comes from a double root93While ve-yamesh, which has one shin, at first glance does not. because with regard to something very similar Scripture uses the term yemishun (handle)94Or feel. in They have hands but handle not (Ps. 115:7).95It too has only one shin, yet its meaning is to feel. As to the root of ve-yamesh and yemishun, they either come from the root mem, vav, shin, which is a variant of the root mem, shin, shin, or they come from the root mem, shin, shin and are conjugated with only one of the double letters. There are a number of other such words. Compare, asev (I will turn around) (root, samekh, bet, bet) and achel (I will begin) (root chet, lamed, lamed). Cf. Weiser. Ve-yamesh refers to Egypt, Egypt being in the singular,96Ve-yamesh is a singular. If ve-yamesh refers to Egypt the plural form should have been used, hence I.E.’s comment. as in so Egypt said I will flee97Anusah (I will flee) is in the singular. (Ex. 14:25). Now the meaning of ve-yamesh choshekh (even darkness which may be felt) is that the Egyptians will feel the darkness with their hands,98According to I.E. ve-yamesh means: and he shall feel. Thus ve-yamesh choshekh means: and he (Egypt) shall feel the darkness. for the darkness shall be so thick that neither a candle nor a fire shall give off light. They saw not one another (v. 23) neither by the light of day nor by candlelight is proof of the aforementioned.99I.E. takes literally, They saw not one another.

AND MOSES STRETCHED FORTH. The Egyptians had no way of knowing that three days passed except through the Israelites, who had light. Now there are times when a thick darkness100I.E. is obviously referring to a thick fog. comes over the Atlantic Ocean during which time it is impossible for a person to distinguish between day and night. The aforementioned occasionally lasts for as long as five days. I myself have been there many times.
NEITHER ROSE ANY FROM HIS PLACE. From his house, as in abide ye every man in his place (Ex. 16:29). For where could they go without light?
AND PHARAOH CALLED. After three days when they saw light.

ONLY LET YOUR FLOCKS AND YOUR HERDS BE STAYED. Pharaoh wanted to know what was in Moses’ mind. He wanted to learn whether Moses planned to escape.101Hence he said, only let your flocks and your herds be stayed. If they intended to return they wouldn’t mind leaving the latter behind. Pharaoh said, let your little ones also go with you because Moses had earlier told him, We will go with our young and with our old (v. 9).
THOU MUST ALSO GIVE INTO OUR HAND SACRIFICES AND BURNT-OFFERINGS. You are obligated to give into our hands sacrifices and burnt offerings to be brought on the altar on your behalf.

THERE SHALL NOT A HOOF BE LEFT BEHIND. Of any kind that are among our cattle, as we do not know which kind we are to choose102For offerings. and how many of them we will sacrifice. This is the meaning of we know not with what we must serve.
BUT THE LORD HARDENED PHARAOH’S HEART. In a manner similar to for the Lord thy God hardened his spirit, and made his heart obstinate (Deut. 2:30).
THOU SHALT DIE. You will deserve to be put to death for rebelling against the king.

THOU HAST SPOKEN WELL. Ken (well) here has the same meaning as ken (right) in The daughters of Zelophehad speak right (Num. 27:6).103I.E. there explains ken as meaning true or correct. Our clause may thus be rendered: thou hast spoken truthfully; or, thou hast spoken correctly.
I WILL SEE THY FACE AGAIN NO MORE. For I will never come to you again.

AND THE LORD SPOKE. The chapter opening with the words, Thus saith the Lord (v. 4)1Rather than our verse. should have been connected to the previous verse.2To Ex. 10:29. In other words, 11:4 should have followed 10:29, for in point of fact Moses told Pharaoh, Thus saith the Lord: about midnight will I go out into the midst of Egypt; and all the first-born in the land of Egypt shall die (11:4), after telling him, Thou hast spoken well; I will see thy face again no more (10:29). However, the chapter stating, Yet one plague more3Verses 1-3. was inserted between them. The reason for this is that Scripture wanted to teach us when4Reading matai, as in Vat. Ebr. 48, rather than u-matai, as in the printed editions. Thus saith the Lord5Verse 4 and what follows. was told to Moses.6According to I.E., And the Lord said (v. 1) means: and the Lord had already said, the reference being to what God told Moses in Midian (Ex. 4:23). It was related to Moses while he was yet in Midian,7Contra Rashi, who believes that verses 1-3 contain a prophecy to Moses while in Pharaoh’s palace. viz., Behold, I will slay thy son, thy first-born (Ex. 4:23). Moses was commanded on Mount Sinai8Ex. 3:22. that when the time came for the plague of the first-born to arrive, every man should ask jewels of his neighbor.9The point is that the command to ask for jewels and raiment was also not given at this point. I have already explained why it is there written, but every woman shall ask of her neighbor (Ex. 3:22) and here it is written, and let them ask every man of his neighbor.10See I.E. on Ex. 3:22. Now the meaning of And the Lord said unto Moses: Yet one plague more will I bring is that the Lord had already told this to Moses.11I.E. interprets va-yomer (and he said) as a pluperfect, meaning: and he had said. There are many such cases in Scripture.12Where Scripture employs the pluperfect. God said, he shall surely thrust you out, in keeping with His statement, and by a strong hand shall he drive them out of his land (Ex. 6:1).
SPEAK NOW. I have already explained that the word na means now.13See I.E. on Ex. 4:13.
AND THE LORD GAVE. Scripture relates that the Lord kept his promise to Moses: of And I will give this people favor in the sight of the Egyptians (Ex. 3:21).
[MOREOVER THE MAN MOSES.] For many let them have what they asked out of respect for Moses.
AND IN THE SIGHT OF THE PEOPLE. The people of Egypt.

ABOUT MIDNIGHT. Some grammarians say that ka-chatzot (about midnight) is an infinitive.14A verbal noun meaning: when the night divides in half. Its meaning is, when it shall be exactly one half of the night. They want to compare ka-chatzot ha-laylah (about midnight) to ba-chatzi ha-laylah (at midnight)15Which the Talmud (Berakhot 4a) takes to mean exactly at midnight. in And it came to pass at midnight (Ex. 12:29). Now it is common knowledge that it is beyond the ken of a wise man to ascertain the exact moment of noon without great effort and the use of large copper instruments.16I.E. apparently refers to a sundial. It goes without saying that it is much harder to ascertain the more difficult time of midnight.17Hence Scripture would not employ terms that are meaningless from a practical point of view. I believe that there is no need for all of this since the meaning of ka-chatzot ha-laylah (about midnight) is, when the first half of the night has passed. The same is the case with ba-chatzi ha-laylah in And it came to pass at midnight (Ex. 12:29). It refers to the remaining half of the night.18Another way of saying after midnight. And it came to pass at midnight (ba-chatzi ha-laylah) (Ruth 3:8)19That the man was startled, and turned himself; and, behold, a woman lay at his feet. and At midnight (chatzot laylah) I will rise to give thanks to thee (Ps. 119:62) are convincing proof of this.20The exact moment of midnight is irrelevant to what is reported in Ruth 3:8, for what reason can there be to pinpoint the exact moment that the man was startled. Similarly, David had no way of determining the exact moment of midnight while he slept.
[WILL I GO OUT.] The reference is to the decree that goes out from the Lord.21In other words, will I go out does not refer to the Lord Himself but to His decree.

THE FIRST-BORN OF PHARAOH THAT SITTETH UPON HIS THRONE. Who is fit to sit upon Pharaoh’s throne after him.22Pharaoh’s first-born did not sit on the throne of Egypt, hence I.E.’s comment. Moses mentioned the most honored of all the Egyptians, namely, the son of their lord whom all of them serve and also the meanest of them all, namely, the first-born of the maid-servant, who is himself a slave.23The point is that all first-born shall die, from the highest to the lowest.

[THAT IS BEHIND THE MILL.] Who grinds.24Because grinding was the most menial work, it was reserved for slaves and prisoners. Compare, And he did grind in the prison house (Jud. 16:21). I have already explained that the prophets are not careful in preserving the exact wording but are rather concerned with reproducing meanings.25I.E. on Gen. 5:29. Also see his commentary to Ex. 20:1 and the first chapter of the Sefer Ha-Yesod. The words hagmi’ini (give me to drink) (Gen. 24:17)26Spoken by Abraham’s servant to Rebekah when he asked her for water. and hashkini (give me to drink) (Gen. 29:45);27Used by Abraham’s servant when he quoted what he had said to Rebekah. zakhor (remember) (Ex. 20:8)28Which opens the fourth commandment quoted in Exodus. and shamor (observe)29Which opens the fourth commandment in Deuteronomy. (Deut. 5:12); sheker (false) (Ex. 20:13)30The term employed for false in the ninth commandment in Exodus. and shav (false) (Deut. 5:17);31The term employed for false in the ninth commandment in Deuteronomy. lo tachmod (thou shalt not covet) (Ex. 20:14)32Which opens the tenth commandment in Exodus. and ve-lo titavveh (neither shalt thou covet) (Deut. 5:18)33Which opens the tenth commandment in Deuteronomy. have one meaning. I will yet discuss this when I comment on the prayer of Moses (Ex. 32:9). Now, the first-born of the maid-servant34The term used by Moses in our verse. means the same as the first-born of the captive (Ex. 12:29).35The term used by God when he first told Moses that he would slay all the first-born in the land of Egypt. I.E.’s point is that Moses was not misquoting God, as “the prophets are not careful in preserving the exact wording.” The captive woman is a maid-servant who sleeps in the dungeon at night as prisoners do, as was noted by Joseph when he said, that they should put me into the dungeon (Gen. 40:15).

AND THERE SHALL BE A GREAT CRY. We do not find Scripture elsewhere stating anything like kamohu lo nihyatah ve-khamohu lo tosif (such as there hath been none like it, nor shall be like it anymore).36A comparable combination of masculine and feminine forms. Kamohu (like it) is masculine whereas nihyatah (hath been) and tosif (shall be) are feminine. The word al (over) has been omitted from our verse and the clause should be understood literally as follows: such as over it there hath been none like it, nor such over it shall be like it a cry anymore.37In other words, nihyatah and tosif refer to tze’akah (cry), a feminine noun mentioned in the first part of the verse. This eliminates the problem of having a masculine preposition/pronoun (kamohu) connected to feminine verbs (nihyatah, tosif).

Such as like it (kamohu) refers to havoc, calamity, death, and the like.38Although they are not explicitly mentioned in our verse. The Hebrew form of these words is in the masculine. According to I.E. our verse is to be explained as follows: And there shall be a great cry throughout all the land of Egypt. Over such a calamity there hath been none like it (a cry), nor over such a calamity shall there ever be such (a cry).

SHALL NOT A DOG WHET HIS TONGUE. To frighten them. None whetted his tongue against any of the children of Israel (Josh. 10:21) is similar. Its meaning is that no dog shall bark at them or bite them. Now no dog shall whet his tongue at them or their cattle here on earth. How much more so when He sends a destroyer from heaven to smite their first-born?39If God will not allow even a dog to bark at the Israelites, He will certainly not permit His angel to harm them.
AND ALL THESE THY SERVANTS SHALL COME DOWN UNTO ME…SAYING. On your behalf.40You will send them down to me with the following message.

AND ALL THE PEOPLE THAT FOLLOW THEE. Be-raglekha (follow thee) means: who are under your dominion.41Be-raglekha (follow thee) literally means at thy feet. Hence I.E.’s comment. For I will lead them to the place which I desire. And there went up ten thousand at his feet (be-raglav) (Jud. 4:10) is similar.42There too be-raglav means under his dominion. Moses went out in hot anger because Pharaoh had told him, see my face no more (Ex. 10:28).

AND THE LORD SAID. According to the manner of the Hebrews and the rules of language this is to be rendered: and the Lord had already said.43Another way of saying that according to the rules of classical Hebrew, va-yomer can be either a perfect or a pluperfect. Here it must be a pluperfect, as God had already told what is reported in our verse to Moses in verse 1. There are many other such instances.

AND MOSES. Even though Moses and Aaron did all these wonders which are mentioned in Scripture, Pharaoh’s heart did not soften and he did not let them go, because God hardened his heart. The chapter opening with the words, And it came to pass at midnight (Ex. 12:29)44Which describes the death of the first-born. should by right have followed next so that the plagues would be described in order. However, the chapter dealing with, This is the ordinance of the Passover (chap. 12) was inserted in the middle to inform us how the first-born of Israel were saved when the destroyer came upon Egypt.45They were saved by the blood of the paschal lamb which was put on the side-posts and on the lintels of the houses wherein the Passover sacrifice was eaten. See Ex. 12:7-13.

AND THE LORD SPOKE. Scripture now mentions the first of the commandments given via Moses and Aaron, as they alone were prophets of the law.1Prophets who revealed commandments to Israel. See I.E. on Gen. 27: 13. After them, except for extenuating circumstances as in the case of Gideon2Who was commanded by an angel of God to build an altar and offer a burnt offering upon it. Cf. Jud. 6:26. and Elijah,3Who built an altar on Mount Carmel. See I Kings 18:31-38. I.E. assumes that Elijah was commanded by God to do so. no new precepts were revealed. Do not take the chanting of psalms in the house of God instituted by David4See I Chron. 6:16. to heart,5Do not assume that it was instituted by divine command. as the latter was an enactment and an institution established by David and Solomon.6Of their own accord. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, “established by David and Samuel.” This reading has the support of I Chron. 9:22. Indeed, Filwarg emends Solomon to Samuel. If we do not emend the text then we must interpret I.E. to mean that David established the practice of singing psalms in the house of God and Solomon reaffirmed it when he built the Temple. Cf. Weiser. Thus Scripture states, by their beliefs (II Chron. 9:22), and not by their prophecies. However, Saadiah Gaon says that they had a tradition going back to Moses that a king would arise and innovate musical compositions.7In other words, David did not institute the temple service on his own accord. Neither carry forth a burden out of your houses on the sabbath day (Jer. 17:22) is similar.8The prohibition against carrying a burden on the Sabbath was not instituted by Jeremiah; it was handed down from Moses.

THIS MONTH. Rabbi Judah Ha-Parsi9One of the early Karaites. He taught that the festivals are to be established in accordance with a solar calendar. It is interesting to note that I.E. uses the title Rabbi in introducing Judah Ha-Parsi. However, in chapter 1 of his Iggeret Ha-Shabbat he quotes the same opinion and there writes, Judah Ha-Parsi says. Similarly, the Karaite Joshua is sometimes quoted with the title Rabbi. As much as one might want to attribute modern notions of civility to I.E., the probability is that the title Rabbi was added by scribes who were not aware of the fact that I.E. was quoting Karaites. The matter bears further investigation. Be the aforementioned as it is, the fact remains that “Abraham Ibn Ezra was the only rabbi to quote Karaite sources” (L. Roth, Standard Jewish Encyclopedia, p. 1106). says that the Israelites, like the uncircumcised,10The Christians. employed a solar calendar. He offers as proof, Thou shalt therefore keep this ordinance in its season (Ex. 13:10). But lunar years are not all equal, as the seasons of plowing and harvest are dependent solely on the movement of the sun as it travels to the north or the south.11The verse continues, from year to year (mi-yamim yamimah). Thus the verse teaches that the festivals are to be observed each year in their season. This can only be done if a solar calendar is employed, as seasons are determined by the sun, not the moon. Indeed, in a lunar calendar the months eventually fall in different seasons. For example, the Moslem fast of Ramadan at times falls in the summer, winter, fall, and spring because the Moslems employ a lunar calendar. However, he did not speak correctly. I will now explain.12The workings of the Jewish calendar. We know that it takes the moon, moving in its sphere13For I.E.’s concept of the moon’s motions, see Vol. 1, p. 5, notes 27-32. in a given point facing the sphere of the zodiac, close to twenty-seven and a third days to return to this very point. Now let us assume a starting point wherein the moon is in conjunction with the sun at the beginning of Aries. In such a case the moon would not find the sun at the head of Aries when it returned there14At the end of nearly 27 and a third days, for the sun and moon do not move in a uniform motion. because the sun, traveling in its mean motion,15For the mean motion of the sun, see Mishneh Torah, Hilkhot Kiddush Ha-Chodesh, (Laws of Sanctification of the New Moon), 6:1-4; 12:1 (henceforth, M.T., New Moon). would by then have journeyed twenty-seven degrees.16“The mean rate of the sun’s motion in one day…is fifty-nine minutes and eight seconds”(M.T., New Moon 12:1). There are 60 minutes per degree. This is because, contrary to the movement above,17That is, of the diurnal sphere which turns from west to east. The stars appear to be moving nightly from east to west. See W. M. Feldman, Rabbinical Mathematics and Astronomy, Hermon Press, p. 65. the sun and the moon move from west to east. The sun and the moon would next be in conjunction at the end of twenty-nine and a half days, two-thirds and seventy-three parts of an hour, according to the way Israelites divide the hour.18The Israelites divide the hour into 1,080 parts. Thus19Before the moon is in conjunction with the sun again. the moon would have traveled the very degrees that the sun journeyed,2027 degrees. That is, it will have traveled 27 and a third days. and the moon also would have had to travel two days and close to five hours in the parts in which the sun had moved.21When the moon journeyed the above-noted 27 degrees. Actually, the year belongs only to the sun,22The term year refers to the time it takes the sun to complete a circuit around the earth. as the sun gives birth to the four seasons of the year, cold, heat, summer, and winter. Now let us assume the sun to be at the beginning of Aries. It will then travel three hundred and sixty-five days plus close to a quarter of a day in its sphere until it returns a second time to where it started out. It is for this reason that a year is called a shanah.23The root shin, nun, heh means once again. Hence a shanah is the time it takes the sun to return once again to its point of departure. Now the moon has no year, as the sun has no month. Nothing new happens to the sun; only to the light of the moon does something new occur.24The Hebrew term for a month is chodesh. It comes from the root chet, dalet, shin meaning new. The light of the moon is renewed every 29 and a third days when it is once again in conjunction with the sun. It is because of this that a month is called a chodesh and also a yerach.25Strictly speaking, chodesh applies to the day that the light of the moon is renewed and yerach to the entire month. Compare, yerach yamim (a full month) in Deut. 21:13 (Krinsky). It is so called26It is called a chodesh. because the light of the moon is renewed. We have conclusive proof that the moon has no light of its own, and that its light comes from the sun. The sun27Being a source of light. therefore does not darken except in the moment when it is in conjunction with the moon at the head or the tail of Aries.28During an eclipse when the moon blocks its light.
