Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, the dragon. Similarly, the moon does not darken except when it is opposite the sun in the aforementioned places29At the head or tail of Aries (or the dragon). at night.30And cannot receive the sun’s light. Hence we see that the sun is the source of the moon’s light. Due to the fact that the year of the uncircumcised is close to a solar year31It lasts 365 days. A full solar year is 365 and a quarter days. and because they saw that the moon is renewed twelve times during a solar year, they divided the days of the year into twelve parts and called each part a month because it is close to the days of a lunar month. This arrangement of theirs is not in keeping with the laws of nature.32For the months of the solar year do not begin or end on the day that the moon starts or completes its cycle around the earth. A lunar month lasts for 29 and a third days and the months of a solar year for 30 or 31 days. Thus the solar months do not reflect reality and are purely arbitrary. Similarly the Moslems,33That is, the Moslems made a similar arrangement with regard to the year. because their festivals are contingent upon lunar months34Hence they were forced to employ lunar months. and a month starts from the night that the moon is first seen. They saw that there are twelve months in a solar year and they did not find a closer way of reckoning than this,35Since 12 lunar months almost equal one solar year, the Moslems decided that 12 lunar months make up a year. However, this type of year is purely arbitrary and does not represent reality, as the moon has no year. as there is only a difference of eleven days between the two ways of numbering the year.36That is, between a solar and a lunar year. They therefore made all of their years lunar. The time of their Passover37There is no Moslem Passover. What I.E. means is the time of the Moslem festivals. Or, if the Moslems celebrated Passover it would recede year by year. recedes each year by eleven days until thirty-three solar years equal thirty-four lunar years.38Eleven multiplied by 33=363. Hence a difference of a year would accumulate in 33 years. As time passes on there would be a substantial difference in reckoning how many years passed from a given event. These things39The lunar year. are not based on the laws of nature. Now God commanded in His Torah that the festivals be kept in their seasons, for He said, Observe the month of spring and keep the passover unto the Lord thy God (Deut. 16:1). Now if spring is not found40If spring does not come. by half of the month41Of Nisan. then we make Passover in the month close to it.42We add an additional month. Cf. Blessed be the Lord who has guided me in the straight path. I will now offer you proof from Scripture that the festivals are dependent upon the Bet Din. Scripture states, For the king100King Hezekiah.had taken counsel, and his princes, and all the congregation in Jerusalem, to keep the passover in the second month (II Chron. 30:2). Now if they had a tradition to look for spring,101That is, only for spring and not for the declaration of the Bet Din as to whether the first month had arrived or not as those who argue with our rabbis of blessed memory claim, why did the king take counsel to establish the Passover in the second month?102He should have kept Passover in the first month, the month when spring fell. It will now be shown if their103Those who disagree with the sages. words are true. Hezekiah did three evils.104If we accept the theory of those who disagree with our sages. See Num. 9:1-8. Why did Hezekiah delay the observance of Passover because most of the congregation had not arrived?107In Jerusalem. Such a thing is only found in the words of tradition,108According to the Talmud the Bet Din may insert an additional Adar and thus celebrate Passover a month later if for some reason the congregation cannot make it to Jerusalem by the 15th of Nisan. not in Scripture.109Nowhere in the Pentateuch is it stated that the observance of Passover may be delayed because most of the congregation has not arrived in Jerusalem. See note 106. on one night,113The night of the 15th of Iyyar. the Lord did not command the observance of the Passover in the second month, for all those who are unclean eat unleavened bread along with all of Israel in the first month. Therefore he did not commit any of the above evils. I will now explain.115Why and what Hezekiah did. Know that Hezekiah took counsel with the entire congregation116Of Jerusalem. Cf. II Chron. 30:2. at the start of the first month that they should observe the Passover in the following month because most of the people had not arrived and the priests had not sanctified themselves in sufficient numbers.117II Chron. 30:3. He thus added a month to the year, and the Passover that he observed was the actual Passover118As opposed to the second Passover observed one month later for those who were impure. See note 106. in its proper season. The fact that God plagued those who ate the paschal lamb in a manner contrary to what is written119That is, in a state of impurity. See II Chron. 30:18 is proof of this. If the Passover observed by Hezekiah was not celebrated in its proper time and was therefore not acceptable to the Lord,120That is, God did not consider it a proper Passover offering. why did He plague them?121For eating the paschal lamb in a state of impurity. If Hezekiah sinned how is it that he prayed on their behalf122On behalf of those who ate the paschal lamb in a state of impurity. and the Lord accepted his supplication and healed the people?123See II Chron. 30:20. The answer to one who would argue that the sages of blessed memory did not maintain124Literally, admit. that Hezekiah acted properly in adding another month during the month of Nisan125The rabbis claim that Hezekiah acted improperly in calling Nisan Adar II after Nisan had already started. Cf. Pesachim 56a. is: they126The sages. spoke the truth. It is the custom of every Bet Din to ascertain at the end of the month of Adar whether it is necessary127For climatic or other reasons. to add another month to the year or not. Now Hezekiah did not do this; he committed a small error in adding another month to the year at the beginning of the month.128Of Nisan. Now since the additional month129Adar II. always comes before the first month,130Nisan. the latter is always the first of the months, and the festivals131That is, Rosh Ha-Shanah, Yom Kippur, and Sukkot. Cf. Lev. 23:23-44. will fall in the seventh month from it.132In other words, the adding of the extra month does not affect the numbering of the months. Nisan is always the first month. Iyyar the second, Sivan the third, and so on. This is the meaning of it shall be the first month of the year to you (v. 2).133The counting of the months must begin with Nisan. We know that many commandments are in memory of the Exodus from Egypt. Behold, it is therefore fitting that the Exodus be the first reference point in Israel’s calculations. Thus it is written, And it came to pass in the four hundred and eightieth year after the children of Israel were come out of the land of Egypt, in the fourth year…in the month Ziv, which is the second month (I Kings 6:1). The gentiles ask, if the year is made up of months and the month of spring is its foundation and beginning, why do you calculate your years from the seventh month and say that a new year begins on its first day?134In other words they argue that the new year, Rosh Ha-Shanah, should begin in Nisan, the first month. It should be noted that the Torah does not explicitly refer to the first of Tishri as new year’s day. The answer is that our sages of blessed memory have already noted135In tractate Rosh Ha-Shanah 2a. that there are four new year days.136Each one of which serves a distinct purpose. The first of Nisan is the new year for festivals and kings. The first of Tishri is for the reckoning of years, of the year of release (shimitah) and the jubilee year. The first of Elul is the new year of the tithe of cattle, and the first of Shebat is for trees (so Beth Shammai, whereas Beth Hillel places it on the 15th of Shebat). We clearly see that the sanctification of the jubilee year is on the tenth day of the seventh month (Lev. 25:9).137Which shows that the counting of the jubilee year starts in Tishri, not in Nisan. Furthermore, God commanded that the Torah be read in the set time of the year of release, in the feast of tabernacles (Deut. 31:10)…that they may hear, and that they may learn (Deut. 31:12). Now if the beginning of the year of release is reckoned from Nisan, why didn’t God command that the Torah be read during the festival of unleavened bread? Now they were idle for half a year.138That is, half of the year of release, when one is prohibited from working the ground, would have passed by the time Sukkot arrived. The Torah connects the reading of the Torah with the year of release. If the year of release starts in Tishri then we can understand why the Torah is read in Tishri. However, if the new year starts in Nisan it makes no sense to read the Torah six months later. Furthermore, Scripture states, and the feast of ingathering 139The reference is to the festival of Sukkot. at the turn of the year (Ex. 34:22). 140We thus see that Sukkot falls in the month at which the year turns, that is, begins. This proves that Tishri is the start of a new year. Elsewhere it states,141With reference to the festival of Sukkot. at the end of the year,142That is, in the month which marks the end of the old and the beginning of a new year. We thus have additional proof that the new year begins in Tishri. when thou gatherest in thy labors out of the field (Ex. 23:16). Additionally, we can derive the aforementioned143That the year of release begins in Tishri. from the way the Torah speaks and from the way nature acts. The Torah first states,144With regard to the sabbatical year. ye shall not sow and afterwards says, neither (shall ye) reap (Lev. 25:12). The season of sowing is close to Tishri,145When the year of release begins. not Nisan. Furthermore, if we reckon the beginning of the year of release from Nisan he who sowed in the sixth year146After Tishri. will not harvest in the seventh year, because the harvest falls after Nisan when the year of release has already started.147Hence he will not sow in the sixth year. He will also not sow in the year of release.148After Tishri. There will thus be two rather than one year of no sowing. However, Scripture only speaks of one year of no sowing. We thus see that the words of our sages are correct.149That the year of release and similarly the years in general start in Tishri.

THE BEGINNING OF MONTHS. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen150See I.E. on Ex. 2:2 and the notes thereto. says that there is no need to use the term rosh chodesh (new moon). The term chodesh suffices,151That is, chodesh means the first day of the month. It does not mean month. Such terms as esrim la-chodesh, usually translated as the 20th of the month, really mean 20 days from the new moon. since the meaning of chodesh is the day that the light of the moon is renewed. Scripture thus states, chodesh ve-shabbat (New moon and sabbath) (Is. 1:13); chodshekhem u-mo’adekhem (your new moons and your appointed seasons) (Is. 1:14); mi-de chodesh be-chodsho (from one new moon to another) (Is. 66:23). Others argued with him and asked, if this be the case, then why does Scripture state, ba-chodesh hashe’vi’i be-echad la-chodesh (And in the seventh month, on the first day of the month) (Num. 29:1)?152If chodesh means the first day of the month, why does Scripture go on to say: on the first day of the month? Thus chodesh must mean month. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen answered, to remove doubt.153That is, to be especially precise. They also quoted, u-ve-roshe chodshekhem (and in your new moons) (Num. 28:11) against him.154Scripture should have read, u-ve-chodshekhem (chodshekhem is the plural of chodesh plus the personal pronoun). He answered that Scripture speaks of the month of Nisan throughout the years,155In other words, u-ve-roshe chodshekhem does not mean, and in your new moons, but rather: and in your chief new moons, that is, every new moon of the month of Nisan. for only Nisan is the chief new moon.156Roshe chodshekhem can be translated as your new moons or your chief new moons. Rabbi Moses insists that the latter is the correct rendition. They then asked him, if so, then what sacrifices are we to offer on other new moons?157If Num. 28:11-15 deals only with the sacrifices to be offered on the new moon of Nisan, then what sacrifices are to be offered on other new moons? He answered that Scripture states in the very same portion, This is the burnt-offering of every new moon throughout the months of the year (Num. 28:14).158Thus the same sacrifice that is offered on the new moon of Nisan is to be offered on all other new moons. Scripture likewise states, Also in the day of your gladness, and in your appointed seasons, and in your new moons (u-ve-roshe chodshekhem),159The reference being to the first of Nisan. Here too roshe chodshekhem means the chief of your new moons. ye shall blow with the trumpets (Num. 10:10) because it is the beginning of the year.160Hence the Torah commands us to sound trumpets on the first day of Nisan. However, we161In contrast to Rabbi Moses. will not set aside the words of our rabbis of blessed memory because of our own opinions. Our sages said that we sound the trumpets on the new moon of every month.162Sukkah 55a. It is correct to say chodesh or rosh chodesh.163When referring to a new moon, since chodesh can either mean new moon or a month. It is written, ad chodesh yamim (but a whole month) (Num. 11:20), the meaning of which is: until the days of the month are complete.164We thus see that chodesh does not necessarily mean a new moon but that it also means a month.

Yefet says that they should start preparing the lamb on the tenth day and do so till the fourteenth day.167So Vat. Ebr. 38. The word ad (until) is missing from our texts. A LAMB, ACCORDING TO THEIR FATHERS’ HOUSES. If they be few.170If those who will eat the lamb be few then one lamb will suffice for a bet av (father’s house). A bet av consisted of all families descended from one person. A bayit (household) referred to the immediate family.

AND IF THE HOUSEHOLD BE TOO LITTLE FOR A LAMB. Too little to eat a lamb because the members of the household are few. Then he and his neighbor shall take a lamb.

YOUR LAMB SHALL BE WITHOUT BLEMISH. It shall be without any deformity. Rabbi Joshua says that there is a difference between ben shanah (of the first year)192Our verse states that the paschal lamb is to be a ben shanah. and ben shenato (of the first year). A ben shanah193That is, a lamb that is a ben shanah. has lived a year and ben shenato means exactly what Scripture says.194Ben shenato literally means of its year, i.e., during its first year of life. Now with regard to the sacrifices offered by the princes it first states, keves echad ben shenato leolah (one he-lamb of the first year, for a burnt-offering) (Num. 7:15) and then states, kevasim bene shanah (he-lambs of the first year) (Num. 7:87).195Scripture tells us that each one of the princes of the tribes of Israel offered a keves ben shenato for a burnt offering. Scripture then gives the number of burnt offerings as kevasim bene shanah shenem asar (he-lambs of the first year twelve). We thus see that the terms ben shanah and ben shenato are one and the same. Therefore Rabbi Joshua is incorrect. I might add that both Krinsky and Weiser missed I.E.’s point. Both indicate that I.E.’s proof is from the five he-lambs of the first year (bene shanah) brought as peace offerings. However, there is no proof from the latter because the peace offering differs from the burnt offering, and one can argue that Scripture required a lamb under a year for a burnt offering and a lamb over a year for a peace offering.
AND YE SHALL KEEP IT. Each one shall keep it in his house.

AT DUSK. Ben ha-arbayim (at dusk) is a difficult phrase. Rabbi Solomon196Rashi. Rashi writes on Ex. 12:6 that from six hours (noon) and upwards is termed ben ha-arbayim. says that it refers to the moment after midday that the sun moves to the west. He does not explain why arbayim is in the dual form.197Actually Rashi does explain. He writes, “It appears to me that the term ben ha-arbayim refers to those hours between the darkening of the day (arivat ha-yom, i.e., when the sun begins its descent) and the darkening of the night (arivat ha-laylah, i.e., when night starts). The day darkens at the start of the seventh hour…and the night begins to darken at the beginning of the night.” Hence according to Rashi, ben ha-arbayim means between the two evenings (or darkenings). I.E. probably quoted from memory. I doubt that I.E.’s manuscript of Rashi differed from ours. Now, Scripture states, And when Aaron lighteth the lamps at dusk (ben ha-arbayim) (Ex. 30:8), and there is no doubt that Aaron is to light the lamps when the sun sets.198Ex. 27:21. We thus see, contra Rashi, that ben arbayim does not refer to a moment after midday. Now, when we researched this phrase we found that Scripture refers to the moment of ben ha-arbayim as erev (evening).199I.E. explains later on. For it is clearly written, At dusk (ben ha-arbayim) ye shall eat flesh (Ex. 16:12), and it is there stated, when the Lord shall give you in the evening (ba-erev) flesh to eat (Ex. 16:8). Likewise, concerning the lighting of the lamps it is written: Aaron and his sons shall set it in order, to burn from evening (erev) to morning before the Lord (Ex. 27:21).200This verse proves that erev means the same as ben ha-arbayim, as this verse is parallel to Ex. 30:8. It is similarly written, even burnt-offerings mornings and evening (erev) (Ezra 3:3), and it is stated, The one lamb thou shalt offer in the morning; and the other lamb thou shalt offer at dusk (ben ha-arbayim) (Ex. 29:39). Now concerning the Passover sacrifice, about which the term ben ha-arbayim (at dusk) is employed, we find that Scripture states, there thou shalt sacrifice the passover-offering at even (erev), at the coming (bo)201Translated literally. of the sun, at the season that thou earnest forth out of Egypt (Deut. 16:6). Rabbi Solomon202So Vat. Ebr. 38. explains that the reference is to the time that the sun comes to the west.203This is not actually said by Rashi. What I.E. means is that according to Rashi, Deut. 16:6 must be interpreted in this way. However, this is not the meaning of bo. It refers to the opposite of the sun’s going forth upon the earth204In other words, bo ha-shemesh means the setting of the sun. since it is written, the sun went out (yatza) upon the earth (Gen. 19:23),205Translated literally. which means the time that the sun first begins to be seen on the earth. Similarly, And when the sun comes (ba) he shall be clean206Translated literally. (Lev. 22:7) means when the sun shall no longer be seen upon the ground. Now it is written concerning a nocturnal seminal emission, But it shall be, when evening cometh on, he shall bathe himself in water; and when the sun comes (u-khe-vo ha-shemesh)207That is, goes down, since the first part of the verse speaks of when evening cometh. he may come within the camp208Only the first part of the verse appears in the text of I.E. However, since his main proof is from the second part, the entire verse is inserted into the translation and translated literally. (Deut. 23:12). If this is not so, then let Rabbi Solomon explain what difference there is between “when the sun comes” with regard to Passover and “when the sun comes” with regard to a nocturnal seminal emission. It is the same with and when the sun comes he209One who is ritually impure. shall be clean (Lev. 22:7).210If he has immersed himself. Let Rashi explain why when the sun comes with regard to Passover means a moment after midday and why when the sun comes with regard to the laws of ritual purity means after sunset. The Sadducees211A term used for heretics and here meaning the Karaites. say that there are three evenings.212When the sun begins to set, while it is setting, when it fully sets (Krinsky). Their proof is from a verse which they found to read, ha-erev ha-shelishit (the third evening)213Translated literally. They interpret this to refer to the final setting of the sun. (I Sam. 20:5). However, they do not recognize or understand the truth. It is written, Tomorrow is the new moon…And in the third day thou shalt hide thyself well (I Sam. 20:18, 19), the meaning of which is: when close to evening of the third day starting from today comes, you shall hide yourself well in the field where you are presently hidden. It is because of this that Jonathan said, until the third evening.214In other words, ad ha-erev ha-shelishit does not mean until the third of the day’s three evenings arrives but rather the evening of the third day arrives. See note 213. I will now backtrack and explain.215What ben ha-arbayim means. Know that the word arbayim is always vocalized according to the paradigm of the dual forms like ovnayim (birthstool) (Ex. 1:16). Luchotayim (planks) (Ezek. 27:5) is similar. So is derachayim (ways) (Prov. 28:18), as But he that is perverse in his ways (derachayim) shall fall in one of them (Ibid.) proves.216One of them refers to derachayim. This shows that derachayim is a dual form and refers to two. Prov. 28:18 is translated according to I.E. The same is the case with the word shamayim (heaven), as the heavens consist of two poles217Hebrew, sadne ha-galgal (anvil). In medieval astronomic terminology sadan refers to a pole. See Klatzkin, op. cit., Vol. III, p. 94. which are like fastened nails upon which the sphere leans. I have already explained in The Book of God, the Glorious,218See Sefer Hashem, chap. 1 in Yalkut Ibn Ezra, edited by I. Levin, Israel, 1985. that the word shamayim comes from the same root as the word sham (there) in There the upright might reason with Him (Job 23:7).219I.E. here contradicts what he wrote in Gen. 1:1, where he connects shamayim to the Arabic word sammah (high). The term shamayim alludes to these two places.220The places where the aforementioned two poles one in the north and one in the south, are fixed. Hence shamayim is a dual form. We thus have two evenings: one when the sun sets, that is, the time when the sun descends beneath the earth; the second when its light disappears from the clouds.221Hence the term arbayim, which literally means evenings. Now there is close to one and a third hours between them. It is at this time222Ben ha-arbayim, between the evenings. that one who experienced a seminal emission223Lev. 22:7. may enter the camp and Aaron kindles the lights.224Ex. 30:8. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon, of blessed memory, says that the altar of the burnt offering measured five cubits in length and five cubits in width. Such an area has room only for a small number of kohanim (priests), who are the ones that sprinkle the blood from the paschal lambs before it coagulates. Now in the days of Josiah,225II Chron. 35:1. when the number of Israelites were few,226As the ten northern tribes were already in exile. the kohanim were not able to sprinkle the blood of the Passover offerings and the peace offerings that they slaughtered; i.e., they were not able to sprinkle them on the altar in one and a third hours.227Scripture states that thousands of lambs and bullocks were slaughtered for the Passover feast (II Chron. 35:7-9). It stands to reason that such a vast number of animals could not be ritually processed by the kohanim on an altar measuring five cubits by five cubits in an hour and a third. How much more unable to do so were they when all the tribes were in their country.228And the number of Passover offerings proportionally more numerous. There was thus a tradition that they begin to slaughter229The paschal lamb. from the moment that it became clear to a person that the sun turned to the west.230Immediately after noon. Cf. Pesachim 64a. Scripture speaks of ben ha-arbayim (at dusk)231Which begins at sunset. See above. because most of the paschal lambs were slaughtered then,232In Egypt. Israel slaughtered the lamb between sunset and the disappearance of the sun’s light. and that marks its time limit;233For the slaughter of the lamb. for one should not wait until the going down of the sun’s light.234The second erev which starts the night (see above) is the final cut-off point for the slaughtering of the paschal lamb.
ON THE TWO SIDE-POSTS. Of the door of the house. Moses will go on to explain235In verse 22. how they are to take the blood.

[LINTEL.] The word mashkof (lintel) means a window.236Contra Rashi, who explains mashkof as a lintel, namely, “the upper beam against which the door strikes when one closes it.” Rashi compares mashkof to the Aramaic words shakef (struck) and mashkofe (blow). Compare, va-yashkef (looked) (Gen. 26:8).237It is called a mashkof because one looks through it. This window was in the door.238The blood was to serve as a sign that the destroyer was not to enter the house via the door. This is the custom in all Moslem countries. The practice of the uncircumcised239The Christians among whom I.E. was living when he wrote this commentary. Windows were apparently not placed in doors in Christian Europe in I.E’s lifetime, hence the need to point out that they were in ancient Egypt. differs from that of the Egyptians240Egypt was and is a Moslem country. I.E. assumed that the practices of medieval Egypt were the same as those of ancient Egypt. even regarding food,241How much more does it differ with regard to the construction of houses. People in the Middle Ages generally did not travel and were uninformed in these matters, hence I.E.’s comments. an example being, Thou shalt break it in pieces (Lev. 2:6).242I.E. is not clear. Weiser suggests that I.E. wants to point out that the bread in Moslem countries is different from the bread in Christian countries. In Moslem countries people eat a flat bread (pitta). The Hebrew word for pieces is pittim. Thus pittim (pieces of pitta) shows that the bread eaten by the two cultures is different. Or, Lev. 2:6 speaks of bread baked in a pan. Europeans do not make bread in that manner. We thus see that different peoples have different food habits. Similarly with regard to women’s jewelry such as the wearing of nose rings and earrings and all that the prophet Isaiah mentioned concerning the daughters of Zion (Is. 3:18-24).243Women in Moslem countries still wear those type of ornaments while women in Christian countries do not. Likewise, all of their houses244And similarly those of ancient Egypt. without exception are built in courtyards. One entrance is called the door to the house and the other the gate of the courtyard. Many say that the purpose of placing the blood on the window and on the two side-posts was to demonstrate publicly that they slaughtered the abomination of Egypt,245Their god. See Mekhilta 6, “On the two side-posts and on the lintel. Rabbi Isaac says…on the outside, so that the Egyptians, seeing it, would be cut to the quick.” The Shulkhan Arukh uses a similar reason for Shabbat Ha-Gadol. See Orech Chayyim 430:1. since by then the fear of the Israelites had fallen on the Egyptians, and the Israelites were not afraid of being stoned.246See Ex. 9:22. Now if this was the case then the blood should have been placed on the entrance to the courtyard.247Where it would be visible to all. Therefore I.E. disagrees with this theory and goes on to explain what he thinks occurred. However, the blood was placed in secret, for they closed the gate of the courtyard. Furthermore, they slaughtered the lamb at dusk, which is close to night, so that no one would see them. Moreover, no man left his house until the morning when each one went on his way and each one closed the gate to his courtyard. The Egyptians thought that the Israelites would return.248That is why they gave them permission to leave. Thus there was no point in antagonizing the Egyptians or giving them any reason to suspect that they were not returning. Indeed, once the Egyptians learned that the Israelites were not returning they pursued them and tried to bring them back. See I.E. on Ex. 14:5. The reason the blood was smeared on the window was to make atonement249For one’s sins, as the blood which is sprinkled on the altar does. for all those eating in the house and to serve as a mark for the destroyer250The angel of death. to see. It is to be understood in the same way as and set a mark on the foreheads of the men (Ezek. 9:4).251So that they will not be harmed when destruction comes to the city.

[HOUSES.] The word battim (houses) is grammatically irregular, as it has a dagesh252In the tav. following a long kamatz.253Beneath the bet. This is contrary to the rule254For a dagesh is not placed in a letter that follows a consonant vocalized with a kamatz. whereby a dagesh is only placed after a short kamatz,255A kamatz katan. as in ronnu (sing)256Wherein the resh is vocalized with a kamatz katan, and a dagesh, is placed in the resh. in Sing, O ye heavens (Is. 44:23). Perhaps battim was vocalized with a kamatz 257In other words, battim (houses) should have been vocalized with a pattach beneath the bet. Hence there is a dagesh in the tav. because of the missing yod in the word bayit.258The singular of battim is bayit. The yod drops out in the plural. Now if the yod were retained there would be no chance of confusing our word with battim meaning baths because our word would have been pronounced beyatim. However, since the yod drops out in the plural, if both words were identically vocalized one could confuse them. This form259Battim (houses), the plural of bayit. would thus not be confused with the form battim (baths) in ten baths are a homer (Ezek. 45:14) wherein battim, the plural of bat (bath) in The ephah and the bath (Ezek. 45:11), is vocalized with a pattach in the plural.260Hence the vocalization of the word battim, meaning houses, was changed from a pattach to a kamatz. The word battim (houses) in upon the houses is indicative,261That battim is irregular (Filwarg). Or that its kamatz is not a “real” kamatz (Krinsky). Or that it indicates why in this word a dagesh follows a kamatz (Weiser). for unlike the rule it is penultimately accented.262Which shows that its kamatz is not a “real” kamatz. If it were, then battim would be ultimately accented (Krinsky). Or it shows that a dagesh may follow after an accented kamatz. Compare, nashattah (faileth) in Is. 41:17 (Weiser). It should be noted that battim is found penultimately accented only in our verse. Elsewhere in Scripture it is always ultimately accented.

WITH BITTER HERBS THEY SHALL EAT IT. One of the Spanish wise men explained that it is well known that because of the Nile and the lack of rain, the humidity in Egypt is very high and the air is always moist. It was therefore their custom to eat all sorts of bitter herbs and mustards with their meals. An Egyptian always had bitters in which to dip his bread, even if he had but one loaf of bread, because the bitters are a cure for their climate.263Hence God commanded the Israelites to eat bitter herbs with the paschal lamb. However, we will rely on the opinion of our ancients of blessed memory, who explained to us that the reason for the bitter herbs is to remind us that they made their lives bitter (Ex. 1:14).264Pesachim 116b.

RAW. Some say that the meaning of na (raw) is: as it is now,265In other words, the word na means now. See I.E. on Gen. 12:11, “Na means now. Na in behold now (na), I am old (Gen. 27.2), and Woe now (na) unto us (Lam. 5:16) are similar.” i.e., when the meat is raw. However, we do not find the word na used in such a way elsewhere in Scripture.266It is so used in reference to time but not with regard to an object. While I.E. rejects the interpretation here, he accepts it in his short commentary. Others say267Menachem ben Saruk (Krinsky). that it comes from the same root as heni (breaks)268From the root nun, vav, ayin. in But if her father breaks her vow (Num. 30:6) and means broken.269The point is that one is prohibited from breaking a bone in the paschal lamb. However, this is incorrect, as Scripture later states, neither shall ye break a bone thereof (v. 46).270Why would Scripture repeat itself? However, in my opinion the word na271As used in this context. has no counterpart in Scripture. It means the opposite of cooked and is272Elsewhere. referred to as chai (raw). Compare, For he will not have sodden flesh of thee, but raw (chai) (I Sam. 2:15). I have previously noted that most of Arabic is similar to Hebrew.273Hence we may learn the meaning of Hebrew words from their Arabic cognates. Now in Arabic raw meat is called nayy, and the alef heh, vav, and yod interchange in the tongue of the Arabs as it does in our tongue.274Hence nun yod equals nun alef.

NOR SODDEN. Bashel (sodden) is an adjective. Here its meaning is, that which is sodden with water.275Hence Scripture reads, u-vashel mevushal ba-mayim (nor sodden at all with water), which literally means, nor boiled, boiled in water. That which is roasted in fire is also called mevushal,276Hence the modifying phrase mevushal ba-mayim (boiled in water). for it is written, And thou shalt roast (u-vishalta)277Here bashel refers to roasting, as it is forbidden to cook the paschal lamb in water. and eat it (Deut. 16:7) and, And they roasted (va-yevashelu)278See note 277. the passover with fire according to the ordinance (II Chron. 35:13). It is possible that nor sodden at all with water279Literally, boiled, boiled in water. If Scripture wanted to lay down the law that the paschal lamb should not be eaten cooked in water it should have said u-mevushal ba-mayim (nor boiled in water). Why be redundant and write u-vashel mevushal ba-mayim, and boiled, boiled in water. means nor cooked, that is, cooked in water, as a royal dish is sodden in liquids. They place a wide copper utensil on the fire and fill half of it with water. When the water boils they place the pot with the meat in cold water above the boiling water. Thus is the meat cooked.280There are thus two acts of boiling. Hence Scripture employs two terms, bashel and mevushal. This dish is better than one prepared close to the fire. I the writer281The copyist of the manuscript. add to the words of this scholar what I heard from his very own mouth.282The copyist was obviously a student of Ibn Ezra. Bashel (sodden)283Literally, u-vashel. is an adjective284Not an infinitive. Our word is not to be confused with the pi’el infinitive bashel (cf. le-vashel, to cook), as the infinitive form is vocalized with a pattach and has a dagesh in the shin (compare the pi’el infinitive dabber). following the paradigm of kaved (heavy) and zaken (old). The term bashel 285Literally, u-vashel. here is similar,286To kaved and zaken. as its bet 287Unlike the bet of bashel in the infinitive (see note 284) but like the kof of kaved and the zayin of zaken. is vocalized with a kamatz and its shin288Unlike the shin of bashel in the infinitive (see note 284) but like the bet of kaved and the kof of zaken. has no dagesh. Bashel is not an infinitive289See note 284. like kabbed (promote) in for I will promote thee (Num. 22:17) or hakkeh (smite) in thou shalt surely smite (Deut. 13:16), as the infinitive is not joined to a word unless it is a perfect or an imperfect. Compare, dabber yedabber (speak well) (Ex. 4:14),290Dabber is an infinitive, yedabber an imperfect. Dabber yedabber (speak well) literally means speak, he will speak. and hakdesh hikdashti (I verily dedicate) (Jud. 17:3).291Hakdesh is an infinitive, hikdashti a perfect. Hakdesh hikdashti (I verily dedicate) literally means dedicate, I dedicated. However, the infinitive is never joined with the po’el or pa’ul. 292With the active or passive participle form. However, it is in bashel mevushal, as mevushal is a pu’al participle. Hence the term bashel in bashel mevushal cannot be an infinitive. Thus bashel (sodden) is similar to kaved (heavy).293It is an adjective as kaved is. Its feminine form is beshelah, as in the shoulder…when it is sodden (beshelah) (Num. 6:19). Do not ask what need Scripture had to use the two terms bashel and mevushal.294See note 279. As the scholar295Ibn Ezra. pointed out,296Above. there are two soddenings, one of which is297Literally, the one is. If we do not interpret it to mean: one of which is, then along with Weiser we must assume that of one of the steps in the copyist’s description of the two-stage cooking process was lost. the placing of the utensil with the meat in the midst of the boiling water. The plural of bashel mevushal is beshelim mevushalim. Compare, chakhamim mechukkamim (exceeding wise) in But they are exceeding wise (Prov. 30:24). The singular form is chakham mechukkam. Compare, barukh u-mevorakh (exceedingly blessed). There is a difference in nuance from a grammatical standpoint between chakham (a wise man) and mechukkam (one who has become wise).298The copyist comments thus because earlier he compared the plural form of bashel mevushal to the plural form of chakham mechukkam. Chakham means a wise man. Mechukkam means one who has been made wise (taught) by others. See I.E. on Prov. 30:24, “Mechukkamim: God gave them the wisdom to do this.” There is, as the scholar explained,299I.E. in his opening comment on this verse. a similar difference between bashel (sodden)300Which means boiled (cooked). and mevushal (sodden).301Which means was cooked (boiled). Hence bashel, mevushal ba-mayim, boiled, boiled in water. The difference between bashel and mevushal is explained by I.E. in his opening comment on this verse.

ITS HEAD WITH ITS LEGS AND WITH THE INWARDS THEREOF. The word al has the meaning of with.302Not on, its usual meaning. Hence rosho al kera’av ve’al kirbo means: its head with its legs and with the inwards thereof, not its head on its legs and on the inwards thereof. The word al in And they came, both men and (al) women (Ex. 35:22) is similar. The head and the legs are to be washed in water303Before roasting, although not stated here. as the ordinance requires.304See Pesachim 74a.

BUT THAT WHICH REMAINETH OF IT…BURN WITH FIRE. If one was unable to eat one’s portion due to circumstances beyond one’s control. Yefet says that the reference is to the bones. However, Scripture only speaks of what is normal.305When people eat some meat and not only bones remain uneaten.

AND THUS SHALL YE EAT IT. The reference is only to the paschal lamb eaten in Egypt. However, those in Argalon306The reference is unclear. Some identify it with a place in Algeria (Weiser). do the same today in memory of the Exodus. These spiritual errants all leave their land on the fifteenth day in memory of the Exodus.

AND YOUR STAFF IN YOUR HAND. To lead the asses.307They did not leave on foot, as they were setting out on a long journey. Hence the staffs in their hands were not for walking. Compare, and he smote the ass with his staff (Num. 22:27).308Balaam was then riding an ass. Thus the staff in his hand was not a walking stick but rather a rod with which to guide the ass.

[IN HASTE.] Israel was not to delay.309Eating the paschal lamb. They were to hurry and eat the paschal lamb before the moment of destruction arrived,310When God would destroy the first-born of Egypt. when God would pass over their homes.311In other words, so that they could begin their departure from the land of Egypt immediately after being freed. They could not have done this if they had been busy eating the paschal lamb. God therefore commanded that the lamb be roasted in fire, because food that is roasted cooks quickly. The holy patriarchs312The rabbis of the Talmud. similarly said the paschal lamb may be eaten only until midnight and it may only be eaten roasted.313Zevachim 56a.

FOR I WILL GO THROUGH THE LAND OF EGYPT. God’s might and His power passed throughout the land. Hence it was as if God Himself went throughout the land.314In other words, I will go through the land is not to be taken literally. It means My might and power will go through the land.

AND AGAINST ALL THE GODS OF EGYPT I WILL EXECUTE JUDGMENTS. In the manner of Dagon was fallen upon his face to the ground (I Sam. 5:4). It is similarly written, upon their gods also the Lord executed judgments (Num. 33:4).

AND THE BLOOD SHALL BE TO YOU FOR A TOKEN. This315Blood. shall be for you a token so that your hearts will be strong and will not weaken as you hear the cries of the Egyptians when their first-born die via the destroyer. [AND WHEN I SEE THE BLOOD.] I will pass over you and there will be no plague among you because I will see the blood. The blood will be a sign to the destroyer.316Literally, on or concerning the destroyer.
AND THIS DAY SHALL BE UNTO YOU. It shall be a memorial for generations.

AND YE SHALL KEEP IT A FEAST. The reference is to the feast of Passover.317That is, the offering of the paschal lamb. Scripture says that it shall be kept a feast by an ordinance throughout your generations. However, it does not say that it is to be kept in all of your dwelling places, because this commandment is, as I will explain, contingent on dwelling in the Land of Israel.

SEVEN DAYS SHALL YE EAT UNLEAVENED BREAD. The reason for shall ye eat unleavened bread is to recall the matzot eaten when they left Egypt. They were not previously commanded to eat unleavened bread save for that which is to be eaten with the paschal lamb before midnight.318And they shall eat the flesh in that night, roast with fire, and unleavened bread; with bitter herbs…(v. 8). However, God now commanded that they eat unleavened bread for seven days319Throughout the generations. in memory of what happened to them when they left Egypt, as it is written there,320In the description of the Exodus. for it was not leavened (Ex. 12:39). Had the Egyptians permitted them to tarry a bit, they would have leavened their dough. They ate unleavened bread for seven days until Pharaoh was drowned on the seventh day. The heavenly cloud led them day and night and they did not tarry very long even when they camped.321They therefore had no time to bake leavened bread. It is similarly written when discussing the paschal lamb,322Which is to be eaten in all generations. seven days shalt thou eat unleavened bread therewith, even the bread of affliction (Deut. 16:3). Now according to its plain meaning, the text Seven days shall ye eat unleavened bread is stating an obligation.323Contra the Talmudic opinion that the obligation to eat unleavened bread is limited to the first night of Passover. See Pesachim 120a. Also see Rashi on this verse. That thou mayest remember the day when thou camest forth out of the land of Egypt all the days of thy life (Deut. 16:3) is proof of this.324Just as remembering the Exodus all the days is an obligation, so is eating matzot for seven days an obligation, since both are written in one verse. It is because of this325It is because Scripture connected the obligation to eat unleavened bread with the paschal lamb, which is only offered in the Land of Israel. that Scripture states, Ye shall eat nothing leavened; in all your habitations shall ye eat unleavened bread (Ex. 12:20), as the latter326Abstaining from leavened bread and eating unleavened bread. is an obligation within the Land of Israel and outside of the Land of Israel.

[HOWBEIT THE FIRST DAY YE SHALL PUT AWAY LEAVEN OUT OF YOUR HOUSES.] Now since Israel had a tradition of commencing the slaughter of the paschal lamb when the sun started going down towards the west, and it is written, Thou shalt not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread (Ex. 34:25), the rabbis of blessed memory interpreted the word ach (howbeit) to mean a part of.327Pesachim 5a. It is a general principle in Talmudic exegesis that ach and rak imply limitations. Thus ach divides the day, indicating that the putting away of the leaven is to take place in the middle of the day. According to the rabbis, ach ba-yom ha-rishon tashbitu se’or mi-batekhem (howbeit the first day ye shall put away leaven out of your houses) is to be rendered: At the middle of the day which is before the festival of unleavened bread ye shall put away leaven out of your houses. Mark the fact that ceasing an act is not an act. The meaning of And on the seventh day God finished (Gen. 2:2) is: when the seventh day started God had already finished his work.328See I.E. on Gen. 2:2. Similarly, the meaning of the first day ye shall put away leaven out of your houses is: when the first day starts, all leaven shall already have been removed from the houses. Now the first day starts at the end of the fourteenth day at even, as it is written, from the first day until the seventh day. The meaning of the phrase329Howbeit on the first day, etc. then is that the seven full days330Mentioned in the opening of our verse. are from the fourteenth day of the month at even, which is the end of the fourteenth day, until the twenty-first day at even. I will yet speak concerning this.
AND IN THE FIRST DAY. The day of the Exodus from Egypt.331The 15th of Nisan. The seventh day is, as I will explain, the day that the Egyptians drowned.

NO MANNER OF WORK. We do not find the phrase kol melakhah (no manner of work) stated with regard to any of the festivals,332In Lev. 23 and Num. 28 and 29 Scripture prohibits one from “working” on the festivals. The formula used is kol melekhet avodah lo ta’asu (ye shall do no manner of servile work). See Lev. 23:8, 21, 25, 35; 36. Also see Num. 28:18, 26, 29:1, 12, 35. with the exception of the Sabbath and the Day of Atonement.333Wherein Scripture employs the term lo ta’aseh kol melakhah (ye shall do no manner of work). See Ex. 20:10; Lev. 23:3, 28. Also see Num. 29:7. However, the phrase334Kol melakhah. is employed with regard to Passover335Only in our verse and nowhere else is Passover mentioned. with the proviso that that which every man must eat is permitted.336To be done. In all other places, be it Passover,337See Lev. 23:7; Num. 28:18. Sha’vu’ot,338See Lev. 23:21; Num. 28:26. the Day of Memorial,339Rosh Ha-Shanah. See Lev. 23.25; Num. 29:1. or the festival of Sukkot,340Lev. 23:35, 36; Num. 29:19, 35. Scripture employs the abridged form and states, ye shall do no manner of servile341Scripture employs the term kol melekhet avodah (no manner of servile work) and not kol melakhah (no manner of work) with regard to the festivals. Our text follows Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed editions read, kol melakhah. This is obviously a scribal error. work.342Cf. Lev. 23:3. So Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed text read: No work shall be done. It is I.E.’s contention that ye shall do no manner of servile work is short for: ye shall do no manner of work save that which every man may eat, as okhel nefesh (that which every man must eat) is not considered melekhet avodah (servile work). Only in one place343In our verse. with regard to Passover is it stated that you shall do no manner of work under the first stated conditions.344That is, if it is not for the purpose of preparing that which may be eaten.
AND YE SHALL OBSERVE. God here commanded that the matzot be watched345That is, the grain that the matzah is made of. from the time of the harvest.346Lest the grain be mixed with water and leaven.

[HAVE I BROUGHT.] Scripture reads, have I brought your hosts out of the land of Egypt although they had not yet left Egypt. This prophecy took place at the beginning of the month.347See verse 1. Hence they had not yet left Egypt. It meaning is: you will say this in all of your generations.348Scripture employs the perfect form because in the future people will speak of the past and say, on this selfsame day the Lord brought our hosts out of the land of Egypt.

IN THE FIRST. Scripture uses an abridged form since it had already stated, it shall be the first month of the year to you (v. 2). The meaning of in the first thus is, in the first month. In the tenth, on the first day of the month (Gen. 8:5)349Translated literally. is similar.350In the tenth is short for: in the tenth month.

LEAVEN. Se’or (leaven) refers to something which induces leavening. The substance is well known.351I.E. could find no Hebrew synonym for se’or. Scripture then goes on to say, for whosoever eateth anything which is leavened (machmetzet).352In other words, machmetzet refers to anything which is leavened. Scripture first prohibits keeping anything which induces leavening (se’or) in one’s home on Passover. It then prohibits eating on Passover anything which is leavened. Note that from the first day until the seventh day (v. 15) is not connected to what is adjacent, i.e., to shall be cut off353The second part of verse 15 literally reads: For whosoever eateth leavened bread that soul shall be cut off from Israel from the first day to the seventh day. I.E. argues that we should not read the verse in this manner; that is, from the first day, etc., does not follow shall be cut off. but rather is connected to354I.E. explains that we are to connect For whosoever eateth leavened bread to from the first day, etc., and read verse 15 as if written: For whosoever eateth leavened bread from the first day until the seventh day, that soul shall be cut off from Israel. for whosoever eateth leavened bread.355Literally, to the eating of that which is leavened. There is either an error in the text (Weiser, Filwarg) or, more likely, I.E. paraphrased. It is similar to of Solomon’s reign over Israel (I Kings 6:1).356See I.E. on verse 2 and note 58. Yefet says that some letters refer both to the word in which they are placed and to a word previously written, as in odem pitdah u-vareket (carnelian, topaz, and smaragd) (Ex. 28:17), which is to be interpreted as if written, odem u-pitdah u-vareket (carnelian, and topaz, and smaragd).357In other words, the vav (and) placed in front of vareket also governs pitdah. The same is true of mi-yom ha-rishon ad yom ha-shevi’i (from the first day until the seventh day).358The heh placed before ha-rishon also governs the word yom that precedes it. So too the heh placed before ha-shevi’i governs the word yom that precedes it. The verse is thus to be understood as if written: me-ha-yom ha-rishon ad ha-yom ha-shevi’i. Yefet comments thus for it is Hebrew style to place a heh in front of the noun when there is one in front of the adjective. Compare, ha-har ha-tov (that goodly hill country) (Deut. 3:25) (Filwarg). See also Vol. 1, p. 47, note 168.

[WHETHER HE BE A SOJOURNER.] Scripture already noted that whosoever eateth leavened bread from among the Israelites incurs the penalty of excision.359In verse 15. Scripture now adds a sojourner who is a sincere proselyte.360Hence it is not being redundant in repeating the prohibition of eating leaven on Passover and the punishment for doing so.

NOTHING LEAVENED. Scripture first mentions the punishment361For eating leaven on Passover in verse 19. and then the warning.362Not to do so in verse 20. In all your habitations shall ye eat unleavened bread is not optional as Six days shall work be done (Ex. 35:2) is. On the contrary, it is an obligation so that one will remember.363The Exodus.
AND MOSES CALLED FOR ALL THE ELDERS OF ISRAEL. So that they would tell the people.
AND TAKE YOU LAMBS. On the tenth day, as he was commanded by God.364Verse 3.

[AND KILL THE PASSOVER LAMB.] The grammarian365Jonah ibn Janach in his Sefer Ha-Shorashim.(Weiser). says that ve-shachatu (and kill) in and kill the passover lamb is a pi’el.366A pi’el imperative. Compare, dabberu, hallelu However, he spoke incorrectly. Ve-shachatu (shall kill it) in and the whole congregation of Israel shall kill it (v. 6) is a kal.367And so too in our verse. It368Shachatu in verse 6. is properly vocalized with a kamatz beneath the shin because of the silent missing letter.369That is because a kamatz (a silent missing letter) is always placed beneath the first letter in the kal perfect. I.E. refers to the kamatz as a silent missing letter because the kamatz vowel implies an alef. See I.E. on Ex. 2:4 and the notes thereto. However, ve-shachatu (and kill) in and kill the passover lamb is imperative in the kal. We do not find this root in the pi’el in any place in Scripture.370Hence shachatu in our verse cannot be a pi’el. The shin of ve-shachatu371In our verse. should have been vocalized with a chirik,372Because it is an imperative. as miskhu (draw)373Kal plural imperatives are vocalized with a chirik beneath their first letters. is. However, since the shin is followed by a guttural374A chet. it was vocalized with a pattach, as is Hebrew practice. Compare, bacharu (choose) in choose you (Josh. 24:15).375Which is vocalized bachaeru, not bicharu because a guttural, a chet, follows the bet. There are many other similar instances.376Compare, nahagu, sha’alu. The shin377In shachatu. is therefore vocalized with a long pattach in the imperative. Both words378Ve-shachatu (vocalized with a kamatz beneath the shin) in verse 6 and ve-shachatu (vocalized with a pattach beneath the shin) in our verse. are from the same conjugation.379They are both in the kal. However, shachatu in verse 6 is a perfect and shachatu in our verse is in the imperative.

AND YE SHALL TAKE. Moses now explains the manner in which the blood is to be taken and placed on the lintel.380In verse 7 they were told to take the blood and place it on the lintel. Moses now explains the details of the ritual. Hence verse 22 is not redundant.

[A BUNCH OF.] The word aguddat means a bunch (of). Compare, la-aggudah (band) in and became one band (II Sam. 2:25). Rabbi Merinus says that the alef in aguddah is appended,381Or superfluous. It is not a root letter and has no meaning, as the word could read gudah and mean the same. as aguddah comes from the same root as gedud (troop).382Gen. 49:19. Its root is gimel, dalet, dalet. Hence the alef is appended. Others say that the alef in aguddah is a root letter383Its root being alef, gimel, dalet. like the alef in afuddato (skillfully woven)384From the root alef, peh, dalet. Afuddato minus the pronominal suffix is afuddah. Thus aguddah follows the paradigm of afuddah. in and the skillfully woven band (Ex 28:6).

[HYSSOP.] Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that azov (hyssop) is a plant known in Arabic as zatr and in the vernacular as oregano. It is an herb distinguished by various kinds of flavors. However, this interpretation is incorrect, for Scripture states, even unto the hyssop that springeth out of the wall (I Kings 5:13).385The oregano plant does not grow out of walls. I do not know the identity of the azov. However, logically speaking it is not a very mighty plant for it is the opposite of the cedar mentioned in Scripture.386I Kings 5:13 reads: And he spoke of trees, from the cedar that is in Lebanon even unto the hyssop that springeth out of the wall.

[BASIN.] Some say that they slaughtered the paschal lamb in the threshold of the gate,387In a trench cut in the threshold (Krinsky). In other words, saf (basin) means a threshold. and they dipped the hyssop into it and then touched the side-posts with the blood. They say that the word saf (basin) is similar in meaning to the word saf (threshold) in and he measured the threshold (saf) of the gate (Ezek. 40:6)388New J.P.S. translation. and to sippim (thresholds)389Sippim is the plural of saf. in and the posts of the thresholds moved (Is. 6:4).390Translated according to I.E. Others say that saf (basin) is similar to sappot (basins) in brought beds, and basins (II Sam. 17:28) and that saf is a vessel over which they slaughtered the paschal lamb.
[UNTIL THE MORNING.] I will yet explain what this means.391See I.E.’s comments on verse 31.

AND WILL NOT SUFFER. He will not suffer the destroyer. Yitten (will suffer)392The word yitten literally means, will give. At times it has the meaning of will give permission. Rashi similarly interprets, “He will not give him the power to come” into your homes. here is similar in meaning to netatikha (suffered I thee) in Therefore suffered I thee not (Gen. 20:6). Now, the destroyer is under God’s power. If God allows him to come into their homes it is as if He gave him permission to do so.

AND YE SHALL OBSERVE THIS THING. Many are of the opinion that the placing of the blood on the lintel and on the two side-posts is an obligation for all generations because this thing393That is, And ye shall observe this thing for an ordinance to thee and to thy sons for ever. is connected to394It immediately follows. the taking of the hyssop and dipping it into the lamb’s blood. Furthermore, Scripture afterwards states, for that he passed over the houses of the children of Israel in Egypt (v. 27).395This is to be offered in response to the question, “What mean ye by this service? which will be asked by children in future generations (v. 26). Prima facie, the question pertains to the placing of the blood on the lintels and on the side-posts. This interpretation would be correct from a logical point of view were it not for the true tradition which states otherwise.396That the placing of the blood on the side-posts and lintels was only to be done in Egypt. The correct interpretation is that this thing397What mean ye by this service? See note 395. refers to and kill the passover lamb.398In verse 21, and not to the taking of the hyssop and dipping it into the lamb’s blood. The meaning of the children’s question is,399Verse 26. when your children will see their family in a group eating an entire lamb, whose bones one is prohibited to break, with its head, with its legs, and with the inwards thereof, unlike the custom on all other festivals, and from which a gentile, an uncircumcised one, a sojourner, and a hired servant may not eat, they will question you.400In other words, the children’s question does not pertain to the smearing of the blood on the lintel and side-posts but to the manner in which the Passover sacrifice is eaten.

AND IT SHALL COME TO PASS. Moses now explains that the slaughter of the paschal lamb is contingent upon dwelling in the Land of Israel. Do not be troubled by the Passover observed by Israelites at Mount Sinai.401Which was celebrated outside the boundaries of the Land of Israel. See Num. 9:1-5. That was a commandment from on high.402To observe that particular Passover outside of Israel (Num. 9:5). Otherwise Israel would not have offered the paschal sacrifice. They did not observe another Passover in the desert. At Mount Sinai they were in an inhabited land and were thus able to find unleavened bread. However, when they were in a land that no man passed through403Jeremiah’s description of the wilderness in which Israel journeyed on the way to the promised land (Jer. 2:6). I.E. borrows Jeremiah’s description because he wants to emphasize that Israel had no one to buy wheat from to bake matzot. Hence the only Passover they could have celebrated was the one at Sinai. they only had manna.
AND IT SHALL COME TO PASS…WHAT MEAN YE BY THIS SERVICE. The strange ritual that I noted.404See I.E.’s final comments on verse 24.

THAT YE SHALL SAY: IT IS THE SACRIFICE OF THE LORD’S PASSOVER. The word pesach (passover) is to be rendered pity, as we find, paso’ach ve-himlit (He will pity it and He will rescue it) (Is. 31:5).405Translated according to I.E. The lamb is termed pesach (passover), as in and kill the passover (pesach) (v. 21), because God had pity on the first-born of Israel because of the blood of the lamb. However, Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that the word pesach is derived from the word pi’se’ach (limp), since a lame person supports himself on his healthy leg.406And hops or skips along. Hence a lame person is called a pise’ach, a hopper or skipper. The destroyer acted in a similar manner. He exterminated the first-born in the Egyptian home and passed over407Or hopped or skipped over. the home of his Hebrew neighbor and did not destroy him. The term posechim (hopping) in How long will you keep hopping between two opinions (I Kings 18:20)408So J.P.S. new translation. is similar.
AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL WENT AND DID SO. They took a lamb on the tenth day of the month. They did as the Lord had commanded Moses and Aaron: This is the ordinance of the passover (v. 43).
AND IT CAME TO PASS AT MIDNIGHT. The reference is to the second half of the night.409See I.E. on Ex. 11:4. This comment is not found in Vat. Ebr. 38.

[UNTO THE FIRST-BORN OF THE CAPTIVE THAT WAS IN THE DUNGEON.] Yefet says that the captives who grind the millstone in prison during the day are put at night into a pit whose opening is covered with the millstone.410That they ground with during the day. The literal meaning of bor (dungeon) is pit. Hence Yefet’s interpretation. This is the meaning of behind the mill (Ex. 11:5).411There is thus no contradiction between our verse and Ex. 11:5.
AND PHARAOH ROSE UP. He himself. But the Levites alone shall do the service (Num. 18:23), meaning the Levite himself, is similar.
FOR THERE WAS NOT A HOUSE WHERE THERE WAS NOT ONE DEAD. Scripture speaks of the majority of houses.412For there must have been many houses in which there was no first-born male (Weiser).

AND HE CALLED. Logically speaking Moses and Aaron were not in the land of Rameses with the Israelites on the night of the fifteenth. On the contrary, they were in that part of Egypt in which was the royal seat where Pharaoh lived.413Awaiting Pharaoh’s permission to leave Egypt. Nahmanides interprets similarly. Now Moses and Aaron left the doors of their homes at midnight414Pharaoh called for them after the first-born had been slain. in accordance with God’s dictate.415Otherwise they would not have been permitted to leave their homes. See verse 22. Hence I. E. assumes that God told Moses and Aaron to leave their dwellings in response to Pharaoh’s call. I.E.’s interpretation is contra the Mekhilta, which pictures Moses and Aaron as staying in their homes until the morning and Pharaoh going around the land of Egypt asking, “Where does Moses dwell? Where does Aaron dwell?” According to the Mekhilta, when Pharaoh found Moses and Aaron he said to them, “Rise up, get you forth,” etc. Moses responded, “We are warned not to go out except in broad daylight as it is written, And none of you shall go out of the door of his house until the morning” (v. 22). After Pharaoh gave the Israelites permission to go and worship God, Moses went with the servants of Pharaoh to Rameses to bring Israel out of Egypt. It is common knowledge in our time that there are six Persian miles416A Persian mile is, 8000 cubits, or approximately 2 1/2 miles. between ancient Egypt, where Joseph’s treasures are known to be until this very day, and Rameses. Now the Israelites began to leave Egypt in the morning,417They were not allowed to leave their homes till this time (v. 22). namely, at the break of dawn when the light of the sun is seen in the clouds. There is a full hour and a third between the moment that dawn breaks and sunrise. We find that it can be very dark and still be morning. Thus Scripture states, And she418Ruth. lay down at his feet419Boaz’s feet. till the morning (Ruth 3:14), and then adds, before one could discern another.420We thus see that when morning begins people still cannot recognize each other because it is yet dark. Now some Israelites exited Egypt at the break of dawn when, from the Torah’s standpoint, it is still night until sunrise.421According to I.E. when the Torah speaks of day it means after sunrise. This group was close to Egypt. Another group who were further from Egypt exited that very day.422That is, after sunrise. The Israelites constituted a very large congregation.423That is why it took so long for all of them to leave. It is more than eight Persian miles from one end of Rameses to another.424Those Israelites who lived in that part of Rameses that was close to Egypt left at dawn and the others after sunrise. Scripture therefore states in one place, the Lord thy God brought thee forth out of Egypt by night425The reference is to those who left at the break of dawn. (Deut. 16:1), and elsewhere reads, This day ye go forth426The reference is to those who left after sunrise. (Ex. 13:4). It is further stated, the children of Israel went out with a high hand in the sight of all the Egyptians (Num. 33:3),427This too refers to those who left after sunrise. and it is there recorded, while the Egyptians were burying them that the Lord had smitten. Now the Egyptians buried their dead during the day. I have thus explained the meaning of morning.428As he promised to do at the end of verse 22. I.E. literally reads, I have already explained.
BOTH YE…AS YE HAVE SAID. Our cattle also shall go with us (Ex. 10:26).
[AND BLESS ME ALSO.] Pharaoh asked them to bless him and pray for him.429So too Mekhilta, Onkelos, Rashi, and Nahmanides.

[ALSO.] Scripture reads also because Pharaoh, as Moses had foretold,430See Ex. 10:25. The meaning of our verse is: take your flocks and go but also pray for me over the sacrifices which I now give you. gave them sacrifices.

WERE URGENT. Va-techezak (were urgent) is in the feminine,431However, mitzrayim (Egypt) is a masculine form. Scripture thus should have read, va-yechezak. because the state of Egypt includes everything.432Mitzrayim is short for medinat mitzrayim (the state of Egypt). Medinah is feminine, hence the reading va-techezak (Krinsky).
[WE ARE ALL DEAD.] I have explained its meaning in my comments on lest he fall upon us with pestilence (Ex. 5:3).

THEIR KNEADING-TROUGHS. Misheret (kneading-trough) is a wooden vessel. Compare, mishartekha (thy kneading-trough) in thy basket and thy kneading-trough (Deut. 28:5). Their asses were laden with garments which they asked of the Egyptians.433Hence they had to carry their kneading-troughs on their shoulders.

AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL DID. Each one asked in accordance with his status. Thus we find that only the princes donated precious stones, spices, and oil for the work of the tabernacle (Ex. 35:27, 28).434The other Israelites did not have these precious items. They did not ask the Egyptians for these items because their status did not allow them to do so.

AND THEY DESPOILED. We do not find the root nun, tzadi, lamed 435Which is the root of va-yenatzelu (and they despoiled). I.E. literally reads: we do not find the root of hatzalah in the kal. in the kal. We find it only in the hifil and the pi’el. They436Verbs formed from this root in the kal and the hifil. are both transitive verbs because there is no difference in meaning between va-yenatzelu (and they despoiled)437A pi’el. and va-yatzel (hath taken away)438A hifil from the root nun, tzadi, lamed. in Thus God hath taken away (Gen. 31:9) except that in the hifil the object439Which is being taken way is mentioned, as in Thus God has taken away (va-yatzel) the cattle. is mentioned and in the pi’el it is omitted.440As in our verse. Scripture states, And they despoiled (va-yenatzelu) the Egyptians. However, it does not say what they took.

AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL JOURNEYED. The samekh in the word va-yisu (journeyed)441From the root nun, samekh, ayin. should have received a dagesh to compensate for the missing nun,442There is no nun in va-yisu. A missing first root letter is compensated for by placing a dagesh in the second stem letter. as the gimel in va-yiggeshu (and drew near)443From the root nun, gimel, shin. In va-yiggeshu the nun drops out and is compensated for by a dagesh in the gimel. (Gen. 44:18) and the tav in va-yittenu (and they gave)444From the root nun, tav, nun. (Gen. 35:4) do. It is possible that the dagesh was omitted to simplify enunciation.

FROM RAMESES. Rameses is vocalized with a pattach beneath the resh and a sheva beneath the ayin. It is not a city445That is the city of Raamses (Ex. 1:12) which the Israelites built. Both words have the same consonants. However, they differ in vocalization. See I.E. on Ex. 1:11 and Gen. 47:11. but rather the name of a district.446That is, the name of the district where Israel dwelt. See I.E. on Ex. 1:11.
TO SUCCOTH. Sukkotah means: to Succoth.447The heh at the end of the word is like a lamed at the beginning of a word; i.e., it means to.
[MEN.] Scripture mentions men. There was no need to mention the women because there were as many women as there were men, maybe even more.448Since some of the men had more than one wife.
BESIDE CHILDREN. Taf (children) refers to those under the age of twenty.449As clearly implied in Num. 14:29, 31.

AND A MIXED MULTITUDE. Of Egyptians who intermingled with them. They are the asafsuf (mixed multitude) who joined them.450See Num. 11:4. I.E.’s point is that the asafsuf mentioned in Numbers is to be identified with the mixed multitude mentioned in our verse.

AND THEY BAKED. The dough which they brought out of Egypt had leaven in it.451Scriptures implies that the bread did not leaven because there was no time for it to do so. The implication is that if there had been time for it to rise it would have done so. Hence we may assume that it had leaven (yeast) in it. They did not bake it452The matzot. until they camped in Succoth.453Their first stop after leaving Rameses (v. 37).

NOW THE TIME THAT THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL DWELT IN EGYPT WAS FOUR HUNDRED AND THIRTY YEARS. There are many calculations454Of years. in Scripture whose point of departure is unknown to us. I will now mention a few of them. And it came to pass at the end of forty years, that Absalom said unto the king (II Sam. 15:7). Now Absalom was not then forty years old.455David reigned for 40 years (I Kings 2:11). Absalom was born after David was crowned king in Hebron (II Sam. 3:2) and predeceased David (II Sam. 18:14). Thus Absalom’s entire life span was less than 40 years. Hence the number 40 cannot apply to the years that passed from Absalom’s birth. Furthermore, King David’s reign was not yet over.456David reigned for 40 years. However, since his reign was not yet over, the number 40 cannot apply to it. The commentaries tell us that the point of departure for this calculation is from the day that the ark abode in Kiriath-jearim (I Sam. 7:2). It is stated, Now it came to pass in the thirtieth year (Ezek. 1:1). Some say that Ezekiel was thirty years old when he began to prophesy.457In other words, the thirtieth year refers to the thirtieth year of Ezekiel’s life. Others say that the reference is to the thirtieth year of the jubilee.458So Rashi and Kimchi. Other say that its point of departure is the finding of the Torah which was discovered by Hilkiah the priest.459See II Kings 22. This is the opinion of Seder Olam 26 and Targum Jonathan. However, I am uncertain, for they are opinions without foundation or support. It is written: And within threescore and five years shall Ephraim460Another name for the kingdom of Samaria. be broken, that it be not a people (Is. 7:8). The latter prophesy was uttered during the days of Ahaz, whose reign lasted for sixteen years. Samaria was exiled in the sixth year of his son Hezekiah’s reign.461Thus at most 22 years could have passed between Isaiah’s prophecy and the exile of Ephraim/Samaria. What then did Isaiah mean by saying that at the end of 65 years Ephraim shall cease to be a people? The commentaries were therefore forced to say that the sixty-five years start from the day that Amos prophesied, And Israel shall surely be led away captive out of his land (Amos 7:11). Others say that its point of departure is the earthquake.462See Amos 1:1. Now when we investigated the years starting with the time that Israel came to Egypt in the days of Joseph and his brothers we found that they do not come to the number of years spoken of in Scripture.463430 years. There is no doubt that Kehat464Son of Levi. was among those who descended to Egypt.465Scripture explicitly says so. See Gen. 46:11. Let us imagine that Kehat466Who lived 133 years. See Ex. 6:18. begot his son Amram at the end of his life and that Amram467Who lived 137 years. See Ex. 6:20. similarly begot Moses at the end of his life. Now the years of Kehat and Amram’s lives come to two hundred and seventy. Moses was eighty years old when the Israelites went out of Egypt.468Ex. 7:7. It all thus comes to three hundred and fifty years. We are missing eighty years. It is for this reason that the elders469The 70 elders who translated the Torah into Greek. added, “dwelt in Egypt and other countries.”470See Megillah 9a. The four hundred years in and shall serve them; and they shall afflict them four hundred years (Gen. 15:13) is not connected to and they shall afflict them471Israel was not enslaved for 400 years. but rather to thy seed shall be a stranger (Ibid.).472The verse should be understood as follows: Thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs for four hundred years, part of which time they shall serve them and afflict them. There are many other such instances.473When a clause is not connected to what immediately precedes it. We similarly find in our own chapter, from the first day until the seventh day (v. 15).474Which is not connected to what immediately precedes it. See I.E. on verse 19 and notes 353 and 354. Now we find it stated that God told Abraham at the covenant made “between the pieces,”475Hebrew, brit ben ha-betarim. See Gen. 15. that thy seed shall be a stranger…four hundred years. We know that the number of years that Israel dwelt in Egypt476Mentioned in our verse. is contingent upon the “end,”477The end of 400 years of being strangers. which was told to Abraham.478In Gen. 15:13. The author of the Seder Olam479Rabbi Jose bar Chalafta, a second-century Tanna. was compelled to say that after Abraham came to the land of Canaan he returned to Haran.480In order to reconcile the number 430 given in our verse with the number 400 given in Genesis Seder Olam explains that the number 430 refers to the time that passed from the “covenant between the pieces” (Gen. 15), and the number 400 refers to the time from the birth of Isaac. The accounting is as follows: Abraham was 70 years old when God made the “covenant between the pieces” with him and told him that his children would be strangers for 400 years (Gen. 15:13). Abraham then went to Haran and spent five years there, as it is written, And Abraham was seventy and five years old when he departed out of Haran (Gen. 12:4). Now Isaac was born when Abraham was 100 years old (Gen. 21:5). Abraham thus lived in Canaan for 30 years without a son. Exodus, as noted above, starts the count from the “covenant between the pieces.” Genesis starts the count with the birth of Isaac 30 years later. However, it must be pointed out that the Seder Olam’s accounting is based on a number of assumptions: a) That the covenant between the pieces occurred when Abraham was 70 years old. Scripture nowhere says so. b) That Abraham returned to Haran. Scripture does not say this either. Hence I.E. did not want to accept the Seder Olam’s calculations. The question thus remains how to reconcile the number of years mentioned in Exodus with those given in Genesis. The commentaries were forced to say that the prophecy I am the Lord that brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldees (Gen. 15:7) is not connected to the above-noted chapter481Chapter 15, the “covenant between the pieces,” as Abraham was yet to leave the land. but was said later.482After he returned to Canaan and permanently settled there. This too is not in keeping with the plain meaning of the text and is an argument against the Seder Olam. However, there is no need for all of this.483a) To assume in contradiction to Gen. 15:5 that Abraham was 70 at the “covenant between the pieces”; b) to assume that Abraham returned to Haran; c) to assume that Gen. 15:7 is out of place and was not said at the “covenant between the pieces.” Only the counting of the four hundred years is from the day that Isaac was born.484As explained by the Seder Olam, for Scripture speaks there of thy seed. The additional thirty years start from the day that Abraham left Ur of the Chaldees, the land of his nativity, and came with his father to Haran, as it is written, and they came unto Haran, and dwelt there (Gen. 11: 31). Abraham lived in Haran with his father for five years.485If the 430 years start from the day that Abraham left Ur then Abraham had to be 70 years old when he left that city, for Isaac was born when Abraham was 100 years old and Israel was liberated 400 years later (see note 480). Now Scripture tells us that Abraham left Haran when he was 75 (Gen. 12:4). Therefore he spent five years in Haran. In his commentary on Genesis, I.E. implies that we cannot ascertain how many years Abraham spent in Haran. See I.E. on Gen. 12:1 and the notes thereto. He came to the land of Canaan at the age of seventy-five and never returned to Haran. Now thirty years passed from the time that Abraham left Haran till the day Isaac was born. Abraham was the important one,486Hence the calculations in our verse begin with him. and to him was the land of the Canaanite given. The verse I am the Lord that brought thee out of Ur of the Chaldees (Gen. 15:7) is connected to the entire chapter preceding487Literally, above. and following it.488Literally, below. In other words, the words in the verse were said to Abraham at the “covenant of the pieces.” The meaning of Now the time that the children of Israel dwelt in Egypt is to be explained: they were strangers there, also their fathers were strangers, as it is written, Yea, very few, and sojourners in it (Ps. 105:12); and as Abraham said, I am a stranger and a sojourner with you (Gen. 23:4).
FOUR HUNDRED AND THIRTY YEARS. From the day that their father Abraham left the land of his birth.

[AND IT CAME TO PASS AT THE END OF FOUR HUNDRED AND THIRTY YEARS.] Scripture states this so that it be known that they did not exit Egypt because of their cries to God until the time489430 years starting from the day that Abraham left Ur Chasdim. that the Lord had decreed for them had come.490Their crying reminded God that the period He ordained for their being strangers was over. Had they not cried out unto the Lord, the period of their servitude would not have ended, because according to the arrangement of the stars they were destined to remain in servitude for a much longer time. See I.E. on Ex. 2:23, 24 and 33:21 (Weiser).

IT WAS A NIGHT OF WATCHING UNTO THE LORD. Since Scripture notes, it was a night of watching unto the Lord, and concludes by saying, this same night is a night of watching unto the Lord for all the children of Israel throughout their generations, the plain meaning of our verse appears to be: since God watched them and did not suffer the destroyer to come into their homes to plague them,491I.E.’s paraphrase of It was a night of watching unto the Lord. the Lord commanded that this night be a night of watching492That is, observance. The Hebrew shamar means both watch and observe. Since God watched (shamar) Israel on this night, Israel must observe (li-shemor) God’s special laws this night. Hence lel shimurim (a night of watching) means a night of observance.for all the children of Israel throughout their generations through the eating of the paschal lamb according to its ordinance and the ingesting of unleavened bread and bitter herbs on this night. Others say that watching here has the same meaning as the word watching in The watchers of the walls (Cant. 5:7); its meaning is that they should not sleep on this night but should praise God and relate the might that the Lord displayed when they went out of Egypt.493According to this interpretation lel shimurim means a watch night.
