Our sages hinted at the latter meaning when they said, The time for the reading of the morning shema has arrived.494This implies that the sages stayed up all night on the night of the seder. See Passover Haggadah. Also see Tosefta Pesachim 10.

AND THE LORD SAID…THIS IS THE ORDINANCE OF THE PASSOVER. Since Scripture mentioned that it was a night of watching (v. 42), the reference being to the night of the fifteenth wherein the paschal lamb is to be eaten, the Torah completes its explanation of the laws of the Passover495In verses 43-50. that is to be observed in future generations. Now Scripture does not mention the lintel and the side-post. Neither does it mention that the lamb is to be eaten with unleavened bread and bitter herbs,496In verses 43-50. as they were previously mentioned with regard to the Passover observed in Egypt. Its meaning497The meaning of This is the ordinance of the passover. thus is: you shall eat the Passover offering in the future as you ate it in Egypt. Scripture then added other commandments.498The purpose of this chapter was to give additional rules concerning the Passover. However, the commandments with regard to the lintel and the side-post have nothing to do with the eating of the paschal lamb.499Hence unlike the eating of unleavened bread and bitter herbs it does not have to be observed in future Passovers. Do you not see that at the beginning of the chapter (i.e., v. 43) it states, there shall no alien eat thereof (bo)?500Which is a law not previously mentioned. We thus see that the purpose of this chapter was to give additional rules concerning the Passover. The meaning of bo (thereof) is, of it.501The word bo usually means in him or in it. Its usage in this context is correct in Hebrew502It is proper Hebrew to say, lo yokhal bo (he shall not eat of it), although from a very literal point of view it means he shall not eat in it. and also in Arabic.503A similar term is used in Arabic. Ve-hanotar ba-basar u-va-lechem (and that which remaineth of the flesh and of the bread) (Lev. 8:32) is similar.504Here too the bet means “of.” Ba-basar literally means in the meat and ba-lechem in the bread. However, in Lev. 8:32 ba-basar u-va-lechem are to be rendered of the flesh and of the bread.

BUT EVERY MAN’S SERVANT…WHEN THOU HAST CIRCUMCISED HIM. According to his wish, that he be converted to the law of Israel, if he is of the age when one is obligated to observe the commandments.505The age of thirteen. The law dealing with someone that is bought for money and someone born in the house is the same.506The two are usually coupled together. See Gen. 17:12, 13; Lev. 22:11. However, Scripture deals with that which is more prevalent.507Hence only someone that is bought for money is mentioned here

A SOJOURNER AND A HIRED SERVANT. Who are Israelites508Contra the rabbis who interpreted the verse as applying to non-Jews. Cf. Mekhilta 15, Rashi, and Nahmanides. shall not eat of the paschal lamb if a portion of the lamb has not been assigned to them, as is the law for the entire congregation.

IN ONE HOUSE SHALL IT BE EATEN. As the paschal lamb eaten in Egypt was. Thou shalt not carry forth aught of the flesh abroad out of the house is proof of this.509Carry forth aught implies that house is to be taken literally (Krinsky). However, our sages of blessed memory said that in one house means in one company.510See Mekhilta 15, Onkelos, and Rashi. The latter is the correct interpretation.

ALL THE CONGREGATION OF ISRAEL SHALL KEEP IT. All those of the age when one is obligated to observe the commandments are required to prepare a paschal lamb. When I researched the Torah, I found that the twenty-three times where karet (excision) is stated511It should be noted that according to the Mishnah in Kritot 1:1, the Torah prescribes excision for 36 transgressions. The discrepancy is explained by Krinsky. refer to negative precepts. However, I found only two dealing with positive precepts, namely, the paschal lamb512The question thus arises, why is such a harsh penalty inflicted upon one who violates the positive commandment of offering a paschal lamb? and circumcision.513Gen. 17:14. Perhaps the reason for this is that there is an obligation to “remember” the Exodus from Egypt, and there is no greater manifestation of “remembering” than eating the paschal lamb in its proper time. And the beginning of the decalogue states, I am the Lord thy God, who brought thee out of the land of Egypt (Ex. 20:2).514Hence remembering the Exodus is a very important commandment, and by not offering the paschal lamb one is in effect denying the Exodus.
AND WHEN A STRANGER SHALL SOJOURN WITH THEE. The meaning of with thee is, with thee in the land of Egypt.515As a mixed multitude joined Israel.
[AND WILL KEEP THE PASSOVER.] Its meaning is, and he wants to keep the Passover. Then let him first be circumcised.

[BUT NO UNCIRCUMCISED PERSON SHALL EAT THERE-OF.] The reference is to uncircumcised Israelites516Not to sinners. such as those born on the way in the wilderness.517Who because of the danger involved could not be circumcised. See Josh. 5:5, 7.

ONE LAW. The stranger spoken of in this verse refers to a righteous proselyte, not to a stranger that dwells within the gates.518And does not accept Judaism. Such a stranger who is uncircumcised cannot eat of the paschal lamb, and the statement in verse 49 (one law, etc.) which deals with the eating of the Passover offering cannot apply to him.

[THUS DID ALL THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] Scripture has already mentioned this above.519Verse 28. Perhaps the reason it is noted again is that it refers to the Passover offering brought in the wilderness of Sinai,520Num. 9:5. at which time the strangers were circumcised.521In other words, thus did all the children of Israel does not repeat what is stated in verse 28, but refers to the circumcision of the strangers (gerim). It was a convenient place to circumcise those strangers who were not circumcised in Egypt. Do not be surprised that this is written in this place.522When it happened a year later. Scripture states in the chapter dealing with the coming down of the manna that they should take a jar and put manna therein and place it before the Lord (Ex. 16:33). However, God had not yet commanded the making of the ark of the testimony.523Recorded in Ex. 25:10-14. Thus Ex. 16:33 is chronologically out of place. Have I brought your hosts out of the land of Egypt (v. 17) is similar.524It is chronologically out of place because when this was said Israel was still in Egypt. See I.E. on verse 17.

AND IT CAME TO PASS THE SELFSAME DAY. I believe that this verse is connected to the verse which follows,525Ex. 13:1, 2. in which God told Moses to sanctify the first-born. The plague of the first-born took place at midnight, and when Israel went out of Egypt the next day God immediately commanded that the first-born of Israel and the first-born of their cattle be sanctified.526Ex. 12:51 and what comes next should be understood as follows: And it came to pass the selfsame day that the Lord did bring the children of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their hosts, that the Lord spoke unto Moses saying: Sanctify unto Me all the first-born, etc.

AND THE LORD SPOKE. Scripture employs a short form,1Scripture should have followed up our verse with: speak unto the children of Israel and say unto them as in Num. 6:1,2. As things stand, it is nowhere stated in our chapter that Moses told or was commanded to relate the contents of verse 1 to the Israelites. for Moses stands in place of Israel.2Hence And the Lord spoke unto Moses is the same as saying, the Lord spoke unto Israel; i.e., the contents of this chapter pertained to Israel. However, Yefet says that Moses was commanded to verbally sanctify all first-born.3According to Yefet this command was only for Moses. Moses personally was to declare all first-born holy. The aforementioned is the reverse of then the priest shall defile him (Lev. 13:8);4Translated literally. J.P.S. renders, then the priest shall pronounce him unclean. Both Moses and the priests perform their actions verbally. What I.E. means by the term “reverse” is that one makes someone unclean while the other makes one holy. the priest, being holy, defiles an individual by declaration.5And not in any other way. The verse can be taken to mean that the priest shall place an unclean object upon the subject in order to make him unclean, hence I.E.’s comment.

OPENETH. Peter (openeth) means the opening of. Peter is similar to peture (open) in and open flowers (I Kings 6:18). Its meaning is, the son who first opens the womb.6Peter kol rechem literally means the opening of the womb, hence I.E.’s comment. The word rechem (womb) is irregular, as according to the rules of Hebrew grammar the letter preceding a guttural is vocalized with a pattach.7Rather than a segol in penultimately accented nouns. Compare, nachal (river), lahav (flame), and na’ar (youth) (Weiser). Hence our word should have been vocalized racham rather than rechem. Cf. Jud. 5:30.

AND MOSES SAID. Remember this day was said by Moses on the fifteenth day.8Of Nisan, the day that they actually left Egypt. The Hebrew literally reads: on the day (ba-yom) of the 15th day (yom) he said remember. Filwarg correctly points out that the second yom is a scribal error and should be deleted. It means the same as And this day shall be unto you for a memorial (Ex. 12:14).

[OUT OF THE HOUSE OF BONDAGE.] This indicates that the Egyptians forced them to work as if they were their slaves.9Hence Scripture speaks of the place/house of bondage. However, the Israelites were not true slaves. They were a separate nation. They lived in their own houses, not in the homes of their masters; they had a family life and a culture. I.E. apparently comments thus so that people would not think of the ancient Israelites in the same way that they thought of contemporary slaves, i.e., as mean people. Cf. Aristotle’s Politics, 1:5, “From the hour of their birth, some are marked out for subjection, others for rule…Clearly there are some who are by nature free, others are by nature slaves, and for the latter their condition of servitude is both advantageous and just.” Elsewhere Scripture reads, out of the iron furnace (Deut. 4:20), for the Egyptians overpowered them.10And forced them to work as if they were the slaves, of the Egyptians. However, the Lord brought them out by strength of hand from the mighty.

THIS DAY. Moses first mentions, there shall be no leavened bread eaten, its meaning being, do in future generations what you did on the day that you left Egypt.11Eat no leaven on that day. As you left Egypt at the time when the first ears (aviv) are found,12Verse 4 reads, ha-yom attem yotze’im be-chodesh ha-aviv (This day ye go forth in the month Abib). I.E. interprets this verse to mean: This day ye go forth in the month of fresh ears. so shall you do yearly in the future in the Land of Israel when the first ears come. The first ears refers to the first ears of barley. The word aviv (Abib) means the first that ripens.13The barley ripens first. Aviv comes from the same root as av (father), which means first to the one whom one begets, or sage14A sage is called an av. Cf. Jud. 17:10, Dwell with me, and be unto me a father (av) and a priest; and Pirke Avot (Ethics of the Fathers/Sages). to the student whom one teaches.15In this case av means first in wisdom. Furthermore, it is written, for the barley was in the ear (aviv) (Ex. 9:31).16Which shows that aviv refers to ears of barley. Even of the first-fruits (bikkure) of wheat harvest (Ex. 34:22),17The Torah refers to the first ears of the wheat harvest as bikkurim, not avivim, for aviv refers to the first barley ears, which ripen about two months before the wheat does. which is written with regard to the festival of weeks,18Which falls seven weeks after Passover. is proof of the above.19That aviv means first.

AND IT SHALL BE. Scripture does not list all of the seven Canaanite nations because they have already been mentioned elsewhere.20They are listed in Gen. 15:19-21 and there is no need to repeat all of them here.
THE SEVEN DAYS. This is the service.21Spoken of in verse 5.

UNLEAVENED BREAD. Now the stranger that is within the gate was exhorted by God to observe the Sabbath,22Ex. 20:10. as it is only on the condition that he do no work before the Lord on the Sabbath that he may dwell within the gates. Similarly on the Day of Atonement, for it is so written.23The Day of Atonement is called a sabbath of solemn rest (Lev. 23:32). The same applies to Passover, as a stranger is not permitted to eat leaven even on his own property. This is the meaning of in all thy borders.

IT IS BECAUSE OF THAT. Rabbi Merinus says that ba’avur zeh (it is because of that) should have been written, zeh ba’avur; i.e., this is because of what the Lord did for me.24Our verse literally reads: And thou shalt tell thy son in that day saying, because of this (ba’avur zeh) the Lord did for me when I came forth out of Egypt. Rabbi Merinus could find no sense in this. Prima facie, “because of this” refers to the eating of matzah. What meaning is there in: because of the eating of the matzah, the Lord did for me when I came forth out of Egypt? He thus interprets our verse to mean: It is because of that (zeh ba’avur) which the Lord did for me when I came out of Egypt that I eat matzah and abstain from leaven. He cited what in his opinion are many other such instances.25Where the word order has to be inverted. See Sefer Ha-Rikmah, chap. 28. However, I do not think that he was right in even one instance. For how can we invert the words of the living God? The meaning of the verse is just the opposite of what he understands it to be, because we do not eat unleavened bread “because of this.”26In other words, ba’avur zeh is not to be interpreted as a reason for the eating of the matzah and abstaining from leaven. Its meaning rather is: it is because of this, i.e., it is because of this service, namely, the eating of unleavened bread and the abstention from leavened bread, which are the first of the precepts that God commanded us, that the Lord did signs for us and brought us out of Egypt.27Our verse is to be understood thus: And thou shalt tell thy son in that day saying: It is because we should observe this (and other) precept(s) the Lord did signs for me when I went out of Egypt. So too Rashi. Its meaning thus is: God took us out of Egypt only to serve Him, as it is written, when thou hast brought forth the people out of Egypt, ye shall serve God upon this mountain (Ex. 20:12). It is furthermore stated, I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, to be your God:28That is, so that you will serve me. I am the Lord your God (Num. 15:41).

AND IT SHALL BE A SIGN UNTO THEE. There are those who oppose our holy patriarchs29Who interpret our verse literally and say that for a sign unto thee upon thy hand, and for a memorial between thy eyes refers to the phylacteries placed upon the hand and head. and say30Those who oppose the rabbis. I.E. reads, she-amar. This is obviously a scribal error. The correct reading is, she-ameru. that for a sign…and for a memorial is to be understood in the manner of For they shall be a chaplet of grace unto thy head, And chains about thy head (Prov. 1:9).31Which is not to be taken literally, for it refers to the teachings of one’s father and mother (Prov. 1:8). Similarly with our verse (see note 20). It is worthy of note that this interpretation is found in Rashbam, who notes that from a literal point of view our verse is to be taken metaphorically: that is, a person should recall the Exodus as if it were written upon his hand and adorned his head as a jewel. They also say that And thou shalt bind them for a sign upon thy hand (Deut. 5:8) is like Bind them continually upon thy heart, Tie them upon thy neck (Prov. 6:21)32Which is not to be taken literally. and also that And thou shalt write them upon the door-posts of thy house (Deut. 6:9) is like Write them upon the table of thy heart (Prov. 3:3). They furthermore say that it shall be for a sign…and for a memorial means for with a strong hand hath the Lord brought thee out of Egypt shall drop from your lips.33Its knowledge shall be second nature, so that you can recall it and speak of it at the drop of a hat. However, this is incorrect, for at the beginning of the book of Proverbs it is stated, The Proverbs of Solomon. Thus whatever Solomon henceforth mentions is by way of parable. However, it is not, heaven forbid, written in the Torah that it is metaphoric. Hence it is to be taken only at face value. We thus will not interpret it except literally. It does not contradict reason if explained according to its plain meaning, like Circumcise therefore the foreskin of your heart (Deut. 10:16), which has to be interpreted according to the requirements of reason.34See I.E.’s third approach to Biblical interpretation, Vol. 1, pp. 10 and 11.

[UPON THY HAND.] Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that the term yad (hand) in most of Scripture refers to the left hand,35According to the rabbis the hand phylactery is placed on the left hand. as in Yea, My hand (yadi) hath laid the foundation of the earth, And My right hand hath spread out the heavens (Is. 48:13); and Her hand (yadah) she put to the tent-pin, And her right hand to the workmen’s hammer (Jud. 5:26). However, the teachings of tradition are firmly established and do not require any support.36I.E. disagrees that yad usually refers to the left hand.

FROM YEAR TO YEAR. Mi-yamim yamimah (from year to year) is similar to yamim tiheyeh ge’ullato (for a full year shall he have the right of redemption (Lev. 25:29). The meaning of mi-yamim yamimah is, from year to year. The year begins when the Bet Din announces its commencement.37As explained by I.E. in his comments on Ex. 12:2.
AND IT SHALL BE. Moses mentions only the Canaanite, because he was the father of them all.38Gen. 10:15-18. Hence the term Canaanite includes all the inhabitants of Canaan. Also see I.E. on Gen. 15:20

[AS HE SWORE UNTO THEE.] Its meaning is similar to for unto thee, and unto thy seed, I will give this land (Gen. 26:3).39As He swore unto thee and to thy fathers means as He swore unto your fathers to give this land to you their seed (Krinsky), as we do not find God taking this oath to the generation enslaved in Egypt.

THAT THOU SHALT SET APART. Thou shalt set it apart unto the Lord so that it does not get mixed up with another. Now these two precepts40The sanctification of the first-born (v. 2) and the eating of unleavened bread (v. 3 and 6). were commanded on the fifteenth day.

COMING OF. Sheger41Vocalized segol, segol. (coming of) follows the paradigm of eretz (land of) whose vocalization does not change in the construct. However, a number of irregular cases42Nouns vocalized segol, segol whose vowels change to sheva, pattach in the construct. are found. They are: shegar (the increase of)43Rather than sheger, as in our verse. in the increase of thy kine (Deut. 7:13), chadar (chamber of)44The absolute form of which is cheder. in and in the chamber of thy bed (Ex. 7:28), havel (vanity of)45The absolute form of which is hevel. in Vanity of vanities (Eccles. 1:1), hamatekha (thy venom)46The absolute form of which is chemet. in That puttest thy venom thereto (Hab. 2:15), and delatekha (thy doors)47The absolute form of which is delet. in and shut the doors (Is. 26:20). I have not found any additional instances.
AND EVERY FIRSTLING OF AN ASS. Which is unclean, thou shalt redeem with a lamb.

THOU SHALT BREAK ITS NECK. Some say that va-arafto (thou shalt break its neck) means thou shalt write the word holy on its neck.48The word oref means a neck. Hence va-arafto literally means: and you shall neck it. Hence the possibility of this interpretation. However, I say that anyone who says this is himself a stiff-necked ass. For behold it is written, He will break down (ya’arof) their altars (Hos. 10:2),49We thus see that the verb derived from oref means to break. and ve-arefu sham et ha-eglah ba-nachal (and shall break the heifer’s neck there in the valley) (Deut. 21:4), in which the meaning of ve-arefu is, as explained by the transmitters of the law, to cut off the neck.50Apparently no one disputes the rabbinic interpretation. Otherwise I.E. would be guilty of circular reasoning. All firstlings that are not brought up on the altar or are not redeemed are required to be killed, as all the first-born of Egypt both man and beast perished. God did not save them51The first-born of Israel, both man and beast. from the decree which he had issued on the first-born of the Egyptians except that they should be prepared for His service. The Israelites had no unclean animals except for asses. Therefore no other52Unclean. first-born53Animal. is to be redeemed.

AND IT SHALL BE. Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi of blessed memory says that the word machar (in time to come)54Literally, tomorrow. is missing an alef, its meaning being that which comes after today.55In other words machar is short for me’acher (after). Rabbi Judah Ha-Levi interprets this way because “And it shall come to pass when thy son asketh thee tomorrow (machar),” etc., makes no sense in our context, whereas And it shall come to pass when thy son asketh thee in time to come (machar) does. Also see Rashi, “There are instances when machar means after some time.”

AND IT CAME TO PASS. Moses begins by saying, By strength of hand the Lord brought us out from Egypt (v. 14) and backtracks and explains that what the strength of hand refers to is the plague of the first-born. It was because of this plague, and not because of the first plagues, that Israel went out of Egypt. The poet similarly says, To Him that smote Egypt in their first-born, For His mercy endureth for ever (Ps. 136:10).56Which is followed by And brought out Israel from among them (Ps. 136:11). None of the other plagues are recalled in Ps. 136. Only this plague is mentioned, because it was the one that caused Pharaoh to permit Israel to leave Egypt. Moses wrote elliptically. When Moses said, that the Lord slew all the first-born in the land of Egypt, both the first-born of man, and the first-born of beasts, it was known57At that time. that God saved our first-born and the first-born of our cattle. It is to the latter,58Although it is not stated in the text. not to the slaying of the first-born, that therefore I sacrifice to the Lord all that openeth the womb is connected.
ALL THAT OPENETH THE WOMB, BEING MALES. From a kind fit to be sacrificed to the Lord.59In other words, “all” is not to be taken literally because it does not include unclean animals.

AND IT SHALL BE FOR A SIGN. Scripture mentions, And it shall be for a sign upon thy hand with regard to two commandments.60The eating of unleavened bread (v. 9) and the sanctification of the first-born (v. 16). That which the sages of blessed memory transmitted, namely, that the chapters61Ex. 13:1-10 and Ex. 13:11-16, which contain these commandments. are to be written,62In the phylacteries. is true.

AND FOR FRONTLETS. Totafot (frontlets) means a memorial.63Our verse is similar to verse 9, which has zikaron (memorial) in place of totafot (frontlets). Others say64Menachem ben Saruk (c. 910-970 C.E.). See Rashi. that the tet of totafot65Which is spelled with two tafs. is doubled,66From the root tet, peh. Menachem believed that Hebrew words come from a two-letter root its meaning being to speak. They say that it comes from the same root as ve-hettef (and preach) in and preach toward the south (Ezek. 21:2). However, in my opinion this is far-fetched.67Because ve-hettef comes from the root nun, tet, peh whereas totafot comes from the root tet, tet, peh (Krinsky).
Can a fool who rebels against his maker succeed? When at peace his liver an arrow shall split. Note and take heed, O recusant; All that the portion Be-Shallach records concerning Pharaoh.

AND IT CAME TO PASS WHEN PHARAOH HAD LET THE PEOPLE GO. The vav in ve-lo nacham (led them not) is like an unaspirated fa in the Arabic tongue.68In other words, a vav prefixed to a word does not always mean and. Hence ve-lo nacham does not mean: and led them not, but may mean: that God led them not, or something similar. It is known that the distance between Egypt and Jerusalem by way of the land of the Philistines is not very great. It is about a ten-day journey by straight road. If this was not so, how did the tribes69Jacob’s sons. come as far as Egypt upon their asses?70To buy food. See Gen. 42-44. If the distance was very great how much would have been necessary for them and their asses to eat?71In other words, if the distance between Egypt and Canaan had been very great they would not have been able to carry enough food with them for the journey. Furthermore, upon returning they brought back food for their households.72If the distance was very great they would have had to carry a vast amount of food for the journey plus an additional amount for their households.

ALTHOUGH THAT WAS NEAR. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that ki karov hu means although that was near.73In other words, the word ki, which usually means “for” or “because,” has the meaning of “although” here. Rabbi Moses interprets thus, for prima facie, the word, “because” is out of place here, as God should have led them by the way of the Philistines because it was close. In my opinion, ki am keshe oref hu (for it is a stiff-necked people) (Ex. 34:9); refa’ah nafshi ki chatati lakh (Heal my soul; for I have sinned against Thee) (Ps. 41:5); and ki rekhev barzel lo (though they have chariots of iron) (Josh. 17:18) are similar.74The word ki in these verses is to be translated as although. Hence Ex. 34:9 is to be translated, although it is a stiff-necked people; and Ps. 41:5, Heal my soul; although I have sinned against Thee. However, I see no need for this interpretation,75For interpreting ki here as although. for its meaning is: the reason God did not lead them by way of the land of the Philistines was that it was close.76In other words, ki karov hu is to be rendered, because it was close. God thus led them via a distant way so that they would not witness any war and say, Let us make a captain, and let us return to Egypt (Num. 14:4).

[LEST PERADVENTURE.] We know for certain that the Lord knows the future.77Lest peradventure implies that God was uncertain about the future. This contradicts the concept that the Lord is omniscient, hence I.E.’s comments. God knew that the people would repent if He led them by the way of the land of the Philistines. Scripture reads, Lest peradventure the people repent because the Torah employed human terminology so that those who study78The Torah. will understand.79What the Torah is trying to convey. See I.E. on Gen. 1:26.

LED THE PEOPLE ABOUT. Va-yassev (led about)80Vocalized with a pattach beneath the yod, a tzere beneath the samekh, and a dagesh in the samekh. is a verb81In the hifil. that comes from a double root. Its stem is samekh, bet, bet. Va-yassev also has an alternative vocalization.82It may be vocalized va-yasev, with a kamatz beneath the yod and a segol beneath the samekh. For a double root in the hifil imperfect may be vocalized pattach tzere, as in yassev, or kamatz segol, as in yasekh, yagel, yasev. Compare, va-yasekh (shut up) in Or who shut up (Job 38:8)83Vocalized kamatz, segol. and va-yagel (and rolled) in and rolled the stone (Gen. 29:10).84Vocalized kamatz, segol. Pay no heed to those who say that the root of va- yassev is nun, samekh, bet.

[THE WILDERNESS.] The word ha-midbar (the wilderness) is to be read as if written twice.85The Hebrew reads, ha-midbar yam suf. Now a definite article cannot be prefixed to a word in the construct. Hence I. E. argues that ha-midbar yam suf is short for ha-midbar, midbar yam suf. See Vol. 1, Foreword, p. XV, and I.E. on Gen. 2:9. The clause is to be understood as if written, by the way of the wilderness, wilderness of the Red Sea. Similarly, ha-aron ha-bebrit (the ark of the covenant) (Josh. 3:14) is to be understood as if written, the ark, ark of the covenant,86See Vol. 1, p. 54, note 36. and, ve-etz ha-da’at tov va-ra (the tree of the knowledge of good and evil) (Gen. 2:9) as if written, and the tree of the knowledge, knowledge of good and evil.87See Vol. 1, p. 54. Likewise the terms ha-sefer ha-miknah (the deed of the purchase)88The phraseha-sefer ha-miknah, is short for ha-sefer, sefer ha-miknah (the deed, deed of the purchase). (Jer. 32:12) and ha-yayin ha-chemah (the wine of fury) (Jer. 25:15).89Ha-yayin ha-chemah is short for ha-yayin, yen ha-chemah (the wine, wine of fury). There are many other similar instances.

RED SEA. Suf (Red) is the name of a place. Others say that suf comes from the same root as sof (the end)90In other words, yam suf (Red Sea) is a variant of yam sof and means the Sea of the End, that is, the sea which lies at the end of the world. in The end of the matter (Eccles. 12:13). It is so called because it lies at the end of the world. The reference is to the Atlantic, which I have already mentioned.91Ex. 10:19. Literally, as I have already mentioned. However, this is a major blunder, because the yam suf (Red Sea) lies in the east, opposite Egypt.92Whereas the Atlantic does not. The Spanish Sea93The Mediterranean. is larger than it.94The Red Sea. How much more so the Atlantic, which is greater than the Mediterranean. Hence the Red Sea cannot be identified with the Atlantic.

ARMED. Some say that chamushim (armed) means full of wealth, possessing all that they need. Now Scripture states, neither had they prepared for themselves any victual (Ex. 12:39).95Which shows that they did not have everything they needed. Furthermore, what reason is there to mention this now?96That they had provisions. It adds nothing to the account here. Its proper place is in Ex. 12:39. The only meaning of chamushim is, girded with weapons for war. Compare, chalutzim ta’avoru (ye shall pass over armed) (Deut. 3:18), the meaning of which is: ye shall pass over with girded loins.97The word chalatz means loins. Therefore, chalutzim ta’avoru literally means: ye shall pass over with loins, i.e., with loins girded with weapons. The fact that Scripture in one place reads, ve-attem ta’averu chamushim (but ye shall pass over before your brethren armed) (Josh. 1:14) and in another place refers to the Israelites as chalutzim (Deut. 3:18) is true witness to the aforementioned.98That chamushim means armed. What reason was there for them to carry food before their brethren?99If chamushim means stocked with food then Josh. 1:14 tells us that the tribes of Dan and Reuben and half the tribe of Manasseh passed over the Jordan before the rest of Israel, carrying food. Now what conceivable reason was there for this? Food carriers or baggage follow behind troops. They do not precede them. The reason Scripture at this point notes that the children of Israel went up armed is that it is previously stated, Lest peradventure the people repent when they see war, and they return to Egypt (v. 17).100Hence we might assume that they were unarmed. For101Contrary to what verse 17 might imply. the Israelites went out with a high hand (Ex. 14:8), with weapons of war and not like fleeing slaves.

AND MOSES TOOK THE BONES OF JOSEPH. Scripture mentions above that the children of Israel who were alive in that generation went up out of the land of Egypt. Scripture now notes that the children of Israel also brought up with them the most honored one of them, the one through whom they came down to Egypt. The latter had made them swear before his death that they would tell their children, and their children would instruct their children about this.102To bring his bones up with them. Now Moses busied himself with fulfilling the oath so that no guilt would fall upon Israel. For we see that the princes of Israel swore an oath to the Gibeonites.103That they would not harm them. See Josh. 9. Now they only took this oath on condition that the Gibeonites came from a distant place as they claimed.104See Josh. 9:9. After it was found that the Gibeonites came from close by105That is, from the land of Canaan. it was fitting that they not keep their oath so that they and all Israel not violate the injunction, thou shalt save alive nothing (Deut. 20:16). However, they kept their oath out of regard for God’s glory so that they not desecrate it.106As they swore upon God’s name. Many years later God punished the children of Israel107See II Sam. 21:1. because Saul permitted the Gibeonites who were in Nob, the city of the priests, to be put to death.108See Rashi and Kimchi on II Sam. 21:1.

[THE BONES OF JOSEPH.] Scripture mentions the bones of109Rather than the body of. for all of the flesh and skin breeds worms and putrefies, and after a few years only the bones remain.110I.E. was apparently unaware of the process of mummification.
AND THEY TOOK THEIR JOURNEY…ETHAM. Etham is, as I will explain,111See Ex. 15:22. the wilderness of Shur.

AND THE LORD WENT BEFORE THEM BY DAY. We know that the Lord inhabiteth eternity and His name is Holy (Is. 57:15), and that He is enthroned of old. Selah (Ps. 55:20).112In other words, God is incorporeal, for if He had a body He could not be eternal. This being the case, why does Scripture read, And the Lord went? Scripture speaks in the language of men. It reads so because God’s power went with Israel, as in That caused His glorious arm to go at the right hand of Moses (Is. 63:12).

[IN A PILLAR OF CLOUD.] Scripture reads, in a pillar of cloud because it was not shaped like other clouds but was in the form of a pillar stretching from the sky upon the earth. A pillar is called an ammud113From the root ayin, mem, dalet. in Hebrew because the base (ma’amad)114From the root ayin, mem, dalet. of the house is on it.115An alternative translation is: because the existence (ma’amad) of the house depends on it. See the word ammud in Kimchi’s Sefer Ha-Shorashim. Be that as it may, I.E.’s point is that the passive form ammud (it was stood up), rather than the active omed (stands) is used for a pillar because the house is stood up, i.e., stands/exists (ammud) because of it.

[THAT THEY MIGHT GO BY DAY AND BY NIGHT.] Scripture reads, that they might go by day and by night because the camp was large and they could only journey a short distance.116At a time. They therefore journeyed part of the day117That is, a little by day (Cohen). and also part of the night.118That is, a little by night. These two pillars were, as I shall explain,119Ex. 15:22 before the Israelites until they came to the sea.

DEPARTED NOT. Yamish (departed) is a transitive verb.120Meaning he caused to depart, the reference being to the Lord mentioned in verse 21. Thus lo yamish ammud he-anan (the pillar of cloud departed not) means: God did not cause the pillar of cloud to depart. For God mentioned above121In verse 21. did not cause the pillars to depart from before the people.

[BY DAY.] The word yomam (by day) is not found employed in Scripture except for the time when the sun shines upon the earth. The word yom (day) found in the Torah, the Prophets, and the Writings refers also to nighttime, for it is written, on the day (yom) that I smote all the first-born in the land of Egypt (Num. 8:17). Now the slaying of the first-born took place at night.122Ex. 12:29. It is also written, this day (ha-yom) is a day (yom) of good tidings (II Kings 7:9). Now it was then night, for we read there, if we tarry till the morning light (Ibid.). Scripture also reads, The day (yom) I cry in the night before Thee (Ps. 88:2).123Translated literally.

AND THE LORD SPOKE. It is truly not proper for an intelligent person to scrutinize God’s actions and ask, why did the Lord act thus?1In other words, truthfully speaking one can not always fathom God’s will. For all of God’s actions are done wisely. Man’s wisdom is as nothing before God.2Cf. Ps. 39:6. I mention this because you will read in this Torah portion that God3Acting like the general of an army. guilefully commanded the Israelites to turn back4Compare, verses 2 and 3. so that Pharaoh would go out and pursue them, and drown in the sea.5Compare, verse 4. God’s thoughts are very deep.6Hence we cannot understand why the Lord chose to destroy Pharaoh and his hosts in this way when he could have killed them with a plague or the like.

PI-HAHIROTH. Pi-hahiroth is elsewhere called Pene-hahiroth (Num. 33:8). It is so called7By these two names. because the mouth (peh) is on the face (panim).8Hence pi (mouth of) and pene (face of) interchange. It is the name of a place.

BEFORE BAAL-ZEPHON. Some say that the Egyptian magicians made bronze images which drew power from the stars, and that Baal-zephon was a statue that no slave fleeing Egypt was able to pass by.9They held that Baal-zephon was an image on the border of Egypt which supernaturally prevented fleeing slaves from crossing it. It is because of this that Scripture reads, that the people were fled (v. 5).10Once the Israelites passed Baal-zephon the Egyptians realized that the statue was ineffective against Israel and that the Israelites had fled. However, in my opinion because Moses said to Pharaoh, We will go three days’ journey into the wilderness (Ex. 8:23), it appeared to Pharaoh from these words that Moses knew the road that they would take to the place where they intended to sacrifice. Thus when Pharaoh heard that the Israelites started to go by way of the wilderness,11To the place where they were going to offer sacrifices. and when they had traveled some distance12Into the desert away from Egypt. backtracked to go in another way, Pharaoh surmised that everything that Moses had told him was said in guile, that he did not intend to sacrifice but to flee. For one who flees becomes confused on the way and does not know which road to take.

OVER AGAINST IT. The word nikhcho (over against it) is vocalized with a chirik.13Rather than a kamatz katan. The word nikhcho consists of the word nokhach (against) plus the pronominal suffix. In such cases the cholam changes to a kamatz katan. Thus we would expect nokhcho rather than nikhcho, hence I.E.’s comment. It is similar to the word niflo (was fallen)14Which should have been vocalized noflo, for niflo consists of the word nofel plus the pronominal suffix. in after that he was fallen (II Sam. 1:10). There are many other such instances.15In which the chirik comes in place of a kamatz katan where a word vocalized with a cholam is combined with a pronominal suffix.

AND PHARAOH WILL SAY OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. This is similar to say of me (Gen. 20:13).16Hebrew, imri li (say of me); literally, say to me. I.E.’s point is that there are instances in which the lamed is to be interpreted to mean of, concerning, about. Thus li-vene yisrael does not mean to the children of Israel but of the children of Israel.

ENTANGLED. Nevukhim (entangled) is vocalized with a shuruk in place of a cholam.17The singular form of nevukhim is navokh. Thus we would expect to see nevokhim rather than nevukhim. Compare, nakhon, nekhonim, navon, nevonim. It is similar to the word ta’avuri (pass)18In which a shuruk comes in place of a sheva. The usual form of the kal feminine imperfect is ta’avri. in neither pass from hence (Ruth 2:8), for nevukhim is a nifal as the word nekhonim (ready) (Ex. 19:11) is.19Hence it should have followed that paradigm and been similarly vocalized. See note 17. Now navokhu (perplexed) (Joel 1:18) and also navokhah (perplexed) in but the city of Shushan was perplexed (Est. 3:15) are like nakhonah (established)20They are all nifals and follow the same paradigm. Similarly nevukhim despite its irregular vocalization. in And the kingdom was established (I Kings 2:46). Its meaning is, they are like a person who cannot find anyone to advise him and does not know what to do.21In other words, nevukhim means perplexed. The nun in nivkhe (depths of) in the depths of the sea (Job 38:16)22Translated according to I.E. is a root letter.23Whereas the nun of nevukhim is not a root letter but the nun of the nifal form. The root of nevukhim is bet, vav, kaf and the root of nivkhe is nun, bet, kaf. The meaning of nivkhe yam (the springs of the sea) is the depths of the sea. Nivkhe has no place here.24Contra Rashi and Rashbam, who connect nevukhim and nivkhe. Rashi comments, “Nevukhim means enclosed and sunk deep, as in nivkhe yam.”
THE WILDERNESS HATH SHUT THEM IN. The ways of the wilderness are closed to them, and like fugitives they do not know where to go.

AND I WILL HARDEN PHARAOH’S HEART. As if he forgot the plagues25That is, And I will harden Pharaoh’s heart means: I will harden his heart so that he will act as if he forgot the plagues. with which the Egyptians were smitten because of Israel.
AND I WILL GET ME HONOR UPON PHARAOH. My glory shall be manifest in the world when I drown Pharaoh and his army.26In other words, be-faroh (upon Pharaoh) is to be interpreted, via Pharaoh.
AND THE EGYPTIANS SHALL KNOW. The remnants27Those who remained in Egypt and did not pursue Israel. and those who drowned prior to their death shall know that I am the Lord.

AND THEY DID SO. Scripture’s short way of saying that they turned backwards.28In other words, and they did so is short for: and they turned backwards and encamped before pi-hahiroth. According to Krinsky, and they did so is short for: and Moses told Israel to turn backwards, etc.
AND IT WAS TOLD THE KING OF EGYPT. That they are not going for any purpose but to flee.

AND HE MADE READY HIS CHARIOT. By command.29Contra Rashi, who explains that Pharaoh himself made ready his chariot. It is like So Solomon built the house (I Kings 14:4).30Which means Solomon commanded that the house be built.
AND HE TOOK SIX HUNDRED CHOSEN CHARIOTS. The chosen chariots of all the chariots that he had.31The best of his chariots.

AND CAPTAINS. Note that the king is like the number one. Therefore the one who is next to him in rank is called the mishneh (the second), which is derived from the same root as shenayim (two). The third in rank is called the shelishi. 32See I.E. on Gen. 41:43. Thus shalishim (captains) are third in rank.
WITH A HIGH HAND. They had all the weapons of war and so did not go out like fugitives.

AND THE EGYPTIANS PURSUED AFTER THEM. This is in keeping with linguistical style.33For Scripture to repeat itself in this manner. The previous verse reads, and he pursued after the children of Israel. It is similar to and the people saw,34Which follows And all the people saw. and they trembled and stood far off35Translated literally. (Ex. 20:15), the meaning of which is, when they saw this,36In others words, va-yar (and they saw) is to be rendered: and when they saw. Otherwise Scripture would be literally repeating itself. they trembled and stood far off. The meaning of and the Egyptians pursued after them thus is: when the Egyptians pursued them,37In other words, va-yirdefu (and they pursued) is to be rendered: and when they pursued. Thus Scripture does not literally repeat itself. they overtook them as they were encamping by the sea.

[ALL THE HORSES.] Scripture notes this38The Hebrew text reads, kol sus (all the horses); literally, every horse, hence I.E.’s comment. to inform us that they did not come upon them scattered.39The horsemen did not approach Israel in scattered groups but as a united force (Cohen).
AND HIS HORSEMEN. Parashav means his horsemen.
AND HIS ARMY. Chelo (his army) means his foot soldiers.

AND WHEN PHARAOH DREW NEAR. When Pharaoh caused his camp to draw near.40In other words, u-faroh hikriv (and Pharaoh drew near) means: and when Pharaoh caused to draw near, i.e., when Pharaoh caused his army to draw near. The verb hikriv (drew near) is always transitive in Scripture.41Hence it means to cause to draw near rather than drew near.

AND THEY SAID. We find that the holy tongue employs two words with one meaning back to back when one would suffice. Now the phrase ha-mibbeli en kevarim (because there were no graves)42Literally, because there are no graves, for bli and en mean the same thing. is similar to ha-rak akh be-mosheh (only with Moses?) (Num. 12:2).43Literally, only only with Moses? For rak and akh mean the same thing.

TO BRING US FORTH. Le-hotzi’anu (to bring us forth) is vocalized with a long kamatz in place of a tzere.44Literally, a short kamatz. According to the rules of Hebrew grammar the word should be le-hotzi’eni. Compare, hotzi’eni (Ps. 25:17); ve-hotzie’ni (I Kings 22:34). It is similar to ro’ani (seeth me)45Wherein a long kamatz has been substituted for a tzere. The word should have read, ro’eni. Compare, ro’enu (Is. 29:15). in Thou hast said:46This is how Scripture reads. I.E. has: And I say. He probably quoted from memory and erred. None seeth me (Is. 47:10).

IS THIS NOT THE WORD. This is not stated.47In the Exodus narrative. Nowhere is it stated that the Israelites told Moses, Let us alone, that we may serve the Egyptians, etc. However, we know that this was the case, for how could they say to his face something that was not true? This remark was included in but they hearkened not unto Moses (Ex. 6:9).48It is worthy of note that Let us alone, that we may serve the Egyptians, etc., follows but they hearkened not to Moses, etc., in the Samaritan Pentateuch.

STAND STILL, AND SEE THE SALVATION OF THE LORD. For you will not wage war but you shall see the salvation which the Lord will work for you this day. One may ask: How is it that a large camp comprising six hundred thousand armed men were afraid of those who pursued them? Why did they not stand and fight for their own and their children’s lives? The answer is: The Egyptians were masters over Israel. The generation that left Egypt were trained from their youth to bear the yoke of the Egyptians. They were of humble spirit. How then could they now wage war against their masters? The Israelites were lazy and not learned in war. Can you not see that were it not for the prayers of Moses, the Amalekites, who came49To attack Israel. See Ex. 17:8-13. with a small number of men, would have defeated Israel. God alone, Who doeth great things (Job 5:9); And by Him actions are weighed (I Sam. 2:3), so arranged events that all Israelite males50Under the age of 20. See Num. 14:31. who left Egypt died out,51See Num. 14:22. for they had no spirit to fight the Canaanites; and a new generation with a noble spirit, who had never tasted exile, arose after the generation of the wilderness.52The generation that left Egypt and died in the wilderness. I have noted the aforementioned in the account of Moses recorded in the Torah portion Ve-Eleh Shemot.53Ex. 2:3.

THE LORD WILL FIGHT FOR YOU. Lakhem means for you.54Literally, to you, hence I.E.’s comment. Similarly, whenever the word war (milchamah) is followed by a lamed it indicates aid. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen therefore explains li (me) in For there are many that fight (lochamim) me (li) on high55Translated according to I.E. (Ps. 56:3) to mean for me.56For a lamed follows the word war (lochamim.) According to Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen, Ps. 56:3 should be translated: For there are many that fight on high for me. The meaning of on high is, a war on high, as is the case with all that sit.57It is unclear what I.E. means. Filwarg suggests emending ha-yoshevim (that sit) to ha-chashuvim (that are important), the idea being that important people have others who fight for them. The verse thus states: For there are many that fight for me on high as is the case with all important people. However, in I.E.’s short commentary the reading is ha-moshekhim, which is a technical term for words that are to be read as if written twice. In this case our verse is to be read as follows: For there are many that fight for me, that fight for me on high, the reference being to angels who fight on his behalf. See I.E. on Ps. 56:3. In this case the last line of I.E. should be interpreted as: The meaning of on high is a war on high, as our verse belongs to those verses in which there is a word that is to be read as if written twice.
AND YE SHALL HOLD YOUR PEACE. In contrast to and the children of Israel cried out (v. 10).

WHEREFORE CRIEST THOU UNTO ME. Some say that Moses was crying out unto the Lord.58See Mekhilta and Rashi on this verse: “This teaches us that Moses was standing and praying.” However, this is incorrect, for God had already told Moses, and I will get Me honor upon Pharaoh (v. 4).59Thus Moses knew that God would destroy Pharaoh and his army and would not cry unto the Lord. On the contrary, this was told to Moses who stood in Israel’s stead60The words were directed to the children of Israel, not to Moses. because the children of Israel cried out to the Lord.
THAT THEY GO FORWARD. Little by little until they reach the edge of the sea.

AND LIFT THOU UP. God told Moses to lift up his rod and divide the sea before the children of Israel went forward. The Lord did not tell Moses to strike the sea.61Which shows that Moses was some distance from it. He told him to stretch out his hand toward the sea62Which he could do from a distance. According to I.E. al ha-yam (over the sea) is to be rendered, toward the sea. in the manner63That is, al means toward. of And Moses stretched forth his rod toward heaven 64Hebrew, al ha-shamyim which literally means over the heaven. (Ex. 9:23). We know that the rod did not divide the sea but that from the moment that Moses stretched his hand toward the sea God caused the sea to go back by a strong east wind and the waters then65Reading az rather than oh (Vat. Ebr. 38). split. For it is so written.66In verse 21.

AND I. We know that the Red Sea is not situated between Egypt and the Land of Israel. There was no reason for them to enter the sea.67I.E. apparently assumes that yam suf is the Red Sea. However, the Red Sea is not located between Canaan and Egypt. There was thus no reason to cross the Red Sea, hence I.E.’s comment. However, God commanded them to do so, so that the Egyptians would enter behind them and drown. The children of Israel, as I will explain,68See I.E. on verses 22 and 29 and Ex. 15:22. entered the sea from the wilderness of Etham and exited the sea to the wilderness of Etham.
AND THE EGYPTIANS SHALL KNOW. Those that remained.69In Egypt shall know that I am the Lord, for those who pursued Israel all perished (v. 28). See I.E. on verse 4.
WHEN I HAVE GOTTEN ME HONOR UPON PHARAOH. Who will drown along with his chariots and horsemen.

AND THE ANGEL OF GOD. This took place before speak unto the children of Israel, that they should go forward (v. 15).70The incident described in verses 19 and 20 must have taken place before Israel was commanded to go forward, since the pillar of cloud came between the two camps and prevented the Egyptians from harming the Israelites all the night (v. 20). It’s meaning thus is, and the angel of God had already removed.71In other words, va-yissa (removed) is a pluperfect, meaning had removed. I have already showed you many such instances.72Where Scripture employs a pluperfect. Now because these three verses73Verses 19, 20, 21. are connected to each other and each one has seventy-two letters we find in them, as stated in the books,74Post-talmudic works such as Lekach Tov on Ex. 14; Responsa of R. Hai Gaon. Also see Ozer Ha-Geonim, Hagigah, p. 23. The Talmud speaks of the 72-letter name of God. See Sukkah 45a. Those who see the 72-letter name of God in these verses do so in one of the following two ways. They arrange the three verses on top of each other and arrive at God’s name by reading down, i.e., vav, vav, vav; yod, yod, yod; samekh, bet, tet, etc. Or they invert verse 20 and arrange the three verses as above and read down, i.e., vav, heh, vav; yod, lamed, yod; samekh, alef, tet, and so on. The reason they invert the middle verse is that it states, and the one did not come near the other all the night; i.e., one is not to combine the letters of this verse in their normal fashion but they are to be read backwards as the word ha-laylah (the night) is. For ha-laylah reads the same whether from left to right or right to left (Krinsky). the sign of the secret of God’s explicit name. However, in my opinion it is so written75These three verses. In other words, verses 19-21 consist of 72 letters each, not because a combination of their letters spells out a secret name of God, but rather they allude to God (YHVH) whose might delivered Israel. because, as I will explain in the Torah portion Ki Tissa,76I.E. insists that when the Talmud speaks of the 72-letter name of God it refers to the tetragrammaton (YHVH),which when calculated as follows, Y (10) YH (15) YHV (21) YHVH (26), comes to 72. Cf. I.E.’s Sefer Ha-Shem 5. the numerical value of God’s glorious name comes to seventy-two. The Book of Raziel77An early cabalistic work which is supposed to have been given to Adam by the angel Raziel (Hebrew, mystery of God). It contains mystical teachings, letter mysticism, descriptions of heaven, as well as formulas for amulets. states that one who wants to query the heavenly powers in a dream should read the verse, Now it came to pass in the thirtieth year, etc. (Ezek. 1:1), for it contains seventy-two letters.78In the Sefer Raziel, and apparently also in I.E’s version of Scripture, the words ha-golah and marot in Ezek. 1:1 were spelled without a vav. Otherwise the number of letters in Ezek 1:1 comes to 74 as they do in our editions of the Prophets. Cf. Minchat Shai on Ezek. 1:1.

THE ANGEL OF GOD. The reference is to the great prince79The angel Michael. Cf. Dan. 21:1, And at that time shall Michael stand up, the great prince who standeth for the children of Israel. who goes in the cloud, concerning whom it is written, And the Lord went before them by day (Ex. 13:21). When this angel, who went before the camp of Israel, moved and went behind them, the pillar of cloud moved with him. Let the one who identifies the angel of God with the cloud show us where we find the pillar of cloud called the angel of God. Furthermore, if the angel and the pillar are one and the same, why is and the pillar of cloud removed from before them repeated? If he should answer that Scripture repeats the same idea in different words,80As it often does. then we respond that it is not the manner of Scripture to repeat itself except in prophecy81Which is given in poetic form. or reproof.82Prophet’s words of reproof. Moreover, it is unfit to repeat oneself when reporting how something happened.83When prose is employed. In other words, Scripture repeats the same idea in different words in poetry but not in prose.
AND IT CAME. And the angel came.84The Hebrew reads, va-yovo, which may mean: and it came, or, and he came, hence I.E.’s comment.
AND THERE WAS THE CLOUD AND THE DARKNESS HERE. Between the camps.

AND IT LIT UP THE NIGHT.85I.E. renders this, and he lit up the night, the reference being to the angel who lit up the night via the pillar of fire (Krinsky). As was the manner on all the nights, so that Israel could cross the sea. They crossed it at night. Rabbi Merinus says that the meaning of va-ya’er (he lit up) is, he darkened. And the night shall be light about me (Ps. 139: 11)86Translated literally. So too Rashi on Ps. 139:11. is similar. Furthermore, we find, On the light of the fourteenth day87Pesachim 2a. The meaning of which is, on the night of the fourteenth day, i.e., the night preceding the fourteenth day. We thus see that the word light can refer to night or darkness. in rabbinic literature. However, the one who interprets thus turns darkness into light and light into darkness, for it is impossible in any language for a word to mean both a thing and its opposite unless it is euphemistically used, as in Naboth did bless God and the king (I Kings 21:13).88Translated literally. Its meaning is, as J.P.S. translates, Naboth did curse God and the king. The word light in shall be light about me refers to the light itself, as I have explained.89Cf. I.E. on Ps. 139:11. Similarly, the sages said90Pesachim 3a. that On the light of the fourteenth is a refined language,91They did not want to mention darkness. which is similar to a euphemism. Furthermore, what reason was there for Scripture to say, and he darkened the night? It is dark every night. The only meaning of va-ya’er et ha-laylah is that he92The angel via the pillar of fire (Krinsky). lit up the night93In other words, va-ya’er et ha-laylah means: and he lit up the night. as he did from the day that Israel went out of Egypt, for the pillar of fire was seen every night. Now if Israel had no light how did they cross the sea?94Another argument against Rabbi Merinus’ interpretation. For behold, by the time Pharaoh came into the sea and the Lord looked forth upon him in the morning watch, most of the Israelites had already crossed.95Thus most of the Israelites crossed during the night. However, if they had no light how could they have crossed?
AND MOSES STRETCHED OUT HIS HAND…ALL THE NIGHT. Even while Israel was crossing, the wind did not cease.

AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL WENT INTO THE MIDST OF THE SEA. Do not think that because Scripture reads, in the midst96Hebrew, be-tokh in (the middle), hence I.E.’s comment. of the sea that the Israelites reached the middle of the Red Sea. On the contrary, even if they entered the sea for even half of a Persian mile one may say that they came in the midst of the sea.97In other words, the word tokh is not to be taken literally. It is like And the mixed multitude that was in the midst of them98Translated literally. (Num. 11:4), for the mixed multitude was not in the middle of the camp. The meaning of the midst of the sea is, the place where there was water at the beginning of the night.99Not literally in the midst of the sea.

AND THE WATERS WERE A WALL UNTO THEM. The waters froze.100The waters on either side of the Israelites froze and formed two solid walls (Krinsky, Cohen). It is also written, The floods stood upright as a heap (Ex. 15:8).101The verse continues, The deeps were congealed in the heart of the sea. After most of Israel crossed, the waters which formed a wall for them melted. This is the meaning of that the waters may come back upon the Egyptians (v. 26). These waters102Which formed from the melting walls. separated between the Egyptians and the dry land.103That the Israelites were on. It therefore states, and the Egyptians fled against it (v. 27), as the Egyptians thought that they would go out onto dry land.104The dry land that the Israelites were on. But the walls of water melted and separated them and dry land. There is no doubt that those who pursued Israel saw the light by which Israel crossed.105Hence they saw the Israelites on dry land and wanted to follow them.

AND IT CAME TO PASS IN THE MORNING WATCH. The alef of ashmoret106From the root shin, mem, resh. (watch) is a superfluous letter.107It is not a root letter, nor is it a prefix. It has no translatable meaning.

THAT THE LORD LOOKED FORTH. The reference is to the angel of the Lord mentioned earlier.108Verse 19. The same is the case with Gideon,109Concerning whom we read, And the angel of the Lord came (Jud. 6:11), And the angel of the Lord appeared unto him (Ibid.). This angel is subsequently referred to as the Lord in verses 14, 15, 23, 27; i.e., and the Lord turned, And the Lord said, etc. Similarly, the angel mentioned in verse 19 of this chapter is subsequently called the Lord. where the messenger is called by the name of the sender. Since the sender commands his agent to commit an act, it is as if the sender himself had executed it.

THROUGH THE PILLAR OF FIRE AND OF CLOUD. Between these two pillars.110Contra Rashi, who interprets the bet of be-ammud (through the pillar) to mean with; i.e., God threw the Egyptians into confusion through the use of the two pillars. I.E. interprets the bet of be-ammud as meaning in the pillars, i.e., between the pillar of cloud, which was behind the camp of Israel, and the pillar of fire, which was in front of Israel (Filwarg).

AND DISCOMFITED. Possibly because of this the poet says, The voice of Thy thunder was in the whirlwind (Ps. 77:19).111For va-yaham (discomfited) refers to a discomfit brought about by lightning and thunder. Ps. 77:19 speaks of the splitting of the Red Sea (Weiser). Similarly And He shot forth lightnings, and discomfited them112Hebrew, va-yehummem. This is the reading in Ps. 18:15. However, I.E. has va-yahom. He probably quoted from memory. The parallel verse in II Sam. 22:15 has va-yahom as the kre. Be that as it may, this verse shows that the root heh, mem, mem refers to discomfit brought about by thunder and lightning (Weiser). (Ps. 18:15). Elsewhere it is written, And He sent…Lightning, and discomfited them113Hebrew, va-yahom. (II Sam. 22:15).

AND HE TOOK OFF. Va-yasar (and He took off) is a hifil.114From the root samekh, vav, resh. It should have been vocalized va-yaser with a segol beneath the samekh. I have already noted its grammatical explanation.115See I.E. on Ex. 8:27.

[AND HE TOOK OFF THEIR CHARIOT WHEELS.]116Literally, and he removed the wheel of his chariots, hence the various interpretations. Some say its meaning is that they117In other words, “he” refers to each one of the chariot drivers. untied the knot of the wheel118That is, the chariots. from the horses119They untied the knot by which the horses were tied to the chariots and tried to escape by riding on the horses. so that, being lighter,120Not having to pull the chariots, the horses had a lighter load, i.e., only the rider. they could flee more easily. However, the above-mentioned divine discomfit fell upon them and their horses, and they could only drive them with great difficulty.121Cohen paraphrases I.E. in this way: “To hasten their flight, the Egyptians unharnessed the chariots; but the general confusion also affected the horses.” Others say that va-yasar comes from the root of sorer (rebellious) (Deut. 21:18).122From the root samekh, resh, resh, meaning to rebel. Thus va-yasar (and he took off) means: and he rebelled. He who went before them wanted to turn the chariot around.123Filwarg believes that the reference is to the leading chariot. He wanted to turn his chariot around and flee. In this case, “and he rebelled” means: and he turned the wheels of his chariot around. That is, instead of going forward as his orders said, the lead charioteer tried to turn his chariot around and flee. Rashbam interprets similarly.

FOR THE LORD FIGHTETH FOR THEM AGAINST THE EGYPTIANS. Lahem124Its literal meaning is, to them. means for them.125When the word to fight is followed by a lamed it means on behalf (see Weiser). It now becomes clear that God’s word, and the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord (v. 4), which He spoke earlier meant: and the Egyptians shall know before their deaths.
THAT THE WATERS MAY COME BACK. The waters which served as walls for them should return to their previous state.
WHEN THE MORNING APPEARED. Lifnot boker (when the morning appeared) means toward morning.

TO ITS STRENGTH. Le-etano means to its strength. It is a noun,126That is, etan is a noun. Cf. I.E. on Ps. 74:15. Le-etano is the noun etan plus the prepositional lamed and the pronominal suffix. like etan in mighty rivers (Ps. 74:15).127Translated according to I.E.

FLED AGAINST IT. I have already explained128In verse 22. that the Egyptians in fleeing thought that they were returning to dry land when in actuality they were going toward the sea. May the bones of Chivi129Chivi Al-Balkhi, a Persian Bible exegete born in Balkh (now in Afghanistan) who lived in the latter part of the 9th century. He wrote a book containing two hundred queries on the Bible. Surviving quotations show Chivi to have been a free-thinking man “who sought to explain biblical miracles naturally…His views aroused intellectual ferment among Oriental Jewry and Saadiah Gaon published a refutation” (Roth, p. 916). the dog130A play on Ha-Balkhi. By inverting the letters of Ha-Balkhi from Balakh, we get ha-kalbi (the dog). be crushed. Chivi said that Moses knew the time of low tide, when the level of the sea goes down, and the time of high tide, when the sea comes in and its level rises, and so brought his people across the sea when the tide was normally low. However, Pharaoh did not know the manner of the sea and therefore drowned. This interpretation is sheer madness, as the sea is not normally dry in any place when its level goes down. However, all was dry.131According to verse 29 Israel crossed on dry land. Neither do walls of water remain on the right or the left.132When the sea retreats at low tide. Furthermore, the end of low tide and the beginning of high tide do not become clear until some hours have passed.133It takes some hours before the effects of high and low tide are perceptible. Thus it would take quite a while for the waters to have enveloped the Egyptians. However, it appears from Scripture that the waters overwhelmed the Egyptians in a short period of time. Moreover, the Israelites had not yet finished crossing before Pharaoh and his army drowned.134If it was low tide why did Pharaoh and his army drown?

AND THE LORD OVERTHREW. Va-yena’er (overthrew) is a pi’el. Na’arti (I shook) in Also I shook out my lap (Neh. 5:13) is similar to it.135It comes from the same root. Thus va-yena’er means to shake, or cast out something from one’s lap, hand or vessel. Va-yena’er is to be understood in the manner of hath He thrown into the sea (Ex. 15: 1).136And the Lord overthrew is to be interpreted: and the Lord threw them into the sea (Weiser).
AND THE WATERS RETURNED. The waters that were walls returned.

SO MUCH AS ONE OF THEM. Even one of them did not escape.137In other words, ad echead (literally, until one) means so much as one. Similarly ad echad in and, behold, there was not so much as one (ad echad) of the cattle of the Israelites dead (Ex. 9:7). Indeed, the poet says, There was not one of them (echad me-hem) left (Ps. 106: 11).138We thus see that ad echead means so much as one.

BUT THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. The reason this is noted a second time139After already noting it in verse 22. is that there remained some Israelites who were still crossing the sea while Pharaoh was drowning. This was a miracle within a miracle, for in the place where the Israelites were crossing the sea there was a strong east wind drying140The sea. and where Pharaoh and his host were, God brought another wind to melt the waters that were frozen and formed walls. There were thus two winds in two places in the sea close to one another.141At the same time. True proof that this interpretation is correct is offered by the statement in the Song of Moses, And with the blast of Thy nostrils the waters were piled up (Ex. 15:8), which speaks of the wind that blew for Israel; and the statement, Thou didst blow with Thy wind, the sea covered them (Ex. 15:10), which speaks of the wind that caused the Egyptians to drown. It is because of this that the end of the song reads, and the Lord brought back the waters of the sea upon them; but the children of Israel walked on dry land in the midst of the sea (Ex. 15:19). Do not ask, how could all of Israel cross in one night? Did not the six hundred thousand men on foot142Who left Egypt. See Ex. 12:37. They were married and had children. Additionally, a mixed multitude went up with them. make up only a quarter of the camp?143Of the Israelites. The reading in Vat. Ebr. 38 is: For the six hundred thousand men on foot did not make up even a quarter of the camp. Perhaps they passed over some other way.144Pharaoh only pursued the 600,000 armed men. The rest continued along on an overland road and eventually joined up with the group that crossed over (Filwarg). See the rest of I.E.’s comments. Or perhaps the sea split into twelve parts, as the sages of blessed memory say.145Cf. Pirke de-Rabbi Eliezer 42; Tanchuma, Be-Shallach 10; Mekhilta, Be-Shallach 4. Now the Israelites did not cross the width of the sea.146See I.E.’s comments on verse 22. On the contrary, they moved along its length and came out in the wilderness of Shur from wherein, as I will explain, they entered the sea.147See I.E. on Ex. 15:22.

THUS THE LORD SAVED. Now the Israelites were saved from the hand of the Egyptians. Until now the fear of Pharaoh was upon them.148The Israelites dreaded Pharaoh until they saw the Egyptian corpses. Scripture tells us that the Egyptians drowned in the sea. The sea did not cast their bodies out upon the dry land,149Contra Rashi and Mekhilta on this verse, and Pesachim 118b. for it is clearly written, The earth swallowed them (Ex. 15:12).150That is, the sea bed swallowed them (Krinsky). The meaning of and Israel saw the Egyptians dead upon the sea-shore151Which implies that the sea cast them out. therefore is: when the Egyptians drowned, the Israelites, who were on the shore, saw their dead bodies.152Before they sank.
FEARED. When Israel saw this great blow they feared God, as in And David was afraid of the Lord that day when Uzzah who put forth his hand to the ark of God died (II Sam. 6:9).

AND THEY BELIEVED IN THE LORD. They believed that the Lord is truth153Unchanging and Ultimate Being. Cf. Mishneh Torah, Mada 1:3,4: “The Truth of His being is incomparable to the truth of any other individual being…He alone is the Truth, and no other being possesses a truth similar to His Truth.” and that Moses is His servant and will do only that which the Lord commands him to do.

THEN SANG MOSES. It is Hebrew style to employ an imperfect preceded by the word az (then) in place of a perfect.1Az yashir mosheh (then sang Moses) literally means: then Moses will sing. I.E. points out that an imperfect preceded by the word az occasionally has the meaning of a perfect. Similarly, in the next three verses cited by I.E. verbs that are in the imperfect are to be translated as perfects, for the imperfects are preceded by the word az. Compare, Az yivneh shelomoh (then did Solomon build) (I Kings 11:7);2Yivneh is an imperfect that means will build. Thus az yivneh shelomoh literally means: then will Solomon build. az yedabber yehoshu’a (then spoke Joshua) (Josh. 10:12);3Yedabber is an imperfect that means will speak. Therefore az yedabber yehoshu’a literally means: then will Joshua speak. az yavdil mosheh (then Moses separated) (Deut. 4:41).4Yavdil is an imperfect that means will separate. Thus az yavdil mosheh means: then Moses will separate. The same is true in Arabic. Moses composed the song by himself. He then taught it to all of Israel, each one of whom then sang and said, I will sing unto the Lord.5Hence the song is in the singular even though the verb which introduces it reads, va-yomeru (and spoke), which literally means: and they spoke. Then sang Moses and the children of Israel this song may be interpreted to mean that Moses and Israel simultaneously broke into song. However, this interpretation is untenable, as it is impossible for a whole nation to know the contents of a song without first being taught its words. Hence I.E.’s comment. And Moses and the elders of Israel commanded the people (Deut. 27:1) is similar. The commandment was first spoken only by Moses. The elders of Israel then repeated it to everyone.6For Moses and the elders did not simultaneously command the people.

AND SPOKE, SAYING.7In Hebrew, lemor (saying). Lemor is used when a statement is directed to someone. However, what follows is a hymn, hence I.E.’s comment. Cf. Filwarg. Each one of the Israelites was to say the following, or the following was to be said in every generation.

FOR HE IS HIGHLY EXALTED. He demonstrated His exaltation by casting both the mighty rider and his exalted and powerful steed into the sea as one casts an arrow. The meaning of ramah (thrown) in ramah va-yam (hath He thrown into the sea) is similar to the word rome (throws) in armed with that which a bow throws (Ps. 78:9).8Translated according to I.E.

THE LORD IS MY STRENGTH AND SONG. Rabbi Solomon9Rashi. of blessed memory says that there is a difference between ozzi (my strength), which is vocalized with a furtive kamatz, and uzzi, which is vocalized with a kubbutz. He therefore says that the yod in ozzi (my strength) in the Lord is my strength and song is superfluous.10According to Rashi the yod of ozzi is not a first person pronominal suffix. The word ozzi has the same meaning as the word oz. It means strength. Cf. Rashi’s comment on this verse. However, Rabbi Solomon does not offer another such instance.11Actually Rashi does. He offers ha-yoshevi (enthroned) and shokheni (dwelt), the yods of both of which are superfluous. Cf. Filwarg. If this is what I.E. meant then he must have quoted Rashi from memory and erred. However, it is possible that what I.E. means is that Rashi offered no other instance of two words ending in a yod coming from the same root, one word vocalized with a kubbutz, the other with a kamatz, with the yod of one superfluous and the yod of the other a first person pronominal suffix. Rabbi Solomon goes on to say that ve-zimrat (and song) is in the construct with Yah (the Lord). He interprets our verse as if it read: The strength and vengeance12According to Rashi ve-zimrat (and song) is to be rendered, and vengeance. Rashi connects ve-zimrat to zamar, which means to prune or cut. God, as it were, pruned Israel’s enemies. of the Lord became my salvation.13Rashi reads our verse as one clause. The problem with this reading is that the second part of the sentence starts with va-yehi (and he is become), which usually opens a new clause. Hence Rashi points out that va-yehi at times has the meaning of hayah, which continues a thought rather than starting a new clause. Rabbi Solomon thought that our verse is similar to va-yehi ba-yom ha-shelishi va-yissa avraham et enav (on the third day Abraham lifted up his eyes) (Gen. 22:4).14Wherein va-yissa (lifted up), which is grammatically similar to va-yehi, does not begin a new clause but rather continues a thought. However, one who knows Arabic knows the difference between the two verses.15Knows when an inverted imperfect such as va-yehi or va-yissa can be used with the meaning of hayah or nasa and when it cannot, for Hebrew and Arabic are sister languages. It is neither correct Hebrew nor Arabic form to say ozzi ve-zimrat Yah va-yehi li li-shu’ah.16That is, to connect part a and b of the line and read it as one clause. Hence va-yehi li li-shu’ah cannot mean: became my salvation, but rather, And He is become my salvation. There is no difference between ozzi vocalized with a furtive kamatz and the same word vocalized with a kubbutz.17In other words, contra Rashi, ozzi and uzzi mean the same. For while Scripture reads, chukki (mine allotted)18With a kubbutz. in Feed me with mine allotted bread (Prov. 30:8) it elsewhere reads, chokkha19Vocalized with a furtive kamatz. ve-chok ba-nekha (thy due, and thy son’s due) (Lev. 10:13). Now we find the word ve-ozzekha (in Thy strength) (v. 13) vocalized with a furtive kamatz, later on in this song and similarly in O Lord, in Thy strength (be-ozzekha) the king re-joiceth (Ps. 21:2).20Ozzekha is the word oz plus the second person pronominal suffix. Similarly, ozzi is the word oz plus the first person pronominal suffix. This contra Rashi, who maintains that the yod of ozzi is superfluous. The yod of ozzi is thus a first person suffix. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that the meaning of ve-zimrat Yah is, the Lord is my song,21In other words, ve-zimrat (and song) is short for ve-zimrati (and my song). for the resh of ve-zimrat (and song) is vocalized with a kamatz.22Hence ve-zimrat cannot be in the construct with Yah, for if ve-zimrat were in the construct with Yah it would be vocalized with a pattach rather than with a kamatz. Similarly,23According to Rabbi Moses. the meaning of shenat in I will not give sleep (shenat) to mine eyes (Ps. 132:4) is, my sleep,24For shenat is short for shenati (my sleep). as shenat is vocalized with a kamatz.25Rather than with a pattach. If shenat were vocalized with a pattach it would be in the construct. Likewise, the meaning of nachalat, which is vocalized with a kamatz26Rather than with a pattach. in Yea, I have a goodly heritage (nachalat) (Ps. 16:6) is my heritage.27For nachalat is short for nachalati (my heritage). Similarly,28According to Rabbi Moses. the meaning of menat, which is vocalized with a kamatz29Rather than with a pattach. in, O Lord, the portion (menat) of mine inheritance and of my cup (Ps. 16:5), is my portion.30For menat is short for menati (my portion). However, what will Rabbi Moses do with the word menat (portion) in the king’s portion (II Chron. 31:3) in which menat is vocalized with a kamatz and is in the construct. It is the same case with the word yam (sea) in the salt sea (Num. 34:3) and in the sea (yam) of Chinnereth (Num. 34:11). Should one respond that the latter are irregular, we would tell him to place ozzi ve-zimrat Yah among them.31Once it is established that a word ending in kamatz tav is occasionally in the construct it is possible to interpret ve-zimrat as being in the construct with Yah. Hence there is no need for the novel interpretation that ve-zimrat is short for ve-zimrati. I believe that the word ozzi (my strength) is, as is the style of the Hebrew language, to be read as if written twice.32I.E. makes this point throughout his commentary. Our clause is to be read as if written, ozzi, ve-zimrat ozzi33Ve-zimrat is in the construct with ozzi, which is carried over from the first part of the verse. Yah (The Lord is my strength and the song of my strength).34Literally, my strength, and the song of my strength is the Lord. The reason behind this verse is that Moses earlier mentioned, The horse and his rider hath He thrown into the sea (v. 4). Moses now states that this was not through his own majesty and strength. On the contrary, he confesses, my strength and the glory of my strength35I.E. interprets the song of my strength to mean: the glory of my strength. is Yah alone who is the Lord. Yah is, as I have explained,36Cf. I.E. on Ex. 3:15. one of the three proper names of God. All three37YHVH, EHEYEH, YAH. come from one root.38Heh, yod, heh. Since the word eheyeh39Which means I will be, and is also one of the names of God. See Ex. 3:14. is frequently employed in speech it was necessary to substitute a vav for a yod in God’s glorious name.40The point is, since God’s name comes from the root heh, yod, heh, the form YHVH was used for God’s name rather than YHYH, which means he will be, and is frequently employed in speech. Filwarg suggests emending our textto read: since the word yihyeh is frequently employed in speech it was necessary for a vav to be substituted for a yod in God’s glorious name. The word Yah41Short for YHVH. What I.E. means by Yah are the letters yod heh. is likewise known.42It is known that Yah is short for yehi (let there be) (Filwarg). Filwarg suggests emending to: The word yehi is likewise frequently employed. Its yod was vocalized with a pattach because of the guttural43Because it precedes a heh. and the silent yod44Since Yah is short for YHVH, its shortened form should be YHY (yehi), as YHVH is really YHYH (which stands for yehiyeh), the vav being substituted for a heh. Hence I.E.’s comment. For I.E.’s explanation of the divine name see I.E. on Ex. 3:15. was dropped45And a vav was not substituted for it as in the full name of God (Filwarg). because it has another secret numerical meaning.46If the letters of the name Yah are spelled out and then computed they come to 26. The latter is the same as the numerical equivalent of the letters making up the divine name YHVH. Yah is spelled yod heh. Yod heh spelled out = 26.
