That is, yod spelled out comes to 20: yod (10), vav (6), dalet (4). Heh, which is spelled heh (5), alef (1), comes to 6. The full name of God, Y (10) H (5) V (6) H (5), comes to 26. Thus Yah = YHVH. We find Yah combined with God’s glorious name in ki ozzi ve-zimrat Yah YHVH (for God the Lord is my strength and song) (Is. 12:2). I have already explained that the name YHVH is at times a proper name and at times an adjective.47See I.E. on Ex. 3:15.
THIS IS MY GOD. My power.48El (God) means power. Hence Eli (my God) means my power. See I.E. on Ex. 3:15.

AND I WILL GLORIFY HIM. I will place Him in a building.49I will erect for Him a temple. I.E. connects ve-anvehu (and I will glorify Him) to naveh (habitation), hence his translation. See Onkelos and Rashi.

[THIS.] The word zeh (this) is to be read as if written twice. The last clause of our verse is to be read as if written: And this is my father’s God, the reference being to the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.50In other words, “my father” refers to the patriarchs.
AND I WILL EXALT HIM. For I will recount His might.
THE LORD IS A MAN OF WAR. The Lord supports those who love Him and cleave unto Him and He is a man of war to their enemies.

[MAN.] The word ish (man) means a being.51Or an entity. I.E. makes a similar point in his comments on Gen 15:10. Translating ish as a being obviously eliminates an anthropomorphism. Scripture thus states in reference to the stars, ish lo nedar (not one faileth) (Is. 40:26); and in reference to the living creatures, ish el ever panav yelekhu (they went every one straight forward) (Ezek. 1:9); and in reference to the angels, ve-ha-ish gavriel (the man Gabriel) (Dan. 9:21). The meaning of ish milchamah (a man of war) thus is, a being who wages war. It is similar to the term ish emunim (a faithful man) (Prov. 20:6), the meaning of which is, a being52Cf. Krinsky and Weiser. imbued with faith.

THE LORD IS HIS NAME. His name will now be known. Compare, That calleth for the waters of the sea, And poureth them out upon the face of the earth; The Lord is His name (Amos 5:8). He alone can do such a thing.53After God does a wondrous thing people speak of it and His name thus becomes known.
PHARAOH’S CHARIOTS. God, as it were, cast Pharaoh’s heavy chariots and their hosts as if they were a light arrow.
[AND HIS CHOSEN CAPTAINS.] Moses made mention of his chosen captains “who were over all them”54See Ex. 14:7. because he had previously spoken of Pharaoh’s hosts.

[THE RED SEA.] Yefet55See notes on I.E. Ex. 3:3. says that suf in yam suf (the Red Sea) has the same meaning as the word suf (flags) in The reeds and flags shall wither (Is. 19:6) and the word suf in and laid it in the flags (Ex. 2:3). For reeds and rushes grow around the yam suf,56Hence the meaning of yam suf is the Sea of Flags or the Sea of Reeds. and not around other seas.57This is Yefet’s assumption. However, Rabbi Joshua says that suf is the name of a city.58Hence the meaning of yam suf is the Sea of Suf. It is like yam kinneret (the sea of Chinnereth) (Josh. 13:27).59Chinnereth was the name of a city. See Jud. 19:35. The area around the city was called the land of Chinnereth (I Kings 15:20). The sea adjacent to this area was called the Sea of Chinnereth. Similarly, the Talmud refers to it as the Sea of Tiberias (Megillah 6a) because the city of Tiberias is situated on it shores.
THE DEEPS. The deeps of the earth.60The bottom of the ocean floor. Compare, The earth swallowed them (v. 11).

[COVER THEM.] A shuruk has been substituted for a cholam in yekhasyumu (cover them).61According to the rules of grammar the word should have read yekhasyumo. Compare, timla’emo, torishemo (v. 9). Compare, ta’avuri (pass) in neither pass from hence (Ruth 2:8).62Wherein a shuruk has been substituted for a cholam, for the word should have read ta’avori.
THE DEPTHS. Metzolot (the depths) means the deep waters. Similarly va-tashlikheni metuzlah, (for thou did cast me into the deep waters) (Jonah 2:4).63Translated according to I.E.

GLORIOUS. The yod of nedari (glorious) is superfluous.64It has no meaning. Scripture could have employed nedar as it does i n verse 11. It is like the yod of akhzari (cruel).65Which is superfluous. The word akhzari is found in Is. 13:9; Jer. 6:23; Prov. 11:17; and elsewhere in Scripture. Scripture uses the term akhzar in Deut. 32:33; Job 30:21; 41:2; and Lam. 4:3.

[THY RIGHT HAND.] The repetition of the phrase Thy right hand, O Lord indicates the same as the repetition of For, lo, Thine enemies, O Lord (Ps. 92:10)66The line repeats itself in Ps. 92:10. and The floods have lifted up (Ps. 93:3).67The line repeats itself in Ps. 93:3. It indicates time and time again. Its meaning is: your right hand dashes the enemy in pieces times without number.

[GLORIOUS IN POWER.] Glorious in power refers to God.68The verse should be interpreted, Thy right hand, O Lord who art glorious in power. However, there are those who say that it refers to the Lord’s right hand.69They claim that the verse should be interpreted, Thy right hand, O Lord, which is glorious.

AND IN THE GREATNESS OF THY EXCELLENCE. Which is superior to all who exalt themselves. You are able to shatter (overthrow) those that rise up against You. You need no iron weapons to shatter them. All You have to do is send forth Your wrath and it consumeth them as stubble, for God’s wrath is as hot as fire.
AND WITH THE BLAST OF THY NOSTRILS. You rebuke the waters and they congeal. Compare, By the breath of God they perish (Job 4:9).
THE WATERS WERE PILED UP. The word ne’ermu (were piled up) is similar to the word aremat (a heap of) in a heap of wheat (Cant. 7:3).

THE FLOODS STOOD UPRIGHT AS A HEAP. The waters, whose nature is to flow and descend, turned into a heap (ned), as in And rose up in one heap (ned) (Josh. 4:16).70The reference is to the waters of the Jordan that split so that Israel could enter Canaan. The meaning of ned (heap) is a wall.
THE DEEPS WERE CONGEALED. Kafe’u means were congealed. Compare, ve-kippa’on (frost) (Zech. 14:6).71Translated according to I.E.
IN THE HEART OF THE SEA. The heart lies in the middle of the body from the point of view of the body’s width.72In the heart of the sea thus means in the midst of the sea.
THE ENEMY SAID. The reference is to Pharaoh.

[SHALL BE SATISFIED UPON THEM.] The word timla’emo (shall be satisfied upon them) is difficult.73Here. For the suffix mo in timla’emo means them. Hence our verse literally reads, My soul will fill them (or satisfy them). However, this was not Pharaoh’s intention. Pharaoh’s intention was to be full of their wealth. Hence our text should have read: My soul will be full of them; i.e., I will be full of their wealth. Rabbi Merinus explains that timla’emo nafshi (my lust shall be satisfied upon them) means: my person74Nafshi (my lust) may also be translated as, my person or my soul. shall be full of them;75In other words, even though the suffix mo means them we can interpret it to mean from them or of them. We can thus interpret timla’emo to mean full of them rather than will fill them. i.e., I will take all of their wealth. The term timla’emo is to be understood like the term yetza’uni (gone forth of me)76The suffix ni means me. Thus yetza’uni literally means: gone forth me. However, this is not the meaning of the word in the context of the verse. Its meaning is, gone forth of me. We thus see that Scripture sometimes employs a direct object suffix with the meaning of an indirect object. The same is true of timla’emo. in My children are gone forth of me (Jer. 10:20). Its meaning77Timla’emo nafshi. is connected to I will divide the spoil.78In other words, I will be full of them means: I will be full of their spoils. Others say that timla’emo is used in the same sense as the word me’lo’o (presume)79The root mem, lamed, alef doesn’t only mean to fill. It also means to presume. In our verse it is used in the latter sense. in that durst presume in his heart (Esth. 7:5).80Thus timla’emo means: will carry out my intentions. Hence timla’emo nafshi means: I will carry out my intentions upon them or, according to J.P.S., my lust shall be satisfied upon them.
[MY HAND SHALL DESTROY THEM.] After doing the latter81Satisfying his lust upon them. I shall destroy them.

MY HAND SHALL DESTROY THEM. Torishemo means shall destroy them.82The root of torishemo is yod, resh, shin. This root also has the meaning of to inherit, hence I.E.’s comment. Similarly the word torishu (you will destroy) in But if you will not destroy (Num. 34:55).83Translated according to I.E.

THOU DIDST BLOW WITH THY WIND. Nashafta (Thou didst blow) comes from the same root as neshef (night). The meaning of nashafta ve-ruchakha (Thou didst blow with Thy wind) is: You brought a wind at night that drowned them.84Thus nashafta ve-ruchakha literally means: you “nighted” with a wind.

THEY SANK. Tzalelu (they sank) comes from the same root as metzolot (depths). Compare, My lips quivered (tzalelu) at the voice (Hab. 3:16).85This comment presents a problem. If tzalelu is the verbal form of metzolot (depths) then its meaning is, they sank. This being the case, what connection is there between tzalelu in our verse and tzalelu in Hab. 3:16, which means quivered? Krinsky suggests reading metzilot (bells, cymbals) (Zech. 14:20) rather than metzolot (depths). Indeed, I.E. connects tzalelu in Hab. 3:16 to metziltayim (cymbals). According to Krinsky we should read, “Tzalelu (they sank) comes from the same root as metzilot (bells, cymbals).” In other words, tzalelu means they tingled, and the meaning of our verse is, they tingled like lead in the mighty waters; i.e., they cried and shrieked as they drowned as if they were lead cymbals. The point is, they did not die quietly.

IN THE MIGHTY WATERS. This is connected to they sank. Our verse is to be read as if written: they sank86If we accept Krinsky’s emendation then we should render, they tingled. as lead in the mighty waters.

AS LEAD. Oferet (lead) comes from the same root as afar (dust).87Its root being ayin, peh, resh. If one puts any of the six kinds of metal88For the six other metals see I.E. on Ex. 3:15 and the notes thereto. in the ground each will lose one of its familiar elements in a given number of years.89They decompose in the ground. However, lead will always maintain itself.

WHO IS LIKE UNTO THEE, O LORD, AMONG THE MIGHTY. Elim (the mighty) refers to the holy angels in the celestial heights. The sons of the mighty (bene elim)90Spoken of elsewhere in Scripture. See Ps. 29:1. refers to the stars. I will explain this further in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.
GLORIOUS IN HOLINESS. The reference is to the Throne of Glory.

[FEARFUL IN PRAISES, DOING WONDERS.] For all who want to acclaim God are afraid to praise His name because who can recite all of His praises. However, they are obligated to praise Him because He alone does wonders.

THOU STRETCHEDST OUT THY RIGHT HAND. Your wonders91Spoken of in the previous verse. Literally, what is the wonder? were manifest when You stretched forth Your hand from the highest realm of the celestial heights where Your name is exalted, and the ground which is beneath all earthly creatures swallowed up the enemy of Israel. Your right hand, which is above the heaven of heavens, reached, as it were, in a moment to the bottom of the sea.92I.E.’s description of the fate of the Egyptians.
[THY RIGHT HAND.] Its meaning is, Thy strength.

THOU IN THY LOVE HAST LED. Moses used the perfect nachita (led) in place of the imperfect,93The verse speaks of God bringing Israel to His holy habitation. It thus deals with the future. I.E. interprets Thou in thy love hast led as: Thou in thy love will lead. as is the style in prophecy.94For the prophet speaks of the future as if it already has come to pass. See I.E. on Gen. 48:22.

[IN THY LOVE.] The reference is to the pillars of cloud and fire, for God led them.95God, out of love for His people, caused the pillar of cloud and the pillar of fire to lead Israel. On the other hand, it might allude to the fact that God led them up till now.96This refers to I.E.’s opening comment that Scripture uses a perfect in place of an imperfect. I.E. now suggests that the Pentateuch uses a perfect because it speaks of the past; i.e., up to this point God lovingly led Israel i n their march to His holy habitation.

THOU HAST LED. Nehalta (thou hast led) is similar to etnahalah (I will journey) in I will lead on97J.P.S. renders journey. gently (Gen. 33:14).98In other words, the root nun, heh, lamed means to lead.
IN THY STRENGTH. Not by their strength.
TO THY HOLY HABITATION. The reference is to Mount Sinai where God’s Glory dwelt. It is similarly written, and brought you unto Myself (Ex. 19:4).
THE PEOPLES HAVE HEARD. The reference is to the peoples round about them and also to the peoples whom they would pass by.99On their journey to the promised land.

PANGS HAVE TAKEN HOLD ON THE INHABITANTS OF PHILISTIA. The inhabitants of the land of Philistia.100In other words, Philistia is short for the land of Philistia. Peleshet (Philistia) is the name of a nation, hence I.E.’s comment that here it refers to their country (Krinsky). The word inhabitants indicates this.101It indicates that Scripture speaks of a country.

THE MIGHTY MEN. Ele (mighty men) spelled with a yod102As it is in our verse. means sheep,103Or rams. Thus ele mo’av (the mighty men of Moab) literally means the rams of Moab. for the sheep have leaders.104The rams lead the sheep.

[THEN WERE THE CHIEFS OF EDOM AFFRIGHTED…THE MIGHTY MEN OF MOAB, TREMBLING TAKETH HOLD UPON THEM.] The Philistines, the Edomites, and the Moabites did not wage war with the Israelites in the wilderness.105See I.E.’s comment on verse 14.

ALL THE INHABITANTS OF CANAAN ARE MELTED AWAY. Because of the reports which they received, as in And as soon as we heard it, our hearts did melt (Josh. 2:11). The inhabitants of Canaan is also106Like the inhabitants of Philistia. See I.E.’s comments on verse 14 and the notes thereto. to be interpreted as the inhabitants of the land of Canaan.107For Canaan is short for the land of Canaan.

TERROR AND DREAD FALLETH UPON THEM. This refers to Edom and Moab even though Canaan is mentioned above.108Canaan is the last mentioned in verse 15. He spoke unto them in a pillar of cloud (Ps. 99:79) is, as I have explained, similar.109For He spoke unto them refers only to Moses and Aaron even though Samuel is also mentioned in the verse. See I.E. on Gen. 20:17 and Ex. 7:7. Likewise, and shed the blood of war in peace (I Kings 2:5) only refers to Abner.110Not to Amasa, although both are mentioned in the verse. So too, and God healed Abimelech, and his wife, and his maid-servants; and they bore children refers to Abimelech’s wife and handmaids.111Not to Abimelech. See I.E. on Gen. 20:17. All of this112I.E. had to take the trouble to say all of this, i.e., that the verse does not refer to the Canaanites even though they are the last nation mentioned in the previous verse, and then he had to offer other similar instances. because Scripture reads, Till thy people pass over, O Lord.113Which implies that the verse speaks of the march to and not the conquest of Canaan. For Israel passed them114Edom and Moab. before they came to the land of Canaan. Moses repeated Till Thy people pass because they circled Mount Seir for many days.115Deut. 2:1.
[THOU HAST GOTTEN.] Its meaning is: they were slaves in Egypt and Thou hast gotten them to be Your servants.

THOU BRINGEST THEM IN, AND PLANTEST THEM IN THE MOUNTAIN OF THINE INHERITANCE. A prayer that Israel remain long in the land and not be exiled from it.116As a tree takes root in the ground and remains there permanently, hence the use of the term titta’emo (plantest them). Our verse is like in the mountain of the height of Israel will I plant it (Ezek. 17:23).

IN THE MOUNTAIN. The goodly hill country and Lebanon (Deut. 3:25)117Literally, the goodly mountain and Lebanon. In the mountain thus refers to the land of Canaan, which is mountainous. is similar. Or it alludes to Mount Moriah.118The mountain in Jerusalem upon which the Holy Temple was built. It is therefore followed by The place, O Lord, which Thou hast made for Thee to dwell in.

[WHICH THOU HAST MADE.] Its meaning is: which Thou hast prepared as a place for a sanctuary for Thyself.119The verse literally reads, a place for a dwelling Thou hast made. I.E. thus explains that the word order has to be rearranged. He then interprets the rearranged word order. The place mentioned lies opposite the glorious celestial place,120See Mekhilta Ex. 10, “The Sanctuary below is directly opposite the Throne above.” Also see Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 4:5 and Rashi. for the places on earth vary in accordance with the star that is over them.121I.E.’s interpretation of the rabbinic text quoted in the previous note. According to I.E. the greater the star, the more important the place under it (Krinsky). Those who are versed in the science that deals with the constellations will understand this.122The greater the star over a place, the greater the importance of the place (Weiser). I.E. believed that the Temple was under the influence of the sphere wherein all the stars are embedded. Hence its site was the most important place on earth (Krinsky).

[THE SANCTUARY.] The word mikkedash (sanctuary)123In our verse, which has a dagesh in the kof. has the same meaning as mikdash (sanctuary).124Which does not have a dagesh in the kof but has one in the dalet. Mikdash is the form for sanctuary used throughout Scripture. The form mikkedash is found only here. The word mittoharo (his brightness) in Thou hast made his brightness to cease (Ps. 89:45) is similar, as the dagesh in the tet is superfluous, like the dagesh in the kof of mikkedash.125The mem in mittoharo, like the mem of mikkedash, is a form mem and not a prepositional mem. Hence the dagesh following it, like the dagesh which follows the mem in mikdash, is superfluous. If the mem of mittoharo or mikkedash was a preposition then the dagesh following it would not be superfluous, for it would be in place of a nun. For the prepositional mem is in place of the word min (from). The dalet126In mikkedash. does not receive a dagesh127A dagesh kal, as does the dalet of mikdash. because the kof128Of mikkedash. is vocalized with a mobile sheva.129Because of its dagesh. A dagesh kal follows a sheva nach (quiescent sheva). It does not follow a mobile sheva (sheva na). Hence mikdash, which is vocalized with a quiescent sheva, has a dagesh in its dalet whereas mikkedash, which is vocalized with a mobile sheva, does not. With the exception of the form shetayim we do not find it to be the way of Scripture to place a dagesh in a word which follows a mobile sheva. I have already noted its grammatical uniqueness.130In his commentary on the letter nun, in the Sefer Ha-Tzachot, I.E. notes that shetayim is the only word in Hebrew in which a sheva na is followed by a word with a dagesh.

WHICH THY HANDS HAVE ESTABLISHED. Its meaning is similar to thou hast made,131The meaning of The sanctuary, O Lord, which Thy hands have established is the same as The place, O Lord, which Thou hast made for Thee to dwell in. for Scripture repeats itself.
THE LORD SHALL REIGN. God’s Kingship will be seen when the Holy Temple132Mentioned in the previous verse. which will be dedicated to His name shall be built.

[FOR EVER AND EVER.] Le-olam va-ed (for ever and ever)133Literally, forever and until. is an abridgment. The full form is le-olam ve-ad134Va-ed is a variant of ve-ad. olam (for ever and until ever). Do not be amazed that the word ed135In le-olam va-ed. is not in the construct,136With another word. For the word is a preposition and it seems strange to end a phrase with it. for we find, shokhen ad137Here too ad, a variant of ed, is not in the construct.ve-kadosh shemo (That inhabiteth eternity, whose name is Holy) (Is. 57:15). It is the custom of Hebrew to vocalize a vav with a pattach138That is, a kamatz. I.E. occasionally refers to the kamatz as a pattach (Krinsky). when the syllable which follows it is accented.139Hence the word reads va-ed rather than ve-ed. Compare, va-ez (or goat) in of ox, or sheep, or goat (Lev. 7:23). It is for this reason that va-ed is vocalized with a pattach.140That is, a kamatz. Now Scripture reads, va-okhal141Vocalized with a pattach. mi-kol (I have eaten of all) (Gen. 27:33). However, at the end of a verse it reads, ha-nachash hishi’ani va-okhel142Vocalized with a tzere. In other words, the pattach changes to a tzere at the end of a sentence. Similarly, the word ad is vocalized ed at the end of a sentence. (the serpent beguiled me, and I did eat) (Gen. 3:13). Hence the statement, le-olam va-ed.143Rather than le-olam va-ad.

FOR THE HORSES OF PHARAOH. This verse is, in my opinion, part of the song.144Even though it is in prose. It was for the latter reason that Nahmanides does not interpret it as part of the song. See Nahmanides and Shadal on this verse. Its purpose is to recall the wonder within the wonder,145Namely, that Israel was crossing the Red Sea at the same time that the Egyptians were drowning. which I have noted.146See I.E. on Ex. 14:29.

[UPON THEM.] Upon them refers to the horses of Pharaoh…his chariots and his horsemen. It also includes Pharaoh.147Contrary to the Midrashic opinion that Pharaoh survived. For Scripture clearly states, The enemy (Pharaoh) said (v. 9) and then goes on to say, The earth swallowed them148Scripture thus clearly states that Pharaoh drowned. (v. 12). Furthermore, it is explicitly written, But (God) overthrew Pharaoh and his host in the Red Sea (Ps. 136:15).

AND MOSES LED. I believe that the pillar of cloud, and likewise the pillar of fire, that went before the people when they left Egypt was to ensure that Israel was able to go by day and by night (Ex. 13:21). After Pharaoh and his hosts drowned, Israel was no longer frightened and did not travel at night.149Hence they no longer needed the pillars. Indeed, we do not find it recorded in the Torah portion Be-Halotekha150In which we find a description of Israel’s journey. See Num. 8:15-22. that Israel journeyed at night. Behold, Moses now led the people according to God’s command.151In other words, Moses rather than the pillars now guided Israel. It is I.E.’s opinion that the pillars led Israel from the time they left Egypt till they came to the Red Sea, and that from the Red Sea to Sinai Moses led Israel. When the Tabernacle was erected the pillars of cloud and fire descended upon it, and the pillar of cloud once again led Israel. See I.E.’s short commentary on Ex. 13:21. There are only six journeys from the Red Sea until Mount Sinai152Listed in Num. 33:14,15. lasting less than forty days.153Israel journeyed from the Red Sea on the 21st of Nisan until the first of Sivan when they came to the desert of Sinai. The air154At that time of year in the wilderness. is then good. It is neither humid nor cold. He who does not have a tent can live outdoors155At this time of year. without harm. When Israel came to the wilderness of Sinai they all erected booths,156As I.E. goes on to explain, they were informed by Moses that they would spend the fall and winter at Sinai. as they camped there for about year. Moses informed them that they would tarry there until they constructed the Tabernacle. It was for this reason that, as I will explain,157See I.E. on Ex. 25:5. Israel brought out acacia wood from Egypt. The festival of booths was established in commemoration of the booths that Israel made there, for Scripture states, that your generations may know that I made the children of Israel to dwell in booths when I brought them out of the land of Egypt (Lev. 23:43). How can one maintain that Israel dwelt in clouds?158According to Rabbi Ishmael the booths spoken of in Lev. 23:43 refer to the “clouds of glory.” Cf. Sukkah 34:4. I.E. disagrees. For the booths do not resemble clouds.159For an explanation of Rabbi Ishmael’s opinion see Nahmanides on Lev. 24:43. I will yet explain why the festival of Sukkot is observed in the seventh month.160See I.E. on Lev. 23:43. When the Tabernacle was erected God descended upon it in a pillar of cloud, as it is clearly written, and there was fire therein by night (Ex. 40:38). When the cloud journeyed the children of Israel went onward (Ex. 40:36). It is because of this that Scripture reads, and thou goest before them, in a pillar of cloud by day (Num. 14:14). There were thus two interchanging pillars161A pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night. over the Tabernacle. If the statement to the effect that there were seven interchanging pillars over the Tabernacle162Mekhilta, Be-Shallach 1. is based on tradition, then we will rely on tradition and set aside our own opinions.

INTO THE WILDERNESS OF SHUR. This is the very wilderness of Etham.163See I.E. on Ex. 13:20. I.E. insists that the wilderness of Shur is to be identified with the wilderness of Etham because he wants to harmonize verses 22 and 23 with Num. 33:8. For the latter states, and (Israel) passed through the midst of the sea into the wilderness; and they went three days’ journey in the wilderness of Etham, and pitched in Marah. See I.E.’s comments on verse 23. Perhaps there were two cities in the wilderness that were so called.164One named Shur and the other Etham. The wilderness was named after these cities. At times it is called after one, at other times after the other. Or the wilderness had two names.165Shur and Etham. And they went three days in the wilderness, the reference being to the wilderness of Shur, is proof of this.166That the desert had two names, Shur and Etham. For, the line and they went three days in the wilderness (of Shur) is parallel to and they went three days’ journey in the wilderness of Etham (Num. 33:8). Therefore to indicate this167That the desert spoken of is Shur. the bet of ba-midbar (in the wilderness), which precedes and found no water, was vocalized for emphasis with a pattach.168Which indicates the subject, i.e., the wilderness mentioned earlier in the verse, namely, the wilderness of Shur. Cf. Vat. Ebr. 38.

AND WHEN THEY CAME TO MARAH. It is elsewhere written, And they journeyed from the Red Sea (Num. 33:11). The latter is similar to And Moses led Israel onward from the Red Sea,169In other words, Num. 33:11 and Ex. 15:22 refer to the same event. (and they went out into the wilderness of Shur and came to Marah) (v. 22). We similarly find, and they went three days’ journey in the wilderness of Etham, and pitched in Marah (Num. 33:8).170Thus the wilderness of Shur is to be identified with the wilderness of Etham.

THEREFORE THE NAME OF IT WAS CALLED MARAH.171Literally, Therefore he called the name of it Marah. The question is who? Hence I.E.’s comment. Someone called it Marah.172The verse is abridged. Who was born unto Levi in Egypt (Num. 26:29)173Literally: whom she bore unto Levi. Here too the subject is missing and the verse should be interpreted as whom someone bore unto Levi. is similar.

AND THE PEOPLE MURMURED. Va-yillonu (murmured) is a nifal. It is similar to ve-yikkonu (shall be established)174Which is a nifal and is similarly vocalized. in And thy thoughts shall be established (Prov. 16:3), which comes from the same root as nakhonu (prepared) (Prov. 19:29).175The root of which is kaf, vav, nun. Similarly, the root of va-yillonu is lamed, vav, nun. It comes from a double root176A two-letter root. That is, its root is lamed, vav, nun. However, the vav is usually dropped in the conjugation. Hence it appears to have only two letters (Weiser, Krinsky). or from a root in which the middle letter is missing.177That is, its root may be described as a double root or as a root in which the middle letter is dropped. If it came from a root which begins with a nun178Nun, lamed, nun. I.E. makes this point because there is a dagesh in the lamed. Now one might argue that the dagesh in the lamed is not the dagesh of the nifal conjugation but rather a dagesh that compensates for a missing nun, as in va-yippelu from the root nun, peh, lamed. it would have followed the paradigm of va-yiggashu (came near) (Gen. 45:4).179That is, it would have been conjugated as a root whose first letter is a nun. However, it is not. Hence it has to be taken as an ayin vav in the nifal.

AND HE CRIED UNTO THE LORD; AND THE LORD SHOWED HIM A TREE. We do not know what type of tree this was.180Contrary to the rabbis in the Midrash who identify the tree as a willow, olive, pomegranate, or date tree. See Mekhilta, Be-Shallach 1; Yalkut Shimoni on Ex. 15:25. What happened can only be described as a miracle. If the waters were stationary181If we knew for a fact that Scripture deals with water gathered in a pool or the like. then we would say that they were medicinally sweetened.182However, it is equally possible that our text deals with running water. In the latter case we can’t maintain that the waters were medicinally sweetened because what was healed moved on and new bitter water replaced it. What the sages said is correct.183That it was a miracle. See Yalkut Shimoni on Ex. 15:25.
THERE HE MADE FOR THEM. God184He might be taken to refer to Moses, hence I.E.’s comment. for Israel.
A STATUTE AND AN ORDINANCE. To discipline them and to instruct them.

[AND THERE HE PROVED THEM.] This is to be understood in the manner of for the Lord your God putteth you to proof, to know whether ye do love the Lord your God with all you heart and with all your soul (Deut. 13:4). Scripture similarly states, And He afflicted thee,185This refers to the lack of water which the Israelites suffered. and suffered thee to hunger (Deut. 8:3); and that He might prove thee, to do thee good at thy latter end (Deut. 8:16),186Which is preceded by that He might afflict thee. that is, to do good to those who did not murmur against Moses.187To those who showed their love for God by not murmuring against Moses.

AND HE SAID: IF THOU WILT DILIGENTLY HEARKEN. I have already noted that when the word shema (hearken) is followed by a lamed188As in our verse where the word le-kol (to the voice of) follows shamo’a tishma (diligently hearken). or a bet it does not mean to hear the words being spoken but rather to understand the subject which is being verbalized. Shema in our verse thus means to understand what the Lord commands us to do.
AND WILT DO THAT WHICH IS RIGHT IN HIS EYES. This refers to the positive commandments.
AND WILT GIVE EAR TO HIS COMMANDMENTS. To understand what the negative commandments consist of.

AND KEEP ALL HIS STATUTES. Not to violate them. Compare, And ye shall not walk in the statutes189J.P.S. renders customs. of the nation (Lev. 20:23). It is God’s statute not to imitate the practices of the nations.190In other words, the meaning of and keep all his statutes is: and you will not imitate the practices of the nations.

[NONE OF THE DISEASES.] Its meaning is, the diseases you should remember. For you saw with your own eyes the diseases, the strokes, and the plagues which I put upon the Egyptians because they rebelled against Me. Now if you will hearken to My statutes you will be saved from these plagues, for I will not do to you what I did to them. Additionally, you have no need of a physician for I am the Lord that healeth thee from all disease which I have decreed to be upon the earth. I will heal you as I healed the bitter waters which no physician has the ability to heal. Behold, what happened at Marah was the opposite of what occurred when the first plague struck, for the waters of the Nile were sweet but the Egyptians could not drink from them.191After the first plague struck. However, here192At Marah. the bitter waters turned sweet. You should therefore love the Lord and keep yourself from rebelling against Him, for He will do good for you.

AND THEY CAME TO ELIM. Saadiah Gaon says there were seventy species of palm trees there.193Seventy palm trees would not suffice for a such a large population. Hence Saadiah Gaon says that there were 70 species of palm trees there, each species consisting of numerous trees. Others added, for each and every tribe.194There were 70 types of palm trees for every tribe. Others said, for each and every person.195There were 70 palm trees per person. However, there is no need for these interpretations, for the springs of water, of which there were twelve, and the seventy palm trees did not come into being now because of Israel.196There is thus no reason to assume that Israel found a forest of palm trees in the wilderness vast enough to feed a large nation. Additionally, this was not the time for the ripening of palms.197In other words, there are no dates on the palm trees in the month of Iyyar. Thus Scripture does not imply that Israel ate from the palm trees. Hence there is no reason to exaggerate their number. I believe that Israel tarried in Marah for only one day198I.E. offers no proof for this. He may base his opinion on the fact that Scripture does not note here that Israel camped in Marah. (However, Scripture does so in Num. 33:8). It rather mentions Marah as a place that Israel passed by on the way to Elim. and that they stayed in Elim for about twenty days.199Israel journeyed from Elim on the 15th of Iyyar (16:1). There are 24 days from the 21st of Nisan, when Israel crossed the Red Sea, to the 15th of Iyyar. Israel journeyed for three days without water (v. 22) and spent one day at Marah. Hence they spent about 20 days at Elim. Scripture therefore says, and they encamped there by the waters.200To emphasize that their main camp at this time was at Elim. The next verse therefore informs us that Israel journeyed from Elim on the fifteenth day of the second month.201That is, where they spent the longest period of time from the crossing of the Red Sea up to this point. Now Israel camped in the following four places202Listed in Num. 8:12-16. in fifteen days:203There are 15 days from the 15th of Iyyar until the first of Sivan, when Israel came to Sinai. the wilderness of Sinai,204This should be emended to read Sin, Israel’s first stop on the way to Sinai. If it is not emended then I.E. lists Israel final destination first. Dophkah, Alush, and Rephidim, for they came to the desert of Sinai at the beginning of the third month.205See I.E. on Ex. 19:1. Scripture mentions the palm trees to let us know that contrary to the waters of Marah the waters here were sweet, for palm trees cannot flourish in a land of bitter waters.206I.e., contrary to the opinion of the commentaries quoted earlier, Scripture does not mention the palm trees to inform us that Israel ate of them.

AND THEY TOOK THEIR JOURNEY. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that the reason Scripture mentions the fifteenth day of the second month is to inform us that Israel left Egypt on the fifth day of the week.1Saadiah’s reasoning is explained in what follows. Now, the first day of Nisan fell on a Thursday2If we assume that Israel left Egypt on a Thursday then the first day of Nisan had to fall on a Thursday, as Israel left Egypt on the 15th of Nisan. and Iyyar on a Friday and on a Sabbath.3Rosh Chodesh (new moon) Iyyar fell on Friday and Saturday, as it does whenever the 15th of Nisan falls on a Thursday. Friday was the 30th of Nisan and Saturday the first day of Iyyar. Israel came to the wilderness of Sin4On the 15th day of the second month (v. 1). on a Sabbath5For the manna started to fall on a Sunday (see further in I.E.’s comment on this verse). Saadiah Gaon assumes that the manna began to fall on the day following Israel’s arrival in the wilderness of Sin. This is crucial for the establishment of Thursday as the day of the Exodus. For if the 15th of Iyyar fell on a Saturday, then the 15th of Nisan had to fall on a Thursday. Incidentally, this last happened in 1989. and complained6That they were starving (v. 3). upon camping. Moses then told them that they would eat meat at even7Of that day. and that manna would come down in the morning.8That is, on the following morning. Now it is logical to assume that the manna first came down on a Sunday because Scripture states, And it shall come to pass on the sixth day (v. 5), the reference being to the sixth day of the week and the sixth day from the day on which the manna began to descend.9When Scripture says, and it shall come to pass on the sixth day (v. 5) it means: and it shall come to pass on the sixth day from the day that the manna begins to fall. For after creation, with the exception of the Sabbath, Scripture does not refer to days of the week (Filwarg). It so happened that the sixth day fell on a Friday (see v. 23). We will accept that which the Gaon says because of tradition,10According to Talmudic tradition the Israelites left Egypt on a Thursday. See Sabbath 87b. not because of his explanation, for who told the Gaon that the manna came down on the morning following the coming of the Israelites to the wilderness of Sin?11Nowhere does Scripture say this. The Israelites may have camped there for four or more days12Scripture does not state that the Israelites started to complain that they lacked food immediately upon arriving in Sin. The Israelites could have come to Sin on a day other than the Sabbath. They could have stayed there a few days and then started to complain on a Sabbath about a lack of food. There is thus no proof that the 15th of Iyyar fell on a Saturday. Hence there is no proof that the Exodus took place on a Thursday. but the manna started to come down on Sunday. The latter is so because we start the count13In order to get the number six mentioned in verses 5 and 22. from the day that the manna began to fall,14Thus if the sixth day from the start of the manna falling was a Friday (v. 22), the first day was a Sunday. for all the nations rely on Israel with regard to this numeration.15That the week ends on the Sabbath and the days are numbered from it. There can thus be no doubt that the manna started to fall on a Sunday. Observe, the Christians named the days of the week after the stars.16Sunday, Monday, and the like. However, they did not do the same with the Sabbath day. The first five days of the week in Arabic are numbered. The sixth day is called al juma17The day of gathering. because it is the most honored day of the week for the Arabs and they congregate on this day. The Arabs refer to the day of shabbat as sabbat because the shin and samekh interchange in their script. They learned this18That the week ends with the Sabbath. from the Israelites. Behold, the natives of India, who do not have the belief of six days of creation, begin the week on Wednesday because the sun is the star of that day and according to their beliefs it rules over them.

AND THE WHOLE CONGREGATION OF THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL MURMURED. The Israelites murmured only against Moses at the waters of Marah (Ex. 15:23)19In contrast to Sin, where they murmured against Moses and Aaron. because it was he alone who led Israel onward.20From the Red Sea to Marah. See Ex. 15:22. Only a part of Israel and not the whole nation complained.21At Marah. Scripture therefore reads, And the people22That is, some of the people murmured. However, here at Sin all the people murmured. murmured against Moses (Ex. 15:24). However, in the wilderness of Sin we find that Scripture states, And the whole congregation of the children of Israel murmured against Moses and against Aaron because both of them had brought them out of the land of Egypt. In Marah they complained because of the water. However, they now complained about a lack of bread and meat because they had already consumed most of their cattle, for thirty days had passed since they left Egypt. A congregation as large as Israel could only buy food at very great expense.23From the surrounding nations. For demand drove the price up. Hence they complained against Moses and Aaron.
BEHOLD, I WILL CAUSE TO RAIN BREAD FROM HEAVEN. The bread will come down like rain from the sky.

[BREAD.] The word lechem (bread) means food. It is found used for bread itself and also for meat, as in lechem isheh (food of the offering made by fire) (Lev. 3:11). It is also used for fruit, as in Let us destroy the tree with the fruit thereof (be-lachmo) (Jer. 11:19).
[THAT I MAY PROVE THEM.] For they will daily need Me.
[TWICE.] The meaning of mishneh (twice) is two omers per person, for it is so written.24In verse 22.

AND MOSES AND AARON SAID. Moses and Aaron said, then shall ye know that the Lord hath brought you out from the land of Egypt because the Israelites charged, for ye have brought us forth into this wilderness (v. 3). They answered, “Observe, we will perform two signs for you, one at the evening of this very day25The coming of the quail. and one on the morning of the morrow26The appearance of the manna. so that you will know that the Lord hath brought you out from the land of Egypt.” Scripture should have read: at even and in the morning ye shall know27That the Lord hath brought you out of the land of Egypt. because and in the morning28Which opens the next verse. is not connected to then ye shall see the glory of the Lord.29Which follows it, but rather to the previous verse. The meaning of our verse is: At even, then ye shall know that the Lord hath brought you out from the land of Egypt. Similarly in the morning. For as Scripture goes on to say,30In verse 10. Israel saw God’s glory on that very day.
AND IN THE MORNING. I have already explained this.31That is, that and in the morning is not connected to what follows but rather to what comes before. See I.E.’s comments on the previous verse.

FOR THAT HE HATH HEARD YOUR MURMURINGS. This is connected to then ye shall see the glory of the Lord.32Rather than to and in the morning. Our verse is to be understood as follows: Ye shall see the glory of the Lord for He hath heard your murmurings against the Lord.
AND WHAT ARE WE. What can we do? We only did what we were commanded to do. The word ve-nachnu (and we) is missing an alef.33The usual form is va-anachnu.
AND MOSES SAID. Moses now told them what the two signs34Alluded to in verses 6 and 7. would consist of.
COME NEAR BEFORE THE LORD. Turn35It appears from the next verse that they did not actually go out into the wilderness, hence I.E.’s comment. to the wilderness.36Where Moses’ tent was located.
AND IT CAME TO PASS. It became clear to them that when Aaron spoke to them, they came near before the Lord. The cloud came immediately and God’s glory was seen in it.
AND THE LORD SPOKE. The Israelites saw that Moses went to the glory of the Lord and spoke to God.

I HAVE HEARD. The word telunnot is irregular in that its nun has a dagesh.37Telunnot is vocalized with a shuruk. A dagesh is not usually placed in a letter which follows a shuruk. This prophecy38That God would give them flesh to eat in the evening and bread in the morning. is repeated.39That is, it is stated for a second time in our verse. Scripture had already noted,40In verse 8. the Lord shall give you in the evening flesh to eat, and in the morning bread to the full. It was only repeated41That God revealed Himself a second time to Moses. so that Israel would see the glory of the Lord.42Speaking to Moses.

[AT DUSK.] The term ben ha-arbayim means, as I have already explained, at dusk.43See I.E. on Ex. 12:6. This verse proves my interpretation of and in the morning, then ye shall see the glory of God. (v. 7).44That these two clauses are not connected to each other. See I.E. on verses 6 and 7. For the verse states, At dusk ye shall eat flesh, and in the morning ye shall be filled with bread.45Rather than, and in the morning ye shall see the glory of God.
AND IT CAME TO PASS AT EVEN. At the end of that very day.
THAT THE QUAILS CAME UP. Possibly from the direction of the sea.46Came up indicates that they came from the sea. Compare, Come ye up from the Jordan (Josh. 4:17) (Filwarg).

A LAYER OF DEW. Shikhvat (a layer) is similar to yashkiv (bring down) in Or who can bring down (yashkiv) the bottles of heaven (Job 38:37).47Translated according to I.E. They both come from the root shin, kaf, bet. It means a descent.48According to I.E. shikhvat ha-tal (a layer of dew) means a dew fall. Scripture elsewhere writes, u-veredet ha-tal (And when the dew descended)49Translated according to I.E. (Num. 11:9). May the name of Chivi50See I.E. on Ex. 14:27 and the notes thereto. rot for saying that the manna is to be identified with what is known in the Persian tongue as tarnagbin, in Arabic as man, and in the vernacular as manna. There are many questions raised against him. First of all, no manna falls today in the wilderness of Sinai,51If the Biblical manna is to be identified as the substance mentioned by Chivi then it should still be found in Sinai today. It is not. Therefore it was not there in the days of Moses. for we know the location of the mountain.52Mount Sinai. Hence we can ascertain that no manna falls there today. Now I have seen that which resembles manna in the kingdom of Al tzakir,53This place cannot be identified. and it only comes down in Nisan and Iyyar and in no other months.54Whereas the manna appeared daily for 40 years. Additionally, if you place it in the sun it does not melt.55Whereas the manna did. See verse 21. Furthermore, it does not rot in the evening.56Whereas the manna did. See verse 20. Moreover, it is not very hard and one does not have to grind it in a pestle57As one had to do with the manna. See Num. 11:8. if one wants to make cakes out of it. Furthermore, it melts when placed upon the tongue.58Which I.E. assumes the manna did not. If it did Scripture would have informed us of this. In addition, it does not satisfy59Which the manna did. because it does not produce good blood. It is only used as a medical ingredient.60It cannot serve as food. Furthermore, a double portion of manna came down on Friday.61Which shows that it is not the substance spoken of by Chivi. Moreover, the manna did not come down on the Sabbath. Furthermore, the manna came down wherever Israel camped.62It came down only in the places where Israel camped. When Israel moved on, it ceased to appear there. Thus it cannot be identified with the substance mentioned by Chivi. In addition, the manna crossed over the Jordan with the Israelites and did not cease to descend, according to the plain meaning of Scripture, until half the month of Nisan,63However, after the 15th of Nisan it ceased to come down. It thus cannot be identified with the substance mentioned by Chivi. had passed.

AND WHEN THE LAYER OF DEW WAS GONE UP. The meaning of va-ta’al (was gone up)64From the root ayin, lamed, heh (to go up). is ceased.65The usual meaning of va-ta’al is, went up, hence I.E.’s comment. It is similar to alah (went up) in Then defiledst thou it — my couch went up (alah) (Gen. 49:4).66Translated literally. The meaning of the latter verse is: from the time that you defiled my couch it was removed from me and ceased to function.67Thus Gen. 49:4 should be translated: Then defildedst thou it — my couch was removed. Cf. I.E. on Gen. 49:4. Ta’aleni (take me away)68Literally, bring me up. in O my God, take me not away in the midst of my days (Ps. 102:25) is similar. The dew came down first to clean the earth. When the dew was gone the manna descended. The latter69Unmentioned here. is clearly written,70In the book of Numbers. viz., And when the dew fell upon the camp in the night, the manna fell upon it (Num. 11:9).

A FINE, SCALE-LIKE THING. Mechuspas (scale-like thing) means round shaped. It has no cognate.71The word is not found again in Scripture. The one who says72Rashi, interpreting Onkelos. According to Rashi mechuspas means uncovered; that is, the manna was similar to a peeled seed (Ralbag). that mechuspas is similar to machsof (uncovering) (Gen. 30:37),73Translated according to I.E. and Rashi. which is spelled with a sin,74Whereas mechuspas is spelled with a samekh. However, the latter presents no problem, for the sin and the samekh interchange. is incorrect. For it is the manner of Hebrew to double the first and second root letters,75When it makes a quadriliteral out of a three-letter root. as in the word yafyafita (thou art fairer)76From the root yod, feh, heh. (Ps. 45:3), or to double the second and third stem letters, as in the word yerakrak (greenish)77From the root yod, resh, kof. (Lev. 13:49), or to double only the third stem letter, as in sagrir (a very rainy day)78From the root samekh, gimel, resh. (Prov. 27:15). However, we never find the second root letter79That is, only the second root letter. doubled80As it would be if mechuspas came from the same root as machsof, for the root of machsof is chet, sin, feh. except for instances when the heh81That is, in words that end in heh. is silent, as in hagigi (my meditation)82From the root heh, gimel, heh. (Ps. 5:2) in which the gimel appears to be a third root letter after the heh is dropped.83When we look at the word hagigi it appears to come from the root heh, gimel, gimel, not heh, gimel, heh with the gimel doubled. Hence it was doubled. However, we do not find the middle root letters to be doubled in words where all root letters are sounded.84As they are in the root chet, sin, peh. Hence mechuspas cannot be derived from that root.

AND WHEN THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL SAW IT. Rabbi Solomon85Rashi. However, this comment is not found in Rashi but in Rashbam. I.E. most probably quoted from memory and erred. Krinsky cites an opinion that I.E. had an early edition of Rashi which had this interpretation and that Rashi later changed his mind and omitted it from subsequent editions. says that the meaning of man hu (what is it) in Arabic is, what is it? However, someone misinformed him, because the Arabic phrase for “what is it” is mah huwi, as the term man is used in Arabic exclusively in reference to people. The way to explain man is to note that it comes from the same root as minnah (appointed) in who hath appointed your food and your drink (Dan. 1:10).86Thus man hu means: it is something appointed (for us); it is a food allotment set aside for us.

[AND MOSES SAID UNTO THEM.] Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that we know that the Torah is not written in chronological order. Thus the meaning of And Moses said unto them is: and Moses had previously said unto them.87If Moses had not first said, this is the bread which the Lord hath given you to eat, Israel would not have known that the substance on the ground was their food allotment. There are many similar instances.88Where the vav introduces a pluperfect. See I.E. on Gen. 1:9. Indeed, we find that Scripture states in this very portion, and it bred worms and rotted, the meaning of which is: and it bred worms and had previously rotted.89According to I.E. if it had not rotted first it would not have bred worms. The sequence of events thus was: it rotted and as a result bred worms. Indeed, Scripture states, and it did not rot, neither was there any worm in it (v. 24).90We thus see that rotting precedes the breeding of worms. Scripture delayed reporting the words of Moses91That is, it is the bread which the Lord hath given you to eat is out of sequence. See note 87. because it had to elaborate and go on to say, This is the thing which the Lord hath commanded, etc. (v. 16).92In other words, Scripture wanted to present all the words that Moses spoke at that time in one unit.

[GATHER YE OF IT EVERY MAN ACCORDING TO HIS EATING.] This was to be done by logical estimate.93Every man according to his eating implies that one is to estimate how much the person for whom one is gathering will eat. I.E. says that this part of the verse refers to minors. An omer for a head was for someone fully grown, for minors gather according to how much they consume.94That is, every man according to his eating.

AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL DID SO. According to the plain meaning of the text some gathered more and some less according to the number of people in their tents. However, our sages said that our verse speaks of a miracle.95Some gathered more and some gathered less. Nevertheless, when they came home and measured what they had gathered they found that they had gathered an omer per person. Yoma 75a. Also Rashi.

AND WHEN THEY DID METE IT WITH AN OMER. Each one found that he had the amount that he had estimated.96When they gathered the manna they did not use a measure but collected by estimation. When they came home they measured the amount gathered and it came to an omer per head. In common with the other commentaries, such as Rashi and Rashbam, I.E. explains that verse 17 describes what Israel did in the field, and verse 18 what they found to be the case at home, hence his interpretation.

AND MOSES SAID UNTO THEM: LET NO MAN LEAVE OF IT TILL THE MORNING. Its meaning is, do not leave some of the manna over to eat on the next morning. Rather, trust in the Lord that it will descend on the following day. There was no command to eat the entire omer.97Let no man leave of it till the morning could conceivably be interpreted as a command to consume the entire omer, hence I.E.’s comment. However, that which a person did not consume was to be thrown outside of his tent.

NOTWITHSTANDING THEY HEARKENED NOT UNTO MOSES. The word anashim (some of them) is connected to Notwithstanding they hearkened not unto Moses.98Our verse is to be interpreted as if written: Notwithstanding, some of them hearkened not unto Moses but left of it until morning. They were few in number.99That is, those who did not hearken unto Moses. Hence ve-lo shame’u (they hearkened not) does not refer to alehem (unto them) in the previous verse, which refers to all of Israel, but rather to anashim (some of them) which follows (Filwarg). Rabbi Merinus100See notes on Ex. 1:10. says that va-yarum (and it bred worms) comes from the same root as rimmah (worms).101From the root resh, mem, mem. Hence va-yarum literally means: and it wormed; i.e., it bred worms.
AND THEY GATHERED IT MORNING BY MORNING. The meaning of ve-cham ha-shemesh (and as the sun waxed hot) is: and when the day waxed hot. For the sun does not wax hot.
IT MELTED. Namas (melted) comes from a double root102Mem, samekh, samekh. and is in the nifal.

AND IT CAME TO PASS. More than the usual amount of manna descended on this day, as Scripture goes on to note. Israel gathered twice as much food on this day because Moses had commanded them to do so.103Not because they happened to find twice as much on the ground. However, they did not know why.104Moses commanded them to gather twice as much manna on this day. Also,105Aside from merely assuming that Israel gathered twice as much manna because Moses told them to, we have an indication from Scripture that this indeed was the case. Scripture states, they gathered, not they found.106Which shows that they deliberately gathered twice as much. They would only do so at the command of Moses. The rulers of the congregation came and told Moses that Israel did as he commanded them. They then asked Moses: What should be done with the extra portion? Why did he command them to gather twice as much food?107On this day. How could they consume such a large amount of food?

AND HE SAID UNTO THEM. God has already told me that you are obligated to rest tomorrow and not do any work including the preparation of food,108Hence you are to gather a double portion of manna on the sixth day. for tomorrow is a Sabbath day unto the Lord. This is God’s day109Compare, today is a sabbath unto the Lord (v. 25). because He rested from all His work on the seventh day. We find the same with regard to the Sabbatical year, viz., then shall the land keep a sabbath unto the Lord (Lev. 25:2).

[SABBATH.] The word shabbat is grammatically difficult. It does not belong in the paradigm of gannav (thief)110In which it appears to belong. because the tav of shabbat is a feminine suffix,111Whereas gannav is masculine. as is proven by the phrase shabbat hi la-Adonai (it is a sabbath unto the Lord) (Lev. 23:3).112Hi (it; literally, she) is a feminine pronoun. Hence the word shabbat must be feminine. The word shabbat113From the root shin, bet, tav. is a noun meaning cessation.114That is, cessation from work. The following is its grammatical explanation. The word should have been spelled and vocalized shabbetet115Vocalized pattach, segol, segol. according to the paradigm of dalleket (inflammation) (Deut. 28:22). When one of the tavs116The root tav. was dropped the bet was vocalized with a kamatz117Literally, a pattach. I.E. refers to the kamatz as a pattach a number of times in his commentary on Exodus. See I.E. on Ex. 15:18. to indicate that the word is feminine. It is the same, as I will explain, with the word achat (one).118See I.E. on Ex. 26:8. Also Sefer Ha-Tzachot 4.

[BAKE.] The word efu (bake) is irregular. It should have followed the paradigm of asu (do).119It should have been vocalized afu, as is the rule for words in the kal imperative which begin with a silent letter. Behold, Moses told the rulers of the congregation120In this verse. what they should do.121With the extra portion of manna.

BAKE THAT WHICH YE WILL BAKE. Bake as you normally do so that you will have what to eat on this day. And see the that which ye will seethe has a similar meaning.122That is, seethe as you normally seethe so that you will have what to eat on this day. Behold, prepare and cook all this according to your heart’s desire from one omer and eat as much as you need.123And leave over the second omer for the morning.

AND ALL THAT REMAINETH. Lay it up till the morning and I will tell you what to do.124With the second omer. I.E. held that the Israelites ate the second omer uncooked. Now Moses did not inform them that no manna would descend on the Sabbath day. It was only in the morning that he revealed this secret to them

AND MOSES SAID. Many lacking in faith erred because of this verse and said that a person is obligated to keep the Sabbath day plus the night which follows it,125Not the night before, as it is according to normative halakha. I.E. composed his Sefer Ha-Shabbat to refute this view. See Introduction to Vol. 1, p. XIX. because Moses said, for to-day and not the night before is a sabbath unto the Lord. Additionally, Moses said, Tomorrow is a solemn rest (v. 23).126He did not say this evening. They interpreted, in accordance with their view, And there was evening and there was morning one day (Gen. 1:5) to mean that the first day was not finished until the morning of the second day.127Began. However, they spoke incorrectly. As I have already made mention to you, Moses spoke to Israel only in accordance with their practice. Now the manner of the land of the uncircumcised128Europe, where I.E. wrote his commentary. with regard to their food, their dress, their buildings, and affairs is not the same as that of the Land of Israel. It is the practice in the Land of Israel that no one bakes, cooks, or does any other work, both in summer or winter, at any time but during the day.129Whereas in Europe people work at night. Hence Moses said, Tomorrow is a solemn rest.130He did not say, “This evening is a solemn rest,” because people in any case did not do any work in the evening. However, if the Torah had been written in Europe Moses would have said, “This evening is a solemn rest.” Now pay close attention to understand the stupidity of those who explain and there was evening and there was morning in the manner which I noted above. For Scripture says, And God called the light day (Gen. 1:8), the reference being from the time that the sun rises until the time that it sets; and to the darkness He called night, the reference being from the time that the sun sets until the time that it rises. The night is thus the opposite of day, as the darkness is the opposite of the light. This being the case, how can Scripture refer to the evening, which commences at the time that the sun sets and lasts until the morning, as “day” when it is then night? Behold, concerning such people Scripture states, They change the night into day (Job 17:12). Now note that the word day is used in Hebrew in two ways. I have already mentioned one of them, viz., as long as the light of the sun is over any place on the earth. Therefore Scripture states, three days, night and day (Esth. 4:16) and, and night and day (Gen. 8:22). Now if the measure of the day includes the night in it, why mention night?131In Esth. 4:16 and Gen. 8:22. It is also incorrect from the point of view of the science of linguistics132Aside from the Biblical texts we have additional proof from linguistics that day cannot refer to nighttime. for a noun to refer to two things which are the opposite of each other.133Hence day cannot refer to nighttime. The word day is used secondarily in the sense of close or far-off time, as in on the day that I smote all the first-born in the land of Egypt (Num. 3:13); thou art to pass over the Jordan this day (Deut. 9:1); and cast them into another land, as it is this day (Deut. 29:27); And it shall come to pass in that day (Is. 7:21). There are many other similar instances. Now let us leave all these things aside and seek, as I have said, only after the day of the Torah,134That is, accept the fact that day begins at sunrise and ends at sunset. for our years are not established according to the movement of the sun and moon but rather according to what the Bet Din decrees.135Whereas each individual can establish when it is day by observing when the sun rises and sets. Now we find that Scripture states, Seven days shall ye eat unleavened bread (Ex. 12:15). Scripture then goes on to explain that this number136Of days, i.e., the seven days when unleavened bread is to be eaten. This shows, contra the sectarians, that the evening is connected to the day that follows. begins on the evening of the fourteenth of the first month (Ex. 12:18). Scripture also states, from even unto even, shall ye keep your sabbath (Lev. 23:32).137The Day of Atonement. Furthermore, a man who has a seminal emission during the night or day, for it is so written, viz., that which chanceth him by night (Deut. 23:11), does not become “clean” until sunset, which is the end of the first day.138Following the emission or the day on which the emission occurred. Now if it were so,139As the sectarians maintain, that the night following the day is considered part of the previous day. namely, that the first day ends on the morning of the next day,140Following a seminal emission. then it is only fit for the one who experienced an emission to immerse himself in the morning.141Following an emission. For if we say that the day and the night which follows it make up one day then the one who experienced an emission142During the day. will be “unclean” for half a day143That is, till evening when he immerses himself. and clean for half a day.144From evening till the next morning. And one who experienced an emission at the beginning of the night will be unclean for half of a day that passed145For the night belongs to the previous day. and also for half of the coming day.146For he immerses himself the following evening. This is the opinion of those who err.147As noted, however, it is illogical. I have already explained to you the meaning of and there was evening and there was morning (Gen. 1:5) in its place.148See I.E. on Gen. 1:5. There he explains and there was evening and there was morning not as meaning that the day came to a close at morning, but rather as meaning that the evening and the morning of the first day came.

AND MOSES SAID. Moses now explained to them what they should do with the additional manna which was laid up, and he revealed to them its secret, that they would not find it this day because it did not come down.
SIX DAYS SHALL YE GATHER IT. It shall always be as it is now for as long as you are in the wilderness; that is, ye shall gather it for six days but on the seventh no manna shall come down.

[IN IT THERE SHALL BE NONE.] The word bo (in it) is added for additional clarification. It is similar to but of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat of it (Gen. 2:17).149Of it is inserted for clarification. See I.E. on Gen. 2:7.
AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE SEVENTH DAY. Of the manna’s appearance.150For the manna started to come down on a Sunday. See I.E.’s comments on verse 1.
THAT THERE WENT OUT…TO GATHER. To see whether Moses’ words would stand up.

AND THE LORD SAID UNTO MOSES. Moses was Israel’s representative.151I.E.’s point is that the words How long refuse ye to keep My commandments, etc., although spoken to Moses, were directed at Israel. The meaning of our verse is: the Lord said unto Moses, tell the following to the Israelites.
[MY COMMANDMENTS.] This was said in reference to the people who left some of the manna over until the morning.152Verse 20.

[MY LAWS.]153Hebrew, torotai. For God taught them the reason for the Sabbath.154I.E. explains torotai to mean my teachings, that is, my teachings concerning the Sabbath, namely, that it is God’s day and manna would not fall on it. They therefore gathered twice as much bread on the sixth day. There is a reason why Scripture employs the plural, namely, My commandments and My laws.155When in reality one command and one teaching were violated. All the commandments and laws are, beyond any doubt, to be taken literally. However, they have secret meanings pertaining to the soul that only the enlightened can understand. Thus every commandment has two meanings.156Thus when one violates a commandment one disregards its obvious meaning plus its secret meaning, hence the use of the plural commandments and laws in our verse.

SEE. Its meaning is: see the wonder that the Lord will perform for you so that it shall become clear to you that God commanded you to rest as He rested when He made all things in the beginning. God is therefore permitting twice as much manna to come down today as normally comes down every day.
ABIDE YE EVERY MAN IN HIS PLACE. In one’s tent.

[LET NO MAN GO OUT OF HIS PLACE.] It meaning is: let no man go out of his place on the seventh day to gather manna as the men who went out to gather did.157Contra the Karaites, who took this verse to mean that one is not permitted to leave one’s house on the Sabbath.
SO THE PEOPLE RESTED. Scripture tells us that from that day on, no man went out on the Sabbath to gather.158Manna.
AND THE HOUSE OF ISRAEL CALLED THE NAME THEREOF MANNA. Behold, Scripture previously noted the miracles associated with the manna.159Ex. 16:15-30. It now turns to relate its praises.

[AND IT WAS LIKE CORIANDER SEED, WHITE.] Some say that gad (coriander) refers to kosbarta, in Arabic, kusbar. Others say that it means mustard. However, I do not know, as it is not found in any other context save in reference to the manna. The same is the case with the word tzappichat (wafers), which Saadiah Gaon says means an unleavened wafer. Now when the manna was eaten as it was when it came down, it had the taste of a wafer made with honey. However, when cooked it had the taste of a cake baked in oil (Num. 11:8). Scripture mentions these two delicacies.160However, when prepared in other ways it had other tastes.

AND MOSES SAID. This chapter should have followed the account of the construction of the Tabernacle.161Our verse states, and lay it (the jar of manna) up before the Lord. This implies that the Tabernacle was in existence, as before the Lord means before the ark (v. 33). Hence the command to set aside a jar of manna was not given when the manna stated to fall but later, after the construction of the Tabernacle. It was placed here to relate the miracle of the manna162That was placed in the jar. lasting for generations.163Since Scripture here mentions the miracle associated with the manna it relates this miracle as well. Now Moses told this to Israel.164In the name of God. He therefore said, wherewith I fed you.165Our verse reads, that they may see the bread wherewith I fed you. Prima facie, our verse should read: that they may see the bread wherewith I fed them. Hence I.E. points out that when Moses spoke to Israel he used the second person. Thus our verse reads, I fed you.
A JAR. A clay or copper utensil. The word is not found elsewhere.
[BEFORE THE LORD.] Its meaning is, before the divine glory which is upon the cherubim.

AS THE LORD COMMANDED MOSES. Scripture here explains that before the Lord means: before the Testimony, the reference being to the ark. The ark is referred to as the Ark of the Testimony because of the tablets of the covenant166Also referred to as the tables of testimony. See Ex. 32:15. that were in it.

AND THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL. This miracle167That the manna accompanied Israel for forty years. was greater than all the other miracles that were done via Moses, for many miracles were connected with the manna. These miracles, unlike all other wonders, lasted for forty years.

[UNTIL THEY CAME TO A LAND INHABITED.] Scripture says this for they were in the wilderness, in a land that no man passed through (Jer. 2:6).168Translated according to I.E. Now once Israel crossed the Jordan they ate the grain that they found there.169See Josh. 5:11. The reason Scripture found it necessary to say, they did eat the manna, until they came unto the borders of the land of Canaan is that the manna accompanied them until they came to Gilgal,170Josh. 5:10. which lies on the border of the land of Canaan. The manna then ceased to fall, for now they had new grain.
NOW AN OMER IS THE TENTH PART OF AN EPHAH. Scripture mentions this measurement because one omer per person was sufficient for satiation.

JOURNEYED. Scripture is being brief in saying by their stages. For from the wilderness of Sin Israel journeyed to Dophkah; from there to Alush, and from Alush they went to Rephidim.1See Num. 33:12-14. In other words, by their stages alludes to all the places that Israel stopped between Sin and Rephidim.

[ACCORDING TO THE COMMANDMENT OF THE LORD.] Its meaning is, as I have already noted,2See I.E. on Ex. 15:22. via the hand of Moses.3Moses alone, rather than the pillars of cloud and fire, now led the people.

WHEREFORE THE PEOPLE STROVE. Scripture mentions the people, not all of the people as it does with regard to the manna,4See Ex. 16:2. for there were two parties. One had no water to drink. This is the group5The people mentioned in our verse. that strove with Moses. The second group had water which they brought from Alush. This group,6The second group did not strive with Moses. as Scripture goes on to say,7In the last part of our verse. wanted to test God and see if He would provide water.

GIVE US WATER. They spoke to Moses and Aaron.8The Hebrew reads, tenu (give). Tenu is in the plural, hence I.E.’s comment. There was no need to mention Aaron,9In our verse even though the people’s words were also directed at him. Aaron is not mentioned in our verse, hence I.E.’s comment. for I have already explained that Moses spoke to Israel only through Aaron.10See I.E. on Ex. 4:30. [WHY STRIVE YE WITH ME?] Moses answered them,11The first party. Why strive ye with me? Let us all cry out unto the Lord.12This, according to I.E., is implied in Why strive ye with me? He said, wherefore do ye try the Lord? to those who wanted to test God.13The second party.

AND THE PEOPLE THIRSTED. When the thirst overpowered them they raged against Moses and accused him of doing them evil in bringing them out of Egypt.14Hence and the people murmured follows and the people thirsted.

AND THE PEOPLE CRIED…THEY ARE ALMOST READY TO STONE ME. Scripture speaks metaphorically.15Moses was not in actual danger of being stoned. Its meaning is: they have striven with me and they rage against me. If they had the power they would stone me.

AND THE LORD SAID. Some say that because Moses said, they are almost ready to stone me, God told him, Pass on before the people who strive with you and inform them that you will now give them water.16In this interpretation, pass on before the people is short for: pass on before the people who strive with you, etc.

AND TAKE WITH THEE OF THE ELDERS OF ISRAEL; AND THY ROD, WHEREWITH THOU SMOTEST THE RIVER. By command.17Moses did not personally smite the river. He told Aaron to do so. See Ex. 7:19 and I.E. on Ex. 17:25.

BEHOLD, I WILL STAND BEFORE THEE THERE UPON THE ROCK IN HOREB. Its meaning is, you will find Me there, the idea being you will encounter My strength and power on Horeb.18Our verse is not to be taken literally. It should be understood as: you will find My strength and power upon the rock in Horeb.
AND THOU SHALT STRIKE THE ROCK. Which contains no water.19At present.
[AND MOSES DID SO.] Scripture is being brief, for it does not mention, and the congregation drank, and their cattle (Num. 20:11).20As it does in recording a similar account in the wilderness of Sin.
CALLED. Moses or someone.21Our verse literally reads, And he called the name of the place Massah and Meribah. The subject is omitted, hence I.E.’s comment.

MASSAH AND MERIBAH. Because of the two reasons noted.22In our verse Massah means trying and Meribah strife. It is the style of the Hebrew language to begin its comments with the second of two items when two particulars are listed,23Scripture first mentions Massah and then Meribah. It then goes on to first explain Meribah and then Massah. as the second item is at hand. Compare, And I gave unto Isaac Jacob and Esau (Josh. 24:4), which is followed by and I gave unto Esau (Ibid.). Scripture similarly first mentions Massah and then Meribah and turns to explain that the name of the place was called Meribah because of the striving of the children of Israel with Moses. It then explains that the place was called Massah because they tried the Lord. Now “trial” refers to Israel’s asking, Is the Lord among us to provide for all of our needs? This second party angered God more than the first.24For the first complained because they were overpowered by thirst. Scripture therefore says, Ye shall not try the Lord your God, as ye tried Him in Massah (Deut. 6:16).25The first party is not mentioned at all in this verse.
THEN CAME AMALEK. The reference is to the nation of Amalek, which dwelleth in the land of the South (Num. 13:29).26And not to any other nation or person by that name. See I.E.’s comment on verse 20.

AND MOSES SAID UNTO JOSHUA. Joshua was the grandson27Reading nin, as in Vat. Ebr. 38 and in some of the printed editions. Some editions have nun. The latter is probably a scribal error. However, Filwarg believes it to be correct and tries to justify it. It is also possible that I.E. was playing on the words nin and nun, the former meaning grandson and the latter being the name of Joshua’s father. of Prince Elishama ben Ammihud, the possessor of the banner of the tribe of Ephraim.28Cf. Num. 1:10; 2:18; I Chron. 7:26, 27. Scripture refers to him here as Joshua,29His birth name was Hoshe’a. See Num. 13:16. which is the name by which Moses called him in the account of the spies.30See Num. 13:16.

CHOOSE US OUT. It is Hebrew style to speak in this manner.31To employ the possessive pronoun, lakh (for thee) or lanu (for us) for purposes of emphasis. Compare, choose thee (II Sam. 24:12); Tarry ye here for us (Ex. 24:14).
MEN. Renowned, powerful men and men of war, as in all of them men (Num. 13:3).
AND GO OUT, FIGHT WITH AMALEK. Go out from the camp of Israel to fight against Amalek.
I WILL STAND ON TOP OF THE HILL. Horeb, which is the same as Mount Sinai.
WITH THE ROD OF GOD IN MY HAND. With which I will lift my hand to pray.

SO JOSHUA DID. Aaron and Hur are mentioned because of the need to explain (they) stayed up his hands (v. 12).32Since Scripture goes on to note that Aaron and Hur held up Moses’ hands it first had to tell us that they went up the hill with Moses.

AND IT CAME TO PASS. Some say that Moses held his hand33Which grasped the rod of the Lord. up in a manner similar to one holding up a banner in war.34Cf. Rashbam. However, if this was the case then Aaron or Hur would have lifted the rod up or they would have placed it on a high place on the mountain so that the people would see it standing. The correct interpretation is the one offered by the ancient sages.35Moses’ raised hands served to direct the heart of Israel towards heaven. Cf. Rosh Ha-Shanah 3:8: “Now do the hands of Moses promote or hinder the battle! It is rather to teach you that when the Israelites directed their thoughts on high and subjected their hearts to their Father in heaven, they prevailed; and if not they were defeated.”

BUT MOSES’ HANDS WERE HEAVY. We know that a human being does not have the strength to hold his hands up for an entire day. One cannot even hold them up for a few hours, certainly not until the going down of the sun.36Therefore what purpose does Scripture have in telling us but Moses’ hands were heavy? Now Scripture notes that Moses’ hands were heavier than the hands of other old people.37Ibn Ezra does not indicate why Moses’ hands were heavier than those of other people his age. Moses thus could not continually hold his hands up.

[AND PUT IT.] Its meaning is, they strengthened his place38By placing a stone beneath him (Krinsky). because he was not able to stand up.39Not only were Moses’ hands tired but Moses himself was unable to stand.

AND AARON AND HUR. Stood. Scripture employs the masculine kevedim (heavy)40Rather than the feminine kevedot. Yad (hand) is a feminine, hence I.E.’s comment. and similarly reads, mi-zeh echad u-mi-zeh echad (the one on the one side, and the other on the other side).41I.E. interprets our text as meaning: one was supporting this hand and one was supporting the other hand. In other words, mi-zeh refers to the hands. However, since yad is feminine Scripture should have read mi-zot echad u-mi-zot echad. Ve-hinneh yad sheluchah elai, ve-hinneh vo megillat sefer (behold, a hand was put forth unto me; and, lo, a roll of a book was therein) is similar (Ezek. 2:9).42Vo (therein) is masculine. However, yad is feminine. We thus see that Scripture occasionally combines feminine nouns with masculine pronouns or adjectives.

AND HIS HANDS WERE STEADY. Each one of his hands.43Yadav (his hands) is plural; emunah (steady) is singular. Hence va-yehi yadav emunah (and his hands were steady) means: and his hands was steady. I.E. holds that when a verb or an adjective in the plural governs or modifies a noun in the singular, the verb or adjective refers to each one within the plural. Hence, “and his hands was steady” means: and each one of his hands was steady. See Vol. 1, Foreword, p. xvii. The phrase is grammatically similar to Its branches run over the wall (Gen. 49:22)44Banot (its branches) is plural; tza’adah (run) is singular. According to I.E., Gen. 49:22 should be translated: each one of its branches runs over the wall. See I.E. on Gen. 49:22 and the notes thereto. and But the righteous45Tzadikim (righteous) is plural; kefir (young lion) is singular. According to I.E., Prov. 28:1 should be translated: but each one of the righteous is secure as a young lion. are secure as a young lion (Prov. 28:1).

STEADY. Emunah (steady) is a noun meaning something lasting and permanent.46Literally, standing and everlasting. Moses’ hands turned into something firm and steadfast (Shadal), for he did not lower his hands but held them up steadily. The image is of something pillar-like. Others say that emunah comes from the same root as the word omen (brought up)47The noun omen means a person who raises a child. Cf. Num. 11:12; II Kings 10:1; Is. 49:2. in And he brought up Hadassah (Esth. 2:7). Aaron and Hur were like nursemaids who lifted up his hands.48Netter. The idea being that Aaron and Hur lifted up Moses’ hands the way a nursemaid carries a child. Thus va-yehi yadav emunah (and his hands were steady) means: and his hands were nursed by nursemaids.
