For other interpretations and possible translations see Weiser and Krinsky.

AND JOSHUA DISCOMFITED AMALEK. There is no difference between va-yachalosh49Which is an efol. (discomfited or weakened) and va-yechelash50Which is an efal. Both words come from the root chet, lamed, shin, and may be used interchangeably. (weakened) (Job 14:10).51Translated literally. Likewise, the word yitrof52An efol. (tear) (Ps. 7:3) means the same as yitraf53An efal. (tears) (Gen. 49:27).54Translated literally. J.P.S. renders, raveneth. The same is the case with the words tiddor (voweth)55An efol. in voweth a vow (Num. 30:4) and va-yiddar (vowed),56An efal. which is vocalized with a pattach in and Jacob vowed a vow (Gen. 28:20). However, this root,57Chalash, unlike taraf (tore) and nadar (vowed). like the word shav (returned), is sometimes transitive and sometimes intransitive.58In our verse it is transitive. In Job 14:20 it is intransitive. Or,59That is, va-yachalosh in Job 14:20 is not only intransitive but also a pluperfect. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: “Or va-yechelash means he weakened others… Scripture therefore employs gever, which indicates a mighty man.” Thus “or” introduces a new interpretation of the word va-yechelash. Whereas the previous interpretation believed it to be intransitive, this one believes it to be transitive. va-yechelash (weakened) in a man (gever) dieth, and is weakened (Job 14:10) means he was already weakened,60Reading u-devar chalash acherim as Vat. Ebr. 38 does. The printed texts read: u-khvar chalash acherim (he has already weakened others). See above note. The point is va-yechelash is a pluperfect. Translated according to I.E., our verse should be interpreted: the mighty man (gever) who killed others dieth. Or, the mighty man weakened and dieth. like the word va-yivash (and rotted)61Which is a pluperfect. See I.E. on Ex. 16:20 and the notes thereto. in and it bred worms, and rotted (Ex. 16:20). Scripture therefore employs the term gever (man), which indicates a mighty man.62For purposes of contrast. Mighty man is in contrast to dieth.

WRITE THIS FOR A MEMORIAL IN THE BOOK. This chapter63Verses 14-16. was said in the fortieth year.64Of Israel’s sojourn in the wilderness rather than immediately after the battle with Amalek. The fact that Scripture reads ba-sefer (in the book) with a pattach beneath the bet65Rather than be-sefer (in a book). is proof of the aforementioned. For ba-sefer refers to the well-known book, that is, the book of the Torah.66Which Moses completed shortly before his death. It is also possible that they had another book67And the reference is to that book rather than to the Torah. In this case it is possible for this chapter to have been written shortly after the Exodus. known as The Book of the Wars of the Lord68See Num. 21:14. which was lost to us, as were the Sefer Ha-Yashar69See Josh. 10:13; II Sam. 1:18. and the Midrash of Iddo70Cf. II Chron. 13:22. and the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel71See I Kings 14:19, 29. and the works of Solomon.72Which were not preserved in Scripture. See I Kings 5:12.
[IN THE EARS OF JOSHUA.] For God knew that Joshua was destined to wage war with the kings of Canaan.73And Amalek dwelt in the southern part of Canaan. See I.E. on verse 1.

[FOR I WILL UTTERLY BLOT OUT THE REMEMBRANCE OF AMALEK.] Because Amalek angered God. For the chiefs of Edom and similarly those of Moab and of Philistia feared and trembled before God because of the signs which the Lord displayed in Egypt and at the sea.74See Ex. 15:14, 15. Now this very Amalek heard of the might that God displayed on behalf of His people Israel. Behold, he came from a distant place to wage war against Israel. He did not fear God. Indeed, Scripture explicitly states, and he (Amalek) feared not God (Deut. 25:18).75Hence God decreed this punishment for him. Some say that Amalek was the name of a king.76Not that of a nation. Hence the command to blot out Amalek (Deut. 25:19) applies only to the king and his descendants. They say this because Scripture reads, Amalek and his people. On the other hand, it is possible that another nation joined Amalek.77In other words, Amalek and his people means the nation of Amalek and its allies.

AND MOSES BUILT AN ALTAR. On Horeb. The word mizbe’ach (altar) is to be read as if written twice. Our verse is to be read as if written, mizbach Adonai (the altar of the Lord).78Our verse reads: And Moses built an altar, and called the name of it Adonai-nissi (the Lord is my banner). I.E. suggests that we read the verse as follows: And Moses built an altar, and called the name of it the altar of the Lord who is my banner.

THE HAND UPON THE THRONE OF THE LORD. It is as if God put His hand upon His throne. This was the taking of an oath.79Placing His hand upon the throne is equivalent to saying: I swear (Krinsky). It is similar to For I lift up My hand to heaven (Deut. 32:40).80Raising the hand to heaven and making a statement is equivalent to swearing. Rabbi Joshua says that its81The hand upon the throne of the Lord. meaning is that the first one to sit upon the throne of Israel, the reference being to Saul,82Who waged war against and defeated Amalek. See I Sam. 15. will have a mighty hand.83The meaning of our verse being: the first king that will sit on the Lord’s throne will have a mighty hand and defeat Amalek. We similarly find it said concerning Solomon: Then Solomon sat on the throne of the Lord (I Chron. 29:23).
The word of Abram,1Short for Abraham. I.E. used the short form because of metrical reasons which are not apparent in translation. the prisoner of hope; Who loosened his bowstring (yitro).2Cf.

For He hath loosed my cord, and afflicted me (Job 30:11). The bow is a symbol of power. I.E. here indicates that he himself has passed the prime of life and has grown weak and weary. Half of his courage is forever gone; And the rest3Of his courage. (yitro) was dissipated by his tortuous wanderings.
This4The above interpretations of the word yitro as meaning both bowstring and the rest. is a comment5Actually a play on words. upon the chapter Which opens with the word Yitro (Jethro).

NOW JETHRO HEARD. Scripture notes above6Ex. 17:8-16. the incident of Amalek because Amalek came to Rephidim.7Where Israel encamped on the way to Mount Sinai. Now the chapter that opens with the words In the third month (Ex. 19:1) should have followed the incident of Amalek,8Chapter 19 should have followed chapter 17. for Scripture states there, And when they were departed from Rephidim, and were come to the wilderness of Sinai (Ex. 19:2).9Translated literally. This being the case, why was the account of Jethro inserted between these two chapters?10I.E. will answer this question later on in his commentary. Saadiah Gaon says that Jethro came to the wilderness of Sinai before the giving of the Torah.11This is also the opinion of Rabbi Joshua in the Talmud (Zevachim 116a), and of Rashi and Nahmanides. According to the Talmud, Jethro heard of the splitting of the sea and Israel’s war with Amalek at Rephidim. Hence the account of Jethro follows the war with Amalek. However, I believe that Jethro came to Sinai in the second year,12Of Israel’s sojourn in the wilderness. after the erection of the tabernacle.13The tabernacle was erected on the first day of Nisan at the start of the second year following the Exodus. For the chapter14Our chapter, 18. speaks of a burnt-offering and sacrifices for God (v. 12),15Which assumes the existence of an altar. and it does not mention that he built a new altar.16But used the altar he found in existence, the altar of the tabernacle. Furthermore, Scripture writes, and I make them know the statutes of God, and His laws (v. 16).17That is, the laws of the Torah. Now this18Moses’ teaching of God’s laws and statutes. took place after the giving of the Torah.19For before the revelation there were no laws and statutes to teach. True proof that my words are correct is the fact that Scripture clearly states, where he20Moses. was encamped, at the mount of God (v. 5).21The use of the particle choneh (encamped) indicates that when Jethro came to Moses, Moses had been encamped there at Sinai for a long time. See I.E. on verse 19. Hence Jethro came after the giving of the Torah. Now Moses spoke to Hobab,22And told him, Leave us not, I pray thee; forasmuch as thou knowest how we are to encamp in the wilderness (Num. 10:31). See further below. I.E. starts relating the aforementioned, then goes off on a tangent explaining who Hobab was, and then picks up the thread two sentences below. the latter being Jethro as I explained in the Torah portion These Are The Names.23See I.E. on Ex. 2:18. For Moses’ father-in-law24That is, the phrase father-in-law in Num. 10:29, which reads, And Moses said unto Hobab, the son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses’ father-in-law: ‘We are journeying unto the place of which the Lord said: I will give it to you; come thou with us, and we will do thee good; for the Lord hath spoken good concerning Israel.’ does not refer to Reuel, which precedes the term father-in-law,25In Num. 10:29. but refers to Hobab.26Mentioned at the beginning of the verse under discussion. Scripture clearly states, from the children of Hobab the father-in-law of Moses (Jud. 4:11). Moses told Hobab, [Leave us not, I pray thee] forasmuch as thou knowest how we are to encamp in the wilderness (Num. 10:31). Now we know that Israel camped around Sinai for about a year. Lo and behold, Moses’ very words prove this to be so. For Moses is quoted in the Torah portion, These are the words as saying, The Lord our God spoke unto us in Horeb, saying: …turn you, and take your journey (Deut. 1:6,7).27From Sinai. Now this was said close to their time of journey.28For And we journeyed from Horeb (Deut. 1:19) follows immediately. Moses continued, And I spoke unto you at that time saying: I am not able to bear you myself alone (Deut. 1:9); for the Lord your God hath multiplied you, and, behold, ye are this day as the stars of heaven for multitude (Deut. 1:10). The reason Moses mentioned this to them was that God told Jacob, Behold, I will make thee fruitful, and multiply thee, and I will make of thee a company of peoples; and will give this land to thy seed after thee for an everlasting possession (Gen. 48:4). Now the meaning of the latter is: when your seed increase I will give them the land. Moses therefore said, the Lord your God hath multiplied you and the time for you to inherit the land has come. However, since you are so numerous I was not able to carry you alone,29Deut. 1:9,12. and I had to place over you captains of thousands and captains of hundreds.30Deut. 1:15 Now this31Placing captains of thousands and captains of hundreds over the people to assist Moses in judging them. was the advice given to Moses by Jethro on the morrow following his coming to the wilderness of Sinai.32Ex. 18:13. Moses therefore said to Hobab, who, as we explained, is to be identified with Jethro, We are journeying (Num. 10:29).33Unto the place of which the Lord said: I will give it to you; come thou with us, and we will do thee good; for the Lord hath spoken good concerning Israel. Hobab responded, I will not go; but I will depart to mine own land, and to my kindred (Num. 10:30). This is what And Moses let his father-in-law depart; and he went his way into his own land (v. 27) refers to. I will now explain why the chapter dealing with Jethro was inserted here. It was placed here because Scripture had just mentioned the evil that Amalek did to Israel. The Torah wants to contrast it with the good that Jethro rendered Israel. Scripture notes, And Jethro rejoiced for all the goodness which the Lord had done to Israel (v. 9) and that he gave proper and correct counsel to Moses and Israel. Moses told Jethro, and thou shalt be to us instead of eyes (Num. 10:31), meaning that he enlightened their eyes.34I.E. takes ve-hayita (and thou shalt be) as a perfect. He renders Num. 10:31 as: and you were to us instead of eyes; i.e., you enlightened us with your council. See I.E. on Num. 10:31 where he quotes this interpretation and prefaces it with the phrase, “many say.” King Saul similarly said,35To Jethro’s descendants. for ye showed kindness to all the children of Israel (I Sam. 15:6).36The reference is to the good advice which Jethro gave to Israel. King Saul said ye because the good that Jethro had done accrued to the benefit of his descendants. See Kimchi on I Sam. 15:6. Now because Scripture states in the preceding chapter, the Lord will have war with Amalek from generation to generation (Ex. 17:16), namely, that when God gives Israel rest they are obligated to wage war against Amalek, the Torah mentions the account of Jethro. For the descendants of Jethro lived in proximity to the nation of Amalek,37See I Sam. 15:6. Literally, For they were with the nation of Amalek. Vat, Ebr. 38 reads: should they ever be found together with Amalek. It reads, k i im rather than ki hem. and the Torah wants Israel to remember the kindness that Jethro demonstrated so that they do not harm his seed. Thus we find the Rechabites, who were descended from Jethro, living among the children of Israel in Jerusalem. We find Jonadab the son of Rechab38Actually the descendants of Jonadab the son of Rechab. For Jonadab the son of Rechab lived some 250 years earlier, during the reign of King Jehu. in the time of Jeremiah (Jer. 35:19).39That is, we find the descendants of Jonadab ben Rechab living in Jerusalem in the days of Jeremiah. The text in I.E. is a bit garbled. It reads: Now we find the Rechabites who were descended from Jethro living among the children of Israel in Jerusalem, and in the days of Jeremiah, Jonadab the son of Rechab. There is another chapter similar to the one above.40Where Scripture interrupts a narrative by inserting a chapter which does not chronologically belong there, for purposes of contrast. The chapter that I.E. is referring to is Gen. 38. See I.E. on Gen 38:1 and the notes thereto.

ALL THAT GOD (ELOHIM) HAD DONE. Scripture employs the name of God41Elohim. that was known in the world before the appearance of Moses, for all admitted that God existed.42See I.E. on Shemot 6:2 and the notes thereto.

AND FOR ISRAEL HIS PEOPLE. God’s people, or the people of Moses.43Amo (his people) refers either to God or to Moses. It is possible that the lamed44The Hebrew reads, le-moshe u-le-yisra’el amo (for Moses and for Israel His people), the lamed usually means “to”. Thus the verse should be translated: to Moses and to Israel His people. I.E. suggests that the lamed here has the meaning of because. Thus our verse should be rendered: because of Moses and because of Israel His (or his) people. See note 43. should be translated as “because,” that is, because of Moses and Israel, the reference being to the plagues and the drowning of Pharaoh.
HOW THAT THE LORD (YHVH) HAD BROUGHT. Scripture employs the divine name revealed to Moses, since it was through the miracles45Performed by YHVH the God of Israel. that Israel went out of Egypt.
AND JETHRO TOOK. Scripture reads, Moses’ wife, and not Jethro’s daughter, because Moses was more important than her father’s house.46That is, Moses was more important than Jethro.

AFTER HE HAD SENT HER AWAY. Some say that Moses gave her permission to return to her father’s house, at the lodging place, prior to his returning alone to Egypt.47See Rashi. Other say she sent gifts to Moses.48That is, achar shilluche’ha (after he had sent her away) should be rendered as: after her gifts, i.e., after she had sent him gifts. See Rashbam on this verse. Compare, shilluchim (gifts) in gifts unto his daughter (I Kings 9:16).49Translated according to I.E.

AND. Note that those who speak the holy tongue preserve the verbal forms in all conjugations.50That is, the verbs are conjugated and combined with pronouns according to fixed rules. However, they are not careful to do so with proper nouns.51No strict grammatical rules are followed when proper nouns are formed. In the latter case, assonance rather than grammar prevails. Therefore do not be amazed that Moses called his son Gershom because he lived (gar) there (sham).52In a strange land. I.E. explains the name Gershom as being a combination of gar and sham. However, in this case Moses should have named his son Garsham (Krinsky). We thus see that the Hebrews did not follow strict grammatical rules when coining proper nouns. For look, kayin (Cain) was so called because Eve said, kaniti (I have gotten) (Gen. 4:1). However, this is grammatically incorrect.53Kaniti comes from the root kof, nun, heh. Kayin comes from the root kof, vav, nun. The name Noah, which Scripture derives from yenachamenu (shall comfort us) (Gen. 5:28),54From the root nun, chet, mem. is even more difficult.55For Noah (no’ach) comes from the root nun, vav, chet. If Noah were derived from yenachamenu, then he should have been called Menachem. See I.E. on 5:29. Scripture at times inverts a name. Thus Hushim (Gen. 46:23) and Shuham (Num. 26:42) are one and the same. Yabetz (Jabez)56From the root yod, bet, tzadi. was so called because his mother bore him in pain (otzev).57The root of which is ayin, tzadi, bet. Thus the root of otzev is inverted in the name Yabetz. Sometimes a letter is dropped in a name, as in the case of Maacah58Spelled mem, ayin, kaf, heh. See II Chron. 11:21. which is a variant of Micah.59Spelled mem, yod, kaf, heh. See Chron. II 13:2, where her name is given as Micaiah. Micah is a short form of Micaiah. I.E. apparently quoted from memory. Scripture drops the ayin the second time the name is mentioned. The reverse is true of Yov (Iob) (Gen. 46:13), which is the same as Yashuv60Here Scripture adds rather than drops a letter from the name. (Jashub) (Num. 26:24). Many say it is the same61That Scripture is not following the rules of grammar. with Shemu’el (Samuel), which62According to the plain meaning of I Sam. 1:20. is derived from she’iltihu (I have asked him) (I Sam. 1:20).63The root of which, unlike that of Shemu’el, is shin, alef, lamed. However, in my opinion a shuruk has been substituted here64In the name Shemu’el. for a cholam, as in the case of Tohu65Spelled with a shuruk. (I Sam. 1:1) and Toah66Toah is spelled with a cholam. Both refer to the same person. (I Chron. 6:19); Zuph67Spelled with a shuruk. (I Sam. 1:1) and Zophai68Spelled with a cholam. Both refer to the same person. (I Chron. 6:11); Nun69Spelled with a shuruk. (Ex. 33:11) and Non70Spelled with a cholam. Both refer to the same person. (I Chron. 7:26). Now Shemu’el (Samuel) comes from shemo el (his name is God).71Not from she’iltihu as the plain meaning of I Sam. 1:20 seems to imply. Samuel’s mother called him by God’s name because the Lord answered her request.72I.E.’s interpretation of I Sam. 1:20. Do not be amazed that a human being should be called by God’s name, for, observe, we find this to be the case with the name Zurishaddai73Which means the Almighty is my rock. (Num. 7:36). There are many other similar instances.74There are many theophonic names in Scripture. In my opinion the altar which Moses built was similarly called Adonai-nissi (the Lord is my banner) (Ex. 17:15).75It should be noted that in Ex. 17:15, I.E. offers a different interpretation for Adonai-nissi. Likewise, the name of the Messiah will be called Adonai-tzidkenu (the Lord is our righteousness) (Jer. 23:6). However, Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that God’s name is connected to the word yikre’o (shall call him) and the name of the Messiah will be tzidkenu (our righteousness).76Jer. 23:6 reads, ve-zeh shemo asher yikre’o Adonai-tzidkenu. I.E. renders this clause: and this is the name whereby he shall be called: Adonai-tzidkenu (The Lord is our righteousness). Saadiah disagrees. He places a comma after the word Adonai, and translates: and this is the name whereby he shall be called by the Lord: Tzidkenu (Our Righteousness). Now its correct interpretation is in keeping with the opinion of the master of the cantillical notes,77I.E. does not identify him. However, the thrust of his words is clear. The cantillical have a comma after the word yikre’o. who placed a tircha78Called a tippekha in the Ashkenazic tradition. in the word yikre’o.79That is, beneath the word yikre’o. The tippekha is similar to a comma. Thus contra Saadiah, yikre’o is not to be connected to Adonai, and the clause is to be read as I.E. reads it. For there is a great difference between va-yikra be-shem Adonai (and called upon the name of the Lord) (Gen. 12:8), written in connection with Abraham with a tircha beneath the word va-yikra,80That is, Gen. 12:8 is to read, va-yikra, be-shem, Adonai. The latter is to be translated: And he, Abraham, proclaimed the name of the Lord. and vayikra ve-shem Adonai (and proclaimed the name of the Lord) (Ex. 34:5)81Ex. 34:5 is to be read, va-yikra ve-shem, Adonai. The latter is to be rendered: And He (the Lord) proclaimed the name, Lord. See I.E. on Ex. 35:4. which is written in the Book of Moses82The Book of Exodus in which Moses plays a role, in contrast to Genesis where he is not mentioned. Some emend the text to read, be-sippur Mosheh, i.e., in the story of Moses (Krinsky). as I will explain in its place.83See I.E. on Ex. 34:5.

AND THE NAME OF THE OTHER84Literally, the one. WAS. It is the custom in Hebrew to say, “This is how the second one was called.”85As in Num. 11:26, which literally reads, the name of the one was Eldad, and the name of the second was Medad. At other times it uses the term “the one,” as in86Translated according to I.E. and the name of one was Bozez, and the name of the other was Seneh (I Sam. 14:4).87So too in our verse.

[FOR THE GOD OF MY FATHER WAS MY HELP.] The word amar (he said), which should have followed the word ki (for), has been omitted in for the God of my father. Scripture does not read, “for he said the God of my father was my help” because the phrase refers to for he said: I have been a stranger (v. 3), which is written above.88That is, the phrase for he said in verse 3 also applies to verse 4. It is similar to for God hath made me fruitful (Gen. 41:52).89There too the word amar is missing. See I.E. on Gen. 41:52. I have already explained why Moses named his younger son Eliezer.90See I.E. on Ex. 2:15.
AND CAME. Scripture notes that Jethro followed etiquette when he came to Moses. Jethro went first, the sons of Moses went behind him, and after them Moses’ wife, as is the custom.
WHERE HE WAS ENCAMPED. He encamped there for many days.91The participle choneh (encamped) indicates a lasting action.

AND HE SAID UNTO MOSES. He had already said92In other words, va-yomer (and he said) is a pluperfect. unto Moses prior to his coming,93What point would there be for Jethro to say upon coming to Moses, I thy father-in-law…am coming unto thee. via an agent94So too Rashi. or by a written message: I thy father-in-law Jethro am coming unto thee, and also thy wife, who is uppermost in importance, and her two sons who are coming with her.

AND MOSES WENT OUT TO MEET HIS FATHER-IN-LAW. Out of regard for Jethro and his wisdom, but not out of regard for his95His own. wife and children, for it is not customary for a respected person to go out to meet his wife or children.

AND BOWED DOWN. Va-yishtachu (and bowed down) is grammatically difficult.96Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: “Va-yishtachu (he bowed) and also estachaveh (I will bow) are grammatically difficult.” That is, the entire paradigm is difficult, for its root is shin, chet, heh and it is spelled with a vav. Va-yishtachu is especially difficult in that the heh drops out and it is irregularly vocalized. We know that it comes from a root ending in a heh.97Its root is shin, chet, heh. The vav in va-yishtachu98That is, the final vav. is in place of a heh,99The root heh. like the vav of shalev (at ease)100The root of which is shin, lamed, heh. However, a vav has been substituted for a heh. in I was at ease (Job 16:12), from whose root we get the word shalavti (at ease) in I was not at ease (Job 3:26). Now the term va-yishtachaveh101There appears to be an error in the text, for va-yishtachaveh ends vav, heh, while I.E.’s point is that the word should really have no vav at all. See note 96. Filwarg suggests two possible emendations: one, va-yishtacheh, the other, va-yishtachev. In the former, I.E. is explaining that if a vav had not been substituted for a heh, the word would have been va-yishtacheh. For the latter is the way third person hitpa’el’s are vocalized. If we emend to va-yishtachev, then I.E. is merely explaining why the word is vocalized va-yishtachu when, as noted above, according to Hebrew grammar the word should have been vocalized va-yishtachev. The error in transcription probably arose from the fact that the normally used word for “and he bowed” is va-yishtachaveh. See Filwarg and Krinsky. should have been employed in the singular,102That is, the third person singular perfect. rather than va-yishtachu, for the tav103In va-yishtachu. is a sign of the hitpa’el conjugation. It is like the tav in mishta’eh (steadfastly)104Which is not a root letter but is the tav of the hitpa’el conjugation. in And the man looked steadfastly on her (Gen. 24:21). For the rule relating to the dentals105A shin, samekh, tzadi, or zayin. states that if the first letter of a root before which the tav of the hitpa’el conjugation is placed106The tav of the hitpa’el conjugation precedes the root. Compare hitkatev, hityashev, etc. is a dental, then107In the Hebrew text the sentence ends here. There is either a scribal error or I. E. did not finish his thought. [the tav is placed after the first root letter].108Rather than before it. Thus in va-yishtachu the tav follows rather than precedes the shin. Now because the heh has been changed into a vav in va-yishtachu Hebrew allows the first vav,109In the third person plural form, va-yishtachavu (and they bowed) (Filwarg). which is not a plural suffix, to remain in place of the root heh110In the third person. and silences the vav.111That is, they vocalized the word with a shuruk. I.E. refers to the shuruk as a silent vav. Hence the word reads va-yishtachu.112This should be emended to va-yishtachavu. For other interpretations see Krinsky and Weiser. Now a vav at the end of a word is the sign of the plural suffix when silent as in titra’u (look one upon the other) in Why do ye look one upon the other (Gen. 42:1). Thus the word va-yishtachu, ending in a silent vav, would appear to be in the plural. Va-yishtachu was therefore penultimately accented113Rather than ultimately accented as is the usual case with words in the third person perfect. to differentiate between it and the customary way of vocalizing plurals.114Which is to accent them ultimately. In other words, va-yishtachu is penultimately accented to indicate that it is not a plural.
[AND BOWED DOWN.] Logically speaking, the one who goes out is the one who bows to his counterpart.115Thus it was Moses who did the bowing.
[EACH OTHER.] Scripture refers to Jethro as Moses’ friend because of his greatness in wisdom.116See I.E. on Ex. 3:15.
AND THEY CAME INTO THE TENT. Which was known as Moses’ tent.

AND MOSES TOLD. This verse indicates that the meaning of for Moses, and for Israel (v. 1) is: because of them.117Because of Moses and because of Israel, for Scripture reads: for Israel’s sake. See I.E. on Ex. 18:1

THE TRAVAIL. Tela’ah (travail) comes from the same root as ve-nilu (shall loathe)118Its root is lamed, alef, heh. According to I.E. ve-nilu means unable. See I.E. on Ex. 7:18. in and the Egyptians shall loathe (Ex. 7:18). The tav is superfluous.119It is neither a root letter nor a prefix. Its meaning is, an affliction which a person is unable to bear or verbalize. It refers to Egypt’s pursuit of Israel at the sea, the war with Amalek, and the thirst and hunger which the congregation suffered. God delivered them from all of these.

AND JETHRO REJOICED. Va-yichad (rejoiced) comes from the same root as the word chedvah (rejoicing).120Its root is chet, dalet, heh The meaning of va-yichad thus is, and he rejoiced. It should have been vocalized like the word va-yift (enticed) in And my heart hath been secretly enticed (Job 31:27) and va-yishb (and took captive) in and took some of them captive (Num. 21:1).121The root of va-yift is peh, tav, heh, and that of va-yishb is shin, bet, heh. Va-yift is short for va-yifteh and va-yishb for va-yishbeh; that is, in words ending in a heh, the heh may be dropped in the imperfect. The latter is referred to as an abbreviated root. Now since the root of va-yichad is chet, dalet heh, va-yichad should have been vocalized va-yichd. However, the chet was vocalized with a pattach122Rather than a sheva. because it is a guttural, and the dagesh123Which is placed in the dalet in the long form, viz., yechedeh. remains in the dalet124In the short form. Va-yichad has a dagesh in it. Prima facie, there is no reason for this dagesh. Hence I.E.’s comment. as it was. I am not aware of a letter having a dagesh at the end of a word in all of Scripture except in the case of a bet, gimel, dalet, kaf, peh, tav at the end of a word when two sheva’im come together,125That is, when the last two letters in the word are vocalized with a sheva. as in the word va-yishb (and took captive)126Which has a sheva beneath each of the last two letters, the shin and the bet. in and took some of them captive (Num. 21:1) and va-yesht (and he drank)127Which has a sheva beneath each of the last two letters, the shin and the tav. in And he drank of the wine (Gen. 9:21). However, we never find a dagesh at the end of a word when preceded by a vowel128A sheva is not considered a vowel. except in the case of a pattach. In the latter case we find two such words namely, va-yichad (rejoiced) in And Jethro rejoiced and yichad (rejoice) in Let it not rejoice among the days of the year (Job 3:6).

AND JETHRO SAID: BLESSED BE THE LORD. Give your attention to the grammatical explanation of the word barukh (blessed). Note that the pa’ul129The passive kal participle form. can only be formed from transitive verbs. If you find a verb following the pa’ul form, look around; if you find it has a transitive po’el130Po’el is the active kal participle form. form, then the word is a real pa’ul. However, if you do not find it to be so,131If the word does not have an active form. then the word132In the pa’ul. is an adjective.133According to I.E. all intransitive verbs in the participle form, whether active or passive, are adjectives, for they describe a state. Similarly, if a word is in the po’el form and its root does not come in the pa’ul in the same conjugation, then the word is also not a po’el but an adjective. For example, the po’el and pa’ul forms of shamar (kept) are shomer (keeps) and shamur (kept).134Thus shomer and shamur are true po’el and pa’ul forms. Compare, shamur in riches kept by the owner thereof to his hurt (Eccles. 5:12). Now we encounter holekh (goes), omed (stands), yotze (goes out). All these words appear to be verbs in the po’el, for they follow the form of shomer. However, since these roots form intransitive verbs, for one cannot say halukh (wented), amud (stooded up), yatzu (wented out), these words do not come in the pa’ul. Therefore when Scripture uses the term holekh (went) in because he went (Num. 22:21), it employs an adjective, not a verb. We find [Scripture using] the word atzum (mighty). The word appears to be a pa’ul because it follows the paradigm of shamur (kept). However, when we investigated this root we found the word va-ya’atzmu (waxed mighty), in and multiplied, and waxed exceedingly mighty (Ex. 1:7), to be among the intransitive verbs. For its transitive form comes in the hifil135Whereas va-ya’atzmu is in the kal. as in va-ya’atzimehu (and made them too mighty) in and made them too mighty for their adversaries (Ps. 105:24). Now we cannot say that otzem (strengthens) following the paradigm of shomer (keeps) means strength,136Even though the word atzam in the kal means waxed mighty, its po’el form does not mean waxes mighty but closes. In other words, the word atzam meaning strength has no po’el form. for in this case it has a different meaning, as in otzem (shutteth) in And shutteth his eyes from looking upon evil (Is. 33:15). Now we find the word barukh, which follows the paradigm of shamur (kept). We searched all of Scripture and we did not see this root137Bet, resh, kaf. used with this meaning138That is, meaning blessing. in all of the kal conjugation.139I.E.’s point is that the root bet, resh, kaf in the kal means to kneel. It is only used with regard to a blessing in the pa’ul form. We found it used140In the kal. only with another meaning, namely, to kneel, as in va-yivrakh (kneeled) in and kneeled down upon his knees (I Chron. 6:13), which141Like the above-noted words. is also intransitive and does not have a pa’ul142There is no kal pa’ul form for kneeled because barukh means blessed. form. The word barukh (blessed) is thus like the word atzum (might), a kal adjective. Rabbi Merinus143Rabbi Jonah ibn Janach. says that barukh (blessed) is an adjective in the pi’el. Its resh should have received a dagesh like all other such roots,144Words in the pi’el receive a dagesh in their middle stem letters. When the middle root letter cannot receive a dagesh, the preceding letter is vocalized with a tzere in place of a chirik. such as berekh (curse)145Which is vocalized with a tzere rather than a chirik because the resh cannot receive a dagesh. In other words, the word for blessed should have been vocalized berukh rather than barukh. in Naboth did curse (I Kings 21:13). Barukh follows the paradigm of shakkul (bereaved)146Which is a pi’el. It should be noted that shakkul is vocalized with a pattach, and barukh with a kamatz. The reason for the latter is that since the resh of barukh cannot receive a dagesh, the pattach preceding it is changed to a kamatz. in as a bear that is bereaved of her whelps (Hos. 13:8). However, Rabbi Merinus spoke incorrectly, for all adjectives such as shakkul (bereaved), gibbor (warrior), shikkor (drunk)147That is, all pi’el adjectives. do not undergo any change by having the vowel that precedes the dagesh change in the singular construct or in the plural.148In other words, the vowel beneath the first letter of a word in the pi’el does not change in the singular construct or in the plural. However, they do in the kal. Compare, gibbor (mighty man)149Which is a singular construct. in And Zichri, a mighty man of Ephraim (II Chron. 28:7), and gibborim150Which is a plural absolute. The point is, the chirik preceding the bet with the dagesh in it does not change in gibbor, which is in the construct. Neither does it change in gibborim, which is the plural of gibbor. However, it does change in the kal; viz., davar becomes devar in the construct and devarim in the plural. (mighty) in Woe unto them that are mighty (Is. 5:22). Now the word berukh (blessed of),151The construct of barukh. in Come in, thou blessed of the Lord (Gen. 24:31) and berukhim (blessed) in, Blessed be ye of the Lord (Ps. 115:15), argue against Rabbi Merinus.152The singular of which is barukh. We thus see that in the case of these two words the kamatz changes to a sheva. However, as noted above, this does not occur in the pi’el form. Hence barukh cannot be a pi’el. It has to be a kal.

WHO HATH DELIVERED YOU. He said this153In other words, And Jethro said means: and Jethro said to Moses and Aaron. to Moses and Aaron, who were God’s messengers and through whom the plagues came upon Pharaoh and Egypt. Jethro therefore said, out of the hand of the Egyptians, and out of the hand of Pharaoh. After this154After blessing God. he blessed the Lord, who hath delivered the people from under the hand of the Egyptians in Egypt and at the splitting of the Red Sea.155In other words, after blessing God for delivering Moses and Aaron, he blessed God for saving Israel.
NOW I KNOW. I have explained the meaning of now I know in the Torah portion Shemot, in the verse and they shall say to me: What is His name? (Ex. 3:13).156See I.E. on Ex. 3:13.

[YEA, FOR THAT.] Because of the fact that the Egyptians dealt willfully with Israel.157In other words, ki va-davar (yea, for that) means: because of the fact, viz., the bet prefixed to davar means because. The bet usually means in. Hence I.E.’s comment. Jethro similarly, noted above, I know that the Lord is greater than all gods in that he punished the Egyptians because they made Israel work with rigor. It is similarly written, Thou knewest that they dealt proudly (hezidu) against them (Neh. 9:11) that is, they158The Egyptians. behaved like a person who does whatever he wants to.159In other words, the words hezidu and zadu mean dealt willfully. Scripture already stated, for I know their pains; and I am come down to deliver them out of the hand of the Egyptians160The hand of the Egyptians indicates that the Egyptians did what they wanted with Israel. (Ex. 3:7,8).
AND JETHRO, MOSES’ FATHER-IN-LAW, TOOK A BURNT-OFFERING AND SACRIFICES. The latter refers to peace-offerings.161Zevachim (sacrifices) usually refers to peaceofferings (Weiser).
[FOR GOD.] The meaning of for God is that henceforth the revered Lord shall be his God.
AND AARON CAME, AND ALL THE ELDERS OF ISRAEL. There is no need to mention Moses, as they were in Moses’ tent.
TO EAT BREAD. Peaceofferings.

[BEFORE GOD.] Scripture reads thus because Moses’ tent was on the east side of the tabernacle.162The tabernacle faced east. Hence Moses’ tent was in front of God’s tabernacle. It will be recalled that according to I.E., Jethro arrived in the second year following the Exodus, after the erection of the tabernacle.
AND IT CAME TO PASS ON THE MORROW. Of Jethro’s coming.
THAT MOSES SAT. As was his custom.

FROM THE MORNING UNTO THE EVENING. Note that true morning163Hebrew, boker. begins with sunrise. The term morning is, as I have previously noted,164See I.E. on Gen. 12:31. also applied to the breaking of dawn, when light begins to be seen in the clouds. In the latter instance the term is artificially used. Similarly, true evening begins when the sun sets. The term is also artificially applied up to the time that the light sets.165That is, from sunset till the disappearance of the light. David similarly said, The sun ariseth, they166The nocturnal creatures. We thus see that morning begins at sunrise. slink away (Ps. 104:22). Scripture then states, Man goeth forth unto his work, And to his labor until the evening (Ps. 104:23).167Erev. The psalm seems to describes man’s working hours from sunrise to sunset, for erev is antithetical to sunrise. We thus see that evening begins at sunset. It is therefore fitting to interpret from even unto even, shall ye keep your sabbath (Lev. 23:32) to mean: from the true evening to the true evening.168That is, from sunset to sunset. However, our sages of blessed memory “added from the weekday to the holy day”169That is, the sages extended the holy day. and said that the Sabbath does not end until the stars come out.170See Sabbath 34b. It is thus fitting from the Torah’s point of view to start the Sabbath at sunset. All scientists and astronomers admit that the day’s boundary is171That is, day begins. the moment when the circle of the sun faces all over the area of the earth. This starts at sunrise and ends at sunset.

AND…SAW ALL THAT HE DID TO THE PEOPLE. That he caused them to stand from morning to evening. Rabbi Solomon172Rashi. says that Jethro reacted in this manner because Moses alone sat and Israel stood, the latter being improper.173Cf. Rashi, “[Moses] sat like a king and all of the people stood. Jethro was troubled by this. For Moses did not show respect for Israel. He chastised Moses for this and said, What is this thing that thou doest to the people?” There can be no doubt that Moses’ station was too great for Jethro to say this.174To rebuke Moses for sitting in judgment while the litigants stood. For behold, Aaron, who was a great man in the eyes of Israel and was older than Moses, said to Moses, Oh my lord (Num. 12:11). Moses acted in the proper manner, for the judge sits and the litigants stand. We thus read, then both the men, between whom the controversy is, shall stand (Deut. 19:17). Jethro said, why175Sittest thou alone, etc. to Moses for no reason other than that Moses was sitting alone and had no other judges to assist him.

[WHY.] Rabbi Merinus says that the word maddu’a (why) is similar to mallakhem (what mean ye) (Is. 3:15) and to mazzeh (what is that) in what is that in thy hand (Ex. 4:2), each of which is a compound of two words.176Mazzeh being a compound of mah (what) and zeh (this) and mallakhem being a compound of mah (what) and lakhem (to you). The same is true of maddu’a, which means: what is in your mind that you do this?177In other words, maddu’a is a compound of ma (what) and du’a (opinion), i.e., what is your opinion? Du’a is spelled dalet, vav, ayin, and is a variation of the root yod, dalet, ayin, meaning knowledge.

AND MOSES SAID. Moses answered, I do two things. One, Because the people come unto me to inquire of God, that is, to inquire of God’s law.178That is, to inquire of God is short for, to inquire of God’s law. The other, when they have a matter, it cometh unto me (v. 16). Moses explained the second task first, namely, and I judge between a man and his neighbor (ibid.); and, he then said,179Explaining verse 16. to one who inquires, I make them know the statutes of God.

AND…SAID…THE THING THAT THOU DOEST IS NOT GOOD. In my eyes. Jethro then explained himself, Thou wilt surely wear away. Navol tibbol (thou shalt surely wear away) comes from the same root as yibbol (wither)180The root, of which is nun, bet, lamed. Navol is an infinitive and tibbol an imperfect. The literal translation of navol tibbol is: wither you will wither; that is, you will collapse. in And whose leaf doth not wither (Ps. 1:3) and novelet (fadeth)181Or withers. in For ye shall be as a terebinth whose leaf fadeth (Is. 1:30). Its meaning is, you shall, as it were, drop like a withered leaf. The word gam (both)182Literally, also. Verse 18 reads: also thou, also this people. is to be prefaced also to for the thing is too heavy for thee.183That is, for the thing is too heavy for thee is not a reason for what precedes it but an additional reason why Moses should not judge the people all by himself. For an alternate interpretation see Filwarg.

TO PERFORM IT. Asohu (to perform it) is grammatically inconsistent.184The root of asohu is ayin, sin, heh. When roots that end in a heh are combined with a pronoun, the heh changes to a tav. Hence our word should read asoto rather than asohu. It follows the form of lishmerehu185Which, unlike the root of asohu, is a “whole,” i.e., a root that does not drop a letter. (to preserve him),186Cf. yishmerehu (preserve him) in Ps. 41:3. for we do not find the heh to be visible in the root ayin, sin, heh.187The heh in this root is dropped when conjugated. Compare, asiti, asita, etc. Thus there is no reason why the root should follow the paradigm of a “whole” root when combined with a pronoun. Hence the grammatical inconsistency of asohu.
HEARKEN NOW UNTO MY VOICE, I WILL GIVE THEE COUNCIL. I’atzekha, means I will give you council.

[GOD.] Note that the term Elohim (God) is, as I have noted, an adjective.188See I.E. on Ex. 3:4,15. It is only because the word is used often that this adjective is considered as if it were a proper noun. Examples of the latter are: Elohim (God) in God will let me gaze upon my adversaries (Ps. 59:11); In the beginning God (Elohim)created the heaven and the earth (Gen. 1:1), and many other instances. It is for this reason that our sages of blessed memory placed Elohim among the names that are not erasable.189One is forbidden to erase any of God’s name. Elohim is included among the latter. See chapter 4 of Tractate Soferim.

[AND GOD BE WITH THEE.] Its meaning is, God will help you if you act in this manner. At the close of his words, Jethro told Moses to ask permission of God to act in accordance with Jethro’s counsel. This is what Jethro meant by and God command thee so (v. 23). There is no doubt that Moses did so.190Even though this is not stated in the text.
[BE THOU FOR THE PEOPLE.] The meaning of la-am191Literally, to the people. Hence I.E.’s comment. is, for the people.

BEFORE GOD. From God’s side.192Hebrew, mi-pe’at Elohim. The Biblical text reads, mul ha-Elohim; literally, before of God. I.E. apparently interprets it as: you will face the people from the same side as God faces them: that is, you will serve as God’s messenger to the people (Weiser). It is interesting to note that Peshita interprets similarly. It reads, “teaching the people from God.” However, the mem in I.E. often has the meaning of a lamed. Thus mi-pe’at Elohim might be interpreted as li-fe’at Elohim; that is, you will be the intermediary between the people and God (Krinsky). See Rashi. In this case, mul ha-Elohim means before God.

AND BRING THOU THE CAUSES UNTO GOD. If they be difficult. These are the things that Moses mentioned at first,193In response to Jethro’s question, why do you sit and the people stand around you from morning till evening (v. 14). Also see I.E. on verse 15. viz., when they have a matter, it cometh unto me (v. 16). Jethro then explained this194That the people should bring before Moses only the difficult causes. to him,195In verse 22. viz., the hard causes they shall bring unto thee.

AND THOU SHALT TEACH THEM. As to the second thing you spoke of,196That you are busy instructing the people. you are obligated to teach and instruct them only those things that they are uncertain of. For it takes great effort to teach all, the work that they must do. Now as to the meaning of ve-hizharta (and thou shalt teach): ve-hizharta comes from the same root as nizhar in and took not warning (Ezek. 33:5). Nizhar means took warning.197Hence ve-hizharta (and thou shalt teach) means: and thou shalt warn.
THEM. Ethem (them) is a compound of two words.198It is made up of et and hem.

[AND THOU SHALT TEACH THEM.] You shall warn them199See note 205. to observe the positive and negative commandments that are tied to the heart,200That one observe with one’s heart. Bachya ibn Pekuda (c. 1050-1120) referred to them as chovat ha-levavot (duties of the heart) and wrote a work by that name. such as, to love God,201Deut. 10:12; 11:13; 22:19; 30:6,16,20. to cleave unto God,202Deut. 11:22; 30:20. to fear God,203Deut. 4:10; 5:26; 6:24; 10:12; 14:23; 17:19; 31:13. to walk after God,204Deut. 26:17; 28:9. To imitate God’s attributes of mercy, that is, to be kind, charitable, loving, etc. to circumcise the foreskin of the heart,205Deut. 10:16. not to hate one’s brother,206Lev. 19:17. not to take revenge,207Lev. 19:18. and not to bear a grudge.208Ibid. They are the most important commandments. Moses similarly said, [But the word is very nigh unto thee] in thy mouth, and in thy heart, that thou mayest do it (Deut. 30:14).209Which according to I.E. means that the commandments observed with the heart are the most important commandments. See I.E. on Deut. 30:14. There many such precepts.
THEY MUST WALK. Yelekhu bah means wherein they must walk.

AND THE WORK THAT THEY MUST DO. The reference is to positive precepts which are observed by action. Most of them are not positive commandments that stand by themselves210That is, that the act itself is of inherent worth, such as belief in God, tzedaka, acts of loving kindness. but serve as a reminder, such as the Sabbath,211Which bears testimony that God created heaven and earth. See Ex. 20:11. the Festivals,212Each of which serves as a reminder of a historical or theological proof. For example, Passover commemorates the Exodus from Egypt, Sukkot the booths in which the Israelites dwelt during the sojourn in (he wilderness, and so on. the redemption of the first-born,213Which remind us that God spared the first-born of Israel when he slew the first born of Egypt. See Ex. 13:15. loving the stranger,214This reminds us that we were strangers in Egypt. See Deut. 10:19. It is note-worthy that I.E. did not consider the love of the stranger as an inherently worthy act. A different reading of Scripture was that of Hermann Cohen, who wrote, “[The] law of shielding the alien from all wrong is of vital significance in the history of religion. With it alone, true religion begins. The alien was to be protected, not because he was a member of one’s family, clan, religious community, or people; but because he was a human being. In the alien, therefore, man discovered the idea of humanity.” The Pentateuch and the Haftorahs, ed. by J.H. Hertz, Soncino Press, London, 1967, p. 313. the fringes,215Which recall God’s commandments. See Num. 15:39. the tefillin,216Which reminds the worshipper of God and one’s duties to God and the Exodus. See Ex. 13:9,16; Deut. 6:4-8; 13:13-19. the mezuzah,217Which serves the same purpose as the tefillin. See Deut. 6:4-8; 13:13-19. and also the prohibition against mixing linen and wool,218Which serves as a reminder not to combine what God has set apart. See I.E. on Lev. 19:19. and many others.219There are many other commandments which serve as reminders of theological truths and historical events. I will explain them in their place.

MOREOVER THOU SHALT PROVIDE. I have already informed you that the speakers of Hebrew do not preserve exact wording. They only preserve meanings.220See I.E. on Ex. 11:5 and Gen. 5:29. Hence, as I will yet explain, we will not pay attention to whether the text is full or deficient.221That is, whether two texts that relate the same event match each other exactly. I.E. makes this point here because, as he goes on to note, there are discrepancies between our chapter and the first chapter of Deuteronomy with regard to the description of the quality of the judges chosen by Moses. Now when Moses recounted this incident,222The appointment of judges. in place of able men223Hebrew, anshe chayil. Literally, valiant men, mighty men. he said, Get you…men (Deut. 1:13).224Rather than get you able men, as in our verse. Men in the latter verse has the same meaning as men in Choose us out men (Ex. 17:9) and in all of them men (Num. 13:3).225The meaning of men in both of these verses is, men of valor, for both verses deal with tasks requiring such men. Thus anashim in Deut. 1:13 means the same as anshe chayil in Ex. 18:21 even though the wording is different. Jethro said appoint men.

SUCH AS FEAR GOD. Who do not fear men but fear only God. It was to them that Moses was referring when he said,226To Israel. wise…and understanding (Deut. 1:13).227That is, bring forth wise and understanding men and I will appoint them as judges. For it is not possible for one to be a fearer of heaven unless one be wise.

Jethro continued: MEN OF TRUTH. Who do not lie. HATING UNJUST GAIN (betza). Money.228That is, betza (unjust gain) means money. So too Rashi. People who appear so, and are known as such by the community. It was in reference to these that Moses said, and known (Deut. 1:3).229Translated according to I.E.

RULERS OF THOUSANDS. One may wonder: If the meaning of the term rulers is here to be taken literally, then their number comes to more that seventy-nine thousand.230The Israelites numbered six hundred thousand and three thousand and five hundred and fifty men (Ex. 38:26). The number of rulers over thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens of such a group comes to 79,650 (Krinsky). Now, it is extremely far-fetched for there to have been so many rulers. Indeed, Scripture states, For the transgression of a land many are the princes thereof (Prov. 28:2).231Translated according to I.E. A surfeit of rulers is a punishment for a people. Why then would Moses appoint so many rulers over Israel? Furthermore, how is it possible for an eighth of the camp to be heads of the tribes? For this is what Moses said, that is, So I took the heads of your tribes232The verse continues: And made them heads over you, captains of thousands, and captains of hundreds, and captains of fifties, and captains of tens. (Deut. 1:15). Additionally, how is it possible that all of the above-mentioned virtues233Able men, God-fearing men, truthful men, etc. were found in these people who came out of Egypt and learned their ways? Indeed, Scripture states, After the doings of the land of Egypt, wherein ye dwelt, shall ye not do (Lev. 18:3).234Which implies that Israelites followed Egyptian practice. Otherwise why tell them not to do so? Now the desert generation, who were taught by Moses for forty years, did not have to work, for their bread was freely given and their water faithfully delivered. The manna, which they were not in the habit of eating in Egypt, in contrast to the types of food which they desired,235See Num. 11:5. instilled wisdom. Nevertheless, Moses told this generation at the end of forty years, but the Lord hath not given you a heart to know, and eyes to see, and ears to hear, unto this day (Deut. 29:3). We are thus amazed as to how it was possible to find the above-noted number236Over 79,000. of wise and understanding men.237So soon after the Exodus when, as noted in Deut. 29:3, forty years later such men were a rarity. It appears to me that the rulers of thousands were men who had under them a thousand people, namely, slaves, young men, or hired hands. It is possible that these were the heads of the tribes and that they numbered twelve. The rulers of hundreds were many. The rulers of fifties were so called after the manner of and fifty men to run before him (II Sam. 15:1).238That is, they each had fifty servants. Thus ruler over thousands, hundreds, etc., does not refer to judges in charge of a thousand Israelites, a hundred Israelites, etc., but to the amount of wealth possessed by the people from whom the judges were chosen.
AND LET THEM JUDGE THE PEOPLE. When the people have a matter. What they do not know how to judge you will judge. If you do not know it, then bring thou the causes unto God (v. 19).

THEN THOU SHALT BE ABLE. The vav of ve-yakholta (then thou shalt be able)239Va-yakholta can be taken to mean: and thou shalt be able. Hence I.E.’s comment that it means: then thou shalt be able. is like the Arabic fah.240It does not necessarily mean “and.” See I.E. on Gen. 1:2 and the notes thereto. If you do this thing, and God grants you permission to do it, then you will be able to endure. Now the word amod (endure) is an infinitive. It is like the word amod (stand)241Which is an infinitive. in Stand in the door of the tent (Jud. 4:20). Peshotah (strip you) ve-orah (and make you bare), va-chagorah (and gird) in Strip you, and make you bare, and gird sackcloth upon your lions (Is. 32:11) are also infinitives.

[AND ALL THIS PEOPLE ALSO SHALL GO TO THEIR PLACE IN PEACE.] Its meaning is, when some the disputants who were standing before Moses were not able to present their cases before him242Literally, before you. For Jethro addressed Moses. for adjudication, their conflict intensified when they returned to their tents. However, now243If Jethro’s advice were followed. each one would return to his place, that is, his tent, in peace.

[SO MOSES HEARKENED.] Scripture mentions Jethro’s council but does not mention Moses’ council.244Scripture in our chapter notes that Jethro advised Moses to appoint judges and that Moses followed his advice. However, it omits telling us that Moses decided not only to appoint judges but to appoint officers as well. Moses added to Jethro’s council: that is, Moses placed officers over the tribes to enforce the decrees of the judges. Scripture thus reads, and officers, tribe by tribe (Deut. 1:15), and Judges and officers shalt thou make thee in all thy gates (Deut. 16:18).

AND MOSES CHOSE ABLE MEN. This thing was ascertainable. Such as fear God245See verse 21. is not mentioned, for only God knows what is in a person’s heart. Moses said that he chose wise men for us, for he was able to ascertain this. However, there are wise men who are not God-fearing. Moses mentioned246That is, he appointed. men who are known (Deut. 1:13),247Translated according to I.E. that is, men whom people recognize. He did not mention them here because he was being brief.

THEY JUDGED THEMSELVES. Yishputu (judged) means the same as yishpotu (judged).248This is the more common form. A shuruk has been substituted for a cholam in yishputu. It is similar to lo ta’avuri (neither pass) in neither pass from hence (Ruth 2:5), which has the same meaning as ve-lo ta’avori (and neither pass).249Ta’avori is the more common form. However, Rabbi Solomon250Rashi. wanted to distinguish between them251Between yishputu and yishpotu. Rashi implies that yishpotu is an imperative and yishputu a participle. See Rashi on verse 26. but was unable to do so.252As they mean the same thing. Now from a grammatical standpoint the following may be said. We find the terms chadelu (ceased)253The usual form. and chadellu (ceased) with a dagesh in the lamed because it is marked with an etnach254What is commonly referred to as an etnachtah. in The rulers ceased (chadelu) in Israel, they ceased (chadellu) (Jud. 5:7). We similarly find the word nazollu255Rather than nazelu, the usual form. (quake) at the end of a verse in That the mountains may quake (Is. 63:19). Scripture likewise reads, tehatellu256Rather than tehatelu the usual form. vo (will ye mock him) (Job 13:9) since tehatellu is considered257Literally, “they” considered tehatellu to be the last word, etc. to be the last word in the sentence because it is connected to the word vo, which has only one vowel. Similarly, yishpetu hem is like yishputu (hem),258That is, they mean the same but are vocalized differently because one (yishpetu) comes in the middle of a sentence and the other (yishputu) at the end of a sentence. for one can say259Thus who would dispute this point by saying that the etnachtah and the sof pasuk equally change the word’s vocalization. Hence yishpetu and yishputu should be vocalized in the same way. that the etnach260Placed beneath yishpetu. does not have the same power that the end of the verse has. Observe the word yippelu (fall) in The peoples fall under thee (Ps. 45:6); yeminekha (thy right hand) in The Lord at thy right hand (Ps. 110:5); avdekha (thy servant) in Thou hast dealt well with Thy servant (Ps. 119:65)261All of these words have an etnachtah beneath them and maintain their normal vowels. Similarly yishpetu. and many other such instances. We do not find this to be the case at the close of a verse.262The vowels in these words change at the end of a verse. So too yishputu.

AND MOSES LET HIS FATHER-IN-LAW DEPART. With respect,263Va-yeshellach (let depart) can be translated: and he sent away. as in and Abraham went with them to bring them on the way (Gen. 18:16).264There too le-shallecham (to bring them on the way) is not to be rendered: to send them away, but rather to escort them. See I.E. on Gen. 18:16 and the notes thereto.

IN THE THIRD MONTH. We do not know the meaning of the same day (ba-yom ha-zeh)1We do not know what this phrase refers to. unless the interpretation of Rabbi Moses2For his identity, see I.E. on Ex. 2:4 and the notes thereto. to the effect that it3The word ba-chodesh (in the month) which opens our verse. See note 5. refers to the new moon is correct.4This is the opinion of the Talmud (Sabbath 86b), the Mekhilta (Parshat Yitro), and Rashi, as well. Ibn Ezra apparently quoted Rabbi Moses’ opinion because it can be linguistically defended, while the Talmud derives it from a gezerah shavah. See Sabbath 86b. Also see next note. It is like Tomorrow is the new moon (I Sam 20:18).5Our verse opens with ba-chodesh ha-shelishi (in the third month). According to Rabbi Moses the word chodesh means new moon, as in I Sam. 20:18 which reads machar ha-chodesh (tomorrow is the new moon). According to Rabbi Moses our verse should be interpreted as follows: On the third new moon, i.e., on the first day of the third month after the children of Israel were gone forth out of the land of Egypt, the same day, i.e., on the aforementioned new moon, came they into the wilderness of Sinai. It should be noted that on Ex. 12:2, I.E. quotes Rabbi Moses as saying that the term rosh chodesh (new moon) is tautological because the word chodesh by itself means new moon. Scripture notes this6That Israel came to the wilderness of Sinai on the first day of the third month. because the Torah was given a few days after Israel camped.7Around Mount Sinai. Perhaps Moses went up to God8See verse 3. on day one9Of the third month. In other words, what is reported in verses 3-6 occurred on the first day. and then came down and spoke to Israel.10On the second day of the month (Krinsky), relating all that God had told him on the first day of the month. See verses 7 and 8. Then on the third day of the month he went up again to report the words of the people to God.11Part II of verse 8. It was then told to Moses that the giving of the Torah would take place on the third day.12Verse 11. All of this is by way of logical exegesis because we accept the tradition13Recorded in Sabbath 86b. that the Torah was given on the sixth day of Sivan.14The point is that if there were no tradition that the Torah was given on the sixth of Sivan, there would be no need to say that what is reported in verse 3 took place on day one, that what is reported in verses 7 and 8 took place on day two and most importantly that what is reported in verse 11 took place on the third day. However, once we have the tradition that the Torah was given on the sixth of Sivan we may logically interpret the above verse so. Cf. Sabbath 86b: “The Decalogue was given on the sixth (of the month of Sivan). Rabbi Jose says on the seventh.” According to the rules of the calendar, if15For some reason. a day was not added to the month of Iyyar,16In other words, if Iyyar had 29 days as it usually does. then the Torah was given on a Friday.17According to the rabbis of the Talmud (Sabbath 87b), Israel left Egypt on a Thursday. Now if the new moon at that time was not consecrated by observation but rather by following the rules of the Hebrew calendar, then the sixth of Sivan had to fall on a Friday. See chapter 1 of the Mekhilta on the Torah portion Be-Shallach. It is possible that Scripture reads, the same day because the distance18Reading merchak as in Vat. Ebr. 38 rather than rachok as in the printed editions. from Rephidim and Mount Sinai was greater than the distance between each journey.19In other words, the same day refers to the day that they left Rephidim. Our verse thus tells us that Israel came to the wilderness of Sinai on the same day that they left Rephidim. Scripture notes this because unlike the other journeys, which were normally a day’s journey apart, Rephidim and Sinai were far apart. Yet Israel made the journey in one day. From this comment it is clear that I.E. had serious doubts about whether ba-chodesh ha-shelishi really means on the first day of the third month.

AND WHEN THEY WERE DEPARTED FROM REPHIDIM.20Literally, And they departed from Rephidim. Hence I.E.’s comment. Its meaning is, they had already departed from Rephidim.21Verse 1 tells us that Israel came to the wilderness of Sinai. Thus, And they departed from Rephidim is out of place here, for Israel departed from Rephidim before they came to Sinai. Hence va-yisu is to be rendered: and they had already departed, rather than: and they departed. J.P.S. translates accordingly. I have pointed out to you many other such instances.22Where a verb beginning with a conversive vav is a pluperfect. See Vol. 1, page XVI.
THEY ENCAMPED IN THE WILDERNESS. The previously mentioned wilderness of Sinai.

[AND THERE ISRAEL ENCAMPED.] Scripture reads, and there Israel encamped, after stating, they encamped in the wilderness, because the heads of the tribes and the elders camped before the mountain due to their respected positions.23In other words, they encamped in the wilderness refers to the heads of the tribes. As I will explain,24See I.E. on verse 17. Israel stood around the mountain, in accordance with their status, on the day the Torah was given. Scripture uses the singular form va-yichan (encamped) because they25The heads of the tribes. were few in number. Rabbi Solomon26Rashi. says that before (mi-neged) the mount means on the eastern side of the mountain. However, Scripture states, a good way off (mineged) shall they pitch, round about27We thus see that the word neged (before) does not mean east, for Scripture goes on to say, round about (saviv). Hence the word neged can refer to any direction. the tent of meeting (Num. 2:2), namely, on all sides of the tent of meeting. For28This is not a reason for what comes before but an elaboration. as the standards journeyed,29The tribes journeyed by standards. There were four standards for the 12 tribes, one for every three tribes. so did they camp.30Three sides per side of the tent of meeting.

AND MOSES WENT UP UNTO GOD. Scripture above reads, before the mount (v. 2). Its meaning thus is: and Moses went up to the mount of God.31The word mount in verse 2 is carried over to verse 3. Thus, unto God is to be understood as if written: unto the mount of God.
[AND THE LORD CALLED UNTO HIM.] Its meaning is,32See note 22. and the Lord had already called him.33Before he ascended the mountain. For Moses would not have ascended without permission.

[OUT OF THE MOUNTAIN.] Scripture says this34That God called to Moses from out of the mountain, when in fact He called to him from heaven. becauce Moses did not ascend above the mountain.35I.E. was troubled lest And Moses went up unto God be taken to mean that Moses ascended into heaven. Indeed, there are some Midrashim who do say this. For the Lord spoke to Moses on the mountain. Do not be bothered by the fact that Scripture afterwards states, And the Lord came down upon mount Sinai (v. 20),36Which implies that up to now God spoke to Moses from heaven. for the Torah says this from the point of view of Israel when they beheld the cloud and fire. Scripture explicitly states, and thou didst hear His words out of the midst of the fire (Deut. 4:36).37It thus appeared to Israel that God came down on Sinai amidst the fire.

[SAYING.]38Literally, to say. Hence I.E.’s comment Its meaning is that the Lord39So Vat. Ebr. 38. Some of the printed editions have ha-am. This appears to be an error for ha-shem. called Moses to tell him: Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob). The meaning is, say something relating to all of40So Vat. Ebr. 38. the house of Jacob, to those alive today and to their children after them.

[AND TELL THE CHILDREN OF ISRAEL.] The reference is to the elders. The elders will then tell all of the people.41All the words that you will tell them, namely, that which is recorded in verses 4-6. We thus read, And Moses came and called for the elders of the people (v. 7),42The house of Jacob is not mentioned. and it is then written, And all the people answered together (v. 8).
[HOUSE.] I have previously explained the meaning of the word house (Ex. 1:1).

YE HAVE SEEN. The vengeance that I executed upon the Egyptians on your behalf, and that I bore you out of Egypt as if you were carried on the wings of eagles. For an eagle flies higher in the air than any other bird. All birds are afraid of him and he fears no bird. [I BORE YOU ON EAGLES’ WINGS.] Moses employed a similar metaphor later on when he said, As an eagle that stirreth up her nest (Deut. 32:11),43That is, our verse is like Deut. 32:11 in which Moses describes the Exodus in a manner similar to the way he does in our verse. that is, it slowly leads its young.44It has no need to rush as it fears no other bird. Moses similarly referred to the clouds45The pillar of cloud which accompanied Israel. when he said, Spreadeth abroad her wings (Ibid.).

AND BROUGHT YOU UNTO MYSELF. In that God’s glory came down upon this mountain. This is the holy mountain referred to by Moses.46In Ex. 15:13. Now Moses said,47This appears to be an error, as this was said by God to Moses. See Weiser and Krinsky, who suggest this reading: Now Moses was told. If there is no error in the text, then what I.E. means is that Moses in writing the Torah quoted God as saying this. However, see the reading from Vat. Ebr. 38 in the next note. ye shall serve God upon this mountain (Ex. 3:12). The latter is the same as Thy holy habitation (Ex. 15:13).48So too I.E. on Ex. 15:13, where he explains that Thy holy habitation refers to Mount Sinai. Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: In that God’s glory came down upon this mountain which is a holy mountain. This is what Moses meant by Thy holy habitation (Ex. 15:13).

NOW THEREFORE, IF YE WILL HEARKEN UNTO MY VOICE. To observe my commandments and keep the covenant which I will make with you. The reference, as I will explain with irrefutable proofs in the proper place,49Literally, its place. Krinsky and Weiser claim that the reference is to Ex. 24:8. However, neither there nor anywhere else does I.E. prove that the covenant mentioned here is the one made after the revelation. is to the covenant made by Moses with Israel after the giving of the Torah, when he built the altar.50See Ex. 24:4-8.
[TREASURE.] The word segullah (treasure) means something precious, lovely, and unique.

[FOR ALL THE EARTH IS MINE.] This is connected to all peoples.51Mentioned earlier in the verse. The clause is to be interpreted: for all the peoples of the earth are mine. This is what Scripture means by and [I] set you apart from the peoples, that ye should be Mine (Lev. 20:26).52Lev. 20:26 repeats in different words what our verse says. Rabbi Merinus says that ki li kol ha-aretz (for all the earth is mine) means: even though all the earth is mine.53In other words, ki (for) here means even though. I believe that this is the case with ki am keseh oref attah (it is a stiffnecked people) (Ex. 32:9)54Its meaning being, even though (ki) it is a stiff-necked people. and refah nafshi ki chatati lakh (Heal my soul; for I have sinned against Thee) (Ps. 41:5).55Its meaning being, heal my soul, even though (ki) I have sinned against thee.
AND MOSES CAME. To the camp of Israel.56Moses came down from the mountain and went to the camp of Israel. There is no need to mention that Moses descended.57For that is understood.

AND SET BEFORE THEM. As in And this is the law which Moses set before the children of Israel (Deut. 4:44).58In other words, set means transmitted (Weiser). However, the Gaon says that the word set is used here in the same way as the word set in set59Translated literally. it in their mouths (Deut. 31:19). The reference60In Deut. 31:19. In other words, set it in their mouths means: teach them the law, which they will transmit with their mouth, viz., the oral law. is to the oral law which explains the written law.61In other words, set means to teach.

TOGETHER. The word yachdav (together) is grammatically unique62See I.E. on Gen. 13:6 and the notes thereto. in Scripture because of the added vav.63The vav serves no purpose. The word should have read yachad. Yefet explains it to mean alone, by oneself, without anybody else there.64In other words, according to Yefet yachdav does not mean together, which is the meaning of yachad, but as one person. For the differences in nuance see I.E. on Gen. 13:6, note 10.
[REPORTED.] Scripture mentions, and Moses reported, but has no need to mention that Moses went up65To Mount Sinai to report the people’s words to God. because Scripture is being brief.

AND THE LORD SAID. What reason is there for saying, And Moses told the words of the people unto the Lord (v. 9) after having said,66In verse 8. And Moses reported the words of the people unto the Lord? Note that there are many verses in the Torah that should have come earlier.67Than they are presently positioned. Their meaning is that such and such already took place.68In other words, the verbs opening these verses are pluperfects. See verse 2 and the notes thereto. For example, the meaning of va-yitzar (formed) in, Then the Lord God formed69Man. (Gen. 2:7) is, He70The Lord God. had already formed;71Man earlier, for the creation of man is described in the first chapter of Genesis. the meaning of va-yatzmach (made to grow) in And out of the ground made the Lord God to grow (Gen. 2:9) is, He had already made to grow;72See I.E. on Gen 1:8 and the notes thereto. the meaning of va-yomer (and said) in and said: Whose daughter art thou? (Gen. 24:23) is, and he73Abraham’s servant to Rebekah. had already said.74Whose daughter art thou? before giving Rebekah a ring and bracelets. See I.E. on Gen. 24:14 and the notes thereto. Indeed, Scripture explicitly states,75In repeating the events described in Gen. 24:22,23. And I asked her, and said (Gen. 24:47),76Whose daughter art thou? and then,77Goes on to say. I put the ring upon her nose (Ibid.). Similarly, the meaning of And she78Rebekah. said unto the servant (Gen. 24:65) is, and she had already said unto the servant,79What man is this that walketh in the field to meet us? and then, she alighted from the camel (Gen. 24:64).80For the reason, see I.E. on Gen. 24:64 and the notes thereto. There is no need to elaborate.81Although there are many other instances of Scripture’s use of the pluperfect, for the point has been proven. Now the meaning of And Moses told here82In verse 9. is, and Moses had already told. Scripture does not mention what Moses told.83The Lord in the name of the people. The word higid (told) always refers to something new that has not previously been mentioned. It is thus not connected to and Moses reported.84That is, And Moses told (verse 9) does not refer to and Moses reported. From God’s answer to Moses, “Lo, I come unto thee in a thick cloud” (v. 9), we learn what Moses told.85God. In the next paragraph, I.E. goes on to explain what Moses told God. Furthermore, as I will explain,86Later on in the commentary. we find this clearly stated in Moses’ very words. Note that the Egyptians and the Indians are from the children of Ham. Each one relies on the other.87For their traditions and customs. I.E. makes a similar point in Gen. 46:34. The people of India do not eat meat. The Egyptians used to do the same. They changed their practice only because the kingdom of Ishmael88The Arabs. I.E. did not consider the Egyptians as Arabs. In fact, neither did the Egyptians consider themselves Arabs until modern times. overpowered them and they accepted the religion of the Ishmaelites. The Indian sages offer proofs in accordance with their thinking that it is impossible for God to talk to a person and for that person to live. Now the Israelites were in Egypt.89For a long time and came under Egyptian influence. There were among them people who followed this belief.90That God does not communicate with man. They were in doubt about Moses’ prophecy. And they believed in the Lord, and in His servant Moses (Ex. 14:31) does not dispute this.91That there were Israelites who doubted that God spoke with Moses. For Scripture reads, And Israel saw (Ibid.). It does not say: and all Israel saw.92The verse which reads, And they believed in the Lord, and his servant Moses opens with And Israel saw. Since the latter only applies to a part of the people, so does the former. Hence And they believed in the Lord, and his servant Moses refers to part of the people, not to all of the people. Even if it read, all of Israel,93Saw. it would speak of the majority as is the style of the language,94That is, Biblical style. as in and all the cattle of Egypt died (Ex. 9:6),95As a result of a very grievous murrain (Ex. 9:4). which is followed by Now therefore send, hasten in thy cattle (Ex. 9:19).96So that they will not be struck by the hail. Now all the cattle had previously died, so where did these cattle come from? Hence and all the cattle of Egypt died means: and most of the cattle of Egypt died.

[LO, I COME UNTO THEE.] This is to be understood as an answer to Moses, who told this97That some Israelites doubted the possibility of prophecy. to God.98According to I.E. verse 9 reads as follows: And the Lord said unto Moses, Lo I come unto thee in a thick cloud, that the people may hear when I speak with thee, and may also believe thee for ever. But Moses had previously told the words of the people to God. The verse is to be understood as follows: And Moses told the words of the people to God; that is, Moses told God that some Israelites doubted that the Lord speaks to any human being. God answered, Lo I come unto thee in a thick cloud, etc.
[IN A THICK CLOUD.] When God will descend upon the mountain.
WHEN I SPEAK WITH THEE. The Decalogue. They will then believe that God in truth speaks with a person and he lives.

[AND MAY ALSO BELIEVE THEE.] That you are a prophet. All doubt will be removed from their minds. It is explicitly written, we have seen this day that God doth speak with man, and he liveth (Deut. 5:21). It is also written there, For who is there of all flesh, that hath heard the voice of the living God speaking out of the midst of the fire, as we have, and lived? (Deut. 5:23). And it is there written, Go thou near, and hear (Deut. 5:24).99The word of God and report it back to us. Israel said this to Moses. This is what Scripture means by and may also believe thee for ever.
AND THE LORD SAID…SANCTIFY THEM TO-DAY AND TOMORROW. Observe, God enlarged the time allotted for Israel’s sanctification by giving them the rest of this day and the morrow.100To sanctify themselves.

[AND SANCTIFY THEM.] By washing in water. This is indicated by and let them wash their garments.101Which follows. As their garments were sanctified by washing, so were they sanctified by washing themselves. Our verse is to be interpreted after the manner of But if he wash them not, nor bathe his flesh (Lev. 17:16). Moses therefore said, starting from now, come not near a woman (v. 15) so that they would be sanctified and not be unclean. One who drew near to a women should sanctify himself,102By bathing. as in for she was purified103By bathing. See II Sam. 11:2. from her uncleanliness (II Sam. 11:4).

AND BE READY. Its meaning might be that no person among them should sleep during the night, after the manner of the high priest on Yom Kippur,104The high priest did not sleep the entire night of Yom Kippur. See Mishnah Yoma 1:7. Ibn Ezra takes issue with Midrash, which states that Israel overslept on the morning that the Torah was given. See chapter 42 of Pirke De-Rabbi Eliezer. as Israel would hear God’s voice in the morning.

AND THOU SHALT SET BOUNDS. Place a border on the mount.105The Biblical text reads, And thou shalt set bounds (ve-higbalta) unto the people. I.E. interprets this to mean: And thou shalt set bounds on the mount beyond which the people may not cross. Set bounds about the mount, and sanctify it (v. 23) is therefore similar.106For it repeats what is implied in our verse. I dwell on this because the crazy one107Some identify him with Isaac, son of Solomon Israeli (850-950), a court physician to the caliphs of Egypt and Kairouan. He was a philosopher, Bible commentator, and physician. Shadal identifies him with Jonah ibn Janach. who inverted the words of the living God in his book108In his Sefer Ha-Tzachot. I.E. claims that this commentator wanted to make 100 such emendations in the Torah. I.E. suggests that his works be burned. See I.E. on Gen. 36:31,32. Also see Gen. 50, note 17. said that Moses intended to say,109In verse 23. set bounds about the people,110As in our verse. This commentator obviously held that And thou shalt set bounds unto the people does not mean: and thou shalt set bounds on the mountain.
