Hence he will not keep his anger in check when it comes to the fourth generation. Grandchildren are considered as children.201Thus upon the children is short for upon the children and upon the grandchildren. See Ex. 34:7. Hence Scripture employed a shortened form. One can understand this202That God visits the sins of the fathers upon grandchildren. from the terms the third and fourth generation.203If God visits the sins of the fathers upon the third and fourth generation, He certainly does so on the second generation.

AND SHOWING MERCY UNTO THE THOUSANDTH GENERATION.204Literally, and showing mercy unto thousands (of generations). Hence I.E.’s comments. Scripture elsewhere reads, to a thousand generations (Deut. 7:9). Some people think this represents a problem.205Scripture here promises that God will show mercy unto thousands of generations, whereas in Deuteronomy He promises to show mercy to a thousand generations. However, it does not, for Scripture reads as follows: if you will observe My commandments then God will keep the covenant and the mercy which He swore unto your ancestors, that is, to the three patriarchs.206To a thousand generations. This is the meaning of who keepeth covenant and mercy with them that love Him and keep His commandments to a thousand generations (Deut. 7:9). However this chapter deals with another matter. Scripture here states, and showing mercy to thousands.207Of generations. Its meaning is, without end, namely, forever. This can be explained in two ways. One, God shows mercy to those who love Him by granting everlasting existence to their souls so that they remain alive for thousands upon thousands of years. Two, that God will eternally show mercy to their offspring who are like them. David similarly said, But the mercy of the Lord is from everlasting to everlasting upon them that fear Him, And His righteousness unto children’s children (Ps. 103:17). Now there is no doubt that God’s mercy is eternally upon those who fear Him.208What need then is there for Scripture to state, of them that love Me and keep My commandments? It is only because Scripture mentions the children’s children,209They are alluded to in unto the thousandth generation. in keeping with And His righteousness endureth for ever (Ps. 111:3), that Scripture has to explain that this only applies if the children are good. Scripture therefore says that this is so only in regard to those who keep God’s covenant. When I comment upon the Torah portion Ki Tissa, I will explain to you why the attribute of visiting the sins of the fathers is to be counted among the attributes of mercy.210See I.E. on Ex. 34:7.
[THEM THAT LOVE ME.] The reference is to the pious.211Hebrew, chasidim. [AND KEEP MY COMMANDS.] The reference is to the righteous.212Hebrew, tzadikim.

THOU SHALT NOT TAKE THE NAME OF THE LORD THY GOD IN VAIN. The word shem (name) has the same meaning as the word zekher (memory). It serves as a sign of the one who is so called.213In other words, a proper name calls forth a specific person. However, the term zekher is employed in Hebrew at times when someone is recalled in memory, and at times when someone is recalled in speech, whereas names are only used with reference to the latter. We thus find David saying, Nor take their names upon my lips (Ps. 16:4). Now when a person mentions God’s name214When taking an oath. he is saying, as God is True so is what I will say true. Thus if he does not keep his word, he is, as it were, denying God. It is still the custom in Egypt for one to incur the death penalty if he swears by the head of the king and does not keep his word. The culprit is not spared even if he gives his ransom in gold because he publicly insulted the king. If this is the case with regard to a king of flesh and blood, how many thousands of times more does one have to be careful that one’s mouth does not cause his tongue to stumble and bring his flesh into guilt by mentioning God’s name in vain.215Cf. Eccles. 5:5. Now Scripture tells us that Israel publicly took an oath because of the incident involving the concubine at Gibeah. We find that those who violated the oath were put to death.216See Judges 19-21. It should be noted that Phineas the priest was there.217Judges 20:18. The point is that Phineas could not find an out for the people who violated the oath. Similarly with the people of Jabesh-gilead, men, women, and children.218They were all put to death because the above-noted oath was violated. Even those who desecrate the Sabbath are not dealt with in this manner.219The families of Sabbath violators are not punished. We also read that Saul wanted to kill his son Jonathan for desecrating an oath that Jonathan was not even aware of.220See I Sam. 14:24-45. Scripture also tells us221Literally, we also see. that God brought a famine upon the land because Saul and his house violated the oath taken by the leaders of Israel which they swore unto the Gibeonites.222See II Sam. 21:1 and Josh. 9:15. We are told that when the house of blood was put to death, God was entreated for the land.223I.E.’s paraphrase of II Sam. 21:14. Solomon similarly said to Shimei, Did I not make thee to swear by the Lord (I Kings 2:42).224Solomon put Shimei to death for violating an oath. The sum of the matter is that with the exception of honoring one’s parents,225That is, the reward that is promised for honoring one’s parents. we do not find the reward for observing a commandment clearly spelled out in any of the Ten Statements. We similarly do not find the punishment for violating a commandment226That is, one of the Ten Commandments. spelled out except for idolatry and taking God’s name in vain. Many think that a person who takes the name of the Lord in vain does not commit a great sin. I will show that in reality it is more severe than any of the other prohibitions which follow. For a murderer cannot commit murder, nor an adulterer adultery, both of which are major sins, whenever they want to because they are afraid of being caught. However, the person who is the habit of swearing falsely will daily utter innumerable vows. Such a person is so accustomed to committing this sin that he is not even aware that he is taking an oath. Should someone chide him and say to him, “Why are you swearing?” he responds by swearing that he did not swear, because he is so habituated to swearing. For he prefaces anything he says by saying, “I swear.” They227Those who constantly swear. think that this is an elegant way to speak.228To preface everything they say with “I swear.” If Israel was guilty only of this sin it would be cause enough to prolong the exile and add blows to our blows. I will now demonstrate their madness. For a murderer who kills his enemy satisfies his impulses by exacting vengeance. Similarly the adulterer for the moment. Likewise the thief who finds pleasures for his needs, and the false witness who does so to gain favor or revenge. Now the one who is constantly swearing, although there is no need for him to do so publicly, desecrates the name of God without deriving any benefit from his act.

REMEMBER THE SABBATH DAY TO KEEP IT HOLY. The meaning of to keep it holy is explained by what follows, namely, Six days shalt thou labor. Scripture similarly explains the meaning of and hallowed it (v. 11) by going on to say that God rested on the seventh day from all of His work. The reason the sanctification of the Sabbath is here connected to the Lord blessed [the sabbath day], as it is in the chapter opening with the words were finished (Gen. 2:1), is that God sanctified this day and prepared it so that the souls229Of those who observe the Sabbath. would receive an infusion of wisdom above that of the other days. That is why Scripture states the Lord blessed [the sabbath day].230According to I.E. a blessing means that something good should be increased. See I.E. on Gen. 2:3 and the notes thereto. I have already explained this in my comments on A Psalm, a Song. For the sabbath day.231See I.E. on Ps. 92:50. We have seen232In Scripture. that the sabbatical year is similar to the Sabbath.233See Lev. 25:4. It too is a seventh, that is, it falls every seven years. God commanded that the Torah be read at the beginning of the year234According to I.E. the reference is to the beginning of the Sabbatical year. in the presence of the men, women, and little ones. The reason for this is that they may hear, and that they may learn…and observe to do all the words of this law (Deut. 31:12). Now the Sabbath was given235As a day to be set aside from the other days of the week. for understanding the works of God and the study of His Torah. Scripture thus states,236In the psalm dedicated to and chanted on the Sabbath. For Thou, Lord, hast me glad through Thy work (Ps. 92:5).237Which, according to I.E., means that the study of God’s work gladdens the heart. A person is occupied with his needs all the days of the week. However, it is only right that he separate himself on the Sabbath and rest for the sake of God’s glory. He should not occupy himself with vanity by spending his time seeking advice, even if it concerns his past needs. He should similarly not seek counsel about what he should do in the future. The prophet similarly said, Nor pursuing thy business,238On the Sabbath. nor speaking thereof (Is. 58:13). It was customary for the Israelites to travel before the onset of the Sabbath to where the prophets lived, as indicated in Wherefore wilt thou go to him to-day? it is neither new moon nor sabbath (II Kings 4:23). I have239In his comment on verse 1. already noted that whosoever does any work on the Sabbath is in essence denying creation. However, such an individual does not deny the existence of God the revered.240Hence the prohibition to violate the Sabbath is not subsumed in the first of the Ten Statements. There can be no doubt that the word thou includes all those who are obligated to observe the commandments. Hence nor thy son, nor thy daughter (v. 10) refers to small children for whose rest their father is responsible. Scripture tells us that we are obligated to guard them241On the Sabbath. lest they do anything on the Sabbath that we are prohibited from doing. The same applies to nor thy man-servant, nor thy maid-servant who is in our power. We our obligated to guard him and not allow him to do any work for another party; otherwise, we violate a negative commandment,242Namely, thou shalt not do any manner of work, thou…nor thy man-servant, nor thy maid-servant (v. 10). so that thy man-servant and thy maid-servant may rest as well as thou (Deut. 5:14). This was explained by Moses our master in the way we have noted.243That in repeating the Ten Statements, Moses inserted comments. It is only on this condition that the stranger may dwell in our gates, namely, that the stranger does not do any work on the Sabbath and on Yom Kippur.244Which is referred to as a Sabbath in Lev. 23:32. Hence the stranger is also mentioned in the second version.245Of the Ten Statements in Deut. 5:14. It is the same case with the sexual prohibitions.246Mentioned in Lev. 18. The stranger may dwell among us only if he observes the sexual prohibitions. Likewise with regard to eating blood.247Lev. 17:10. When reading the Book of Jeremiah we noticed that the prophet was very strict about the Sabbath.248The prophet threatens Jerusalem with destruction for violating the Sabbath. The prophet explicitly stated that if Israel returns to Sabbath observance and keeps the Sabbath as they were commanded to, then even though the decree that Jerusalem be destroyed was issued, they would not be exiled from their place, and the thrones of the Davidic dynasty would remain standing in Jerusalem.249I.E.’s paraphrase of Jer. 17:25. See Jer. 17:27

HONOR THY FATHER AND THY MOTHER, AS THE LORD THY GOD COMMANDED THEE. I have already noted that the Lord’s name is mentioned in the first five statements. In all of these statements we find the form, the Lord thy God.

[THAT THY DAYS MAY BE LONG.] The word ya’arikhun (may be long) is a transitive verb. Its meaning is that one’s parents will be the cause of one’s days being long.250In other words, ya’arikhun (may be long) is to be rendered, they (your parents) will lengthen. The term ta’arikhu (ye may prolong) in and that ye may prolong your days (Deut. 11:9) and ve-ha’arakhta (that thou mayest prolong) in and that thou mayest prolong thy days (Deut. 22:7) are proof of this.251Ta’arikhu and ve-ha’arakhta are transitive. Similarly, ya’arikhun. You will find that because of the commandment which you observe, you lengthen your days.252For you will be rewarded with length of years for observing God’s laws.

[UPON THE LAND.] Scripture reads, upon the land because if Israel observes this commandment they will not be exiled from the land. The prophet Ezekiel similarly states, In thee253Jerusalem. have they made light of father and mother (Ezek. 22:7). The commandment Honor thy father and thy mother means that we should not do the opposite; that is, we should not curse or make light of our parents. Now one who curses his parents incurs the death penalty because people hear the curse come out of his mouth.254Ex. 21:17. However, this penalty does not apply to one who disrespects his parents, for one can do so in secret. Therefore the one who is disrespectful to his parents falls under a curse like all those who are listed as cursed,255See Deut. 27:15-26. for their deeds were done in secret.

THOU SHALT NOT MURDER. With your hand or your tongue, that is, by giving false testimony which results in having someone executed, or by tale bearing,256Which results in someone’s death. or by wickedly giving someone counsel which you know will result in his death, or by not revealing a secret which you are aware of, to someone who would be saved if he knew what you know. If you do not reveal the secret you are a murderer.

THOU SHALT NOT COMMIT ADULTERY. Many think that the term ni’uf (adultery) only applies to adultery257With a married woman. This is the opinion of Rashi. because they found Scripture stating, asher yinaf et eshet re’ehu (even he that committeth adultery with his neighbor’s wife) (Lev. 20:10). What reason is there to state this, having just said, asher yinaf eshet ish (that committeth adultery with another man’s wife)?258It is redundant. Hence we must assume that Scripture is explaining that the ni’uf spoken of in the first part of the verse can only be committed with a married woman. In other words, asher yinaf et eshet re’ehu (even he that committeth adultery with his neighbor’s wife) explains the term yinaf in asher yinaf eshet ish (that committeth adultery with another man’s wife). However, its meaning is not as they think.259For the term ni’uf applies to all prohibited sexual acts. Now the previous verse reads, For whatsoever man there be that curseth his father or his mother shall surely be put to death; he hath cursed his father or his mother; his blood shall be upon him (Lev. 20:9). Its meaning is,260The meaning of he hath cursed his father or his mother. he committed a great sin in cursing his parents who bore him. The same is true even of he that committeth adultery with his neighbor’s wife, whom261The reference is to the neighbor. Scripture repeats to emphasize the sin; i.e., he has committed a great sin in sleeping with the wife of a person whom he is commanded to love as himself. he is obligated to love as himself. The word ni’uf refers to an illicit sexual act. Behold, we find that Scripture states, va-tinaf et ha-even ve-et ha-etz (and she committed adultery with stones and with stocks) (Jer. 3:9).262One cannot commit adultery with stones. Hence the meaning of va-tinaf (and she committed adultery) must be rendered: and she committed illicit sexual acts. For other interpretations see Weiser and Krinsky. However, it is unfit to discuss this abomination publicly.263The type of sexual acts committed with stones and stocks. Saadiah Gaon says that there are many levels of illicit sexual acts. The least illicit level is sleeping with a virgin or widow.264That is, an unmarried woman. Next comes sleeping with one’s wife during her menstrual cycle, for she will be permitted to him in a few days. Then comes sleeping with someone else’s wife, for it is possible that her husband will die and she will be permitted to him. Next comes sleeping with a Canaanite woman,265By Canaanite woman I.E. means a non-Jewish woman. who does not follow Israelite law, without giving her seed, for it is possible that she will convert and he can then marry her. However, if he gives her seed then it is as if he himself is worshipping idols. Next comes sleeping with a male, which can never be permitted. Next comes bestiality, that is, intercourse with a nonhuman. The Gaon knew how to classify the various types of illicit intercourse,266This appears to be a sarcastic statement. In Lev. 18:21, I.E. says that Saadiah’s classification of the prohibited sexual acts is a waste of time. However, in his short commentary on Exodus, I.E. writes that Saadiah’s classification is close to the truth. for Scripture decrees the penalty of karet267Excision. for all of the illicit sexual acts listed in the Torah portion Achare Mot.268See Lev. 18:29. In other words, the Torah does not distinguish among them. Saadiah omitted intercourse with one’s mother, sister, and daughter from his list of different levels of illicit sexual acts.269Which shows that Saadiah’s classification is far from perfect.

THOU SHALT NOT STEAL. Stealing implies taking money secretly. There are thieves who incur the death penalty, namely, those who kidnap an Israelite, be he a child or one who cannot speak clearly.270An adult who cannot speak clearly and thus complain to others that he has been kidnapped. The prohibition to steal money applies both to when the owner is present and to when he is not present. It also applies to cheating in number, measure, and weight. The term stealing also applies to what Absalom did,271Deception. See II Sam. 15:6. that is, it prohibits deceiving another person.

THOU SHALT NOT BEAR FALSE WITNESS. For many years I asked myself why Scripture employs the phrase ed sheker (false witness) and not edut sheker (false testimony). I now believe that Scripture is addressing the false witness, and our verse is to be interpreted as if it read, “Thou shalt not give testimony if thou art a false witness.” The implication of this clause is the same as that of neither shall ye deal falsely, nor lie one to another (Lev. 19:11). We find that a bet follows the word for testimony in and hath testified (anah) falsely against his brother (be-achiv) (Deut. 19:18). We also find this verb employed without a bet following it in yishma El ve-ya’anem (God shall hear, and testify against them) (Ps. 55:20).272Translated according to I.E. Now ve-ya’anem is a compound of ve-ya’aneh (and shall testify) and bam (against them).273In effect, a bet follows “to testify,” for the mem suffix stands for the word bam. The phrase lo nega’anukha (not touched thee) in as we have not touched thee (Gen. 26:29) is similar, as the meaning of lo nega’anukha is lo naganu bakh (we have not touched thee).274In other words, the kaf suffix stands for the word bakh. Thus in both cases the suffix stands for a bet. There is a type of false witness who incurs the death penalty, namely, the one concerning whom it is written, then shall ye do unto him, as he had purposed to do unto his brother (Deut. 19:19).275If the false testimony would have resulted in an innocent person’s execution, then the false witness is put to death.

THOU SHALT NOT COVET. Many people are amazed at this commandment. They ask, how is it possible for a person not to covet in his heart all beautiful things that appear desirable to him? I will now give you a parable.276Which will aid you in understanding the commandment that prohibits coveting. Note, a peasant of sound mind who sees a beautiful princess will not entertain any covetous thoughts about sleeping with her, for he knows that this is an impossibility. This peasant will not think like the insane who desire to sprout wings and fly to the sky, for it is impossible to do so. Now just as a man does not desire to sleep with his mother, although she be beautiful, because he has been trained from his childhood to know that she is prohibited to him, so must every intelligent person know that a person does not acquire a beautiful woman or money because of his intelligence or wisdom, but only in accordance with what God has apportioned to him. Indeed, Koheleth states, yet to a man that hath not labored therein shall he leave it for his portion (Eccles. 2:21). Furthermore, our sages taught, children, life, and sustenance are not dependent upon a person’s merits but upon the stars.277Mo’ed Katan 28a. The intelligent person will therefore neither desire nor covet. Once he knows that God has prohibited his neighbor’s wife to him she will be more exalted in his eyes than the princess is in the eyes of the peasant. He will therefore be happy with his lot and will not allow his heart to covet and desire anything which is not his. For he knows that that which God did not want to give him, he cannot acquire by his own strength, thoughts, or schemes. He will therefore trust in his creator, that is, that his creator will sustain him and do what is right in His sight. Observe, we have completed explaining the Ten Statements. One of the wise men of this generation said: We know that nine spheres278See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 and the notes thereto. correspond to the nine numbers279From 2 to 10. that are the basis of all numbers.280See I.E. on Ex. 3:15 and the notes thereto. It is the same with these nine statements.281Of the Decalogue. Now the first statement, which corresponds to the glory of God the revered who speaks, is not included among the nine statements, for it is the first of the ten in number.282It is the basis of all that follows. Similarly, the number one is not included among the ten numbers. Now the second statement, which is Thou shalt have no…etc. (v. 3), corresponds to the highest sphere, which moves west to east and propels the other spheres to make a twenty-four hour east-to-west circuit in contrast to its own motion.283Which moves west to east. It is in reference to this sphere that Scripture states, other gods. It says this to let us know that the spheres run by the power of God. Many considered this sphere to be the creator because it is incorporeal. The third statement, namely, Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain (v. 7), corresponds to the sphere of the constellations wherein are all the hosts of heaven, with the exception of the seven moving stars.284Each of which has its own sphere. Literally, the seven ministers. Now this important sphere encompasses all the forty-eight bodies285Heavenly bodies. and their forms.286See I.E.’s comment on verse 3 and the notes thereto. God’s power is there revealed to the eye.287God’s power is seen in the arrangement of the stars. There are places in this sphere which contain many stars. There are other places in it which have no stars. It is impossible for a man to know this secret. Many of those deficient in wisdom think that these forms in their arrangement were created in vain.288Hence the third statement reads, Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain. The fourth statement, the statement about the Sabbath, corresponds to the sphere of Saturn. The astrologers289Literally, the experimenters. tell us that each one of the moving stars has a certain day in the week in which its power is manifest.290In other words, Saturn dominates on the Sabbath. Indeed, the name Saturday means Saturn’s day. The star is the dominant power the first hour of the day.291On which it is dominant. The same is true concerning the star which is the dominant power in the first hour of the night.292The star which is dominant during the first hour of the night dominates that night. They say that Saturn and Mars are harmful stars. Hence harm befalls anyone who begins any work or sets out on a journey when one or the other dominates. The sages therefore said that permission was given for harming293Which I.E. interprets to mean for Mars and Saturn to have an evil influence. on Wednesday night294Saturn dominates Wednesday night (Weiser). and on the eve of the Sabbath. Now we do not find these two “demons”295Mars and Saturn. ruling night and day, back to back, on any other day of the week except for Saturday.296Literally, this day Mars rules Friday eve and Saturn on Saturday (Weiser). It is therefore unfit for one to occupy himself on Saturday with everyday matters. On the contrary, one should devote himself on this day to the fear of God. The fifth statement, namely, Honor thy father and thy mother, corresponds to the sphere of Jupiter,297Hebrew, tzedek. Literally, righteousness. which indicates peace, righteousness, mercy, and the obligation to reward and honor those to whom we owe a debt of gratitude. The sixth statement, Thou shalt not murder, corresponds to the sphere of Mars, which points to bloodshed and wounding. There is a difference of opinion among the astrologers about whether Venus is above or below298An allusion to sexual intercourse. the sun. The wise men of India brought proof that Venus is above.299This has no bearing on I.E.’s comment. He inserted it as an aside on his comments on the verse. Now the seventh statement, namely, Thou shalt not commit adultery, corresponds to the sphere of Venus, the nature of which points to all acts of intercourse and harlotry. The eighth statement, namely, Thou shalt not steal, corresponds to the sphere of the sun and indicates force. It removes the power of any planet300The moon included. that is in conjunction with it so that its light is not seen. Now the ninth statement, namely, Thou shalt not bear false witness, corresponds to the sphere of Mercury, which indicates language.301Literally, the tongue. According to the Talmud anyone born when Mercury dominates will be wise. See Sabbath 156a. The tenth statement, namely, Thou shalt not covet, clearly corresponds to the sphere of the moon, which is the lowest of the spheres. It indicates desire.

AND ALL THE PEOPLE PERCEIVED THE THUNDERINGS.302Literally, and all the people saw the thunderings, hence I.E. comments. I have already explained the meaning of “saw the thunderings.”303See I.E. on Ex. 5:21. Scripture says the aforementioned because all the senses are perceived in one place.304See I.E. on Ex. 5:21. Now the meaning of our verse is: when Israel saw these wonders, that is, when the people perceived the thunderings and the lightning, which people normally fear, and the voice of the horn, a sound such as had never been heard of before, and the mountain smoking, they trembled. The meaning of va-yanu’u (and they trembled) is, and they moved; that is, each one of them turned from where he was standing and went backwards. Va-yanu’u is similar to the word na (a fugitive) in a fugitive and a wanderer (Gen. 4:12). The word va-yanu’u (were moved) in And the posts (amot) of the door (ha-sippim) were moved (Is. 6:4) is similar. The meaning of amot (posts) in the aforementioned verse is cubits, for the thresholds305I.E. renders sippim (doors) as thresholds. moved a number of cubits from their place.306According to I.E., Is. 6:4 should be rendered: and the thresholds moved some cubits. The prophet was not able to estimate, in his vision, how many cubits they moved. It is impossible to maintain that va-yanu’u means: and they trembled. For if Israel did not remove themselves from their place, how did they stand far off?

AND THEY SAID. The reference is to the priests and the heads of the tribes who were close to Moses. They spoke to Moses after the Ten Statements were completed because they were very anxious, for they feared that God would continue to speak to them and that they would consequently die. That is why Moses told them, Fear not (v. 17).

AND MOSES SAID. The lamed in the word le-va’avor (for) is superfluous.307It has no meaning, for le-va’avor (for) means the same thing as ba-avur. It is like the lamed in the word le-mabbarishonah (at the first) (I Chron. 15:13) and the lamed of le-avshalom (Absalom) in Absalom the son of Maacah (I Chron. 3:2).
[TO PROVE YOU.] To prove you is similar in meaning to and that He might prove thee, to do thee good at thy latter end (Deut. 8:16).

AND THAT HIS FEAR MAY BE BEFORE YOU. As it is written, the day that thou stoodest before the Lord thy God in Horeb (Deut. 4:10).308The verse goes on to say, that they may learn to fear Me all the days that they live upon the earth.
AND THE PEOPLE STOOD AFAR OFF. Scripture mentions this a second time because Moses did the opposite. They stood from afar; however, Moses drew near the thick darkness.

AND THE LORD SAID. Many err because they found Scripture stating, and thou didst hear His words out of the midst of the fire (Deut. 4:36) that God was on Mount Sinai, for it is written, And the Lord came down upon mount Sinai (Ex. 19:20). However, Scripture here states, I have talked with you from heaven. Now he who is intelligent will understand its meaning from my comments on the Torah portion Ki Tissa.309See I.E. on Ex. 33:21. What I will now do is offer a parable. Perhaps this will help the unintelligent understand. Imagine the form of a person standing with his feet on Mount Sinai and his head in heaven. This is the meaning of And the Lord came down (Ex. 19:20) and of God’s speaking from heaven. It is similar to And His feet shall stand in that day upon the mount of Olives (Zech. 14:4), for we know that God’s glory fills heaven and earth.310There is thus no need for Him to go up or come down (Weiser). God is all over.

YE SHALL NOT MAKE WITH ME. Its meaning is: Look, I who dwell in heaven spoke to you without any intermediary.311That is why Ye shall not make with Me—gods of silver, or gods of gold. (v. 20). Indeed, Scripture explicitly states, The Lord spoke with you face to face (Deut. 5:4). Do not be perplexed because Scripture repeats, ye shall not make.312The phrase Ye shall not make appears twice in our verse. Scripture is following elegant Hebrew style. It is similar to Thou shalt not covet (v. 14).313Which is found twice in verse 14 even though once would suffice. It all has one meaning,314Whether repeated or not. to be read as follows: “Ye shall not make with Me gods of silver, or gods of gold.” It is like Thou shalt not make unto thee a graven image (v. 4). Its meaning is: do not make forms that receive powers from above and think that you make them for My glory, in that they will serve as an intermediary between Me and you, like the golden calf which Israel made. As I will explain in its place, Aaron made the golden calf for God’s glory.315See I.E. on Ex. 31:18. God warned Israel at the beginning316Concerning the laws, after revelation of the Ten Statements. not to make gods of gold because He knew that Israel would make the golden calf.

The meaning of with Me thus is: I have no need for intermediaries to be with Me. Scripture therefore states afterwards, I will come unto thee and bless thee. Its meaning is, through My glory I will come unto thee.

AN ALTAR OF STONE.317The Bible reads, an altar of earth. That is what I.E. comments upon. Some say that the reason318The prohibition to use hewn stones in constructing the altar. is that they not make images on the altar. Scripture therefore commanded that the altar be constructed from unhewn stones. Perhaps these commentators can explain why the entire tabernacle was adorned with cherubim and why cherubim of gold were placed over the arkcover. Furthermore, the entire temple constructed by Solomon was decorated with cherubim, images,319Hebrew, temunot. However, I Kings 6:32 reads, timmorot (palm trees). It is possible that temunot is a scribal error and that we should read timmorot. and open flowers (I Kings 6:32). These places were more important than the place of the altar.320Why then would God prohibit similar images on the altar? I will speak on this in the Torah portion Ki Tissa. Some say that the meaning of An altar of earth is that the altar shall not be constructed on a high place. However, this is not what the words imply. The fact that Scripture goes on to state next, And if thou make Me an altar of stone is proof of this.321That “earth” is to be taken literally, for if it is not to be taken literally then neither is “stone.” Our sages said that An altar of earth means that the bronze altar322See Ex. 27:1-8. is to be filled with earth. They spoke the truth, for that is what they did. However, this verse serves only as a reminder323That the bronze altar was filled with earth. and as a support.324For the tradition that the bronze altar was to be filled with earth. This325The interpretation that an altar of earth means that the bronze altar is to be filled with earth. is not its literal meaning. The earth that was placed in the altar was not essential,326It was not an actual part of the bronze altar. Indeed when Israel journeyed from place to place the earth was left behind. Hence it would not be referred to as an altar of earth and the altar327Described in Ex. 27:1-8. was known only as the bronze altar. It was so named because it was made out of bronze. The altar of incense328See Ex. 30:1-8. was also called the gold altar because it was covered with gold.329The point is the altar of incense had two names. However, unlike the earth placed in the bronze altar, the gold was an essential part of the altar. Furthermore, if the implication of An altar of earth is an altar filled with earth, then the meaning of an altar of stone is an altar filled with stones. However, we cannot say that the altar330Referred to in Scripture as an altar of stone. was not constructed of stones, for Scripture explicitly tells us that it was made out of stones.331Deut. 27:5. The reference332In Deut. 27:5. is to the altar made on Mount Ebal. I will now explain. Saadiah Gaon says that there is a difference of opinion concerning the altar that Moses built beneath Mount Sinai.333See Ex. 24:4. Some say that he built the altar before the giving of the Torah. Others maintain that he built it afterwards. The Gaon agrees with the first opinion. He says that what Scripture records in this chapter, namely, the chapter which contains the words All that the Lord hath spoken we will do (Ex. 19:8), is repeated in the second chapter, that is, in the chapter that reads, All that the Lord hath spoken will we do, and obey (Ex. 24:7).334We thus see that they refer to the same event. I will prove to you conclusively that Moses built the altar after the giving of the Torah. This chapter clearly states that God told Moses, when he went up to the mountain of God prior to the giving of the Torah, Ye have seen what I did unto the Egyptians…Now therefore, if ye will hearken unto My voice (Ex. 19:4, 5). God started by saying, Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob (Ex. 19:3). Now Moses did not relate335At that time. any commandments, statutes, or ordinances to Israel. He merely wanted to hear from their very lips whether they wanted to listen to God’s voice and do what He commanded them. Israel replied by saying, we will do (Ex. 19:8). Scripture then goes on to report, And Moses told the words of the people unto the Lord (Ex. 19:9). Moses then sanctified Israel so that they would be fit to hear God’s word, which consisted of the Ten Statements. He now336After the Ten Statements were revealed. started to instruct the people in God’s commandments. When Moses approached the thick darkness God told him everything stated in the section that begins, Ye shall not make with Me (v. 20)337That is, verses 20-23. and the entire chapter of Now these are the ordinances (Ex. 21:1) up to, for they will be a snare unto thee (Ex. 23:33). Scripture then tells us, And Moses came (Ex. 24:3); that is, he came down from the mountain. Scripture then goes on to state, and [Moses] told the people all the words of the Lord and all the ordinances (Ibid.). The words of the Lord refers to the positive and negative commandments, starting with Ye shall not make with Me—gods of silver (v. 20); the account of the altar and all the positive and negative commandments found in the chapter that begins, And these are the Ordinances, such as thou shalt surely bring it back to him again (Ex. 23:4); thou shalt restore it unto him by that the sun goeth down (Ex. 22:25), and Thou shalt not revile God (Ex. 22:27). The ordinances refer to the laws dealing with slavery, assault, fights, goring, arson, theft, oaths. It is concerning these that Scripture there writes, and all the ordinances (Ex. 24:3). It is concerning these laws that our forefathers said, will we do, and obey (Ex. 24:7). The meaning of will we do is, we will observe the positive and the negative commandments. The meaning of and obey is: we will obey the ordinances. The Israelites therefore added and obey, something which they at first338Before the revelation of the Ten Statements. did not say339See Ex. 19:8. following the giving of the Torah. The meaning of An altar of earth clearly is, as the phrase implies, an altar made out of earth. This is what Scripture refers to when it writes later, and builded an altar under the mount (Ex. 24:4). Scripture here writes, and shalt sacrifice thereon thy burnt-offerings, and thy peace-offerings (v. 21), and it is there written, [and they] offered burnt-offerings, and sacrificed peace-offerings (Ex. 24:5).340We thus see that the altar mentioned here and the altar mentioned in Ex. 24:5 were built for the same purpose. This supports I.E.’s contention that the reference is to the same altar. There is no doubt that the section beginning, An altar of earth and also Ye shall not make with Me (v. 20) were stated because of the blood of the covenant which Moses dashed on the altar (Ex. 24:6) and because the people pledged that the Lord alone would be their God and that they would observe His commandments and ordinances (Ex. 24:7). Scripture mentions, thy sheep, and thine oxen (v. 21) because both of them are kinds of animals from which burnt offerings and peace offerings may be brought.341These were the offerings brought by Moses after God’s revelation to Israel. I saw a heretic, may his bones be crushed, arguing against the sages of the Talmud for saying, Which was the place appointed for the sacrifices (Zevachim 5:1).342Chapter 5 of tractate Zevachim deals with the place set aside for the various sacrifices. The term used by the Mishnah for various sacrifices is zevachim. The heretic claimed that he never found the Torah using the term sacrifice (zevach) except for a peace offering.343Whereas the rabbis in tractate Zevachim apply it to all sorts of sacrificial offerings. We thus find Scripture speaking of a burnt offering and sacrifices (zevachim). The burnt offering is an entity unto itself, and sacrifices refer only to peace offerings, as in [and they] offered burnt-offerings, and sacrificed peace-offerings of oxen unto the Lord (Ex. 24:5). We344So argued the heretic. find this to be the case all over. Now I showed this heretic that what he said was incorrect. Scripture here states, and shalt sacrifice345Hebrew, ve-zavachta. We thus see that the term zavach also applies to peace offerings. Similarly with the noun zevach/zevachim. thereon thy burnt-offerings, and thy peace-offerings. He then admitted that he sinned in contradicting people eminently greater than any who lived in all the generations that came after them.

[IN EVERY PLACE WHERE I CAUSE MY NAME TO BE MENTIONED.] Its meaning and interpretation is, in every place where I will set a memorial for My name, that is, in every place where My glory dwells such as Shilo and Nob where the ark stood. If you come to the aforementioned place for the sake of My name to visit Me, I too will come unto you and bless you.

[I WILL COME UNTO THEE.] This is an anthropomorphism. Its meaning is: you will find Me in the place upon which I cause My name to be mentioned, which is the place of My glory.346That is, the place where God’s glory dwells. I, as it were, came to you because I knew that you would come and it is because of you that I came. Furthermore, because you came to pay Me homage, I will come unto thee and bless thee. You will have no need to seek anyone else, for you will find Me as long as My glory is there.

AND IF THOU MAKE ME AN ALTAR OF STONE. The altar that Moses built to make a covenant with Israel with the blood of the covenant347Ex. 24:4. [was made out of earth].348The words in brackets are not in the text, but they have to be added to make sense of I.E.’s comment. See Weiser. God commanded349God now also commanded (Filwarg). that Israel build an altar of stone on the other side of the Jordan before they would inherit the land and that they write the entire Torah upon the stones, because many of the commandments are contingent upon the Land of Israel.350See Deut. 27:1-8. I.E. claims that Deut. 27:1-8 refers to the command given now. We similarly find that God required their children351The children of those who stood at Mount Sinai. to build such an altar when they entered the land352See Josh. 8:30-35. because of the commandments contingent upon the Land of Israel.353That is, because of the many commandments contingent upon living in the Land of Israel. They sacrificed and ate peace offerings there354At Mount Ebel. as their fathers did.355At Mount Sinai. According to the above, the meaning of And if thou make an altar of stone is, now build an altar of earth. However, if you are worthy to enter the Land of Israel, then you will make Me an altar of stone.
IT.356Literally, them. Hence I.E.’s comment. The reference is to the stones.

HEWN STONES. Its meaning is similar to that of but his minister Joshua, the son of Nun, a young man (Ex. 33:11).357Which, according to I.E., is short for: but his minister Joshua, the son of Nun, did the ministry of a young man. See I.E. on Ex. 33:11. Similarly here, lo tivneh ethem gazit (do not build a hewn structure out of them).358In other words, lo tivneh ethem gazit (literally, you shall not build them hewn stones) is short for lo tivneh ethem binyan gazit. The word gazit (hewn stones) comes from the same root as gozeze (shearers) in and went up unto his sheep-shearers (Gen. 38:12) and gaz (cut) in, For it is speedily cut, and we fly away (Ps. 90:10).359Translated according to I.E. It is the same case with nagozu (cut) in Even so shall they be cut down, and he shall pass away (Nahum 1:12). Its meaning360The meaning of gazit. is, cut.361Or hewn. Only unhewn stones, that is, stones as God created them, [were to be used].

FOR IF THOU LIFTED UP THY TOOL UPON IT. The word cherev (tool) refers to an iron instrument made for cutting.362The word cherev usually means a sword. Hence I.E.’s comment. It is possible that the instrument is called a cherev because it destroys (mecharevet). Scripture elsewhere states, thou shalt lift up no iron tool upon them (Deut. 27:5),363The word barzel (iron tool) rather than cherev is used in this parallel verse. We thus see that cherev refers to an iron tool used for cutting. that is, upon the altar of stones that Israel built.364Upon crossing the Jordan. We should not look for explanations for the commandments. However, from a rational point of view it is possible that the prohibition against hewn stones is similar to the law governing “a vile thing.”365Hebrew, piggul. Sacrificial flesh which has spoiled. See Lev. 7:18. It is unseemly for that which is left over from a sacrifice which was brought upon the altar to become vile, for if what remains of a sacrifice becomes vile then the sacrifice, which was sanctified, is defiled. The same is true of the prohibition against hewn stones. It is possible that the chips that result from the stone-cutting be profaned by being dedicated to idolatrous use if the builders cut stones in order to build an altar. The latter would be disrespectful. Now Scripture states366Literally, Now we have seen. that the priest atones upon the altar.367Hence the altar is treated in the manner of a sacrifice which is brought upon it.

NEITHER SHALT THOU GO UP BY STEPS UNTO MINE ALTAR. Ben Zuta says that be-ma’alot (by steps) comes from the same root as ma’al (trespass).368According to Ben Zuta our text should be translated: Neither shalt thou go up in a trespassing manner (be-ma’alot) upon My altar. However, he did not open his eyes and see that the mem in ma’al is a root letter, as u-ma’alah vo ma’al (and act unfaithfully against him) (Num. 5:12) proves.369Ma’alah is a third person kal whole root form. Therefore, the root of u-ma’alah has to be mem, ayin, lamed. Ma’al is the noun form of ma’alah. Now ma’al follows the paradigm of na’al.370It is vocalized pattach, pattach. Its plural absolute form is ne’alot (shoes). Compare, and worn shoes (ne’alot) and clouted upon their feet, and worn garments (Josh. 9:5). Thus be-ma’alot should have been vocalized bi-me’alot, that is, with a chirik beneath the bet371A bet prefixed to a letter beginning with a sheva is vocalized with a chirik. and a kamatz beneath the ayin.372If it came from the root mem, ayin, lamed, for that is the way this paradigm is vocalized. Compare, ne’alot (shoes), ne’arot (girls), and the like. Be-ma’alot373Which is vocalized with a sheva beneath the bet and a chataf pattach beneath the ayin. can only have the meaning of ma’alot374Which comes from the root ayin, lamed, heh. in And there were seven steps (ma’alot) to go up to it (Ezek. 40:26). Ben Zuta clearly intended to ascend the ladder of wisdom with his follies. However, his nakedness was uncovered thereon. This is what happens to every heretic who does not believe in the words of our ancient sages. The law prohibiting the use of steps to go up to the altar takes in all altars of earth, stones, or copper. The phrase Mine altar implies all altars made for the Lord.

One who pays attention to meanings, Both general and particular; Will understand why a vav Precedes Eleh Ha-Mishpatim.1This portion opens with a connective vav. As I.E. explains in his next comment, the vav connects Ex. 21:1 with the verses that come before it.

NOW THESE ARE THE ORDINANCES. After the children of Israel told Moses, Speak thou with us, etc. (Ex. 20:16), God told Moses, when Moses drew near to the thick darkness,2Ex. 20:18. Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel, etc. (Ex. 20:19). God began to warn them against making golden gods.3Ex. 20:20. He told Moses that upon Moses’ descent from Mount Sinai, He would make a covenant with Israel to the effect that the Lord alone would be their God.4I.E.’s interpretation of Ex. 20:21. God taught Moses the ordinances and commandments5Contained in Ex. 20:19-23:19. so that Moses would tell Israel, if you accept these ordinances and commandments then God will make a covenant with you. At the end of these conditions,6The acceptance of the ordinances and commandments. God told Moses the portion of Behold, I send an angel before thee (Ex. 23:20). The most important part of the latter chapter is the elimination of idol worship from their country when they entered it. Moses explained this to Israel before he made the covenant,7Ex. 23:40. So Weiser and Netter. for Moses concluded with, neither shalt thou serve their gods (Deut. 7:16).8I.E. paraphrases Ex. 23:33 with a quote from Deut. 7:16. Now the portion opens with the prohibition against making other gods alongside the Lord9Ex. 20:20. and concludes with the commandment to uproot the memory of idols and molten gods which were made in the land of Canaan.10Ex. 23:24.

IF THOU BUY. Before I begin to explain11The ordinances. let me give you a general rule. Each ordinance or commandment12Recorded in Ex. 21:2-23:19. is an independent unit. If we are able to find a reason that two ordinances or commandments are connected to each other, then we will expend all of our efforts to connect them. If we are not able to do so, we will conclude that the reason this cannot be done is our intellectual deficiency.13Although each commandment or ordinance is an independent unit, they were not thrown together haphazardly. There is nothing in the world more difficult for a human being to bear than to be under the control of another person like himself. Scripture therefore began14The list of ordinances. with the law of the Hebrew servant. Our sages said that the Hebrew servant15Spoken of in our verse. is an Israelite. The same applies to And if a man sell his daughter to be a maid-servant (v. 7).16Verse 7 refers to an Israelite. However, our sages maintain that And if a man smite the eye of his bondmen (v. 26) refers to a Canaanite.17That is, a Canaanite bondman. By Canaanite, the sages meant non-Israelite. Similarly, If the ox gore a bondman (v. 32).18That is, a Canaanite bondman. And they said that then he shall be sold for his theft (Ex. 22:2) refers to an Israelite. Those who dispute with our sages say that the Hebrew slave19Spoken of in this verse. is not an Israelite but rather someone of Abraham’s family.20Someone descended from Abraham, such as an Ishmaelite, Edomite or the like. Abraham was known as Abraham the Hebrew (Gen. 14:13). Hence his descendants, whether Israelites or not, are called Hebrews according to this interpretation. The same is true of the daughter sold into slavery21Verse 7. and of all the slaves mentioned afterwards. They are to be understood in the same way.22As Hebrew slaves, that is, as people descended from Abraham. Their proof is from the wife and her children (v. 4),23Who remain in slavery. They could not believe that the children of an Israelite would remain in slavery, for they believed these children to be Israelites. for they say that family identity is established by the father.24That is, the children of an Israelite man and a non-Israelite woman are considered Israelites. They offer additional proof from and he shall serve him for ever (v. 6), for they say that the latter means all of the slave’s life.25Contra the rabbis, who maintain that for ever means until the jubilee year. It was difficult for them to accept that an Israelite would have his ear pierced.26And be a slave in perpetuity. Let us now seek the plain meaning of the words.27Employed by Scripture. The reference is to the term ivri (Hebrew). If the Hebrew slave is not an Israelite, then why did Scripture state, If thy brother, a Hebrew man…be sold unto thee28The verse continues, he shall serve thee six years; and in the seventh year thou shalt let him go free from thee. Thus Deut. 15:12 and our verse refer to the same type of servant. Now if the term Hebrew does not refer to an Israelite, why does Scripture use the term brother? Brother refers only to an Israelite. If Deut. 15:12 referred to a non-Israelite it should have read, “If a Hebrew man be sold unto thee.” We thus see that our verse refers to an Israelite. (Deut. 15:12)? Do we not know that brother in Thou shalt not hate thy brother in thy heart (Lev. 19:17) means an Israelite? It is the same case with between a man and his brother, and the stranger that is with him (Deut. 1:16).29It is clear that brother refers to an Israelite, for brother stands in contrast to stranger. There are many such cases. Now there is no doubt that the meaning of Abram the Hebrew (Gen. 14:13) is: Abram of the children of Eber, about whom Scripture says avi kol bene ever, (the father of all the children of Eber) (Gen. 10:21),30Any descendants of Eber who accept the teaching of Eber is called an ivri. See I.E.’s comments on v. 8. in contrast to and Ham is the father of Canaan (Gen. 9:18). On the other hand, it is possible that Abram was called the Hebrew because he came from beyond the river,31The Hebrew word for beyond is ever. See Josh. 24:2, Your fathers dwelt of old time beyond the River (be-ever ha-nahar). According to this interpretation, Abraham was called the ivri because he came from beyond (ever) the river. although in this case the term used should have been ivri nahari 32The Hebrew word for river is nahar. rather than ivri. Let us assume that Scripture was being brief,33In other words, ivri is short for ivri nahari. because we find that the Bible states, And I took your father Abraham from beyond the River (me-ever ha-nahar) (Josh. 24:3).34The point is, anyone acquainted with the Bible will know that ivri is short for ivri nahari. The Hebrews are also called Israelites, for we see that Moses told Pharaoh, Thus saith the Lord, the God of Israel (Ex. 5:1). However, when Pharaoh asked Moses, “Who is this God?”35I.E.’s paraphrase of Who is the Lord? (Ex. 5:2). Moses answered him, The God of the Hebrews (Ibid.). The God of the Hebrews thus means the same as the God of Israel. Now if the Israelites are called Hebrews because they are related to Eber, then the children of Ishmael and the children of Keturah36Abraham’s concubine. See Gen. 25:1. and the children of Esau should be joined to us. However, we do not find Scripture referring to any people as our brothers except for Edom,37The descendants of Esau. See Deut. 23:8. who shared one womb with Jacob.38That is, whose ancestor shared one womb with Jacob. We also do not find Scripture referring to Esau39That is, Edom. as our brother in commandments.40Thus Edom too is not joined with us. We find him referred to as a brother only in the account of the messengers.41Moses sent messengers to Edom asking for permission to pass through their land. See Num. 20:14. The same applies to Thou shalt not abhor an Edomite, for he is thy brother (Deut. 23:8)42That is, Edom is not here referred to as a brother in commandments. wherein Scripture mentions he is thy brother after first mentioning the term Edomite.43In other words, brother in Deut. 23:8 explains why we are not to hate an Edomite. It does not mean that he is our brother in commandments. The same is true of Because he44Edom. did pursue his brother45Israel. with the sword (Amos 1:11).46This verse does not imply that Edom and Israel are brothers in mitzvot. Now we do not find in all of Scripture the word Hebrew employed except in regard to the children of Jacob. Scripture thus states: And there was with us there a young man, a Hebrew (Gen. 41:12); because the Egyptians might not eat bread with the Hebrews (Gen. 43:32); an Egyptian smiting a Hebrew (Ex. 2:11); two men of the Hebrews were striving together (Ex. 2:13). Jonah said, I am a Hebrew (Jonah 1:9) because he was asked, and of what people art thou (Jonah v. 1:8). If the term Hebrew had referred to many nations, Jonah would not yet have told them of what people he was.47By saying I am a Hebrew, he might be saying I am an Edomite, or a Moabite, or the like. Scripture also states, that ye be not servants unto the Hebrews (I Sam. 4:9);48The reference there is clearly to that of an Israelite. Now the Hebrews49The reference is to Israelites. that were with the Philistines (I Sam. 14:21). The book of Jeremiah states: that every man should let his man-servant, and every man his maid-servant, being a Hebrew man or a Hebrew woman, go free (Jer. 34:9). The latter closes by explaining, that none should make bondmen of them, even of a Jew his brother (Ibid.). Now it is known that an Edomite is not called a Jew.50Hence the term Hebrew in Jer. 34:9 cannot apply to him. I.E. notes this because he had earlier noted that Scripture refers to the Edomites as brothers. Those who disagree with our sages say, look, it is written: And many from among the peoples of the land became Jews (mityahadim) (Esther 8:17)51We thus see that the term Jew can be applied to someone who is not born a Jew. Hence the term Jew in Jer. 34:9 may also apply to a non-Jew, that is, to a non-Jewish slave who observes some of the commandments (Filwarg). in reference to those who were not Jews. This is blindness. For according to their opinion, whether the meaning of the word mityahadim (became Jews) is that they claimed to be Jews or that mityahadim means they accepted Judaism,52According to I.E., mityahadim means: praised the Jews. Scripture should have read, “even of one of his brothers who became Jewish.”53Jer. 34:9 refers to the man-servant as a yehudi, a Jew. If the reference was to those not born Jewish, i.e., slaves who belong to Jews and practice Judaism, then the term used should have been mityahed, acting Jewish. Furthermore, the word mitabber (becoming a Hebrew)54There is no Hebrew word with this meaning. should be formed from the word ivri according to this interpretation.55If the word mityahed means to claim to be Jewish or to become a Jew, then a parallel form, mitabber, should exist. However, it does not. One who says this, meddleth (mitabber) with strife not his own (Prov. 26:17).56I.E. plays on the word mitabber. It has thus been clearly shown that the words of our sages are correct. We will rely upon them with regard to all of the commandments in accordance with their tradition, which they received from their fathers. Furthermore, how can one think that an Ishmaelite and an Edomite shall serve for six years57As outlined in our verse. and an Israelite until the year of jubilee.58See Lev. 25:39, which states that an Israelite serves till the year of jubilee. I.E. reconciles our verse and Lev. 25:39 in his next comment.

SIX YEARS HE SHALL SERVE. And no longer. It is like Six years thou shalt sow thy field (Lev. 25:3).59And no longer, for the seventh year is a Sabbatical year. At the start of the seventh year of his being sold he shall go free no matter what year it be.60No matter what year of the fifty-year count to the Jubilee. Do not be amazed that Jeremiah writes, At the end of seven years (Jer. 34:14),61Whereas our verse states that a slave goes free at the beginning of the seventh year. because everything has two ends and sometimes the end is found at the beginning and sometimes it is at the end.62Thus at the end of seven years means: at the beginning of the seventh year. A physical object has two ends, Each of the ends is also the first part of the object. I.E. applies this concept to a non-tangible object such as years. Our verse deals with a servant whom the law courts have sold, namely, an individual concerning whom it is written, then he shall be sold for his theft (Ex. 22:2). However, And if thy brother be waxen poor with thee, and was sold unto you (Lev. 25:39)63Translated according to I.E. or to a stranger (Lev. 25:47) refers to a slave who sells himself according to the years remaining to the year of jubilee, for such a servant goes out when the Jubilee comes. Israel has a tradition that males but not females are sold because they stole. I will finish the matter in the chapter which follows. Rabbi Merinus says that the yod of the word la-chofshi (tree) is superfluous.64In other words, la-chofshi (free) has the same meaning as la-chofesh (unto freedom). Cf. Rashi, chofshi: la-cherut (unto freedom). It is like the yod of le-mishi (for cleansing) (Ezek. 16:4) and the yod of akhzari (cruel) (Prov. 11:17). However, Rabbi Judah the grammarian says the lamed of la-chofshi (free) is superfluous because its meaning is similar to chofshi (free) in And when thou lettest him go free (Deut. 15:13).65In other words, la-chofshi means chofshi (free). Its yod is, as it were, the yod of relationship, like the yod of ha-kadmoni (of the east gate) (Ezek. 19:19). The lamed of la-chofshi is like the lamed of la-avshalom (Absalom)66The lamed of la-avshalom is superfluous, for la-avshalom means Absolam, not unto Absolam. in the third, Absalom the son of Maacah (I Chron. 3:2). However, in my opinion the lamed and the yod in la-chofshi are both prepositions, even though one would have sufficed.67Scripture could have read either la-chofesh or chofshi. Chofshi is similar to ha-oholi (of my tent) (Josh. 7:21) in in the midst of my tent.68Ha-oholi has an emphatic heh prefix and a first person pronoun yod suffix. According to Hebrew grammar, the emphatic heh is not suffixed to a declined noun. Josh. 7:21 thus should have read, ha-ohel, or oholi. We thus see that Scripture sometimes combines two forms. Chofshi (free) is an adjective.

[FOR NOTHING.] The word chinnam (for nothing) comes from the same root as channunu (grant)69Its root is chet, nun, nun. in grant them (Jud. 21:22). It means a gift.70Something freely or graciously given. We do not know why chinnam has a mem.71It is not a root letter and it does not have any meaning. Its mem is like the mem of rekam (empty) (Gen. 31:42).72Whose mem has no meaning. A mem suffixed to a word is sometimes a third person plural pronominal suffix. Hence I.E.’s comment.

IF HE COME IN BY HIMSELF. Some say that the word be-gappo (by himself) has the same meaning as be-gufo (with his body). Now we find the phrase gufat sha’ul (the body of Saul) (I Chron. 10:12) in Scripture.73The absolute form of gufat is gufah. Gufah with the third person pronominal suffix is gufato. Thus our verse should have read gufato rather than gappo. However, the forms of nouns change.74The same word comes in different forms. Others say75See Rashi, be-gappo: in the wing (skirt) of his garment. that gappo (himself) has the meaning of wing. Wings are referred to as gappin in Aramaic. It is as if Scripture read, if he came in bondage possessing only the wing of his garment.76In other words, gappo refers to the wing (corner) of his garment. However, this is out of context, for the context requires us to explain be-gappo as meaning that he carries no other body on his back. Gappo is like gabbi (my back) in The plowers plowed upon my back (Ps. 129:3).77In other words, gappo is a variant of gabbo (his back), for the bet and peh sometimes interchange because they are similarly sounded labials. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that Scripture had to say, If he come in by himself, he shall go out by himself78In other words, why repeat that the slave goes out free after having stated the same in verse 2? while saying79That is, immediately after saying (Filwarg). For other interpretations see Krinsky. he shall go out free80The question is, why does Scripture repeat itself? because of his wife,81That is, because it wanted to go on and explain the law dealing with the slave’s wife, and it is the style of Scripture to repeat itself when it introduces a new law. that is, the Torah had to say, if he be married.82Then his wife goes out with him. For other interpretations see Krinsky and Filwarg. Now if an Israelite women is not sold by a law court for theft, why does Scripture say, then his wife shall go out with him? It states this to teach us that the one who acquires a Hebrew slave is obligated to support his [the slave’s] wife. She is with him until they go out together.

IF HIS MASTER GIVE HIM A WIFE. We find that those who employ the holy tongue render honor with various nouns83Literally, with the laws of nouns. The plural form of certain nouns is employed honorifically. but not with verbs. They use the terms adon (lord) and also adonim (lords).84When referring to a lord or master. They employ the latter as a singular in a cruel lord (adonim) (Is. 19:4). They employ the term adonav (his lord)85Adonav is a plural. in the construct.86By construct I.E. means when the word adonim is connected to the third person pronoun shelahem. They do not use the term adono (his lord),87Which is a singular. for we do not find the word adono in Scripture. However, Adoni (my lord),88Which is a singular. as in My lord asked (Gen. 44:19), is employed in the first person. It is prohibited to use the plural form89Adonai. so that it not be confused with God’s glorious name.90Adonai. It is similarly unfit to use the singular declensional form adoni (my lord) in My lord asked (Ibid.) when God is spoken of.91Hence the plural form Adonai is used when God is referred to. The same applies to the term Elo’ah (God).92Elo’ah is in the singular. However, it is not respectful to use the singular when referring to God. Hence the plural form Elohim is used. Rabbi Merinus says that eloho (their god),93Which is elo’ah with the third person pronominal suffix. rather than elohav (their god),94The plural form. in their might unto their god (Hab. 1:11) is used in a disparaging manner.95Because Habakkuk speaks of pagan gods.

IF HIS MASTER GIVE HIM A WIFE. A Canaanite woman according to our sages.96Mekhilta, Mishpatim 1. It is possible that the meaning of a Canaanite women is in keeping with Moreover of the children of the strangers that do sojourn among you (Lev. 25:45) conceming whom it is written, of them shall ye buy bondmen and bondmaids (Lev. 25:44).97In other words, Canaanite is not to be taken literally. It refers to the nations mentioned in Lev. 25:44. The same applies to all Canaanite slaves,98Mentioned in Rabbinic literature. for Scripture states, thou shalt save alive nothing that breatheth (Deut. 20:16) with regard to the seven nations.99That is, the seven Canaanite nations. Scripture states with regard to Solomon, of the nations concerning which the Lord said unto the children of Israel: They shall not come among you, neither shall you go among them (I Kings 11:2).100I.E. quoted from memory and erred. The Book of Kings reads, of the nations concerning which the Lord said unto the children of Israel: Ye shall not go among them, neither shall they come among you. Now this is written101That Solomon loved women of the nations concerning which the Lord said unto the children of Israel: Ye shall not go among them, neither shall they come among you. with regard to Zidonians and Hittites,102Both are Canaanite nations. not Moabites and Ammonites.103A female Moabite and Ammonite whom one is permitted to marry after they convert. Hence they may serve as slaves and a master may give a woman belonging to these nations to his Hebrew bondman.

BUT IF THE SERVANT SHALL PLAINLY SAY. Our sages have already explained104See Mekhilta, Mishpatim 11. that his ear is not pierced unless all these conditions,105Listed in our verse, i.e., I love my master, etc. including because he loveth thee and thy house (Deut. 15:16), have been fulfilled.106That is, the servant’s ear is not pierced unless all the conditions listed in verse 5 and in Deut. 15:16 have been fulfilled.

THEN HIS MASTER SHALL BRING HIM UNTO GOD. The term Elohim (God) means those who establish God’s laws in the land.107That is, elohim means judges. It is customary for the judges to sit in the gate of a city that has doors and a bolt. To the door or the door-post means that what Scripture deals with in this verse is to be performed before those who sit in the gate.

AND HE SHALL SERVE HIM FOR EVER. We know that the word le-olam (for ever) in Hebrew refers to time, as in it hath been already, in the ages (le-olamim) which were before us (Eccles. 1:10), wherein olamim means ages.108In other words, for ever here means some definite time span. Similarly, ve-yashav sham ad olam (and there abide for ever) (I Sam. 1:22) means: and he will there abide until he grows up. Va-avado le-olam (and he shall serve him for ever) likewise means: and he will serve him until the year of jubilee,109This is the opinion of the sages of the Talmud. See Mekhilta on third verse. for there is no season of Israel that is longer than it.110The jubilee year comes around once in 50 years. Going free is comparable to a renewal of the world.111Hence Scripture reads, va-avado le-olam (and he shall serve him for ever); that is, he shall serve him until the world is renewed, namely, the year of jubilee when all slaves are freed. The word le-olam literally means to a world. Hence I.E.’s comment. This interpretation appears to differ slightly from the preceding one, which took the word olam to mean time. It is also possible that its meaning is that he should be as he was in former times.112Literally, he should return to his former “time.” This interpretation takes the word le-olam to mean: to a time.

AND IF A MAN SELL HIS DAUGHTER TO BE A MAID-SERVANT. Scripture speaks of a minor who is under her father’s control, like the daughter whose oaths a father may annul.113See Num. 30:4-6. The phrase unto a foreign people (v. 8) is connected to this verse.114Rather than to what precedes it in verse 8. For unto a foreign people speaks of the father.115That is, the father is not permitted to sell his daughter unto a foreign people. I.E. takes foreign people literally, that is, to a non-Jewish nation.

TO SELL HER UNTO A FOREIGN PEOPLE HE SHALL HAVE NO POWER, SEEING THAT HE HATH DEALT DECEITFULLY WITH HER. Bi-vigdo (that he hath dealt deceitfully) is similar to the word nivgad (we deal treacherously) in Why do we deal treacherously every man against his brother (Mal. 2:10). It is true and correct that the master has no right to sell her to an Israelite.116The sages say that to sell her unto a foreign people he shall have no power refers to both her father and her master. They take foreign nation to mean any stranger. See Kiddushin 19a. We know this from tradition.117According to I.E. to sell her unto a foreign people he shall have no power refers only to the father. See note 121. The sages used this verse as a peg and as a support.118For their tradition. Do not be surprised at the distance between unto a foreign people and the verse to which it is connected,119Verge 7. for as I will explain, it is the same case with he shall make restitution120Which, according to I.E., is connected to Ex. 21:37. (Ex. 22:2). Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that unto a foreign people means to a stranger. The same is true of wilt Thou slay even a righteous nation121Am (people, nation) can refer to a person. Saadiah thus interprets unto a foreign people as unto a stranger, and a righteous nation as a righteous person. (Gen. 20:4). However, it is impossible that Scripture would refer to an individual by one of these terms. It is correct for Scripture to say, “and Israel said,” because Israel is a collective noun, like Egypt in and Egypt said (Ex. 14:25).122Translated according to I.E. However, it is impossible for a noun which refers to a group, such as the terms people, nation, company, and congregation, to be used for an individual. The meaning of wilt Thou slay even a righteous nation is explained by that thou hast brought on me and on my kingdom a great sin (Gen. 20:9).

[SHE SHALL NOT GO OUT AS MEN-SERVANTS DO.] Its meaning is, she shall not go out as men-servants who always go out after six years. The maid-servant also goes out after six years of servitude, as Scripture states, If thy brother, a Hebrew man, or a Hebrew women, be sold unto thee, he shall serve thee six years (Deut. 15:12). However, the maid-servant goes out if she reaches the onset of puberty before six years pass.

IF SHE PLEASE NOT HER MASTER. If she does not find favor in the eyes of her master after he bought her in order to take her for a wife. This is the meaning of who hath espoused her to himself; he espoused her to be his wife123He bought her to marry her. or he espoused her to be the wife of his son.124I.E.’s paraphrase of And if he espouse her unto his son (v. 9). Its meaning is, he bought her to be his son’s wife. Note that the word lo (himself) is spelled125The ketiv. lamed alef in the text126Lo spelled with an alef means no. and is read127Interpreted. as if written with a vav and so spelled in the margin.128The kre. Thus asher lo ye’adah means who hath espoused her to himself. If we translate the text as spelled, then we should translate asher lo ye’adah as who hath not espoused her. The Gaon says that the word lo has two meanings.129That is, lo should be translated both as “no” and as “to him.” It is similar to It is He that hath made us, and we are His (lo) (Ps. 100:3).130Here too lo is spelled with an alef but interpreted as if spelled with a vav. One meaning is, we have not made ourselves.131In this case we interpret lo as written, i.e., as spelled with an alef. In this case the literal reading of Ps. 100:3 is: It is He that hath made us, and not us. The second meaning is, we are His.132Here lo is interpreted as if spelled with a vav, and the verse is translated: It is He that hath made us, and we are His. However, in my opinion only the second is the correct meaning.133The word lo is to be interpreted only as if spelled with a vav, i.e., according to the kre. The same applies to all of them.134Where lo is spelled with an alef but interpreted as if written with a vav. Rabbi Judah the grammarian says that we cannot distinguish in pronunciation between lo spelled with an alef and lo spelled with a vav or a heh, as in is it not (ha-loh)135Here lo is spelled with a heh. The heh has been substituted for an alef. in Rabbah of the children of Ammon (Deut. 3:11). All cases where the text has an alef and the margin a vav136That is, the word is interpreted as if written with a vav. are to be interpreted the way they are read.137That is, according to the kre. Note that the word ve-hefdah (then shall he let her to be redeemed) is a transitive verb. It is similar to ve-happodekha (and redeemed thee) (Deut. 13:6); padah (redeemed) in who hath redeemed my soul (II Sam. 4:9); peditem (redeemed them) in For I have redeemed them (Zech. 10:8).138All of the aforementioned are transitive verbs. Now vehefdah is a hifil. It is like ha-matzmi’ach (maketh to spring) in Who maketh the mountains to spring with grass (Ps. 147:8)139Which is a hifil. or like the word he’ekhil (fed)140Which is a hifil. in saying Reuben fed (he’ekhil) Simeon bread. The meaning of ve-hefdah thus is,141Since ve-hefdah is a hifil, a causative. he shall seek her redemption and accept it whether she redeems herself, or her father or one of her relatives redeems her. If she is close to the end of her years of servitude, they shall compute how many years she has served and how many remain till the seventh year or to the time that she reaches the onset of puberty. The redemption money will be in accordance with the aforementioned computation.142With how many years the maid-servant has served and how many remain until either the seventh year or her onset of puberty.

UNTO A FOREIGN PEOPLE. I have already explained it.143I.E. explained the term am (people) in the earlier part of his comments on this verse. He now goes on to explain the meaning of the term nokhri (foreign). Note that the term nokhri (foreign) applies to all people who are not Israelites. The word nokhri does not have the same meaning as the word zar (stranger), as the term zar refers to one who is not of the same tribal family.144But is a fellow Israelite. Now if we say that the Israelites are called Hebrews because145I.E. in his comments on verse 1 suggested two reasons why Israelites are called Hebrews. He now refers to them. of Eber, who worshipped God, then whoever is descended from Eber and follows Eber’s faith is called a Hebrew.146Thus descendants of Eber who do not follows Eber’s faith are not called Hebrews. I.E. comments thus because Eber had non-Israelite descendants. See I.E. on verse 1. However, if we say that one is called a Hebrew because of Abraham,147Because he is descended from Abraham, who was called Abraham the Hebrew. then Scripture states, for in Isaac shall seed be called to thee (Gen. 21:12).148In other words, only Isaac and his descendants are to be called Hebrews. Now even though Scripture writes with regard to Ishmael, because he is thy seed (Gen. 21:13),149Which implies that the Ishmaelites should also be considered Hebrews. the land150Of Israel. was given only to Isaac.151Thus only Isaac is a full heir of Abraham and entitled to the name Hebrew. Jacob and Esau were sons of Isaac. However, Scripture states with regard to Isaac, for unto thee, and thy seed, I will give all these lands (Gen. 26:3). Now Isaac’s seed was “called” only in Jacob, to whom the land was given. Thus the children of the concubines152Abraham’s concubines. along with the children of Esau are considered foreigners.

AND IF HE ESPOUSE HER UNTO HIS SON. Yi’adennah (espouse her)153From the root yod, ayin, dalet. The literal meaning of yi’adennah is: shall set her aside or shall designate her. follows the paradigm of yirashennah.154From the root yod, resh, shin. The word mo’ed (season)155Which comes from the same root as yi’adennah. is similar to156That is, follows the paradigm of. the word moked (altar).157From the root yod, kof, dalet.
[AFTER THE MANNER OF THE DAUGHTERS.] The reference is to virgin daughters who were not sold.
HE SHALL DEAL WITH HER. The son, and also the father if he took her.
IF HE TAKE HIM ANOTHER WIFE. Be she a daughter of Israel who was sold, or be she a daughter of Israel that was not sold.
HER FOOD. She’erah refers to her food. He must sustain her flesh, which is what she’erah means.

AND HER CONJUGAL RIGHTS. Some say that ve-onatah (and her conjugal rights) means: and the place of her dwelling.158They connect it to the word ma’on (a dwelling place). According to them, the word ve-anah (shall howl) in and jackals shall howl (Is. 13:22) and ve-anetah (and she shall respond) in and she shall respond there (Hos. 2:17) have a similar meaning.159The former is to be rendered: and jackals shall live there; and the latter, and she shall live there. However, I believe that ve-anah iyyim (and jackals shall howl) is to be taken as it implies.160It means and jackals shall howl. Ve-anah is similar to ve-anita (and thou shalt speak) in and thou shalt speak and say (Deut. 26:5). Ve-anah is used metaphorically, for Scripture there metaphorically states, and the satyr shall cry to his fellow (Is. 34:14).161In other words, yikra (cry, or more literally, call) is parallel to ve-anita. Hence ve-anita must have a similar meaning. Similarly, ve-anetah in and she shall there respond means she shall make music. Ve-anetah is similar to enu (sing) in Sing unto the Lord with thanksgiving (Ps. 147:7). Onatah refers to sexual activity, also known as the time of lovemaking.162Literally, to bedding, which is the time of lovemaking. The word et (time) is missing a nun.163That is, the root of et is ayin, nun, tav. It is similar to the word emet (truth).164Which comes from the root alef, mem, nun. Hence the tav of ittekh (thy time) in and, behold, thy time (Ezek. 16:8) receives a dagesh.165To compensate for the missing nun. Likewise,166Literally, or. That is, another example that the word et is similar to the word emet. itto (his time) is similar to amitto (his truth). The word attah (now) is also similar.167It comes from the root ayin, nun, tav and drops a nun. Note, onatah comes from the same root as et. The word attah (now) means this time.168The heh at the end of the word attah takes the place of the heh which should have been placed at the beginning of the word. That is, attah equals ha-et (the time) (Weiser).

AND IF. Scripture employed an abridged form in saying shelosh eleh (these three). It is similar to shelosh se’im (three measures) (Gen. 18:6),169Which is also a short form. for Scripture should have read, ha-shelosh ha-eleh.170And similarly in Gen. 18:6 it should have read, ha-shelosh ha-se’im. Many think that these three refers to her food, her raiment, and her conjugal rights. However, this is impossible. After Scripture stated, he shall deal with her after the manner of daughters (v. 9), and one is obligated to give these three things to all daughters there is no need to mention this here. Furthermore, Scripture writes concerning the beautiful woman171The beautiful captive woman. who is a foreigner, but thou shalt not sell her at all for money (Deut. 21:14).
