How much more so is this maid-servant not to be sold for money.172What need is there for Scripture to say, then shall she go out for nothing without money; i.e., her master cannot sell her. Its correct interpretation thus is: and if he does not do one of these three things, namely, if he does not marry her, or espouse her to his son, or redeem her, she shall go out for nothing when she has the onset of puberty.173That is, if she reaches the onset of puberty before her six years of servitude are over. If any that is unclean by a dead body touch all of these, which means one of these, shall it be unclean174Translated according to I.E. See Lev. 18:24. (Hag. 2:13) is similar. There are many other similar instances.175Where Scripture uses the term these or all of these and means one of these. The Gaon asks, what reason was there for Scripture to say, without money after stating for nothing? He answers: If she took ill in her master’s house and he spent money on medicine,176To heal her. then she did not have to pay him back anything. However, in my opinion there is no need for all of this, for Scripture offers additional explanation, such as for thou shalt die, and not live (II Kings 20:1).177See I.E. on Ex. 2:6.

HE THAT SMITETH A MAN. The reason this follows the laws dealing with the man- and maid-servant is that Scripture wanted to go on and explain how to deal with one who strikes his man- and maid-servants.178It therefore first had to lay down the law dealing with one who strikes a free man. [A MAN.] The reference is to an Israelite.
HE SHALL SURELY BE PUT TO DEATH. By a court of law. This is the case whenever the term mot yumat (he shall surely be put to death) is employed. The one exception to this will be shown shortly.

AND IF A MAN LIE NOT IN WAIT. Tzadah (lie in wait) is similar to the word bi-tzediyyah (lying in wait) (Num. 35:20) and tzodeh (layest wait) in though thou layest wait for my soul to take it (I Sam. 24:12). Observe, it involves laying in wait and acting presumptuously.179In other words, tzadah means to presumptuously lay in wait.

BUT GOD CAUSE IT TO COME TO HAND. Innah (cause it to come) is similar to mitanneh (seeketh an occasion) in he seeketh an occasion against me (II Kings 5:7), the meaning of which is, he looks for reasons and excuses.180To attack me. The meaning of our clause is that God caused and arranged things so that this person would die at this individual’s hand even though he had never intended to kill him. God caused this to happen to him so that he would be exiled from his place because of some other sin which he committed. Scripture explicitly states, There shall no mischief befall the righteous (Prov. 12:21).

AND IF A MAN COME PRESUMPTUOUSLY. To slay him181With guile. is to be understood as if written, and slew him with guile.182That is, the infinitive includes in it the action (Filwarg). Similarly If she profane by playing the harlot (Lev. 21:9),183Translated literally. the meaning of which is, if she profane herself by playing the harlot and therefore she profaneth her father (Ibid.).184Here too the infinitive techel (she profane) includes in it the object; that is, she profane herself. It is known that the term chillul (profanation) and the word techillah (beginning) come from a double root.185They both come from the root chet, lamed, lamed. However, they differ in meaning. It was therefore necessary to differentiate between them. Scripture therefore reads, techel li-zenot (profane by playing the harlot) (Lev. 21:9), for if it had the meaning of beginning, it would read tachel (thou shalt begin), as in tachel lispor (shalt thou begin to number) (Num. 16:9).186Double roots conjugated in the kal are vocalized with a kamatz beneath their prefixes. However, in order to differentiate between the words, to profane was vocalized with a tsere, techel, and to begin follows the normal vocalization, that is, tachel.

FROM MINE ALTAR. This is the reverse of the previous verse. It is there stated, then I will appoint thee a place [whither he may flee], the reference being to the cities of refuge. However, he who presumptuously kills and flees, even if he seeks refuge at the altar as Joab did,187See I Kings 2:28,29. shall be put to death. Our sages said even a priest188Who has committed murder. who wants to perform the service at the altar shall be put to death.189Yoma 85a; San. 35b.

AND HE THAT SMITETH HIS FATHER. Since Scripture had previously mentioned, He that smiteth a man, so that he dieth, shall surely be put to death (v. 12), Scripture had to explain that there is an instance where one is put to death for smiting someone even when the one who is struck does not die. This is the case when one hits one’s father. The word u-makkeh (and he that smiteth) is to be read as if written twice.190Our verse is to be understood as if written: and he that smiteth his father, and he who smiteth his mother, shall surely be put to death. It was out of regard for the parents’ honor that Scripture found it necessary to state191In verse 17. that even when one does not strike one’s parents but curses them, he is to be put to death.

AND HE THAT STEALETH A MAN. Saadiah Gaon asks: Why was this verse inserted between He that smiteth his father (v. 15) and And he that curseth his father (v. 17)? He answers that Scripture speaks only of the commonplace. Those stolen were young children. They were brought up in a strange country and did not recognize their parents. It is thus possible for them to strike and curse their parents. The punishment for this will fall upon the kidnapper.

OR IF HE BE FOUND IN HIS HAND. In the market before he sells him,192In other words, and selleth him means: and intends to sell him. Otherwise, how could Scripture say, “or if he be found in his hand.” then he shall be put to death.
AND HE THAT CURSETH. We find a curse that invokes the name of God, as in and cursed them in the name of the Lord (II Kings 2:24). We also find curses that do not invoke the name of God.

AND IF MEN CONTEND. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that be-egrof (with his fist) is similar to egrofin (strong) in “strong men.”193San. 49a. Hebrew, ba’ale egrofin. The reference194That is, egrof refers to something strong and hard. is to something strong and hard. Rabbi Merinus says that the alef of egrof is superfluous. It is like the alef of ezro’i (my shoulder) (Job 31:22).195Which is superfluous. It comes from the same root as ge-rafam (swept them away) (Jud. 5:21).196The root of which is gimmel, resh, peh. The reference is to something that one drags in one’s hand.197A clod of earth. See I.E.’s short commentary. The same is true in Arabic.

IF HE RISE AGAIN. We will rely on our sages of blessed memory who said that al mishanto (upon his staff) means that he supports himself and does not lean on others as sick people do.198Cf. San. 78b. Also see Rashi.
THEN SHALL HE THAT SMOTE HIM BE QUIT. They shall release him from prison.

[LOSS OF HIS TIME.] Shivto (loss of his time) comes from the same root as shevitah (rest),199Its root is shin, bet, tav. for his work stopped.200According to this interpretation, shivto means his work stoppage; i.e., he must reimburse him for his work stoppage. This interpretation is correct.201In view of the fact that he next offers a different explanation of shivto, I.E. must mean that this interpretation is grammatically defensible. Shivto follows the paradigm of shivro (his corn money) (Gen. 44:2), for the tav is a root letter. It is possible that shivto comes from the same root as shivtah (tarried) in save that she tarried a little in the house (Ruth 2:7). Shivtah comes from the same root as the word yashav (sat).202Its root is yod, shin, bet. Shivto refers to the time that the one who was struck sat at home resting, without work. What proves that this interpretation is correct is that it is the reverse of and walk abroad.203Which indicates that until then he could not walk abroad and had to stay home. The only difference between both definitions is in etymology.

AND SHALL CAUSE HIM TO BE THOROUGHLY HEALED. This is a sign that permission has been granted to physicians to heal blows and wounds that are visible on the surface.204Of the body. However, it is in God’s hand to heal any illness which strikes inside of the body. It is thus written, For He maketh sore, and bindeth up (Job 5:18). Furthermore, Scripture tells us concerning King Asa, yet in his disease he sought not to the Lord, but to the physicians (II Chron. 16:12).205Asa was stricken with an internal disease. The Bible rebukes Asa for seeking the help of physicians rather than the Lord’s. Now Scripture distinguished between them.206Internal and external wounds. It does not state, verafo yirpe (and he shall surely heal), which is in the kal.207The simple active form. When God does the healing Scriptures employs the kal form. Cf. refa (heal) in Num. 12:13 and erpa (I will heal) in Deut. 32:39. The kal is employed because, when contrasted to the pi’el (see next note), it implies ease of effort (Weiser). It rather reads, ve-rappo yerappe (and shall cause him to be thoroughly healed). The latter is in the pi’el.208The intensive form. The pi’el implies an expenditure of effort. Hence it is used when man does the healing. I will explain this very well later on in this portion.209See I.E. on Ex. 23:25. The rabbis received a tradition concerning other payments210Namely, compensation for damage, pain, and shame. See Baba Kama 83b. in addition to the two211That is, healing and loss of time. mentioned in our verse. They similarly received a tradition to include spices which are not stated in the Torah among the incense spices.212According to the Talmud Keritot 6a, the incense consisted of 11 spices. However, only five spices are listed in Ex. 30:34.

AND IF A MAN SMITE HIS BONDMAN. There is no doubt that according to Israelite jurisprudence the same ordinances that apply to a free man apply to a person sold into bondage. Hence it is impossible for the bondman213Spoken of in our verse. to be a Hebrew servant.214For the same law that applies to any Israelite would apply to him. Thus the law codified in verse 21 cannot relate to a Hebrew. Furthermore, Scripture states at the end,215Of the Masoretic chapter, that is, verse 21. for he is his money.216This cannot apply to an Israelite, for one Hebrew does not become the property of another Hebrew. Now the bondman and bondwoman217Spoken of in our verse. are the ones concerning whom Scripture writes, of them shall ye buy bondmen and bondmaids (Lev. 25:44). The bet of ba-shevet (with a rod) is vocalized with a pattach. 218Rather than with a sheva. The reference is to the rod219The pattach beneath the bet indicates a specific rod. According to I.E., bashevet (with a rod) should be rendered, with the rod, i.e., the rod which the master uses to chastise his servants. which the master was in the habit of using to beat his servants. Now all those who dispute the words of our sages220See I.E.’s comments on the next verse. are forced to agree with them with regard to the phrase nakom yinnakem (he shall surely be avenged),221According to the rabbis, nakom yinakkem means: he shall be executed by the sword. for vengeance takes many forms.222Thus were it not for Rabbinic tradition, we would not know what punishment to mete out to a master who kills his slave. Now logic will not help them in this case.223A logical and literal analysis of this verse will not tell us what punishment Scripture had in mind by he shall surely be avenged. The fathers have received the tradition that nakem yenakem (he shall surely be avenged) is similar to a sword that shall avenge (nokemet) the vengeance of the covenant (nekam berit) (Lev. 26:25).224Translated literally.

NOTWITHSTANDING. Observe that the word yukkam (be punished),225In our verse. which is a hofal, has the same meaning as yinnakem (be punished),226Employed in the previous verse. As the former refers to execution so does the latter. which is a nifal. The heretics227So Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed texts have kuthim (Samaritans). say that the meaning of nakom yinnakem (he shall surely be avenged) is that great vengeance shall be exacted, namely, that the master shall be beaten. However, if the bondman lives for a day, less vengeance shall be exacted. If he lives for two days no vengeance shall be taken. They argue228Literally, their proof is. that we do not find the term vengeance used with reference to the death penalty inflicted by a law court. They also say, that there is no positive proof that a sword that shall avenge (Lev. 26:25) refers to being put to death.229See I.E. on verse 20. Furthermore, what need is there to say “two days” after saying “a day”?230If nakom yinnakem refers to execution, then why does Scripture say that if the slave lives for two days the master is not put to death? If the master is not put to death when the slave lives for one day, he is certainly not put to death if the slave lives for two days. However, if we speak of graded punishments, then it is logical to distinguish between the two. However, their231The heretics. real difficulty lies in accepting the idea that the master would be executed because of the death of a bondman. I will now answer them. Why didn’t Scripture specify what greater or lesser vengeance is to be exacted?232If, as the heretics claim, Scripture speaks of graded punishments, then it should have stated what these punishments consist of. Let us now pursue what is written in Scripture. Scripture states, nekom nikmat bene yisrael (avenge the children of Israel) (Num. 31:2). It then goes on to tell us that all the Midianites were killed. Note that Samson said, ki im nikkamti ba-khem (surely I will be avenged of you) (Jud. 15:7). It then states, And he smote them hip [and thigh with a great slaughter] (Jud. 15:8). Samson said, ve-innakemah nekam achat (that I may be this once avenged) (Jud. 16:28) and they died in the house.233The reference is to the temple of Dagon. Scripture states, And a two-edged sword in their hand (Ps. 149:6). It then goes on to say, To execute vengeance (nikamah) upon the nations (Ps. 149:7). The Bible states, For he doth avenge (yikkom) the blood of his servants (Deut. 32:43). Now blood indicates slaughter.234Thus to avenge the blood of his servants means to kill those who slaughtered his servants. This is the way the term235Nekamah (vengeance). is always used. The reason Scripture here refers to execution by vengeance is that a master seeks excuses to fall upon his bondman because he is in his power,236The master thinks that the slave has no one to avenge him and thus abuses his slave. Hence Scripture states the death of an innocent slave must be avenged. as he cannot smite a fellow Israelite.237Who is his slave, for he fears the slave’s family who will avenge him. Now let us turn to Scripture’s statement a day or two. Observe that the latter is like At the mouth of two witnesses [or three witnesses] (Deut. 17:6).238Scripture tells us that capital cases require two or three witnesses. Now if two witnesses are sufficient to establish the fact, why mention three? They239The above-noted heretics. said that they do not know its meaning.240Why Scripture reads, or three witnesses, if two witnesses are sufficient. Let them put our verse along with it.241As they do not understand the reason for or three witnesses, so do they not understand the reason for or two (days). Our sages of blessed memory said that the meaning of a day or two is that the hours shall add up to the twenty-four of a day.242Cf. Mekhilta on this verse: “A day means one that is as long as two days, and two means two days that are as long as one. How so? A twenty-four hour period.” Also see Rashi: “A day which is made up of a part of two separate days, i.e. twenty-four hours calculated from any moment” (Rashi, paraphrased by Cohen). Now when we examined the verse we found that Scripture says, “with the rod,”243This is the literal meaning of ba-shevet. See note 213. the reference being to the disciplining rod, as in Thou beatest him with the rod244Hebrew, ba-shevet. (Prov. 23:14). It is thus clear that the master wanted to punish the bondman. Scripture did not mention what the laws are regarding a master who kills his bondman,245When not disciplining him. According to Rashbam the master is put to death in such cases even if the servant lives beyond two days. because a master normally takes pity on the bondman, whom he owns, and refrains from killing him even as he takes pity upon his cattle. Now God commanded that a master shall not act sadistically when he punishes his bondman. When he sees the bondman dying under his rod the master shall let him be. If he does not leave the bondman alone then he will be put to death on the bondman’s account, for God’s mercy is upon all of His creatures. Indeed, concerning David we read, Thou hast shed blood abundantly (I Chron. 22:8).246The reason David was not permitted to build the temple. The reference was to non-Israelite blood.247We thus see that the blood of all people is precious in the sight of God.

AND IF MEN STRIVE248Hebrew, yinnatzu. TOGETHER. The reference is to Hebrew men249Men means Hebrew men. who strive together and hit each other. Scripture similarly reads, Wherefore smitest thou thy fellow? (Ex. 2:13)250Moses said this to two men of the Hebrews [who] were striving (nitzim) together (Ex. 12:13). Now nitzim and yinnatzu (the word used for strive in our verse) come from the same root. We thus see that the Hebrew word yinnatzu (strive) means to exchange blows (Filwarg).

AND HURT. Both are included.251Both men hurt the woman. Ve-nagefu (hurt) is in the plural. Its literal meaning is, and they hurt. Hence I.E.’s comment. Sometimes its meaning is one or the other.252At times Scripture employs the plural but its meaning is one of those spoken of. Thus the meaning of they shall be burnt with fire, both he and they (Lev. 20:14) is, either this one or that one.253Either the mother or her daughter. The verse speaks of a man who takes a woman and her daughter. For doing so, he and one of the women are executed; i.e., if he is married to a woman and sleeps with her daughter, then it is the daughter who is executed; if he is married to the daughter and sleeps with the mother, it is the mother who is executed. See I.E. on Lev. 20:14. If both254Men who hurt the woman. are Israelites one law applies to them. The woman spoken of in this verse is an Israelite woman.
YET NO HARM FOLLOW. To the woman.
HE SHALL BE SURELY FINED. Because of the children who were aborted and died.

ACCORDING AS THE WOMAN’S HUSBAND SHALL LAY UPON HIM. If the one who hurt the woman wants to do according to the will of the father of the children.255That is, pay an amount of money requested by the woman’s husband. Otherwise he shall pay in accordance to the ruling of the law court. Bi-fililim (as the judges determine) is similar to the word u-fillelo (shall judge him).256In other words, pelilim means judges.

BUT IF ANY HARM FOLLOW. To the woman. We find a difference of opinion.257Concerning the punishment of the one who is responsible for the woman’s death. See Mekhilta on this verse: “Then thou shalt give life for life. He cannot pay for life with money. It is with life that he must pay for life…Rabbi says: Then thou shalt give life for life. This means monetary compensation.” Also see San. 79a. Some say that the one who caused the women’s death is put to death because he intended to kill a fellow Israelite. They offer as proof the fact that Scripture states, he shall surely be fined (v. 22) with regard to the children, but it states with regard to the woman, then thou shalt give life for life. Now if the reference is to a fine,258That is, if then thou shalt give life for life refers to a fine. then in what way is the woman’s death worse than that of the children? On the other hand, if we say that one is to be punished with death for killing the children, why did Scripture alter its style259When dealing with the death of the woman. and read, life for life? The opposing opinion maintains that one who intends to kill one individual and kills another is not put to death, and the reason the Torah altered its language and stated life for life is that the fine for killing a person is much greater than that for killing an embryo. They offer as proof the fact that the Torah afterwards reads, eye for eye, tooth for tooth (v. 24). The latter is not to be taken literally. On the contrary, it refers to ransom.260The culprit pays ransom for his tooth or eye. Thus as eye for eye, tooth for tooth refers to money, so does life for life in this case. This portion261And if man strive together, etc., verses 22-25. was written because of the clause eye for eye, tooth for tooth.262The laws dealing with murder were dealt with in verse 14. Scripture afterwards codifies the law dealing with the eye and tooth of a bondman.263Scripture first wanted to lay down the law dealing with one who takes out the eye or tooth of a free person before it went on to deal with the law regarding one who takes out the eye or tooth of a slave.

EYE. Rabbi Saadiah says that we cannot interpret this verse according to its plain meaning. For if a man struck his neighbor’s eye and the eye lost a third of its sight, how is it possible to punish the culprit with an equivalent blow, that is, with a blow which is neither greater nor lesser?264Than the blow which the culprit inflicted upon his victim. There is a possibility that the culprit will lose his entire eyesight. Burns, wounds, and stripes present even greater difficulties, for if they were inflicted on a dangerous area it is possible for the culprit to die. The mind cannot accept this.265That eye for eye be taken literally. Ben Zuta266See I.E. on Ex. 2:2 and the notes thereto. said to Saadiah Gaon: Does not Scripture elsewhere state, as he hath maimed a man, so shall it be rendered unto him (Lev. 24:20)? Rabbi Saadiah answered him: We have a bet taking the place of the word al (on).267There are verses in Scripture in which Scripture employs the word al. However, it is to be interpreted as a bet. For example, Scripture states, lo ragal al lishono (Ps. 15:3). Its literal reading is: He did not slander upon (al) his tongue (leshono). However, it should be interpreted: He did not slander with his tongue (bi-leshono). Its meaning is, so shall a fine be placed upon him.268Lev. 24:40 reads: ken yinaten bo (so shall it be rendered unto him). According to Saadiah Gaon, ken yinaten bo should be interpreted as if written, ken yinaten alav (so shall it be placed upon him); i.e., he is to be fined accordingly. For just as a bet takes the place of al, al (alav) takes the place of a bet (bo). However, Ben Zuta responded, as he hath done, so shall it be done to him (Lev. 24:19).269Which implies tit for tat. The Gaon retorted: Observe, Samson said, As they did unto me, so have I done unto them270The Philistines. (Jud. 15:11). Now Samson did not take their wives and hand them over to others.271Which is what the Philistines did to him. Hence it is also possible that as he hath done, so shall it be done to him (Lev. 24:19) is not to be taken literally. He only repaid them for their dastardly acts. Ben Zuta responded: If the culprit272Who injures another person and knocks out his eye. is a poor man what shall his punishment be? The Gaon answered: If a blind person shall blind one who can see, what shall be done to him, for it is possible for a poor person to become wealthy and pay. However, it is eternally impossible for the blind to pay.273In other words, the blind man can never regain his eyesight so that the punishment of blinding him can be exacted. The general rule is that we cannot fully explain any commandment written in the Torah unless we rely on the words of our sages of blessed memory. Just as we received the Torah274The written law. from the sages,275Literally, the fathers. I.E. occasionally refers to the sages as fathers. Cf. the Talmudic tractate Ethics of the Fathers. so did we receive the Oral Law.276From them. There is no difference between them. Now the interpretation of eye for eye is, it is fitting for the culprit to give his eye in place of his victim’s eye if he does not pay ransom for it.277He deserves to have his eye taken out. However, Scripture substituted a monetary payment.

[TOOTH FOR TOOTH, HAND FOR HAND, FOOT FOR FOOT.] Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says: In some cases the payment for taking out a tooth is very small.278Hence Scripture mentions this law. This is the case when a youth is struck, because if his tooth is uprooted another will take its place.279Nevertheless, the one who takes it out must pay for it. Scripture mentions the hand because one does work with it.280Thus one might suppose that a greater penalty would be inflicted for harming it. Scripture mentions the foot because the loss of a foot is worse than the loss of a hand, as a person cannot walk on one foot.281Thus one might suppose that a greater penalty, i.e., more than just monetary compensation, would be inflicted for harming it. However, I believe that Scripture mentions these organs because they are the ones that are usually harmed. When a man strikes his neighbor he strikes him in the eye which faces him, or the mouth which faces him and thus breaks his teeth, or in the hand that his neighbor fights with or protects his face with, or his foot when he runs away from him.
BURN. Keviyyah (bum) is to be taken at face value; that is, it refers to a burn caused by fire.

Some say that petza (wound) refers to a bleeding wound and chabburah (stripe) to a blow that does not draw blood. However, the Gaon says that petza refers to breaking a bone and chabburah to a bleeding wound.

AND IF A MAN SMITE. God commanded that a bondman should go free because of his eye or tooth to prevent masters from cruelly striking their servants with terrible blows. Thus if the master destroys his bondman’s eye or even his tooth, then the bondman will pass from his control free of charge and the master will forfeit his property.

AND IF HE SMITE OUT HIS BONDMAN’S TOOTH. Scripture, as I have noted, speaks about the most usual. According to tradition a bondman similarly goes free if any of his major organs282The major external organs, which consist of the fingers and toes, the ears, the nose, the tip of the penis in a male and the nipples in a female. See Nega’im 6:7; Kiddushin 25a. are destroyed.

AND IF AN OX GORE A MAN. This portion283Verses 28-31. is mentioned because of if the ox gore a bondman or a bondwoman (v. 32).284Since Scripture up to now dealt with injuries to slaves, it wanted to go on and codify the law dealing with an ox that gores a bondman or a bond-woman. However, before dealing with the latter it wanted to state the law dealing with an ox that gores an Israelite. The man and the woman referred to in our verse are Israelites. Our verse reads, or a woman. Scripture does not mention a woman in He that smiteth a man, so that he dieth (v. 12) because it is the manner of Scripture to mention the more important, namely, the male. Nevertheless, the same law applies to a female.285A person who murders a woman is put to death. Scripture now mentions a woman286That is, our verse reads, or a woman. so that the owner of the ox does not protest and argue that the woman did not follow the normal practice. For there are places where it is not the custom for women to go out of the city to a field where oxen are found. It is because of this that Scripture afterwards states, Whether it have gored a son, or gored a daughter (v. 31). The law concerning one that smiteth a man applies equally whether the victim is an adult or a minor. Scripture mentions son or a daughter so that the owner of the ox does not protest against the parents and say that the parents should have watched their children.

THE OX SHALL BE SURELY STONED. The meaning of and its flesh shall not be eaten is that its flesh shall not be eaten as the flesh of an animal that dies of itself, which the stranger in the gate or the foreigner may eat.287And its flesh shall not be eaten may be mistakenly taken to imply that the flesh of other oxen not killed by shechitah (ritual slaughtering) is permitted to be eaten by Israelites. Hence I.E.’s comment. Our sages said that every time Scripture states, it shall not he eaten, it means that it is prohibited to derive any pleasure from it.
BUT THE OWNER OF THE OX SHALL BE QUIT. Of punishment.

BUT IF THE OX WAS WONT TO GORE. There is no doubt that there is no ransom for those who are to be executed by a court of law.288See Num. 35:31: Moreover ye shall take no ransom for the life of a murderer, that is guilty of death; but he shall surely be put to death. The transmitters of tradition therefore said that shall also be put to death refers to death at the hands of heaven. Now I believe that here [the term shall be put to death] is similar to eye for eye. Its meaning is, the owner shall be put to death if he does not give a redemption for his life. All of this because Scripture reads, yumat (shall be put to death); not yamut (he will die).289According to I.E., the term yumat always means that others shall put him to death. However, yamut always refers to death at the hands of heaven. Since Scripture here uses yumat, the reference cannot be to death at the hands of heaven (Filwarg).

IF THERE BE LAID ON HIM A RANSOM. This does not contradict Moreover ye shall take no ransom for the life of a murderer (Num. 35:31), for Scripture speaks there of a real murderer. However, the person spoken of in our verse did not commit murder. He is only punished because he did not restrain the ox by tying it up. Or, if he tied the ox up, he did not do so properly so that the ox was able to free itself. Or, the ox did not find the door290Of the bam or corral. closed291In other words, the owner left the bam door open. and it went out and caused damage.
LAID UPON HIM. By the decree of the judges.

WHETHER IT HAVE GORED A SON, OR HAVE GORED A DAUGHTER. Both of whom are Israelites, for Scripture afterwards reads, If the ox gore a bondman (v. 32). God decreed that the owner of the ox292Even though he personally did not directly kill. be punished because it is hard for God to see an animal kill a person who is created in the image of God. Because of this, the ox is also stoned.

AND IF A MAN SHALL OPEN A PIT. Which was dug.293That is, a pit which was dug and then covered. Scripture mentions this because God does not want an animal to die in vain, that is, if its death does not serve human needs. Furthermore, he294The one who opens the pit. injures the owner of the beast.

THE OWNER OF THE PIT. The one who opened it or the one who dug it. This is the law even though the pit is on public property.295And does not belong to the one who opened or dug it. He made it for his use; therefore he is called the owner of the pit.
HE SHALL GIVE MONEY. He shall pay what the fallen animal was worth when alive after deducting the value of the carcass.

AND IF ONE MAN’S OX HURT ANOTHER’S. Ben Zuta says that re’ehu (another’s)296Literally, his neighbor. is an adjective describing the ox.297According to Ben Zuta (a Karaite exegete) our verse should be rendered: And if a man’s ox hurt an ox his neighbor (re’ehu), i.e., the ox , who is his neighbor. However, Ben Zuta did not notice that the word shor (ox) is in the construct with ish (man’s).298Its literal meaning is, a man’s ox. This is also the case with the word shor (ox) and re’ehu (another’s).299I.E.’s point is that shor re’ehu is parallel to shor ish, which literally means a man’s ox. Hence shor re’ehu must similarly mean a neighbor’s ox. However, an ox has no neighbor except for Ben Zuta.300For the term re’a (neighbor) only refers to a fellow human being. The owner of a tame ox pays half of the damage.

OR IF IT BE KNOWN. On the other hand, if the ox was a gorer he shall pay the entire damage. Scripture mentions the laws dealing with the ox up to If a man steal an ox (v. 37).301That is, starting with verse 28 and ending with verse 37. All of this302Scripture found it necessary to codify here the laws contained in verses 28-37. because of the bondman who is sold303By the law courts. because of his theft. This is the way our Torah portion opened, namely, If thou buy a Hebrew servant (v. 2).304The slave spoken of in verse 2 is a slave sold by the law courts for theft.

IF A MAN STEAL. Rabbi Joshua says that God was stricter with an ox than with a sheep because the thief cannot hide an ox as he can a sheep.305Since one has to be more of a professional thief to steal the ox, the fine is heavier. One cannot steal it unless one is experienced in the art of theft.306Hence the thief is punished more severely. However, Saadiah Gaon says that the theft of an ox is more severely punished because the owner of the ox suffers more than that of a sheep because the ox is used for plowing.
IF A THIEF BE FOUND BREAKING IN. At night, as the thief would not break in during the day. If the sun he risen upon him in the verse which follows proves this.

[THERE SHALL BE NO BLOODGUILTINESS FOR HIM.] That is, the one who kills the thief is not guilty of bloodshed.1In other words, damim (literally, blood) means bloodshed. Hence en lo damim (there shall be no bloodguiltiness in him) means he is not guilty of bloodshed. One has to be amazed at those who interpret damim (bloodguiltiness) as life.2The reference is to Rashi. Rashi interprets en lo damim (there shall be no bloodguiltiness in him): “This is not murder. He is considered as dead to begin with.” Also see Rashi on verse 2. “Damim lo (there shall be bloodguiltiness for him): He is considered as a living person, and the owner of the house commits murder if he kills him.” If this is so, what is the meaning of because thou art a man of blood (damim) (II Sam. 16:8) and his blood (damav) shall be upon him (Lev. 20:9).

IF THE SUN BE RISEN UPON HIM…HE SHALL MAKE RESTITUTION. This3He shall make restitution. refers to he shall pay five oxen for an ox, etc. (Ex. 21:37), which is written above.4For the first part of our verse does not deal with what a thief steals. It deals rather with the circumstances under which an owner may kill a thief (Krinsky). It is like unto a foreign people (Ex. 21:8)5Which is connected to the first part of verse 8. See I.E. on Ex. 21:7,8. and And also unto thy bondwoman thou shalt do likewise (Deut. 15:17), which refers to thou shalt furnish him liberally (Deut. 15:14), which is written above it.

HE SHALL BE SOLD FOR HIS THEFT. Because of his theft.6I.E.’s point is that the bet prefaced to genevato (his theft) means because. Thus bi-genevato means because of his theft. The bet prefaced to a word usually means in. Hence I.E.’s comment.

IF THE THEFT BE FOUND IN HIS HAND. This verse refers to all beasts.7Not only to an ox, ass, or sheep. Our sages8Vat. Ebr. 38 reads: however, our sages, etc. received a tradition that Scripture decrees9Hebrew, gezerat ha-katuv. that the law concerning the payment of “four and five” applies only to oxen and sheep.10See Baba Kama 67b.

IF A MAN CAUSE A FIELD OR A VINEYARD TO BE EATEN. This too is connected to what is written above11That is, Ex. 21:28-36. wherein the damage cause by an ox is mentioned. Scripture reads, ki yaver (if…cause…to be eaten). The word yaver (cause to be eaten) comes from the same root as be’irenu (our cattle) in we and our cattle (Num. 22:4).12Thus ki yaver ish means if a man sends his beast, i.e., he sends his beast to pasture. Indeed, this is how I.E. renders yaver in his short commentary. Similarly Rashi on verse 4. It13The reference is apparently to yaver (Krinsky, Weiser). However, see next note. is a pi’el.14Yaver, as I.E. points out in his short commentary, is a hifil. Some believe that our text is corrupt and that we should emend it accordingly. See Krinsky and Weiser. However, according to Filwarg, I.E.’s comment refers to bi’er (feed), which is the pi’el.

[AND IT FEED IN ANOTHER MAN’S FIELD.] Bi-sedeh acker15Literally, in another field. Hence I.E.’s comment. means in another man’s field.16In another field is short for in another man’s field. Ye that have eaten up the vineyard (Is. 3:4)17Ye that have eaten up the vineyard means ye have eaten up the vineyard which belongs to another. is similar.
IF FIRE BREAK OUT. This too is connected to what is written above, for it speaks of damage caused to a field.

[HE THAT KINDLED.] The word ha-mavir (he that kindled) does not have the same meaning as the word yaver (cause to be eaten) in if a man cause…to be eaten (v. 4) even though they both come from the same conjugation.18Mavir and yaver are both hifils. For the word fire indicates what ha-mavir means.19Our verse opens with If fire break out. It then goes on to say that the “mavir” shall surely make restitution. It is thus clear that ha-mavir means he that kindled [the fire]. It is considered beautiful Hebrew style to employ the same word with two meanings,20In one verse or passage. as in With the jawbone of an ass (ha-chamor), heaps upon heaps (chamor chamorotayim) (Jud. 15:16), and in that rode on thirty ass colts (ayarim), and they had thirty cities (u-sheloshim ayarim lahem) (Jud. 10:4). Now in the latter verse the second ayarim means cities, as which are called Havvoth-jair (Ibid.) proves.21Jud. 10:4 reads: And he had thirty sons that rode on thirty ass colts (ayarim), and they had thirty cities (ayarim), which are called Havvoth-jair (the villages of Jair) unto this day. It is highly unlikely that which are called Havvoth-jair refers to ass colts.

IF A MAN DELIVERS. This is also connected to what is written above.22The above verses 1-3 dealing with theft. Scripture speaks of theft so as to complete the ordinances concerning theft.23Begun in the earlier verse.

WHETHER HE HAVE NOT PUT HIS HAND UNTO HIS NEIGHBOR’S GOODS. This indicates that then the master of the house shall come near unto God refers to an oath sworn before judges.24Whether he have not put his hand unto his neighbor’s goods indicates an oath; i.e., then the master of the house shall come near unto God…[and shall swear] whether he have not put his hand unto his neighbor’s goods. So too Rashi. Hence, For every matter of trespass (v. 8) follows. This means that the one who swore sinned.25That is, swore falsely (see Rashi). Since the previous verse deals with an oath taken by the bailee, the verse that follows deals with instances where the bailee commits perjury. Rabbi Joshua says that pesha (trespass) means that it went out of the owner’s possession, as in “Then did Edom revolt from under the hand of Judah.”26There is no such verse. II Kings 8:22 literally reads: “Yet Edom revolted from under the hand of Judah…Then did Libnah revolt at the same time.” I.E. probably quoted from memory and erred. (II Kings 8:22). For every matter of trespass (v. 8) includes everything that follows27That is, oxen, asses, sheep, or raiment. and everything28Else. that passes out of the owner’s possession,29I.E.’s paraphrase, For every manner of trespass. whether stolen30This is implied in every manner of trespass. or lost,31Explicitly mentioned in our verse. with the finder denying and not admitting that he found it.
WHEREOF ONE SAITH. The witness saith, This is it.

THIS IS IT…HE WHOM GOD SHALL CONDEMN. If God32That is, the judge. shall condemn the keeper, because he himself stole it, or one who found an object and denied finding it, and thus became a thief because of it.

IF A MAN DELIVER. Our verse speaks of a paid bailee.33A bailee, or keeper, who is paid for his services. This bailee is obligated to pay if what is placed in his charge is stolen or torn. See verse 11.

UNTO HIS NEIGHBOR’S GOODS. According to the pace of the cattle (Gen. 33:14.) is similar.34Melekhet (goods) is similar to the word melakhah (cattle) in According to the pace of the cattle. The word melakhah literally means work. Hence I.E.’s comment that it sometimes connotes goods, property, or anything that is one’s “work.” See I.E. on Gen. 33:14. The owner takes nothing from the keeper except for the oath.
IF IT BE TORN IN PIECES. He was paid for this.35He was paid to make sure this did not happen.
LET HIM BRING IT FOR WITNESS. Let him bring a piece of the carcass as proof. This is in line with As a shepherd rescueth out of the mouth of the lion, Two legs, or a piece of an ear (Amos 3:12).
AND IF A MAN BORROW AUGHT. According to the plain meaning of the text, the owner thereof not being with it means that the owner can claim that the borrower overworked his animal.

IF THE OWNER THEREOF BE WITH IT. If the owner himself saw how the animal was hurt or died.36The bailee does not have to pay for the animal, for the owner would not have permitted the bailee to overwork his animal. The same law applies to a hired animal accompanied on the way by its lessee and lessor.37I.E.’s interpretion of im sachir hu ba bi-secharo (if it be a hireling he loseth his hire) as: if a hired animal, while being accompanied by its lessee and lessor, was hurt or died, the lessee is not obligated to pay. See Weiser. See also Rashi who interprets differently. Scripture concludes its dealing with theft of property and proceeds to discuss theft of confidence namely, seduction, for we often find men seducing young women of immature mind.38Hence Scripture deals with this vice.

THAT IS NOT BETROTHED. For a betrothed woman is considered to be married39And the one who sleeps with her is punished by death. See Deut. 22:24. even though she has not slept with her husband.40According to Rabbinic tradition there are two stages to marriage, erusin (betrothal) and kiddushin (sanctification). In the first stage the woman lives with her parents and is prohibited from having intercourse with her husband. In the second stage the women leaves her parent’s home and takes up her domicile with her husband. In contemporary times the erusin and kiddushin take place at the same time. A woman who is an arusah is considered to be married even though she still lives with her parents. Thus a “betrothed woman” in Scripture does not refer to an engaged woman; it refers to a married woman.

[HE SHALL SURELY PAY A DOWRY FOR HER.] Mahor yimharennah (he shall surely pay a dowry for her) is similar to the word mohar used in the sense of attachment, as in acher maharu (that attach themselves unto another)41Translated according to I.E. According to I.E., mahor yimharennah (he shall surely pay a dowry for her) is to be rendered: he shall surely attach himself to her; that is, he must marry her. (Ps. 16:4). The root mem, heh, resh having the meaning of quickly (meherah) is only found in the pi’el in all of Scripture.42Whereas mahor yimharennah is in the kal.
HE SHALL PAY MONEY. For seducing her.

A SORCERESS. Scripture mentions the law of the sorceress after the law dealing with a seduced virgin because those who lust desire to satisfy their cravings through magic.43By bewitching in one way or another the objects of their desire. Scripture speaks of a sorceress because women practice sorcery more than men.44The same law applies to a sorcerer. However, Scripture speaks of what is most usual.

WHOSOEVER LIETH WITH A BEAST. Scripture first mentions the laws dealing with the seduction of an immature young woman. It also mentions intercourse with an animal that, unlike a woman, cannot cry for help. It then mentions45In Deut. 22:24-27. the law concerning a woman who can cry for help.46If raped.

HE THAT SACRIFICETH UNTO THE GODS. According to the plain meaning of the text the verse does not speak of an Israelite, for Scripture already warned against this in the second statement.47Of the Decalogue, viz., Thou shalt have no other gods before Me (Ex. 20:3). It is only mentioned because of the stranger who is mentioned in the next verse. It is because of the stranger48Some texts read, for it is on account. that Scripture reads, Whosoever lieth with a beast (v. 18), for this is the manner of the foreign nations. Now a stranger may live in the Land of Israel on the following conditions: that he does not lie with a beast and that he does not sacrifice unto idols. Scripture reads, la-elohim (unto the gods) because the reference is to the gods that the stranger was previously accustomed to worship.49The kamatz beneath the lamed indicates the definite article, namely, the gods that the stranger was accustomed to worship. The term la-elohim (the gods) also takes in the angels.50For the term elohim also refers to angels.
UNTO THE LORD ONLY. Only unto the glorious name51YHVH. which is a common noun not used for any other being.52May one offer sacrifices.

AND A STRANGER. When a stranger commits himself not to worship idols you shall not wrong him in your country because you are more powerful than he is. Remember that you were strangers like him. When Scripture makes mention of the stranger who is powerless, it similarly takes note of the orphan and widow who are powerless Israelites. After saying lo te’annun (ye shall not afflict) (v. 21) which is in the plural, Scripture says im te’anneh (if thou afflict) (v. 22)53Which is the singular. because whoever sees a person afflicting the orphan and the widow and does not aid them, is also considered an afflicter.

IF THOU AFFLICT THEM. Note the punishment.54For afflicting a widow or orphan. If a person afflicts an orphan or a widow and no one comes to their aid, all are punished. The next verse therefore reads, My wrath shall wax hot, and I will kill you, that is, all of you. Scripture says, “for if he cry at all unto me”55Translated literally. in regard to the orphan. The same applies to a widow. However, it is possible that the orphan is very young and cannot articulate his pain like the widow.56That is, he can only cry out.

IF THOU LEND MONEY. If the Lord gave you enough wealth so that you are able to lend to the poor.57If thou lend implies that lending money to the poor is not an obligation. However, it is clear from Deut. 15:7-11 that one is obligated to lend money to the poor. Hence I.E. points out that one is obligated to lend money only if one has money to lend. This section58Verses 21-23. is mentioned here because the poor are like the stranger, the orphan, and the widow.59In that they are defenseless. God calls the poor My people because the pious do not seek to acquire wealth in this world, as can be seen from Elijah’s behavior.60Scripture tells us that Elijah was girt with a girdle of leather about his loins (II Kings 1:8) and fed by ravens (I Kings 17:6). This, and the general description of Elijah’s life in Scripture, led I.E. to conclude that Elijah was poor. Elisha, who did not want to accept Naaman’s gift (II Kings 5:16), also proves this point.61For money was not important to Elisha. So does Samuel from Ramah.62Who did not use his position to gather wealth. See I Sam. 12:3.
[WITH THEE.] Its meaning is, in the place where you dwell.

THOU SHALT NOT BE TO HIM AS A CREDITOR. In that he favors you because of your kindness. Scripture reads, tesimun (shall ye lay) because the lender, the scribe, and the witnesses all violate the law.63Tesimun is a plural. Hence I.E.’s comment. According to the Talmud the borrower also violates the law. See Baba Metzia 75b. I.E. apparently held that according to the plain meaning of Scripture the borrower is not included, for tisimun cannot apply to him.

IF THOU AT ALL TAKE THY NEIGHBOR’S GARMENT TO PLEDGE. After saying salmat re’ekha (thy neighbor’s garment), which is the feminine,64That is, salmat is in the feminine. and similarly, after saying, ki hi kesuto levaddah (for that is his only covering) (v. 26).65Kesuto (his covering) is in the feminine. Actually, ki hi kesuto levaddah follows teshivennu. Scripture says, teshivennu (thou shalt restore it).66Teshivennu is masculine. Scripture should have used teshevennah since both salmat and kesut are feminine nouns. Scripture reads teshivennu because it refers to the pledge.67Chavul (pledge) is masculine. Teshivennu (thou shalt restore it) does not mean thou shalt return the garment but rather thou shalt return the pledge (see previous note). It should be noted that the noun chavul is not explicitly stated in the verse but is implied in the verbs chavol tachbol (take to pledge). Saadiah Gaon asks, what reason is there to take the pledge during the day and to return it at night? He answers, because the lender fears that the borrower might secure an additional loan from someone else and give him the pledge as security for the loan.
FOR THAT IS HIS ONLY COVERING. Its meaning is, you should pity him.

[FOR I AM GRACIOUS.] According to the Gaon the term chanun (gracious) is similar in meaning to channuni channuni (Have pity upon me, have pity on me) (Job 19:21).68According to Saadiah the word chanun means gracious. Thus Job 19:21 should be rendered: be gracious to me, be gracious to me. Its meaning is, I will give him money and take away your money. I believe that this is not the meaning of chaninah (graciousness). What did David seek in saying, Be gracious unto me, O God. according to Thy mercy (Ps. 51:3)?69The context makes it clear that David was not seeking a monetary gift from God. Chanun rather has the same meaning as the word rachum (merciful) although there is a difference between them,70In nuance. as I will note in the Torah portion Ki Tissa.

Now the phrase that I will hear which follows and it shall come to pass, when He crieth unto Me is similar to for if they cry at all unto Me, I will surely hear their cry — My wrath shall wax hot (v. 22,23).71Scripture tells us that when the orphan shall cry unto God, the Lord will hear his cry. It does not state what will happen next. I.E. thus points out that what follows I will surely hear their cry in verse 22 also applies here, viz., My wrath shall wax hot, and I will kill you with the sword; and your wives shall be widows, and your children fatherless (v. 23). How shall you know that I will surely hear their cry? You will know it from My wrath which follows.72In verse 23.

THOU SHALT NOT REVILE73Hebrew, tekalel. GOD. The reference is to the judges,74Elohim (God) means judges. Thus, Thou shalt not revile God, means thou shalt not revile a judge or judges. namely, the priests, the sons of Levi, who have the Torah with them. NOR CURSE75Hebrew, ta’or.

A RULER OF THY PEOPLE. In secret or in public. The Geonim differentiated between revile and curse.76See notes 73 and 75. Kelalah refers to an insult, me’erah (curse) refers to a defect in a person’s body or fortune (Weiser). The ruler spoken of in our verse is the king noted in Deuteronomy. When we examined all the verses that come one after the other until And in all things that I have said unto you take ye heed (Ex. 23:13), we discovered that most of them deal with the poor. They appear to be connected to the section If thou lend money…to the poor (v. 24). Yefet says the reason Scripture mentions Thou shalt not revile God is that if the lender should violate the law and not return the pledge,77At night. the poor man, while in pain during the night, might revile the judge who ruled that the lender should take the pledge.

THE FULNESS OF THY HARVEST, AND OF THE OUTFLOW OF THY PRESSES. Mele’atekha (the fulness of thy harvest) is another name for wine and dimakha (the outflow)78Literally, weeping, or trickling. another name for oil. However, Saadiah Gaon says that mele’atekha refers to both the fullness of the seed and the fullness of the winepress. He says that dimakha alludes to oil, because when an olive is pressed the oil drips like a tear (dema). Now this verse is explained elsewhere, namely, The first-fruits of thy corn, of thy wine, and of thine oil, and the first of the fleece of thy sheep (Deut. 18:4).79Deut. 18:4 is parallel to our verse and indicates that our verse deals with the first fruits. Scripture therefore couples The first-born of thy sons shalt thou give unto Me with it.80That is, it follows the law dealing with the first fruits of the fullness of the harvest and the outflow of the presses. For the first-born are the first of one’s strength.81They are thus similar to the first fruits. Ben Zuta says that mele’atekha (the fulness of thy harvest) refers to pregnancy and dimakha (the outflow of the press) is another term for sperm, which is a drop. He also says that Thou shalt not delay means that one should not delay taking a wife. Hence, The first-born of thy sons shalt thou give unto Me follows it. However, this is sheer insanity. Why did Scripture mention mele’atekha before dimakha? According to Ben Zuta, dimakha refers to the ejaculation of semen into a woman, which is then followed by pregnancy. Furthermore, pregnancy is not in the hand of man. It depends only upon God.82According to Ben Zuta our verse commands a man to marry and have children, viz., The first-born of thy sons shalt thou give unto Me. I.E. claims that there cannot be a command to have children, for while a man can marry and attempt to have children, there is no guarantee that he will. See I.E. on Gen. 1:22 and the notes thereto. Yefet says that this verse is mentioned so that the poor person does not delay to give that which he is obligated to give.83In other words, this verse is addressed to the poor. Yefet comments thus because most of our verses deal with the poor. See I.E.’s notes on the previous verse. SHALT THOU DO WITH THINE OXEN, AND WITH THY SHEEP.] Likewise thou shalt give the first-born84Of thine oxen and thy sheep. to the priest.

AND YE SHALL BE HOLY MEN UNTO ME. Since Scripture mentions thine oxen and thy sheep, which are permitted to be eaten, it warns one not to eat meat which is torn, for it is possible that a poor person might eat torn meat because of his poverty.85I.E. comments thus because most of our verse deals with the poor. See I.E.’s note on verse 27.

[IN THE FIELD.] Scripture speaks of what is most common. The same law applies if the animal was torn in the midst of a city. That chanceth him by night (Deut. 23:11)86The reference is to a seminal emission. is similar.87Scripture speaks of a nocturnal emission because that is when most involuntary emissions take place. However, the same law applies to an emission that occurs during the day.

[TO THE DOGS.]88Literally, to the dog. The lamed prefaced to kelev (dogs) was vocalized with a pattach89Rather than with a sheva. because the reference is to the dog who guards the oxen and the flock.90The pattach beneath the lamed indicates the definite article. Torn meat is not fit for anyone, only for a dog Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that torn meat is unhealthier than meat from an animal that dies of natural causes. There is something poison-like in torn meat that is harmful to the health of a human being. Hence Scripture does not permit one to give torn meat unto the stranger that is within thy gates (Deut. 14:21) or to sell it unto a foreigner (Ibid.) as it does to meat from an animal that dies of natural causes (Ibid.).
THOU SHALT NOT UTTER A FALSE REPORT. One should not invent fantasies in order to spread lies.

[PUT NOT THY HAND WITH THE WICKED.] Its meaning is, do not join a wicked person1Two witnesses are required in Jewish law. in testifying falsely to harm the innocent. A poor person might do this because of his poverty.2According to I.E. most of the laws from Ex. 22:24 to 23:13 deal with the poor. Hence his comment. See I.E. on Ex. 22:26.

THOU SHALT NOT FOLLOW A MULTITUDE TO DO EVIL. If you see many people testifying concerning something that you know nothing of, do not say to yourself all of these people cannot be lying.3Hence I will back up their testimony. Saadiah Gaon says that there are two commandments in this verse. One is a negative commandment,4Thou shalt not follow a multitude to do evil. the other a positive commandment.5You shall follow the majority. The Gaon says that6This verse teaches. we are obligated to follow the majority,7Our verse ends with the words achare rabbim le-hattot. Saadiah, like the Talmud (San. 2a), interprets this to mean you shall follow the majority; that is, legal questions are decided by the majority opinion of the court. for Saadiah thought that the word le-hattot (to pervert) has the same meaning as li-netot (to turn).8Or follow. Hence Saadiah interpreted achare rabbim le-hattot as you shall follow the majority. It should be noted that both li-netot and le-hattot come from the same root, nun, tet, heh. However, this is not the case. Le-hattot is a pi’el.9Whereas li-netot is a kal. There is an obvious error in I.E. Le-hattot is a hifil. The error was probably made by a scribe, or it is a slip of the pen. It is similar to the word matteh (perverteth) in Cursed be he that perverteth the justice due to the stranger, fatherless, and widow (Deut. 27:19). This form10The hifil form of nun, tet, heh. is also found without the word justice following it. See u-matteh11U-matteh is a participle. Le-hattot is an infinitive. Both words are in the hifil. ger (and pervert the stranger)12Translated literally. And pervert the stranger is short for: and pervert the justice due the stranger. See Weiser. (Mal. 3:5). Our rabbis of blessed memory derived the law that the halakha follows the majority opinion from this verse.13See note 5. They transmitted the truth to us, for after Scripture states, Thou shalt not follow a multitude to do evil, we learn that we are commanded to follow a multitude that wants to do good.14Thus the law which the sages transmitted is correct. However, their interpretation of achare rabbim le-hattot does not follow the plain meaning of the text. It was merely a device by which to pass on the law.

NEITHER SHALT THOU BEAR WITNESS. This commandment falls upon all of Israel. How much more so is a judge, before whom a dispute comes, obligated to help his neighbor.15By seeing to it that he gets a fair trial.

NEITHER SHALT THOU FAVOR A POOR MAN. This too is connected [to If thou lend money to any of My people even to the poor],16Ex. 22:24. See note 2. as you might think that you are doing good in helping the poor.17By being partial to him in judgment. Scripture elsewhere states, nor favor the person of the mighty (Lev. 19:15).18Thus it is prohibited to favor either the rich or the poor.

THINE ENEMY’S OX. Oyivkha (thine enemy’s) is spelled with a chirik beneath the yod.19And is thus irregular. For the tzere beneath the second stem letter usually changes to a segol when a word is combined with a pronominal suffix. Since oyivkha is a combination of the word oyev plus the pronominal suffix kha, we would expect Scripture to read oyevkha rather then oyivkha. Oyivkha is a verb,20Oyivkha is not an adjective. It is a transitive participle meaning your hater, i.e., the one who actively hates you. for the word ve-ayavti 21Literally, then I will hate. (then I will be an enemy) (v. 22) is a transitive verb.22Thus its participial form (oyev) is also transitive. Its meaning is, even though you know that he is your enemy.23You must return his lost ox or ass. The same is true of the word sona’akha (him that hateth thee) (v. 5).24It too is a participle. Scripture uses the term oyivkha25An irregular form. See note 17. because it is proper usage.26To use this form (Weiser). This is also the case with sona’akha.27For sona’akha is the proper vocalization of the word sone and the pronominal suffix kha. It is possible that this section28Verse 4. In the Hebrew Bible, verse 4 forms a section. was written because if the ox and the ass belong to a poor person, then the reward for returning them is very great. One observes God’s law and one also acts kindly with the poor.

THOU SHALT FORBEAR. Ve-chadalta (thou shalt forbear) is similar to chadal (forbear) (II Chron. 25:16), the meaning of which is, forbear from doing this thing.29In other words, chadal (forbear) implies forbear from doing this thing. II Chronicles reads, forbear; why shouldest thou be smitten? I.E. says this should be interpreted as forbear from doing this thing; why shouldest thou be smitten? Ve-shamarta (and thou shalt observe) (Deut. 17:10) is similar.30Ve-shamarta (and thou shalt observe) is followed by la’asot (to do). According to I.E. this shows that even in cases where ve-shamarta is not explicitly followed by la’asot (to do), the latter is implied. The meaning of ve-chadalta ma’azov lo (thou shalt forbear to pass by him) is, forbear from leaving the matter31Of unloading the beast. to him alone. On the contrary, assist him in opening the knots32Of the burden that is upon the beast. and leave the burden as it is,33On the beast. and it will fall down on both sides of the donkey.34I.E.’s interpretation of azov ta’azov immo (thou shalt surely release it with him). The beast will then rise.35By itself. Some say36See Rashi. that its meaning37The meaning of azov ta’azov (thou shalt surely release) (see Krinsky and Filwarg). is similar to va-ya’azevu (and they restored) in and they restored Jerusalem (Neh. 3:8), its meaning being, thou shalt surely load the burden. However, this is far-fetched.

THOU SHALT NOT WREST THE JUDGMENT OF THY POOR. This is directed to judges.38Even though it appears that only Israel is being addressed. Thou shalt eat it39The reference is to the firstlings (bekhorim), that is, the first-born of a cow or sheep. See Ex. 13. before the Lord thy God (Deut. 15:20) similarly refers to the one who is fit to eat it.40Namely, a kohen, for an Israelite is prohibited from eating a firstling. Scripture, as it were, separates the kohen from the Israelites and addresses him.41The point is that Thou shalt eat it before the Lord thy God is directed to the kohen even though the passage in which it is found is directed to all of Israel. The person who says42The reference is to Anan, who is considered to be the founder of the Karaites (Krinsky). that the reference43In Deut. 15:20. is to the first-born of the flock44That is, that Deut. 15:20 does not refer to firstlings. It refers to the first animal of the flock or herd to be born that season. Such an animal may be eaten by an Israelite. See I.E. on Deut. 12:17. speaks nonsense.

KEEP THEE FAR FROM A FALSE MATTER. This45Like the previous verse. is directed to judges. They are not to judge falsely.46In other words, Keep thee far from a false matter means do not judge falsely. Justice, justice shalt thou follow (Deut. 16:20) is similar.47It too is directed to the judge. However, in Deuteronomy, I.E. explains that this verse is directed to the complainants.

AND THE INNOCENT AND RIGHTEOUS SLAY THOU NOT. Those who are innocent and righteous in this case. If you know, that the defendant is wicked in some other matter do not say, because he committed some other horrible act, let me kill him and remove him from society.48So that he does not cause any harm in the future. I will exact punishment from him and he will not escape My hand.49Hence there is no reason for you to legally murder him.

AND THOU SHALT TAKE NO GIFT. This verse is also mentioned because the wealthy give bribes to the judges to divert justice from the poor.50In other words, this law like so many of the earlier ones takes Ex. 22:24 as its point of departure. See note 2.

AND PERVERTETH THE WORDS OF THE RIGHTEOUS. Saadiah Gaon says that the word tzaddikim (righteous) modifies divre (words of).51In other words, tzaddikim is an adjective modifying divre. However, this is not possible, for divre is in the construct.52With tzaddikim. Hence divre tzaddikim must be rendered as words of the righteous, as a noun cannot be in the construct with an adjective.
[RIGHTEOUS.] Righteous refers to righteous in the matter before the judges, not righteous with regard to the observance of the commandments.
AND SIX YEARS. This too53Like many of the previous laws. is mentioned because of that the poor of thy people may eat (v. 11).54In other words, it too takes its point of departure from Ex. 22:24.

BUT THE SEVENTH YEAR THOU SHALT LET IT REST. This is the year that the Lord’s release is proclaimed. One is then prohibited from exacting a debt from his needy neighbor.55See Deut. 15:2. Hence this law too takes its point of departure from Ex. 22:24.

AND LIE FALLOW. U-netashta (and lie fallow)56Literally, and thou shalt leave it. Hence I.E.’s comment. means it shall not be sown. And we would forego (ve-nittosh)57Ve-nittosh and ve-netashta come from the same root nun, tet, shin. the seventh year (Neh. 10:32) is similar.58It means we will not sow in the seventh year.

SIX DAYS. Scripture also mentions that the son of thy handmaid, and the stranger, who is in your gate, who is poor, and [who] hires himself out to you, may be refreshed.59Hence this law too takes its point of departure from Ex. 22:24.

AND IN ALL THINGS THAT I HAVE SAID UNTO YOU TAKE YE HEED. Scripture now mentions idolatry. And in all things that I have said unto you refers to God’s commandments and ordinances. Observe them, not the ordinances of other gods. Scripture says, and make no mention of the name of other gods ; that is, do not mention their names in any oath or cause their adherents to swear by their names. The precise meaning of neither let it be heard out of thy mouth is: you shall not cause others to swear by their names; that is, do not tell an idolater, “Swear to me by your god.”

[THREE TIMES.] The meaning of regalim60The word regel means a foot. Hence I.E.’s comment. is times. You shall serve only Me. You shall serve Me three times a year by coming before Me like a servant who comes before his master to bring him a gift. Scripture therefore afterwards reads, el61The I.E. texts have et. This is probably a scribal error, as verse 17 reads el. pene ha-adon Adonai (v. 17),62Literally, to the face of the Lord God. Hence I.E. notes that the word el pene (to the face of) has the same meaning as li-fene (before the face of, i.e., in front of or before). the meaning of which is, before the Lord63Hebrew, adon (master). In other words, Scripture employs the term Lord or Master because we must come before Him as a servant comes before his master. God (v. 17). And none shall appear before Me empty (v. 15) is similar.64Servants bring gifts to their masters. Scripture mentions this because pagans go to worship their vanities on specific days.65In other words, according to I.E., the purpose of the pilgrimage festivals is to keep Israel from worshipping idols. Maimonides offers a similar explanation. See Guide of the Perplexed, 3:45,46. Scripture therefore reads, thou shalt keep a feast unto Me, the meaning of which is, only unto Me.

[THOU SHALT KEEP A FEAST.] The word tachog (thou shalt keep a feast) means thou shalt sacrifice. It is similar to the word chag (sacrifice) in tie the sacrifice with ropes (Ps. 118:27).66Translated according to I.E.
TIMES. The word regalim comes from the same root as regel (foot), for most of the people come on foot.67When they make their annual pilgrimage to the house of God.

THE FEAST OF UNLEAVENED BREAD. Scripture starts with the festival of unleavened bread68That is it lists the festival of Passover before that of Sukkot and Shavu’ot. because it falls in the first month of the year.69See Ex. 21:2. Now Scripture states, seven days thou shalt eat unleavened bread. This is similar to Thou shalt keep the feast of tabernacles seven days (Deut. 16:13). It is thus an obligation.70To eat unleavened bread for seven days. The latter contradicts the Rabbinic opinion that the obligation to eat matzah is limited to the first night of Passover. See Pesachim 120a. However, I.E. spoke only from the point of view of the plain meaning of the text. However, Six days thou shalt do thy work (v. 12) differs.71For there is no obligation to work six days. For Scripture immediately states that one has to rest on the seventh day (Ibid.).72The thrust of Scripture thus is that one must rest on the Sabbath. The meaning of Six days thou shalt do thy work, but the seventh day thou shalt rest is you may do your work during the first six days of the week but you must rest on the Sabbath day. Seven days thou shalt eat unleavened bread differs from it.73From Six days thou shalt do thy work. For seven days thou shalt eat unleavened bread is an obligation, but, Six days thou shalt do thy work is not an obligation. Furthermore, why doesn’t Scripture read, seven days you shall not eat leavened bread?74If seven days thou shalt eat unleavened bread merely means seven days you shall not eat leavened bread, then Scripture should have so stated.
IN THE MONTH ABIB. I have already explained this.

[AND NONE SHALL APPEAR BEFORE ME EMPTY.] Many think that ve-lo yera’u fanai rekam (and none shall appear before Me empty) is like u-fanai lo yera’u (but My face shall not be seen) (Ex. 33:23).75In other words, ve-lo yera’u fanai rekam means: and My face shall not be seen when [the worshipper is] empty-handed. According to this interpretation the words lo yera’u refer to God’s face (fanai). However, this is incorrect, for those who come to the house of the Lord are there seen.76Hence ve-lo yera’u fanai rekam means: and none shall appear before My face [or before Me] empty. I.E.’s point is that ve-lo yera’u in ve-lo yera’u fanai refers to the worshipper but lo yera’u in u-fanai lo yera’u refers to God’s face. Venireh et pene Adonai (That he may appear before the Lord) (I Sam. 1:22) is proof of this.77That it is the worshipper who is said to be seen before God. The phrase et pene Adonai in yera’eh khol zekhurekha et pene Adonai (shall all thy males appear before the Lord thy God) (Deut. 16:16) means before the Lord.78Not the face of God. Yera’eh is a nifal and refers to khol zekhurekha (all thy males) rather than to et pene Adonai. I.E. comments thus because et pene Adonai might be taken to mean the face of God.

AND THE FEAST OF HARVEST. The harvest of the first of the wheat. Now the barley crop which is what Abib refers to79According to I.E., chodesh ha-aviv means the month when the first barley appears. is always there when the festival of unleavened bread arrives. There are seven weeks from the arrival of the first barley to the arrival of the first wheat. Compare, Seven weeks shalt thou number unto thee (Deut. 16:9).

AND THE FEAST OF INGATHERING, AT THE END OF THE YEAR. And a new year commences. Sowing begins in the month of Marcheshvan.80The Torah seems to tell us that the year comes to a close towards the end of Tishri (Sukkot falls in the middle of Tishri). However, the new year begins with Tishri. Hence I.E. points out that Scripture here speaks of an agricultural year. That year ends in Tishri with the fall harvest and begins in Marcheshvan when the new crop is sown.

THREE TIMES. These three times, concerning which I said, None shall appear before Me empty (v. 15), was said only with regard to males who are of the age when they are obligated to observe the commandments. Those who are ill and cannot come are exempt.
THE BLOOD OF MY SACRIFICE. The reference is to the sacrifice of the paschal offering, which is eaten with unleavened bread and bitter herbs.

THE FAT OF MY FEAST. The reference is to the unblemished lamb81The paschal lamb. See Ex 12:5. I.E.’s point is that the blood of My sacrifice and the fat of My feast refer to the same animal. which one is obligated to offer. It is similarly written, in offering the portions that were to be burnt and the fat till the morning (II Chron. 35:14).82There is apparently an error in the text. Chronicles reads: in offering the portions that were to be burnt and the fat until night. It is possibly a scribal error. On the other hand, I.E. may have quoted from memory and erred. If I.E. quoted the verse properly, then he is offering proof from Chronicles that the fat of offering was not allowed to remain overnight (Krinsky). In his short commentary, I.E. explains that the fat of the paschal lamb could be burnt till the morning because of the many sacrifices offered. He quoted II Chron. 35:14 to illustrate the normal procedure.

THE CHOICEST FIRST-FRUITS OF THY LAND. This is what And if thou bring a meal-offering of first-fruits unto the Lord (Lev. 2:14) refers to. As I will explain in its place, the verse83Lev. 2:14. is directed to the individual.84Rather than the community. According to Rashi, Lev. 2:14 speaks of the Omer which the community is obligated to offer. Hence I.E.’s comment. See Rashi on Lev. 2:14. Scripture mentions this law after Thou shalt not offer the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread (v. 18), for the first fruits begin then.85One is permitted to start enjoying one’s first fruits from the second day of Passover. See Lev. 22:9-14.

[THOU SHALT NOT SEETHE A KID IN ITS MOTHER’S MILK.] The fools86The Karaites. Cf. I.E.’s short commentary. say that the word gedi (a kid) comes from the same root as meged (precious fruit).87From the root mem, gimel, dalet. These commentators interpret lo tivashel gedi ba-chalev immo (thou shalt not seethe a kid in its mother’s milk) as you shall not ripen the fruit in the juices of its tree. See below. However, this is impossible, for the mem of meged is a root letter. The word megadim (precious fruit) in with precious fruit (Cant. 4:13) is definite proof of this.88That the mem of megadim is a root letter. Compare, melekh, melakhim. We do not find such a thing in the Hebrew language.89That the first letter of a root that ordinarily does not drop any letters should fall out and a new form be created. Hence the word gedi cannot mean precious fruit. Furthermore, how are we to explain lo tivashel (thou shalt not seethe)?90These commentators explain lo tivashel (thou shalt not seethe) as you shall not ripen. It should be noted that the Hebrew word for ripen and the Hebrew word for cook both come from the root bet, shin, lamed. A person cannot ripen the precious fruit. Indeed, Scripture states, And for the precious things (u-mi-meged) of the fruits of the sun91The sun, not man, ripens the precious fruit. (Deut. 33:14). Additionally, what reason is there to say in…milk?92If the reference is to its juices. Where do we find such an expression?93That is, where do we find milk referring to the juice of a fruit? Additionally, what is the meaning of its mother’s? Where else is the tree called the mother of the precious fruit? The fools came to this conclusion because they found this commandment coupled with The choicest first-fruits of thy land. 94They thus concluded that this verse teaches that the first fruits are to be picked immediately and not allowed to ripen. Elsewhere we find this commandment95Thou shalt not seethe a kid in its mother’s milk. coupled with Ye shall not eat of any thing that dieth of itself (Deut. 14:21). The latter is its proper place. However, it96Thou shalt not seethe a kid in its mother’s milk. was only mentioned together with the first-fruits because the kids increase and grow then.97At the time wherein the first fruits appear. There is another commentator who says that the meaning of Thou shalt not seethe is, thou shalt not prolong; that is, a kid shall not be with its mother more than seven days.98The reference is to a kid that is first-born. See Ex. 22:29. Now if this is the case, why does Scripture mention this law again?99After already having mentioned it in Ex. 22:29. Furthermore, their proof is in the phrase bashel katzir (the harvest is ripe) (Joel 4:13).100Joel 4:13 reads, Put ye in the sickle, for the harvest is ripe (bashel). This commentator interprets the verse as: Put ye in the sickle, for the harvest has been long on the vine. Lo tevashel gedi bachalev immo similarly means: Do not leave the kid so that it continues to nurse its mother milk. However, the term bashel means to seethe,101Not to leave, or prolong its stay. for the sun seethes like fire.102Thus bashel katzir literally means the harvest has been seethed, i.e., ripened. It is the same case with hivshilu (ripe)103Hivshilu literally means they caused it to cook. in and the clusters thereof brought forth ripe grapes (Gen. 40:10). Rabbi Solomon104Rashi. This is also the opinion of the Talmud. See Hullin 113b. says that gedi (a kid) means young and tender. He says it applies to young oxen and young lambs. He claims that the phrase gedi izzim (a kid of the goats) (Gen. 38:17) proves this, since there is no reason to connect them.105That is, to connect gedi to izzim. In other words, if gedi means a young goat, then Gen. 38:17 should have read gedi, not gedi izzim, for gedi izzim means a young goat of the goats. See Rashi. However, this is not so. The term gedi applies only to a goat. Thus in Arabic106A cognate of Hebrew. the term gedi means a goat. It is never used for any other kind. However, there is a difference between a gedi and a gedi izzim. A gedi is larger than a gedi izzim. A gedi izzim still needs to be with other goats. The same applies to the terms sa’ir (a he-goat) and se’ir izzim.107A se’ir izzim cannot survive on its own. It has to be with other goats. Our sages have received the tradition that an Israelite is not permitted to eat meat and milk.108That is, our sages have received the tradition that our verse teaches that an Israelite may not eat meat and milk. See Hullin 113b. I will now explain.109The meaning of Thou shalt not seethe a kid in its mother’s milk and the Rabbinic tradition based on it, regarding the prohibition of eating meat and milk. Note that it is the Torah’s custom to speak of that which is most prevalent. For example, the Torah refers to the ostrich as a bat ha-ya’anah (Lev. 11:16).110Literally, the daughter of wailing. In Leviticus chapter 11, the Torah lists the animals which may or may not be eaten. The only species which is referred to as a bat is the ostrich. Now why does the Torah do something here which it does not do in any other place? For in no other place does the Torah refer to an entire species by the term “daughter of” (bat). Note that the flesh of the ya’anah is as dry as wood. It is not customary for people to eat it, as it contains no moisture. The only flesh of this species that is eaten is that of the “daughter” (bat), whose flesh has a little moisture in it because it is a young female.111The Torah refers to an ostrich as a bat because that is the type of ostrich that is usually eaten by those who eat ostriches. However, young ostrich males have no moisture in them. Similarly, people do not eat meat and milk, for it is not pleasant to do so. Meat takes long to cook, but milk boils quickly.112I.E. believed that food that does not cook equally should not be prepared in the same pot. It is not the custom even today in the land of the Ishmaelites for a person to eat a lamb cooked in milk because the lamb is very moist and so is milk. It is thus harmful.113According to medieval medicine there are four humors: dry, hot, moist, and dry. An imbalance of these humors was thought to cause illness. Hence it is not eaten. On the other hand, the flesh of the kid contains no moisture. When a goat is small it is hot.114And cooks quickly. Therefore they [inhabitants of Ishmaelite lands] cook the kid with milk. Do not be surprised that the people of the surrounding areas are not in the habit of eating a kid of the goats.115I.E. took pains to point out that the fact that people did not eat kid meat in the area where he wrote his commentary does not negate his earlier point. He had explained that the reason Scripture reads, Thou shalt not seethe a kid in its mother’s milk, rather than “thou shalt not seethe meat in milk” was that people do the former and not the latter. People do not refrain from eating goat’s meat because of health reasons. They do so because of local idiosyncrasies.
