The latter implies that the mitre was put on before the garments. Hence I.E.’s interpretation that and clothed him with garments (Ibid.) means, and they had already clothed him.

AND THEY SHALL TAKE THE GOLD. The wise-hearted who made the priestly garments were trustworthy.45Hence the materials for the sacred garments were not measured out to the “wise hearted-men.” On the contrary, on their own they took the gold, the blue, etc. (Filwarg).

AND THEY SHALL MAKE THE EPHOD. Scripture starts with the ephod46Even though in verse 4 it mentioned the breastplate first. because it was larger than the breastplate. The Torah tells us that the breastplate be not loosed from the skilfully woven band of the ephod (v. 28).47This shows that the breastplate was smaller than the ephod, for the smaller object is normally attached to a larger one. There are some very difficult questions relating to the ephod and the breastplate. Moses only made one ephod.48In other words, the Torah implies that there was only one ephod, the one made by Moses. I.E. was especially bothered by the problem of the many ephods cited in Scripture. However, Scripture states, that he49Abiathar. came down with an ephod in his hand (I Sam. 23:6). The latter does not refer to the ephod made by Moses,50This verse implies that other ephods were employed in ancient Israel. for Scripture does not read “the ephod,”51I Sam 23:6 reads “an ephod,” not “the ephod in his hand.” the meaning of which is, the well-known ephod,52That is, the ephod made by Moses. According to I.E. ephod means an ephod. The ephod, with the definite article prefixed to it, is the ephod made by Moses. See I.E. on Gen. 31:19, note 30. as it does when it states, “Bring hither the ephod” (I Sam. 23:9).53The reference being to the ephod made by Moses. Furthermore, why does Scripture state, he came down, but it does not say he brought down? It thus appears that the ephod was accidentally among his possessions.54According to I.E., that he came down with an ephod in his hand implies that Abiathar happened to have an ephod which he brought down, whereas if Scripture had read: that he brought down the ephod in his hand, it would have implied that Abiathar deliberately brought down the ephod. In the latter case, the reference would be to the ephod made by Moses. Additionally, Scripture there states, fourscore persons55The Biblical text has fourscore and five. If it is not a scribal error, then I.E. quoted from memory and erred. that did wear a linen (bad) ephod (I Sam. 22:18).56We thus see that there were 80 ephods. Many commentaries explain this verse as meaning that the persons57Spoken of in I Sam. 22:18. were fit to wear the ephod.58Fourscore and five persons that did wear a linen ephod means fourscore and five persons who were fit to wear a linen ephod. In other words, they did not actually wear an ephod but were worthy of wearing the ephod made by Moses. However, they did not bother to learn the truth.59Their interpretation does not solve the problem of there being more than one ephod. A bad (linen) ephod is an ephod made from a type of flax. However, the ephod made by Moses was not made of bad (linen).60Hence I Sam. 22:18 cannot be interpreted as meaning that the priests were worthy of wearing the ephod made by Moses. It was made of gold, blue wool, purple wool, and scarlet, with shesh (linen)61Shesh is a high quality linen. intertwined with all of the aforementioned.62In other words, even though our verse states that the ephod made by Moses contained linen it was not made wholly out of linen. It was made out of all the material enumerated in our verse (Weiser). They only inquired of the breastplate of judgment which had the Urim and Thummim upon it.63This introduces another problem connected with the ephod. Namely, it is clear from most places in Scripture that questions concerning future actions were directed to the Urim and Thummim, which were placed in the breastplate of judgment, which was placed on the ephod. However, David inquired of Abiathar’s ephod in Ziklag. Now as I.E. later shows, Abiathar’s ephod is not to be identified with Moses’ ephod. Thus in addition to the problem of a multiplicity of ephods, the question arises as to how these other ephods worked, as these ephods did not have the Urim and Thummim attached to them. Scripture similarly writes, by the judgment of the Urim before the Lord (Num. 27:21). Bring hither the ephod (I Sam. 23:9)64Spoken by David who asked: will the men of Keilah deliver me up into his [Saul’s] hand? will Saul come down, as thy servant hath heard? (I Sam. 23:11). does not present a counterargument65Prima facie, this verse implies that the ephod itself served as the instrument by which God’s will was divined. because the breastplate was connected to it. The Urim66And Thummim. See next note. went along with the breastplate.67Thus it was the Urim and Thummim which served to reveal God’s will. We similarly read, till there stood up a priest with Urim and Thummim (Neh. 7:65). Scripture likewise states, Thy Thummim and Thy Urim (Deut. 33:8). Now, Scripture tells us68I Sam. 30:7,8. that God answered David through Abiathar’s ephod.69In Ziklag. This ephod did not have the Urim and Thummim with it. The problem described above in note 61 now follows. However, we also read that when Saul went to war he inquired of the Urim (I Sam. 28:6). These were the very Urim that were placed in the breastplate of judgment which was with the ephod70It was attached to the ephod. and the ark.71It was worn by the priest who accompanied the ark. However, David inquired of Abiathar’s ephod in Ziklag. Abiathar’s ephod was thus not Moses’ ephod.72Moses’ ephod was with Saul. We thus see that other ephods served to divine God’s will. The following problem is even more difficult.73Than the above-raised question relating to a multiplicity of ephods and how they worked. It is clear that the Urim do not refer to the stones of the breastplate,74“Urim [means] they made their words enlightening [and Thummim] because they fulfill their words” (Soncino, Yoma 73b). Rashi explains that the stones on the breastplate of judgment served as the instrument of divination by lighting up. See Rashi on verse 30. Also see note 88. However, Rashi does not identify the stones on the breastplate with the Urim and Thummim. Other commentaries taking the Talmud at face value did. It is with these commentaries that I.E. takes issue. as Scripture openly states, And thou shalt set in it settings of stones (v. 17). The setting of the stones was the work of a stonecutter and not the work of Moses. God then told Moses,75After describing how the stones were to be arranged on the breastplate. And thou shalt put in the breastplate of judgment the Urim and the Thummim (v. 30).76It is thus clear that the Urim and Thummim are not to be identified with the stones on the breastplate of judgment. Scripture, in describing the making of the breastplate,77The printed texts have ephod. This is an obvious error. The word ephod does not appear in Vat. Ebr. 38. The latter reads: “Scripture in describing its making,” the reference being to the making of the previously mentioned breastplate. tells us, And they set in it four rows of stones (Ex. 39:10). Scripture then describes the four rows of stones.78We thus see that the stones are part of the breastplate and are not to be identified with the Urim and Thummim. Scripture tells us that Moses placed the breastplate upon Aaron and in the breastplate he put the Urim and the Thummim (Lev. 8:8). Now according to the plain meaning of the text the stones were not the objects that enlightened or fulfilled,79In other words, the stones on the breastplate are not to be identified with the Urim and Thummim. See note 73. because inquiries were made of the Urim and Thummim. We do not know what they were. The explanation that the names of the tribes80As noted above, the Talmud explains that the letters on the stones lit up. It then says, “But the tzadi was not inscribed on any of the stones.” For none of the tribes has a tzadi in their names. The Talmud responds, “Rabbi Samuel ben Isaac says, ‘The names of Abraham, Isaac (Hebrew, yod, tzadi. chet, kof), and Jacob were also inscribed upon the stones’” (Yoma 73b). and the patriarchs81See note 80. The Talmud says, “But the tet was not inscribed on the stones.” The words shivte yeshurun (the tribes of Jeshurun) were similarly inscribed on the stones” (Yoma 72b). were inscribed on the breastplate is of no help,82It does not help us to understand what the Urim and Thummim were. for the breastplate of judgment was so called only because of the Urim that were on it.83And as we have seen, the Urim cannot be identical with the stones which were upon the breastplate. There is an additional question: we cannot identify the Urim with the Thummim,84In other words, we do not know what the Thummim were. for Scripture states, with Urim and Thummim (Neh. 7:65). Furthermore, the words with Urim and Thummim are in the plural. They thus consisted of many objects.85And we do not know what these objects were. Rabbi Solomon says that the Urim and Thummim consisted of an inscription of God’s explicit name.86See Rashi on verse 30: “The Urim and Thummim consisted of an inscription of God’s explicit name [upon some unknown material] which was placed inside the folds of the breastplate by means of which it [the breastplate] shed light upon its words and fulfilled its words.” That is, made its statements clear and its promises true. However, he would not have said this had he seen the responsa of Rabbi Hai Gaon.87According to Rabbi Hai Gaon, inscriptions of God’s explicit name cannot be used to divine the future. Nor do they assure success in any endeavor (Rabbi Samuel Zarza, Mekor Chayyim). There is a very deep secret behind the ephod and the breastplate. I will allude only to a part of this secret. Perhaps he who knows the mind of the Most High will understand it. The following are the keys to the secret of the ephod.88According to I.E. the ephod was an astrological instrument which corresponded to the arrangement of the heavens. It drew power from above and, when properly used, had the ability to predict the future. Nahmanides sided with Rashi’s interpretation of the ephod and took strong issue with I.E. See Nahmanides on verse 30, “Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra thought to display wisdom in the matter of the Urim and the Thummim, by saying that they were made by a craftsman from gold and silver, and he continued his discussion of them in this vein, for he thought that they were akin to the forms which the astrologers make in order to know the thoughts of the one who comes to ask of them [about the future]. But what [Ibn Ezra] said is of no import. Rather, the Urim and Thummim are as Rashi has written: this was an inscription of the Proper Name of G-d which was placed between the folds of the breast-plate” (Chavel translation). The two wreathen chains on the two rings [represent the head of Aries and Libra].89So Zarza. I.E. does not explain what the two wreathen chains on the two rings stand for. Sarim suggests that a line is missing. However, it is possible that I.E. believed that, from what follows, it is obvious what the two wreathen chains on the two rings stand for. The band of the ephod represents the celestial equator.90The celestial equator extends from Aries to Libra. It divides the 12 constellations into two parts. Hence six names were inscribed on the stone which was on the other shoulder.91They represent the six constellations that lie on the other side of the equator. The point is that six names were written on the two stones of the ephod. Each group of names represented six constellations. Now these things92The division of the heavens into 12 distinct sections can only be grasped by the mind, for when one looks at the sky one does not see 12 distinct areas in the sky. can only be grasped by the mind. Hence six names were inscribed on one stone93On one of the stones of the ephod. in accordance with the number, names, and order of birth of the tribes of the children of Israel.94Each stone contained six names. There were no boundaries between them. The stone, as it were, took in all the names in the same way that the sky encompasses all the stars. Six names were similarly inscribed on the second stone.95Of the ephod. On the other hand, the names on the breastplate were not divided in the same manner as they are grasped by the mind.96That is, six names were not written on one stone and six on another, with their boundaries left to the imagination. See notes 92 and 93. They were divided in a way that could be perceived by the eye.97Each tribe’s name was inscribed on a separate stone. Scripture states, And they shall bind the breastplate by the rings thereof unto the rings of the ephod with a thread of blue (v. 28) to prevent the breastplate from moving to the side.98To correspond to the stars that do not move out of their fixed orbits (Weiser). The breastplate was folded, for the Urim and Thummim were kept there until such time as they were needed. They were then placed outside of the breastplate.99They were removed from the folds of the breastplate. Note, the stones of the ephod were like each other.100They were of the same size. They were of one color.101They were both sapphires. This was not the case with the stones of the breastplate,102Each stone corresponded to a different constellation. for the sapphire stones103Which were placed upon the ephod. served as a memorial,104See verse 12. while the judgment of the children of Israel was upon the stones of the breastplate.105Judgment descended upon the children of Israel via each stone which represented a constellation. The word Urim is related to the word ur (fire) in I am warm, I have seen the fire (Is. 44:16).106According to I.E. ur is a variation of or and should thus be translated as light. Hence, according to I.E., Is. 44:16 should be rendered: I am warm, I have seen the light (Krinsky). It should be noted that Nahmanides’ text of I.E. reads: “The Urim and Thummim were made out of gold.” The Thummim are so called because they are whole.107The root of tummim (thummim) is taf, mem, mem. The Urim were of gold and silver. This was not the case with the Thummim.108I.E. does not identify the material that the Thummim were made of. The [importance of the] number [twelve] has been established by irrefutable proof from the upper and lower worlds.109It has been established by irrefutable proof that the 12 constellations of the upper world determine the fate of all human beings who dwell in the lower world. Or the importance of the number twelve has been established by the fact that there are 12 constellations in the upper world and 12 tribes of Israel in the lower world (Weiser). The intelligent will understand what I say.110The reference is either to the number 12 or to how the ephod functioned. Now the priests had many ephodim. They all had bands. However, they lacked the breastplate and the Urim. A priest who was an expert in using the Urim and Thummim was able to respond to an inquirer because the ephod at hand resembled [the ephod made by Moses].111It was a duplicate of the ephod made by Moses. Hence astrologically speaking it “worked.” However, the priest did not always get an answer.112The priest received an answer only at a propitious time. Now if I wanted to even begin to reveal this secret113Of how the ephod worked. it would take up more space than the entire commentary which I have composed on this book. For only an individual who has studied works on geometry and the secret of the way the sky works can understand the secret of the ephod. There is no need to expand on the form of the ephod, the breastplate, and the rings.

ONYX STONES. The avne shoham (onyx stones) were white. They are called burla in Aramaic and balor in Arabic. We have no way to positively identify the stones that were set in the breastplate. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon translated them114In his Bible translation. as he saw fit, as he had no tradition to rely upon.115I.E. makes the same point in Genesis. See I.E. on Gen. 2:11 and the notes thereto. We read the Gaon’s translation and noticed that he rendered sappir (sapphire) as white.116That is, Saadiah Gaon explained sappir to as a white stone. See I.E. on Ex. 24:10. However, this is not the case. Sappir is red.117That is, sappir is a red stone. As noted before, sapphire is usually blue, sometimes white, hardly ever red. See chapter 24, note 3. The fact that the first stone118Of the breastplate. mentioned by the Torah was a carnelian119Hebrew, odem (a red stone). does not refute this,120That the sappir is a red stone. In other words, one should not assume that there was only one red stone on the breastplate. for there are five visible colors: white, lightning,121The color of lightning. I.E. probably means yellow. red, green, and black. Now since red is the middle color122Its place is third among the five colors. it comes in various shades. Saadiah Gaon renders nofekh (carbuncle) as black on the basis of and she painted (ba-pukh)123The root of pukh is peh, vav, kaf. her eyes (II Kings 9:30).124Which Saadiah understood to mean: and she darkened or blackened her eyes. Pukh is a “black mineral powder, for increasing brilliance of eyes by darkening edges of lids.” (Hebrew and English Lexicon of the Old Testament, edited by Brown, Driver, Briggs, Oxford University Press, Oxford). However, the nun in nofekh is undoubtedly a root letter,125In other words, the root of nofekh is nun, peh, kaf. Hence nofekh and pukh are two different words. for nofekh follows the paradigm of odem (carnelian).126Wherein all three stem letters are present. A great Sephardic scholar said that yahalom (emerald) is a diamond.127Al mus in Arabic. This stone has the ability to break up all other stones and to bore through bdellium. Yahalom is related to the word holem (smiteth) in smiteth the anvil (Is. 41:7). The yod of yahalom is not a root letter.128For its root is heh, lamed, mem. The yod of yahalom is a form letter. It is like the yod of yitzhar (oil).129Which is not a root letter; the root of yitzhar is tzadi, heh, resh. Also achlamah (amethyst) is to be identified with the dream stone.130Al chelmah in Arabic. This is a stone that always induces dreams in the person who wears it.131The Hebrew word for a dream is chalom. One should not be surprised at this,132That a stone can induce dreams. as every stone has a specific power placed in it by nature. Thus there is a stone that attracts iron.133A magnetic stone. There is likewise a stone that stops bleeding. Another stone is repelled by vinegar. There is also a stone whose pieces always form a triangle when broken.

CHAINS. The middle root letter has been doubled in sharsherot (chains).134The original root of sharsherot is shin, resh, shin. However, the resh was doubled and a new quadriliteral root, shin, resh, shin, resh, formed. The latter is the root of sharsherot. However, the word has the same meaning when the middle root letter is not doubled. Compare, sharshot135The root of sharshot is shin, resh, shin. gavlut (plaited chains) (v. 22). It is very difficult to explain the meaning of gavlut (plaited) in Hebrew.136It has no synonym. According to Sarim, I.E. believes that gavlut, choshen, and some of the other terms used by Scripture in relation to the choshen are not Hebrew words. We consequently do not know their meaning. The same applies to many of the words employed by Scripture that refer to the making of the breastplate as well as to the word choshen (breastplate) itself.

AND THEY SHALL BIND. Ve-yirkesu is related to the word me-rukhse (from the plottings) in from the plottings of man (Ps. 31:21). It means twisted.137I.E.’s point is that the root resh, kaf, samekh (the root of ve-yirkesu and me-rukhse) means twisted. He renders Ps. 31:21: from the twisted actions of men. He similarly explains that ve-yirkesu et ha-choshen…al chesehev ha-ephod means that the choshen shall be twisted (that is, attached, for when one attaches something by a thread he twists it) upon the skillfully woven band of the ephod (Meijler). For other interpretations, see Krinsky.

AND THOU SHALT PUT IN THE BREASTPLATE OF JUDGMENT. Judgment refers to the laws of God and his decrees concerning the future. It is these things that people inquire of the Urim and Thummim.138It is interesting to note that I.E. believes that people also addressed legal questions to the Urim and Thummim. This goes against the accepted Rabbinic doctrine that laws are to be decided by legal authorities rather than by supernatural means.

AND THOU SHALT MAKE. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon translates the word me’il (robe) by the Arabic memtar, which is a cloak-like139The Hebrew term used by I.E. is sarbal. garment except that its opening was in the midst of the robe.140That is, the me’il differs from a cloak in that the me’il has an opening on top for the head. Our sages said that the pomegranates (v. 33) were placed all around the robe. A bell was placed between every two pomegranates.141Zevachim 88:b. Also see Rashi on verse 33. However, others say that the bells were not visible. They were placed inside the pomegranates, where they rang.142Nahmanides accepted this opinion.

AND THOU SHALT MAKE A PLATE. The Gaon renders tzitz (plate) atzabah. It143The plate. Tzitz is masculine but I.E. uses the feminine pronoun (hi) because he is referring to atzabah, the Arabic equivalent of tzitz. was placed on the mitre. It was not shaped like a crown, as the plate144The Hebrew reads, ve-hi netunah al ha-mitznefet, ve-enennah ki-demut keter ki hu al ha-metzach le-vado. It is rather strange that I.E. first employs pronouns which refer to the Arabic form of the word and then employs a pronoun which refers to the Hebrew form of the word. It should be noted that Vat. Ebr. 38 has a totally different reading. It reads: “The Gaon renders tzitz (plate) atzabah. It is placed on the mitre. The mitre does not have the shape of head-tires, for the head-tires are similar to the high hats which men in this and surrounding countries place upon their heads as a head covering. However, the mitres are made out of long thin material which is twisted only around the head.” There is no inconsistency in the tenses in this reading. was placed only on the forehead.145Whereas a crown covers the entire head. According to the plain meaning of the text, the migba’ot (head-tires) (Lev. 8:13)146Worn by an ordinary priest, in contrast to the mitznefet (mitre) worn by the high priest. were not shaped like the mitre (mitznefet). The head-tires are similar to the high hats which men in this and surrounding countries place upon their heads as a head covering. [37.] THE MITRE. The mitre147Worn by the high priest. is made from long thin material which is twisted only around the head.148In other words, the mitre had a shape which allowed the priest to attach the plate to it. The turbans worn by women in these areas are somewhat similar. In Spain, Africa, Egypt, Babylonia, and Baghdad and in the land of the Ishmaelites, only men of respect, not the women, wear turbans on their heads.149In other words, the high priest was not donning a woman’s garment. The important officials place a golden plate on the turban over the forehead. I have already noted that the ornaments in the Land of Israel and the customs practiced there differ from those in these areas. Rabbi Solomon150Rashi. found it necessary to harmonize Scripture151According to Rashi, verse 37 appears to contradict itself and Ex. 39:31. For verse 37 states, And thou shalt put it (the plate) on a thread of blue. However, it goes on to say, and it (the plate) shall be upon the mitre. This implies that the plate was on the mitre, not upon the thread. Furthermore, Ex. 39:31 states, And they tied unto it [the plate] a thread of blue. In other words, verse 37 implies that the plate was placed upon the thread, but Ex. 39:31 implies that the thread was placed on top of the plate. by explaining that three blue threads were attached to the plate.152Rashi explains that the plate was perforated at three points, viz., at the top and at the two ends of the plate. A thread was inserted through each of these perforations. Each thread was thus doubled when pulled through. Hence Rashi speaks of six threads. The threads were then tied together at the back of the neck. The thread in the center passed over the head and was bound with the ends of the two other threads. Rashi explains: “All the verses are now harmonized, a thread upon the plate, and the plate upon the thread, and a thread upon the mitre on top.” The first refers to the threads on the outer side of the plate, the second to the threads on the inner side of the plate, and the third to the threads that passed through the middle perforation. However, according to the plain meaning of the text only one blue thread153Attached to both extremities of the plate. was necessary to keep the plate, which was on the face of the mitre on the forehead, in place.

AND THOU SHALT PUT IT ON A THREAD OF BLUE. The meaning of al petil techelt (on a thread of blue) is, with154In other words, al here means with. Hence verse 37 does not contradict Ex. 39:31. See note 152. Also see note 153. a thread of blue,155Contra Rashi. See note 154. as the thread was tied to the plate on two sides.156The two far sides. There is no doubt that the front of the mitre was placed over the forehead.157In other words, upon the forefront of the mitre it [the plate] shall be means that the plate shall be on the forehead. It158The front of the mitre. was not placed over the head. Scripture elsewhere states, And they tied unto it a thread of blue, to fasten it upon the mitre (Ex. 39:31), that is, upon the forehead.159In other words, on the mitre does not mean on the mitre per se, as Rashi says (see note 152) but upon the forehead. Hence Ex. 39:31 does not contradict Ex. 28:37. Do not be surprised that Scripture uses the term al.160In the sense of with. The word al usually has the meaning of on. Hence I.E.’s comment. We find the same161Al used in the sense of with. in the following, And they came, both men with (al) women (Ex. 35:22);162Translated according to I.E.And the priest shall wave them with (al) the bread of the first-fruits for a wave-offering before the Lord (Lev. 23:20); with (al) the two lambs (Ibid.); the fat with (al) the breast (Lev. 7:30). There are many similar instances in Scripture. Now you will never find [the mitre and the head-tires interchanging].163In other words, contra Rashi on this verse, the mitre and the head-tire are not identical, for if they were, Scripture would interchange these terms. I.E. literally reads: “Now you will never find.” This is a very laconic statement. Some would emend it to: Now we do not find [the mitre] to be worn [by all the priests]. In other words, the mitre is not to be identified with the head-tire. For the mitre was set aside only for Aaron, and the head-tires for his children. Some say that the word migba’ot (head-tires) is related to the word givot (hills) (Gen. 49:26).164In other words, the migba’at had the shape of a high hat. The mitre165Hebrew, mitznefet. surrounded and wrapped the head.166Hence it is not to be identified with the migba’at. We similarly read, He will violently roll (tzanof) and toss thee Like a ball (yitznofkha tzenefah) (Is. 22:18); Yea, He will wind thee round and round (ve-otekha ato) (Is. 22:17). The one who knows how the mitre is wrapped knows the meaning of [The mitre shall be removed…] this shall be no more the same: that which is low shall be exalted, and that which is high abased (Ezek. 21:31).167According to I.E. the meaning of the verse is: The mitre shall be removed…this shall no more be the same; the material making up the mitre shall no longer be wound from the bottom up or from the top down; i.e., the miztnefet shall no longer be wound about the head. It takes a special skill to wind a mitre around the head. Now Scripture states, And thou shalt set the mitre upon his head, and put the holy crown upon the mitre (Ex. 29:6). The tzitz (plate) (v. 36) is thus called a nezer (crown).168Not to be confused with the word keter (crown), as the keter covers the entire head. But upon himself shall his crown (nizro) shine (yatzitz) is similar (Ps. 132:18).169In that the root of the word tzitz is used in connection with nezer. Perhaps they all170The word tzitz in our chapter and the word yatzitz in Ps. 132:18. are used in the sense of tzitz, meaning something seen. The same is true with the word metzitz (peereth) in He peereth through the lattice (Cant. 2:9). Note that the five senses come together in the two cavities which are in that part of the brain which is behind the forehead. This is where the imaginative power is located. Furthermore, all thoughts begin there. It is for this reason that Scripture writes, regarding the plate, that Aaron shall bear the iniquity committed in the holy things (v. 38). It is possible that those who hallowed holy things unto the Lord did so while thinking improper thoughts.171According to I.E. the plate atones for improper thoughts.

AND THOU SHALT WEAVE THE TUNIC IN CHEQUER WORK. When Scripture first mentions Aaron’s tunic it says, a tunic of chequer work (v. 4). Only Aaron’s tunic was chequered. His sons’ tunics were not. The tunic was chequered to dignify Aaron. Scripture similar reads, And he put upon him the tunic (Lev. 8:7) when it describes Aaron’s investiture. It reads, the tunic,172Ha-ketonet, with the definite article. the reference being to the chequered tunic. However, concerning Aaron’s children we read, and clothed them with tunics (Lev. 8:13).173The definite article is omitted, as it does not refer to the chequered tunic. The latter is similar to And for Aaron’s sons thou shalt make tunics (v. 40).174Here too the definite article is omitted because the reference is to non-chequered tunics. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon translated ve-shibatzta (and thou shalt weave…in chequer work) as: you shall weave eye-like [designs].175Saadiah Gaon renders ve-shibatzta ha-ketonet as: you shall make the tunic eye-like (Weiser); that is, the tunic shall consist of eye-like designs. It is a coin-like design, that is, a square within a circle.176I.E.’s explanation of Saadiah Gaon’s interpretation.

AND THOU SHALT PUT THEM UPON AARON THY BROTHER. The word otam (them) takes in the chequered tunic, the mitre, and the girdle which are Aaron’s garments. It also takes in the unchequered tunics, the girdles, and the head-tires which are the garments of Aaron’s sons.177Our verse reads, And thou shalt put them upon Aaron thy brother, and upon his sons with him. I.E. explains that the verse is to be read as if written: And thou shalt put them upon Aaron thy brother, and thou shalt put them upon his sons with him. The first “them” refers to Aaron’s garments and the second “them” to his sons’ garments.

AND CONSECRATE THEM. By word of mouth.178You shall declare them to be holy (Weiser). It is similar to the priest shall make him unclean179The meaning of which is, the priest shall declare him to be unclean. Translated according to I.E. (Lev. 13:44).
LINEN BREECHES. The linen breeches were short so that the priest would not trip over them.
WHEN THEY GO IN. To offer incense or to kindle the lamps.180Or to perform any other service (Weiser).
AND THIS IS THE THING THAT THOU SHALT DO UNTO THEM. To Aaron and his sons.

[TAKE.] There is no difference1In meaning. between lekach (take)2The kal imperativel form of the root lamed, kof, chet used in our verse. and kach (take).3The usual kal imperativel form of the root lamed, kof chet. We find the same to be true of tzak (pour out)4The usual kal imperativel form of the root yod, tzadi, kof. and yetzak (pour)5A lesser used kal imperativel form of the root yod, tzadi, kof. in Pour out (tzak) for the people, that they may eat (II Kings 4:41) and in And also pour (yetzak) water into it (Ezek. 24:3).

[ONE YOUNG BULLOCK.] The fact that Scripture notes that the par (bull) was a ben bakar (of the herd)6The term ben indicates a young animal (Krinsky). indicates that the par (bull) was young. The same applies to the phrase bene yonah (turtle-doves)7The term bene indicates young birds (Krinsky). (Lev. 1:14), and the phrase se’_ir izzim (a goat) (Lev. 4:23).8A mature goat is called a se’ir. A young goat is a se’ir izzim (Krinsky).

[AND TWO RAMS.] An ayal (ram)9Our verse speaks of elim (rams). Hence I.E.’s comment. is older than a keves (lamb). The fact that the drink offering for an ayal (ram) consists of a third of a hin10Num. 28:14. and that of a keves (lamb) a quarter of a hin11Num. 28:14. proves this.12For the bigger the animal, the bigger the drink offering. See Num. 28:14.

AND UNLEAVENED…CAKES. They were thick, as wafers13Hebrew, rekike. Rekike is connected to the word rek (empty, poor, or thin) (Krinsky). See rakkot basar (lean-fleshed) (Gen. 41:19). Thus rekike matzot (wafers unleavened) means thin unleavened bread. unleavened proves.14The wafers stand in contrast to the bread and cakes. Thus if the wafers are thin, the bread and cakes must be thick.

[WITH OIL.] Scripture reads ba-shemen (with oil).15Rather than be-shemen. The reference is to the previously mentioned oil, i.e., the oil mentioned in Ex. 27:20. See note 17. The reference, in keeping with the rule,16Hebrew, ka-mishpat. The rule referred to by I.E. is either the rule stated in Ex. 27:20 (Krinsky) or the rules of Hebrew referred to in note 17. It is also possible that what I.E. means by shemen zayit ka-mishpat is olive oil prepared according to the rule, that is, beaten olive oil. See Ex. 27:20 (Sarim). is to olive oil.17The pattach beneath the bet indicates the definite article. Thus the meaning of ba-shemen is, with the oil, i.e., the earlier mentioned oil. [Of FINE WHEATEN FLOUR.] The word solet (fine flour) refers to flour made from wheat cleansed of all impurities. It is called samid in Arabic.18This type of flour, or bread made from it is still produced in Moslem countries. It is produced in the land of the Ishmaelites. There is no better bread than bread made from it.19Or there is no better bread than it. See note 18. Many connect the word solet to the word salita20From the root samekh, lamed, heh. (thou hast trodden)21This is the opinion of Jonah ibn Janach (Krinsky). in Thou hast trodden light all them that err from Thy statutes (Ps. 119:118);22Translated according to I.E. and to sillah (trodden) in The Lord hath trodden All my mighty men in the midst of me (Lam. 1:15).23Translated according to I.E. According to these commentaries the word solet means trodden grain, that is, grain that has been broken up into pieces (Krinsky). Kimchi accepted this definition of solet. They say that makkolet (food) in food to your household (I Kings 5:25)24I Kings 5:25 reads: food to his household. is similar.25The question arises: If solet is connected to salita and sillah, then where does the tav in solet come from? For both salita and sillah come from the root samekh, lamed, heh. These commentaries therefore point out that we find something similar with the word makkolet. Makkolet comes from the root kaf, lamed, heh (Meijler). However, a form tav is added to it in its normal form. The same is true of the tav in solet. See Weiser and Meijler. Others say that solet means ground.26Finely ground flour.

AND BRING THEM IN THE BASKET. You shall bring the bread, which is in the basket as the law requires,27Namely, And thou shalt put them into one basket. to the door of the tent of meeting.28In other words, and bring them means: and bring them to the door of the tent of meeting. The same applies to the bullock and the rams.29They too shall be brought to the door of the tent of meeting.

AND THOU SHALT TAKE THE GARMENTS. The breastplate (choshen) is called a garment30Our verse includes it among the priestly garments. However, it was not really a garment. Hence I.E.’s comment. because it covers that part of the body which lies opposite the heart.

AND THOU SHALT SET. It is also31See note 32. not beyond the realm of possibility that Moses placed the mitre on Aaron last.32After placing all the other garments upon Aaron, for this is what the plain meaning of our text implies. This should be contrasted with I.E. ‘s comments on Ex. 28:4. There he wrote that Moses placed the mitre on Aaron’s head after dressing him in his tunic. I.E. was not sure what the procedure was. Hence he uses the expression, “It is also not beyond the realm of possibility.” Scripture mentions the mitre before the girdle33Ex. 28:4. at the opening of the Torah portion34Even though the girdle was put on before the mitre, as the mitre was put on last. because the mitre is more important than the girdle.35That is, according to this interpretation. Scripture mentions the mitre before the girdle, even though the girdle was put on first, because the mitre is more important.

HIS HEAD. Only on Aaron’s head,36The anointing oil was poured only upon Aaron’s head. as he was the anointed priest. Now Aaron was anointed before the mitre was placed on his head,37Even though Scripture mentions the donning of the mitre before it mentions the anointment. Nahmanides takes issue with I.E. He writes, “He wound [the mitznefet] around and around the head, but left the middle of the head uncovered, and it was on that place that he poured the oil” (Ramban’s Commentary on the Torah, Chavel translation). for Moses poured the oil only upon the head.38Not upon the mitre. Hence the oil had to be poured upon Aaron’s head before the mitre was placed upon it. We similarly read, It is like the precious oil upon the head, Coming down upon the beard; Even Aaron’s beard (Ps. 133:2).39We thus see that the oil was poured only over Aaron’s head. It was not poured upon the mitre.
AND THOU SHALT BRING HIS SONS. To the door of the tent of meeting.

AND THOU SHALT GIRD THEM WITH GIRDLES. Girdles takes in Aaron’s girdle and the girdle of his sons.40The term refers both to Aaron’s girdle and to that of his sons because they all wore the same type of girdle (Krinsky). Sarim is of the opinion that Aaron’s girdle differed from the girdle of his sons. According to Sarim, I.E. is explaining that the term girdles refers both to Aaron’s girdle and to the girdle of his sons even though their girdles differed. Similarly the breeches.41Moses similarly placed breeches upon Aaron and his sons even though Scripture omits mentioning this. Nahmanides held that Moses did not put breeches on Aaron and his sons. He explains that they put on their breeches in private. Hence Scripture omits the donning of the breeches. After stating them, Scripture goes on to explain that the reference is to Aaron and his sons. It is similar to And she opened it, and saw it, even the child (Ex. 2:6).42See I.E. on Ex. 2:6 and the notes thereto.
[AND BIND.] The word ve-chavashta (and bind) is similar to the word chovesh (healer) in I will not be a healer (Is. 3:7).43Literally, a binder, that is, a binder of wounds.

AND THOU SHALT CONSECRATE. The one who translated the Torah into Aramaic44Onkelos. is of the opinion that u-milleta yad (and thou shalt consecrate)45Literally, and you shall fill the hand. is similar to u-milu yadav (so shall they consecrate it)46Literally, and they shall fill its (the altar’s) hands (Targum). See Targum Jonathan on this verse. (Ezek. 43:26).47Onkelos similarly renders u-milleta yad aharon ve-yad banav as u-tekarev kurbana de-aharon ve-kurbana di-venohi (and you shall offer the sacrifice of Aaron and the sacrifice of his children). However, what shall we do with milu yedkhem ha-yom48Literally, fill your hands today. (consecrate yourselves today to the Lord) (Ex. 32:29)?49Ex. 32:29 speaks of killing those who worshipped the golden calf. Thus the term “fill your hand” cannot mean offer a sacrifice. Saadiah Gaon explains the word yad to mean obligation.50According to Saadiah u-milleta yad aharon ve-yad banav means: see to it that Aaron and his sons fulfill their obligation. Thus according to the Gaon, to fill the hand means to do one’s duty. Others say that the term melu’im (consecration)51Literally, filled. is used because it indicates that they are complete, full, and trained.52Thus the phrase to fill the hand means train the hand. See I.E.’s short commentary, “During the days of melu’im the priest learned…to train his hands in the service.” However, what will they do with u-mile’u yadav (so shall they consecrate it53That is, the altar.) (Ezek. 43:26)?54According to their interpretation we should render it, so shall they train the altar. This makes no sense.

AND THOU SHALT BRING THE BULLOCK. This has already been mentioned.55In verse 3. The question thus arises, “Why repeat it?” Its meaning is as follows. When you shall bring the bullock,56In other words, ve-hikravta (and thou shalt bring) is to be rendered, when thou shalt bring. Hence Scripture is not being redundant. See note 57. Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands upon it.57This is not mentioned in verse 3. Some say that the meaning of and Aaron shall lay58The text literally reads: and Aaron shall lay and his sons their hands on the head of the bullock. Ve-samakh (shall lay) is in the singular. Hence the interpretation quoted by I.E. is: Aaron alone shall first lay his hands upon the head of the bullock. His sons shall then do the same. Now with regard to the ram, Scripture later states, and Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands upon the head of the ram (v. 15). Scripture thus describes exactly what happened. They should lay their hands together, not one after the other.59For the text reads, ve-samekhu (shall lay). Ve-samekhu is in the plural. The commentaries on I.E. differ over how to interpret this comment. Some take it to mean that I.E. indicates there was no difference in procedure between the laying of the hands upon the bullock and the laying of the hands upon the rams; in both cases Aaron and his sons put their hands upon the sacrificial animals in unison (Krinsky). Meijler is of the opinion that I.E. believes that in contrast to the laying of the hands upon the rams, Aaron first laid his hands upon the bullock and then his sons did the same. The difference of opinion revolves around how we interpret “Scripture thus describes exactly what happened.” Krinsky takes it to refer to both instances, while Meijler takes it to refer only to the second instance. For further elucidation, see Filwarg.
AND THOU SHALT KILL THE BULLOCK. Moses slaughtered the bullock.

[BEFORE THE LORD.] Scripture reads, before the Lord,60Before the Lord seems to imply before the ark. However, the bullock was sacrificed before the altar which stood in the temple courtyard. because the ark was in the center of the western side of the tabernacle. The incense altar was directly aligned with it. So was the altar of the burnt offerings.61Which stood in the courtyard.

HE SHALL POUR OUT.62Yishpokh. In our text of the Pentateuch the reading is: Thou shalt pour out (tishpokh). Meijler and Krinsky believe that I.E.’s version of the Pentateuch reads yishpokh (he shall pour out). However, Weiser believes that the reading of yishpokh is due to a copyist’s error. According to Weiser, I.E. also reads tishpokh (thou shalt pour out), and I.E. commented thereupon: Yishpokh ha-kohen ha-shofekh (The priest who pours shall pour out). In other words, I.E. explained, that Thou shalt pour is not to be taken literally, for Moses was not commanded to personally pour out the blood. He was told to appoint a priest to carry out this task. Some copyist then dropped the word tishpokh from the heading and made yishpokh into a heading. Hence our reading. The priest who pours shall pour out.63All the remaining blood at the base of the altar. See note 63.
AND THOU SHALT TAKE. Bullock and goats do not have a fat tail (alyah).64But rams do. See verse 22. Hence Scripture does not mention the fat tail here as it does when discussing the rams.

[KIDNEYS.] Some say that kelayot (kidneys) are so called because the word kelayot is related to the word kaletah (pineth) in My soul yearneth, yea even pineth for the courts of the Lord (Ps. 84:3). For the power of sexual desire is located in the kidneys.
BUT THE FLESH OF THE BULLOCK. Flesh takes in the head and the pieces of the bullock.

AND ITS DUNG.65So Vat. Ebr. 38. Also see Meijler. Logically speaking,66The dung was not burned. it67The place in the animal where the dung was collected shall be cleansed (Krinsky). For another interpretation, see note 69. was to be washed and then it68Krinsky explains that the meaning of and its dung shalt thou burn is: and the place where the dung collected thou shalt burn. was to be burned.69Filwarg emends u-firsho (and its dung) to u-lefi. He interprets But the flesh of the bullock as follows: Flesh takes in the head and the pieces of the bullock. Now logically speaking, it was to be washed and then it was to be burned; i.e., the bullock was to be washed in the same manner that the ram (v. 17) was. See Weiser, Sarim, and Filwarg.. AND HE SHALL MAKE THEM SMOKE (ve-hiktir).70The word ve-hiktir (and he shall make them smoke) does not appear in our verse. Weiser suggests that it has been transposed from verse 13. However, verse 13 reads ve-hiktarta (and make them smoke). Weiser explains that the original comment on verse 13 reads as follows: Ve-hiktarta (and [thou shalt] make them smoke). Commenting on this, I.E. writes: Ve-hiktir (and he shall make them smoke). That is, Moses himself was not commanded to personally place the organs on the fire; another priest would do as well. For some reason, a copyist left out the heading ve-hiktarta and the word ve-hiktir was transposed to verse 14. Meijler, on the other hand, claims that the word ve-hiktir should not be read as a heading but rather as the continuation of the previous sentence. The latter should read: Logically speaking, it was washed and then it was burned. After this, the priest smoked the enumerated organs. The reference is to the enumerated organs.71The organs listed in verse 13.

[SIN-OFFERING.] A sin offering is called a chatat 72A sin. because it is brought to atone for a sin. The same applies to the asham (guilt-offering).73Literally, guilt. The sacrifice is referred to as “guilt” because it is brought to atone for one’s guilt. Hence the meaning of ve-chitte’u et ha-mizbe’ach (they shall purify the altar)74Literally, and they shall sin the altar. is: they shall remove the sin from the altar.

THOU SHALT ALSO TAKE THE ONE RAM. Any one of the two rams which you decide to choose.75In other words, the word ha-echad (the one) is short for ha-echad me-hashenayim (one of the two). I.E. comments thus because the one ram seems to imply that Scripture has a specific ram in mind.

AND THOU SHALT SLAY THE RAM, AND THOU SHALT TAKE ITS BLOOD AND DASH IT ROUND ABOUT AGAINST THE ALTAR. Not on the corners of the altar.76As was done with the blood of the bullock. See verse 12. Look, he [Moses] shall dash all the blood round about against the altar and not upon the base of the altar.77As was done with the blood of the bullock. See verse 12.

AND THE RAM. Scripture does not mention that Moses was commanded to cut the bullock into pieces. It was therefore entirely burned. Hence Scripture does not mention the bullock’s legs.78As it does with regard to the ram.
AND WASH.79Literally, and thou shalt wash. By command.80Moses was to command someone to wash the ram. He did not personally have to do so, as implied by the literal meaning of the verse.

AND THOU SHALT MAKE THE WHOLE RAM SMOKE. Hence the fat tail and the fat81Which are mentioned with regard to the second ram. See verse 22. are not mentioned.82For they are included in the term the whole ram.
AND THOU SHALT TAKE. This second ram served as the ram of consecration.83See verse 31. Also see Lev. 8:22.

THEN THOU SHALT KILL…TIP. The word tenukh (tip) has no counterpart.84Hebrew, en lo re’a. This usually indicates that the word appears nowhere else in Scripture. See I.E. on Num. 11:7. However, the word tenukh appears six times in the Book of Leviticus. Hence Krinsky interprets en lo chaver as meaning: it has no counterpart except with regard to the ear. Saadiah Gaon says that it refers to the soft tissue which is connected to the circle of the ear.85The earlobe.

THE GREAT TOE. The plural of bohen (great toe) is behonot (Jud. 1:6). This is grammatically inconsistent.86According to the rules of Hebrew grammar the plural of bohen is behanot, not behonot. Compare, goren, geranot. The singular of bahon is behonot (Weiser). This noun is thus vocalized according to two paradigms.87The singular and plural follow different paradigms. There are many such nouns.

[AND DASH THE BLOOD.] The blood of the second ram shall be dashed88Against the altar round about. like the blood of the first ram.89See verse 16. The reference is only to the remaining blood.90The blood that remains after some blood has first been placed on the tip of the right ear, the right thumb, and the great toe of Aaron and his sons.

AND THOU SHALT TAKE OF THE BLOOD THAT IS UPON THE ALTAR…AND SPRINKLE IT UPON AARON, AND UPON HIS GARMENTS. Beneath his garments91That is, upon Aaron’s body. The blood and the anointing oil were first sprinkled upon Aaron’s body and then, when Aaron dressed, upon his garments (Krinsky). and upon his garments.
AND THOU SHALT TAKE OF THE RAM THE FAT. The reference is to the fat that is upon the innards, as stated in the Torah portion Va-Yikra.92Lev. 3:3.

THE RIGHT THIGH. The thigh that is on the right side93The word shok (thigh) is feminine. Hence our verse should have read, shok ha-yeminit, rather than shok ha-yamin (the right side). Hence I.E. points out that shok ha-yamin is short for shok tzad ha-yamin (the thigh that is on the right side). Tzad is masculine. Hence the use of the masculine form yamin. and the breast were taken from the ram of consecration. From that day on, the thigh and the breast of peace offerings were to be given to Aaron and his sons.94See Lev. 7:34; 10:14,15. However, Moses alone ate the breast of the ram of consecration because he was a high priest.95Moses served as high priest during the days of consecration.
AND ONE LOAF OF BREAD. The reference is to the unleavened bread (v. 2).

AND SHALT WAVE THEM. While they96The organs and bread listed in verse 22 and 23. are in the hands of Aaron and his sons.97Moses placed his hand beneath the hands of Aaron and his sons and waved their hands along with their contents (Krinsky).
AND THOU SHALT TAKE THEM FROM THEIR HANDS. Our verse states, from their hands. Elsewhere Scripture states, from off their hands (Lev. 8:28). They mean the same thing.

A SWEET SAVOUR. The chet is doubled in nicho’ach (sweet savour).98The root of nicho’ach is nun, vav, chet. There are two chets in nicho’ach. Hence I.E.’s comment. [A SWEET SAVOUR BEFORE THE LORD.] The one who understands the secret of man’s soul99Namely, that “A human being cannot speak of things above or below him without employing human terminology.” See I.E. on Gen. 1:26. will understand this.100Why the Torah must employ anthropomorphic language (Weiser).

AN OFFERING. The word issheh (offering) is an adjective. It is related to the word esh (fire). Scripture elsewhere states, from the fire (Num. 18:9).101In other words, Scripture uses the word esh in place of the word issheh. We thus see that they are related.
AND THOU SHALT TAKE. From Aaron’s ram. Aaron’s sons are not mentioned,102Even though the ram of sanctification was also theirs (Krinsky). as Aaron was the principal.
[PORTION.] The word manah means a portion.

AND THOU SHALT SANCTIFY. From this day and henceforth.103So too Rashi, “Sanctify them for all time.” Waving and heaving are not identical.104Our verse speaks of that which is waved (hunaf) and that which is heaved (huram). Hence I.E.’s comment. For what is heaved is lifted up. It is not waved.105Heaving, literally lifting, refers to an up and down motion. Waving is a to and fro motion. See Rashi on verse 24. The meaning of even their heave-offering (v. 28) is: the heave offerings which they will separate from peace offerings, shall be heaved in honor of God.106Verse 28 reads, for it is a heave-offering; and it shall be a heave-offering from the children of Israel of their sacrifices of peace-offerings, even their heave-offering unto the Lord. The phrase even their heave-offering unto the Lord appears to be redundant. Hence I.E.’s comment that the verse is to be understood as follows: For it is a heave offering; and it shall be a heave offering from the children of Israel of their sacrifices of peace offerings. Now these heave offerings which they will separate from their peace offerings shall be heaved in honor of God. See Krinsky and Meijler.

AND THE HOLY GARMENTS OF AARON SHALL BE FOR HIS SONS AFTER HIM. Shall be for his son who is anointed in his place.107In other words, for his sons means for those of his sons who are anointed in his place.
[AFTER HIM.] After his death.

SEVEN DAYS. The word yilbasham (put them on) is vocalized with a long rather than a short kamatz.108A tzerah. According to the rules of grammar the word should read yilbashem. Compare, yishlakhem. The word amilam (I will cut them off) in Verily, in the name of the Lord I will cut them off (Ps. 118:10) is similar.109It too is vocalized with a kamatz in place of a tzere, as the word should have read amilem.

AND SEETHE. By command.110Moses did not have to personally seethe the flesh of the ram of consecration. It is similar to and thou shalt smite the rock (Ex. 17:6),111Nahmanides reads, and thy rod, wherewith thou smotest the river (Ex. 17:5). The commentaries believe this to be the correct reading because I.E. explicitly states that the latter was by Moses’ command. See I.E. on Ex. 17:5. and to So Solomon built the house (I Kings 6:14).112Solomon commanded the temple to be built. He obviously did not personally build it.

AND AARON AND HIS SONS SHALL EAT. The bread remaining in the basket.113“After the rite described in verse 23 had been carried out” (Cohen). The bread that is in the basket might be taken to mean all the bread in the basket. Hence I.E.’s comment.

AND THEY SHALL EAT THOSE THINGS. The verse is abridged.114The subject is missing. According to I.E.’s short commentary on Exodus our verse literally reads: And they shall eat those things who atoned by them. The latter is short for: And the men who atoned by them shall eat those things.

[THEM.] The word otam (them) also refers to something else.115The word otam (them) in le-kadesh otam (to sanctify them) also applies to ve-zar lo yokhkal (but a stranger shall not eat). The latter is to be read as if written ve-zar lo yokhkal otam (but a stranger shall not eat them).
BUT A STRANGER. Who is not of Aaron’s seed.
AND IF AUGHT. The ram of consecration is so called because they are consecrated by it.116Literally, their hands become full by it. For the meaning of this expression, see I.E. on verse 9.

THEE. The word otakhah has an etnach117A note indicating a pause. beneath it.118Hence the tav is vocalized with a kamatz rather than with a sheva, i.e., otakhah rather than otekha. Otakhah is a combination of otakh (thee) (Gen. 39:9), which is vocalized with a long kamatz beneath the tav, and otekha (thee)119Which is vocalized with a kamatz beneath the kaf. in for thee have I seen (Gen. 7:1).
AND EVERY DAY SHALT THOU OFFER THE BULLOCK. Every day of the seven days of consecration.

[BESIDE THE OTHER OFFERINGS OF ATONEMENT.] Its meaning is, in addition to the two rams.120Which were offered for atonement. See Nahmanides. Scripture further states, As hath been done this day, so the Lord hath commanded to do,121For seven days. See I.E. on Lev. 8:34. to make atonement for you (Lev. 8:34).

MOST HOLY. The meaning of kodesh kodashim (most holy) is holy like any other holy object.122The repetition of the word kodesh does not indicate superholiness as most commentators assume. See I.E. on Gen. 9:25.

WHATSOEVER TOUCHES THE ALTAR SHALL BE HOLY. This is similar to Whatsoever shall touch the flesh thereof shall be holy (Lev. 6:20).123The meaning of which according to I.E. is: Whatsoever shall touch the flesh of the sin offering shall be holy to God; that is, only a priest may eat of it (I.E. on Lev. 6:20). Similarly, Scripture here teaches that any flesh that touches the altar shall be holy to God and only a priest may eat of it. Some say that the verse speaks only of the bread. Scripture is telling us that if the bread is not holy, that is, if the bread is unclean, then it shall not touch the altar.124In other words, our verse may be paraphrased as: the bread that touches the altar must be in a state of purity. For another interpretation, see Sarim.

NOW THIS IS. Its meaning is: now this is the sacrifice.125So Meijler. In other words, ve-zeh (now this is) is short for ve-zeh ha-korban (now this is the sacrifice). Similarly, the meaning of This they shall give (Ex. 30:13) is: this amount they shall give.126This is short for this amount. Similarly And this is that thou shalt make it 127Translated literally. (Gen. 6:15).128The meaning of which is: and this is the size that thou shalt make it. Moses shall do this129Offer two lambs daily on the altar. during the seven days of consecration. Afterwards130After the seven days of consecration. See Num. 28:4. Aaron and his sons shall do likewise.

THE ONE LAMB. The heh prefixed to the word keves (lamb) also serves as a prefix to the word echad (one).131Ha-keves echad is ungrammatical. Hence I.E.’s comment. The phrase is to be read as if written, et ha-keves ha-echad (the one lamb).132This is precisely the reading of our texts. However, the parallel reading in Num. 28:4 is ha-keves echad. There too I.E. comments that the heh prefixed to the word keves also serves as a prefix to the word echad and that the phrase is to be read as if written ha-keves ha-echad. I.E. might have been commenting from memory and confused the two sections. However, Shadal, Meijler, and Filwarg believe that I.E. had a version of the Pentateuch in which Ex. 29:39 read: et ha-keves echad. Rabbi Moses Ha-Kohen says that the meaning of et ha-keves echad is, the lamb, one lamb.133In other words, the word keves is to be read as if written twice, that is, et ha-keves, keves echad. This comment is also repeated in Num. 28:4.
A TENTH PART. A tenth part of an ephah.
[A HIN.] Also note that hin is an Egyptian measure.134I.E. similarly believed that the name Moses and the word chartumim are Egyptian words. See I.E. on Ex. 2:10 and 7:11.

AND. The word u-kheniskah (and according to the drink offering thereof)135U-kheniskah is in the feminine. Hence it cannot refer to keves, which is masculine. refers to boker (morning).136That is, to ke-minchat ha-boker (according to the meal-offering of the morning). Minchah is feminine. So Weiser. Filwarg believes that I.E. is of the opinion that boker here is feminine. Hence u-kheniskah refers to it rather than to keves.

IT SHALL BE A CONTINUAL BURNT-OFFERING THROUGHOUT YOUR GENERATIONS. They shall bring these offerings when they enter the land of Canaan. For the Israelites offered burnt offerings only for fifty days in the desert of Sinai. This is what Scripture means by It is a continual burnt-offering, which was offered in mount Sinai (Num. 28:6). The tabernacle was placed at the edge of the camp at the bottom of the mount,137When it was first erected on the first day of Nisan (Ex. 40:17). Israel journeyed from Sinai on the 20th day of the second month (Num. 10:11,12). The tabernacle was thus at Sinai for 50 days. It was during these 50 days that Israel offered burnt offerings. as the tribes were intermingled.138The Israelites formed an amorphous mass. The only open space available for the tabernacle was at the edge of the camp. On the first day of the second month139Of the second year following the Exodus. they began to know the number of each tribe and to make standards (Num. 1 and 2).140That is, it was only on the first day of the second month of the second year that the Israelites were organized into separate groups with their own place around standards, with the tabernacle in the center of the camp. After they traveled a distance of a three-day journey from Mount Sinai, the ark journeyed141It is unlikely that Israel would offer sacrifices while the ark journeyed (Filwarg). in the midst of the camps (Num. 10:33).142Of the 12 tribes of Israel. It is I.E.’s opinion that for the first three days of their journey from Sinai, the ark traveled before the camp (Num. 10:33). After that, it journeyed in their midst. See I.E. on Num. 10:31. Be that as it may, I.E.’s point is that after 50 days at Sinai, the ark was no longer in the tabernacle and thus no sacrifices were offered. See Filwarg. Logically speaking, the Israelites offered burnt offerings and sacrifices only at Sinai and on Yom Kippur in the second year. This is what Scripture states regarding Aaron’s service.143That is, regarding the service which Aaron was to perform on Yom Kippur. The Torah there writes, And he [Aaron] did as the Lord commanded Moses (Lev. 16:34).144That is, Aaron performed the Yom Kippur service. Scripture similarly states, Did ye bring unto Me sacrifices and offerings in the wilderness forty years, O house of Israel? (Amos 5:25). Israel spent about thirty-eight years in a wasteland, in a howling wilderness (Deut. 32:10). Where did they get half a hin of olive oil and a half hin of wine daily?145Necessary for the daily sacrifice. See verses 40 and 41. How could they carry almost fourteen thousand hin around with them?146The total amount of olive oil necessary for the daily burnt offering during their sojourn in the desert of Sinai. Where did they get two lambs daily in the first year? Where did they get the animals for the additional sacrifices on the Sabbath and the festivals? The statement we and our cattle (Num. 20:4)147Which shows that the Israelites had cattle. does not refute our contention, for Israel was then at Kadesh,148Num. 20:1. and they bought cattle from the settled population. Furthermore, they looted the Midianites and the lands of Sihon and Og in that year. They thus had an abundance of cattle.149At that time, but not before.
[I WILL MEET.]150Hebrew, ivva’ed. Scripture clearly explains the reason that the tabernacle is called the ohel mo’ed (the tent of meeting).151Ivva’ed and mo’ed come from the same root.

WITH YOU. Israel.152Lakhem (with you) is a plural. Hence I.E.’s comment. We find this to be the case when the congregation was called together.153God met with the congregation when Moses called them together by sounding trumpets. See Num. 10:3, And when they shall blow with them, all the congregation shall gather themselves unto thee at the door of the tent of meeting. So Meijler and Filwarg. According to Weiser its meaning is: Scripture uses the word ve-no’adu (shall gather themselves), which comes from the same root as mo’ed when it describes the gathering of the congregation. We thus see that the term mo’ed means gathering or meeting.

TO SPEAK THERE UNTO THEE. To speak there alone to you.154Elekha (unto thee) is in the singular. Hence I.E.’s comment. However, Yefet says that the meaning of I will meet with you is: with Moses and occasionally with Aaron.155Hence the use of the plural lakhem (with you). He maintains that to speak there unto thee156Hence elekha (unto thee) is in the singular. hints that God will continually speak there with Moses. He offers, And there I will meet with the children of Israel (v. 43) as proof.157If lakhem refers to Israel, why would Scripture repeat itself in verse 43?

AND [THE TENT] SHALL BE SANCTIFIED BY MY GLORY. I believe that the tent of meeting was the place of meeting because it took in everything, namely, the tabernacle and all its utensils, the ark, and the three objects.158The table of showbread, the menorah, and the incense altar. The tent will be sanctified by My glory, which will rest on the cherubim.159According to I.E., verse 43 should be paraphrased as follows: I will meet with the children of Israel in the tent of meeeting because the tent of meeting takes in the tabernacle and all of its utensils, the ark, the table of showbread, the menorah, and the incense altar. The tent of meeting shall be sanctified by My glory, which will rest on the cherubim. It should be noted that I.E.’s comment is difficult to unravel, and the various commentaries offer differing interpretations and emendations. However, the above seems to be the correct interpretation.

AND I WILL SANCTIFY THE TENT OF MEETING. It is because of the glory that the tent is holy, for it was sanctified by the glory.160Mentioned in verse 33. The altar that stood161In the temple courtyard. before the opening of the tent of meeting was similarly sanctified.162By God’s glory.
AARON ALSO AND HIS SONS WILL I SANCTIFY. I will sanctify Aaron and his sons, who minister in the tent of meeting and upon the altar.

AND I WILL DWELL. Scripture describes how God’s glory will dwell among the children of Israel when the standards will be set up.163In other words, our verse adverts to the time when the camp of Israel will be set up in the form of a square with the tent of meeting in its center. Hence our verse speaks of God dwelling among the children of Israel. See Num. 2-4. Four standards were set up on the four sides.164Num. 2-4. Additionally, there was a separation between the camp of the Levites and the camp of the Israelites165I.E. assumed this, as Scripture does not explicitly so state. See I.E. on Deut. 23:10. According to Meijler, I.E. considers the space between the camp of the Levites and that of the Israelites as a barrier. because they too camped on all four sides,166The tribe of Levi camped around the four sides of the tent of meeting. There was another barrier beyond this barrier where the tent of meeting was placed amidst the children of Israel. Now a person who experienced a seminal emission did not have to leave the camp of Israel.167For there was a separation between the camp of Israel and the tent of meeting. See Deut. 23:11. Neither was there a place set aside beyond the border of the camp for a person to sit down [and relieve himself].168See Deut. 13 and 14. The commandment for a person who experienced a seminal emission to leave the camp169Deut. 23:11. applied only to the camp of Israel when it went to war against the enemy.170Deut. 23:10. The commandment When thou goest forth in camp against thine enemies (Deut. 23:10) similarly does not speak of the entire camp of Israel, men, women, and children. It is only males, and then only a small number of them, who sally out to wage war. Now when the soldiers of Israel carried the ark with them as Phineas did,171See Num. 31:6 along with I.E.’s comment. they were unable to set up a barrier between themselves and the place of the ark.172Hence all who experienced emissions and all those who had to relieve themselves had to leave the camp.

AND THEY SHALL KNOW. Its meaning is, then they shall know that the only reason that I took them out of Egypt was so that they would make a sanctuary for Me that I may dwell among them. This is what Scripture means by ye shall serve God upon this mountain (Ex. 3:12).173The verse refers to the tabernacle which Israel would build at the foot of Mount Sinai.

AND THOU SHALT MAKE AN ALTAR TO BURN INCENSE UPON. The word miktar (to burn) is an infinitive.1In the form of a noun. See Weiser. Also see I.E.’s short commentary. It is like the word u-mishlo’ach (and of sending)2Which is an infinitive in the form of a noun. in and of sending portions one to another (Esth. 9:19).

A CUBIT. The altar was a half a cubit higher than the table.3Of showbread. The table was a cubit and a half high. Perhaps it was similarly half a cubit higher than the menorah.4In other words, the menorah, like the table, was a cubit and a half high. The Torah does not give the height of the menorah. I.E. believes that it is possible that the menorah was the height of the table for aesthetic purposes. The altar5Which stood in the sanctuary. was aligned with the cherubim6Which stood in the Holy of Holies. which spread their wings upward.

AND THOU SHALT OVERLAY IT WITH PURE GOLD. A top is mentioned with regard to the altar of incense. Scripture does not mention a top with regard to the brass altar.7The altar of burnt offerings, which stood in the courtyard. This altar did not have a top. It was hollow and filled in with earth (Rashi). The altar8Of incense. was called the golden altar9See Ex. 3:38; Num. 4:11. because it was overlaid with gold. The same applies to The pure table (Lev. 24:6).10It was made of acacia wood but is referred to as the pure (gold) table because it was overlaid with gold. See Ex. 25:23,24. It is like the pure candlestick (Lev. 24:4).11The meaning of which is, the candlestick made of pure gold. See I.E. on Ex. 25:31. Similarly the pure table means the table made of pure gold.
UPON THE TWO SIDES OF IT. Scripture states this12Upon the two sides of it following upon the two sides thereof. in order to be especially clear.

[WHEREWITH.] THE heh at the end of the word ba-hemmah (wherewith) is superfluous,13Ba-hemmah is a variant of ba-hem. as I have already noted,14See I.E. on Ex. 1:1 and the notes thereto. since hemmah is penultimately accented.15If the heh were an integral part of the word the word would be ultimately accented. See I.E. on Ex. 1:1 and the notes thereto.
AND THOU SHALT MAKE THE STAVES OF ACACIAWOOD. And overlay them with gold like the staves of the ark.16Ex. 25:13.
AND THOU SHALT PUT IT BEFORE THE VEIL. On the outside.17On the outside of the veil, i.e., in the sanctuary rather than in the Holy of Holies.
BEFORE THE ARK-COVER. The altar should be aligned with the ark cover.

AND AARON SHALL BURN THEREON INCENSE OF SWEET SPICES. Along with other spices (besamim).18Our verse reads, “And Aaron shall burn upon them ketoret sammim (incense of sweet spices).” I.E. explains that the incense consisted of sammim (sweet spices) plus besamim (spices). I.E.’s comment is based on Ex. 25:6, which reads, spices (besammim) for the anointing oil, and for the sweet incense (ketoret sammim). See I.E. on the latter. It is possible that the sammim (sweet spices) were the most important ingredient.19Hence the word besamim is not mentioned in its name and the incense is called ketoret sammim. It is also possible that Scripture mentions sammim20With regard to the incense of sweet spices (ketoret sammim). (spices) in order to distinguish between the compounds,21The anointing oil and the incense of sweet spices. as one of the compounds22The anointing oil. consisted only of besamim (spices). It did not contain sammim (sweet spices).23While the incense of sweet spices (ketoret sammim) consisted of sweet spices plus spices. Hence only the former is mentioned in its name.
[WHEN HE DRESSETH.] When he fixes the wick and the oil.

LIGHTETH THE LAMPS. Scripture employs be-he’alot24From the root ayin, lamed, heh, which means to go up. for lighting because the flame of the wick goes up. Be-he’alot is clearly a transitive verb.25Meaning to cause a flame to go up.

A PERPETUAL INCENSE. When they offer burnt offerings.26The law concerning the bringing of incense is contingent on the bringing of offerings. The law is suspended when offerings are not brought. Hence incense was offered only at Sinai, where Israel offered sacrifices. See I.E. on Ex. 29:42 (Krinsky). Scripture therefore says, throughout your generations.27The meaning of which is, following your entrance into Canaan. See I.E. on Ex. 29:42.

YE SHALL OFFER NO STRANGE INCENSE. An incense which is not its exact duplicate.28An incense which is not made exactly in accordance with the prescription that Scripture lays down for the incense. See verse 34.
AND AARON SHALL MAKE ATONEMENT UPON THE HORNS OF IT ONCE IN THE YEAR. On the tenth day of the seventh month.29The Day of Atonement.

[OF ATONEMENT.] The reference is to the blood of the bullock30Brought by the high priest on the Day of Atonement. See Lev. 16:3,6,18. and the blood of the he-goat.31Brought by the people on the Day of Atonement. See Lev. 16:9,18. The aforementioned is a yearly obligation. There is no reason for Scripture to mention the blood of the bullock brought by the anointed high priest when he sins and the blood of the bullock brought by the congregation when they sin.32The blood of these two offerings was also placed on the corners of the altar of incense. See Lev. 4:1-21. For they are not placed on the horns of the altar at fixed times.33As is the blood of the above-mentioned Day of Atonement offerings. They are placed there only on rare occasions.34When the high priest or congregation sins.
May the name of the exalted God be eternally blessed. He did every good for Israel.
To His messenger35Moses. He revealed every secret In the Torah portion called Ki Tissa.

[WHEN THOU TAKEST THE SUM.] Scripture36Now. begins to explain the law of the atonement money which each and every one is obligated to give. The atonement money was not a free will offering.37Everything described up to now was made from donations. See Ex. 25:2. Scripture makes mention of the atonement money here because it notes above38Verse 10. that atonement shall be made [upon the horns of the altar of incense] once a year. The atonement money was, as I will explain, similarly to be given once a year. The description of the laver and its base follow next39Verses 17-21. because they are not to be made from free will gifts of the congregation but only from the mirrors of the women who performed tasks.40Ex. 38:8. This contrasts with the atonement money which every male over 20 was obligated to give. Scripture also mentions the anointing oil41Verses 22 and 33. and the sweet incense,42Verses 34-38. for the princes alone brought them.43In contrast to the atonement money which every male over 20 gave and the mirrors which only the serving women donated. Now since Scripture mentions the anointing oil it mentions the vessels which were anointed.44With this oil. Chapter 31:7-11. Scripture also mentions the great craftsman, the perfumer,45The reference seems to be to Bezalel. However, it might refer to Moses. See Krinsky. and the one whose counsel guided those who constructed the entire tabernacle, namely, Bezalel and Oholiab [who was with him].46Ex. 31:1-6. Scripture mentions the Sabbath47Ex. 31:12-17. in order to warn the Israelites at the beginning48Before they started to work on the tabernacle. not to do God’s work49The construction of the tabernacle. on the Sabbath. Scripture next50Ex. 32:11-14. records the prayer offered by Moses before he came down from the mountain. However, it first had to mention the making of the golden calf51Ex. 32:1-10. so that we would know why Moses prayed. Scripture then tells of Moses’ descent from the mountain,52Ex. 32:14. the burning of the calf,53Ex. 32:20. and Moses’ return to the mountain to pray for Israel a second time.54Ex. 32:31,32. Scripture mentions that Moses’ anger caused him to move his tent outside the camp of Israel.55Ex. 33:7. The first part of the clause is an assumption. See next note. However, some say that Scripture records what happened.56That Moses removed his tent from Israel. In other words, Scripture did not intend to imply that Moses was angry at Israel and therefore removed his tent from their midst. It merely records what happened. Scripture then mentions Moses’ great glory, namely, that Moses saw God’s glory.57Ex. 33:23. What I.E. must mean by “that Moses saw God’s glory” is that God promised Moses that he would show him His glory. Moses actually saw God’s glory after he hewed out the second pair of tablets. See Chapter 34. It tells us that God then commanded Moses to descend and hew out tablets.58A second set of tablets. See Ex. 34:1. It informs us that God inscribed the tablets a second time.59Ex. 34:1,28. Scripture mentions60Ex. 34:11-26. the conditions upon which God made a treaty with Israel.61Ex. 34:27. These conditions are recorded in the Torah portion Ve-Ellaeh Ha-Mishpatim.62These conditions are the same ones that are first mentioned in Ex. 23:12-33. See I.E. on Ex. 24:11 and the notes thereto. Scripture then mentions that the skin of Moses’ face shone when Moses came down from the mountain with the tablets of the covenant in his hand.63Ex. 34:29. Rabbi Saadiah Gaon says that the atonement money was an annual obligation upon Israel. It was obligatory whether their king counted them or not.64In other words, it was obligatory whether or not the people were counted. Saadiah Gaon offers the census taken by Moses in the desert as proof.65II Chron. 24:6 refers to the money collected to repair the temple as the tax of Moses. According to Saadiah the reference is to the annual tax instituted by Moses in the desert. Hence the paraphrase “the tax of Moses in the desert.” Saadiah says that the money collected was used for the congregational sacrifices, the construction of the laver, the making of the anointing oil, and the sweet incense. Part of it was also given to the Sanhedrin.66In later times. Bezalel and Oholiab allude to this.67Ex. 31:1-11 tells us that Bezalel and Oholiab were given the charge of constructing the tabernacle. Scripture tells of this here because part of the atonement money was given to them. Bezalel and Oholiab were the equivalent of the Sanhedrin because they were in charge of constructing the tabernacle. [WHEN THOU TAKEST THE SUM.]68Ki Tissa literally means when you lift up. It is customary for the accountants who are intimate with the details of an account to itemize upon pages. However they write the sum of all the items69Of any particular page. at the head of the page.70Hence Scripture speaks of raising up the sum, for the sum is raised to the top of the page. See I.E. on Gen. 41:13 and the notes thereto. Some say that the plague which occurred in the days of David71II Sam. 24. struck because Israel did not offer a ransom for their soul. If this is true it refutes the opinion of Saadiah Gaon.72According to Saadiah there was an annual obligation to give half a shekel as a ransom for one’s soul. Now if this is an annual obligation it is highly unlikely that David forgot to collect it when he counted the people (Weiser).

[WHEN THOU NUMBEREST THEM.] The meaning of that there be no plague among them, when thou numberest them is: if they do not give atonement money at the very moment of the numbering, a plague will strike. However, Yefet says it means that if they are numbered and do not give their ransom, they will fall before their enemies when they go to war.73In other words, that there be no plague among them, when thou numberest them refers to defeat by their enemies.

THIS. This amount. It is similar to And this thou shalt make it74Translated literally. (Gen. 7:15).75The meaning of which is, and this size thou shalt make it. In other words, here too “this” is an abridged form.

[EVERY ONE THAT PASSETH.] The meaning of every one that passeth is everyone who passes his twentieth year. Twenty years is about three weeks of years [almost twenty-one years].76According to I.E. the number seven has a special significance. See I.E. on Gen. 8:5 and the notes thereto. A person’s mind is then fully developed. His body also no longer grows in height.77A person is then mentally and physically mature.
[GERAHS.] These gerahs78According to I.E. the word gerah is related to the word gargir [berry or pit]. refer to the pits of a carob.79A gerah weighed the same as a pit of a carob.
