Rabbi Saadiah Gaon composed a very important work refuting those who dispute with the ancients regarding the Sabbath lights.10The reference is to the Karaites, who prohibit a candle that is lit before the onset of the Sabbath from continuing to burn on the Sabbath.
AND MOSES SPOKE. Moses now began to explain to the entire congregation what God had commanded him.

TAKE. The word kechu (take) is the opposite of tenu (give). However, when a mem follows a word from the root lamed, kof, chet,11As it does in our verse, for our verse reads, kechu me-ittekhem. Others emend to a lamed not a mem, because I Kings 17:10 reads, kechu li. If this is the case, then the lamed referred to is the lamed in la-Adonai. then it has the meaning of give. The meaning of kechu li (take me) in Take me, I pray thee, a little water (I Kings 17:10)12Translated literally. is, take for me,13Literally, because the taking is for me. take on my account. It is the same case with Take (kechu) ye from among you (me-ittekhem) an offering unto the Lord (la-Adonai).14Its meaning is, take for me an offering for the Lord.

[WHOSOEVER IS OF A WILLING HEART.] The phrase kol nediv libbo (whosoever is of a willing heart) is irregular.15It is irregular for the following two reasons: a) Nediv, which is an adjective, is in the construct. An adjective does not usually come in the construct. b) Libbo is a declined noun. A declined noun is not usually preceded by a word in the construct (Filwarg). It should be noted that the literal meaning of kol nediv libbo is, whosoever willing of his heart. It should be interpreted as if written kol asher nedavo libbo (all whose heart made them willing). We find the same with bi-gedol zero’akha16Bi-gedol (by the greatness of), an adjective, is in the construct with zero’akha (Thine arm), which is a declined noun. (By the greatness of Thine arm) (Ex. 15:16), which should be interpreted as if written bi-zero’akha ha-gadol (by Thy great arm); and zekher rav tuvekha (the fame of Thy great goodness)17Translated literally. Rav (great), an adjective, is in the construct with tuvekha (Thy goodness), which is a declined noun. (Ps. 145:7), which should be interpreted as if written zekher tuvekha ha-rav (the fame of goodness which is great). Rabbi Joshua says that the vav of libbo is superfluous.18In other words, our phrase is to be read as if written, kol nediv lev (whosoever is of a willing heart). This only eliminates libbo’s irregularity. It does not explain the. irregularity of nediv (Filwarg). It is similar to the vav of chayeto in chayeto19Chayeto is be interpreted as if written chayyat. sadai (every beast of the field) (Ps. 104:11) and the vav of beno in beno20Beno is to be interpreted as if written ben. be’or (Balaam the son of Beor) (Num. 24:3).

[LET HIM BRING IT.] After stating let him bring it, Scripture continues to explain, and goes on to say that the reference is to the Lord’s offering.21The Lord’s offering appears to be redundant. Hence I.E. notes that it is the style of Scripture to occasionally elaborate. See I.E. on Ex. 2:6; 3:14. There are many such instances, one of them being, and he hath commanded me, my brother (I Sam. 20:29).22Translated literally. My brother explains and he hath commanded me.

[AND SILVER.] Some say that the word kesef (silver) is etymologically related to the word nikhsefah (yearneth) (Ps. 94:3),23They both come from the root kaf, samekh, peh. and that silver is so called because it is a delight to the eyes.24The phrase “a delight to the eyes” is a quote from Gen. 3:6. Nechoshet (brass) is also so called because women practice magic (me-nachashot) with brass (nechoshet).25They employ brass objects in their magical practices (Filwarg).

AND SCARLET. The word shani (scarlet) is here spelled without a mem. We also find it spelled with a mem. Compare shanim (scarlet) in Though your sins be as scarlet (Is. 1:18). Perhaps the latter is a plural.26Hence it is spelled with a mem. According to this interpretation, shani is the singular form for scarlet and shanim is its plural form.

AND SKINS. The word orot (skins) is masculine.27Even though it has a feminine ending, for the word or (skin) is masculine. Luchot (tables) is similar.28Luchot is masculine even though it has a feminine ending, for the word lu’ach (tablet) is masculine. So is bechorot (firstlings) in and the firstlings of…thy flock (Deut. 14:23).29Bechorot is masculine even though it has a feminine ending, for the word bechor (firstling) is masculine.

ACACIA-WOOD. Shittim (acacia),30The plural of shittah, which is a feminine noun. Feminine nouns usually end in a tav in the future. Hence I.E.’s comment. like the word nashim (women), is spelled with a mem.31Even though it is feminine.

AND OIL. Scripture does not mention pure beaten olive oil32Scripture reads, and oil for the light. However, in view of Ex: 27:20 it should have read: and pure beaten olive oil for the light. because this is known.33It is known that the oil employed in the lighting of the menorah must be pure beaten olive oil. See Ex. 27:20. Scripture therefore reads la-ma’or (for the light), as is the custom.34Whenever Scripture refers to something that is known it employs the definite article. Hence Scripture reads la-ma’or, which, according to I. E., means for the light, rather than le-ma’or, for light. Moses now mentioned that those who were “willing-hearted” should bring their offerings.35Verse 5. He then went on to say that those who were certain that they were experts in the crafts should come and make [all that the Lord hath commanded].36Verse 10. Moses began37His list in verse 6 of what God commanded the Israelites to make. with the tabernacle38The reference is to the woven curtains. See Rashi and Ex. 26:1-6. because it takes in everything.39The term mishkan (tabernacle) does not refer only to the woven curtains. It also refers to the entire sanctuary. See Ex. 25:9. The tent40It is mentioned next in the verse. The tent was made out of goats’ hair. See Ex. 26:7-11. served as its cover. He then mentions its covering.41Which were placed over the woven curtains. Its covering takes in the two coverings.42Which were placed over the covering of goats. See Ex. 26:14.
ITS CLASPS. The clasps of the tabernacle and the tent.43See Ex. 26:6,11.

ITS BARS, ITS PILLARS, AND ITS SOCKETS. The pillars for the veil and the screen.44See Ex. 26:31,32; 36,37. Scripture then mentions45In verse 12. the holy vessels which were placed behind the veil.46In the Holy of Holies.

AND THE SHOWBREAD. For the table was constructed for the showbread.47The showbread was not actually placed upon the table at this time. Hence I.E. points out that the showbread was mentioned at this time because the table was made for it. So Filwarg. Krinsky explains that I.E. interpreted and the showbread to mean: and the other utensils necessary for the preparation of the showbread.
THE CANDLESTICK. Scripture mentions the oil for the light because the menorah was made for it.48The oil was mentioned earlier in verse 8. Why mention it again?

AND THE ALTAR. Scripture concludes the account of the holy vessels. It then mentions the screen for the door. Now the vessels of the oil for the lighting, and the vessels of the anointing oil and the sweet incense, shall be placed between the veil and the screen of the door49Scripture mentions these articles after mentioning the veil (v. 12) but before mentioning the screen (v. 15). Hence I.E. concludes that they were placed between the veil and the screen. of the tabernacle because they are holy.

THE LAVER AND ITS BASE. Observe, the laver and its base had no staves50Unlike the ark and the table of showbread, the laver and its base had no staves by which to be carried.. It is possible that they were carried on wagons.

THE HANGINGS OF THE COURT, THE PILLARS THEREOF (AMMUDAV), AND THEIR SOCKETS (ADONEHAH).51Ammudav is masculine. Adonehah is feminine. Ammudav and adonehah both refer to chatzer (courtyard). Scripture thus treats chatzer both as a feminine and a masculine. Our verse is similar52In its treatment of a word both as a masculine and a feminine in one verse. to and a great (gedolah)53Gedolah is feminine. and strong (chazak)54Chazak is masculine.wind (ru’ach)55Scripture thus treats ru’ach both as a feminine and a masculine. (I Kings 19:11) and to A fire (esh) not blown (nuppach)56Nuppach is masculine. by man shall consume him (te’okhlehu)57Te’okhlehu is feminine. Scripture thus treats esh both as a feminine and a masculine. (Job 20:26).
THE PLAITED GARMENTS. Necessary for the journey.58According to I.E. the bigde ha-sered served to cover the holy vessels when Israel journeyed. See I.E. on Ex. 31:10.

DEPARTED. We learn from this that the entire congregation of Israel came to the tent of meeting group by group.59There was no room in the tent of meeting for the entire congregation of Israel to gather there at one time. Hence I.E.’s comment.

AND THEY CAME, EVERY ONE WHOSE HEART STIRRED HIM UP. The reference is to the wise-hearted.60Mentioned in verse 10. The meaning of nesa’o libbo (whose heart stirred him up) is, whosoever had an exalted heart.61Nesa’o libbo literally means whose heart exalted him. I.E. takes this to mean whose heart exalted him over other craftsmen. He identifies those whose heart stirred them up with the “wise-hearted” mentioned in verse 10. I.E. interprets thus because nowhere else does Scripture indicate that the “wise-hearted” actually came to make the vessels that God had commanded to be made. See Krinsky and Netter.

MEN AND WOMEN. The meaning of al nashim (and women) is, with women.62In other words, al here has the meaning of with. I.E. comments thus because al usually means on. Al here is similar to al (with)63That is, it has the meaning of with. in with (al) the bread of the first-fruits for a wave-offering (Lev. 23:20). There are many other such instances.64Where al has the meaning of with.

AS MANY AS WERE WILLING-HEARTED. Nediv lev (willing-hearted)65Even though nediv lev is masculine. includes willing-hearted women. The term is used in the same sense as ha-shafan (and the rock-badger)66Which, while in the masculine, also includes females, for Scripture does not prohibit only the eating of male shefanim. (Lev. 11:5) and shor seh khevasim (the ox, the sheep) (Deut. 14:4).67The nouns shor and seh khevasim are in the masculine. However the terms also include the female of the species, for the Torah permits cows and female sheep to be eaten.
NOSE-RINGS. Chach is an earring.68J.P.S. translates chach as nose-ring.
AND EAR-RINGS. Nezem is a nose-ring.69J.P.S. translates nezem as ear-ring.
AND SIGNET-RINGS. Taba’at (signet-ring) is a ring which is placed on the finger.
AND GIRDLES. Kumaz (girdle) is a ring which is placed around the arm.70A metal armband.

AND EVERY MAN. Or woman.71The term ish (man) includes women. In addition,72Aside from bringing what the men brought, the women spun the blue, the purple, etc. the women spun the blue and the purple, the scarlet, the fine linen73Verse 25. and also the goats’ hair,74Verse 26. a craft which required exceptional skill.75Literally, wisdom.

AND THE RULERS BROUGHT THE ONYX STONES, AND THE STONES TO BE SET. They had these items because when Israel left Egypt and despoiled the Egyptians,76See Ex. 12:35,36. every Israelite asked for articles in accordance with his status.77The rulers asked for precious stones. Now it was truly a great thing that the rulers possessed oil for the light many months after Israel left Egypt. Scripture next mentions the men and women together78Verse 29. and backtracks and speaks of the women whose heart stirred them up to do the work.79According to I.E. the term la’asot (to be made) refers to the work done by the women (Weiser). It mentions the chief,80Bezalel, in verse 30. whom all should obey because there is no one as wise as he among them.
AND HE HATH FILLED HIM. Look. God bore witness that Bezalel was saturated with wisdom, understanding, and knowledge, and in addition was skilled in all manner of workmanship.

AND TO DEVISE SKILFUL WORKS. Ve-la-chashov machashavot (and to devise skilful works) is to be interpreted as meaning: and to devise in his heart designs which were never seen. [IN GOLD, AND IN SILVER.] For some people are skilled in working with gold but not in working with silver. Others are skilled stone masons but are not skilled wood carvers. However, Bezalel was a master of all of these crafts.

[AND HE HATH PUT IN HIS HEART THAT HE MAY TEACH.] In addition to the above, God put in his heart the ability to teach because there are many wise men who teach with great difficulty. Now Oholiab was Bezalel’s colleague in all the crafts and in the skill of teaching to others. Scripture therefore says with regard to both of them, even of them that do any workmanship, and of those that devise skilful works81I.E. assumes that as Bezalel and Oholiab were colleagues in workmanship, and…skilful works, so were they colleagues in the ability to teach these skills. (v. 35).

SHALL WORK. Look. Bezalel himself shall make the glorious object.1The ark. See Ex. 37:1. Va-asah (shall work or shall make) is in the singular. Hence I.E.’s interpretation (Filwarg, Krinsky). However, he and Oholiab shall teach.2Hence Oholiab’s name is coupled with that of Bezalel.

CALLED. The heh of the word le-korvah (to come) is superfluous. It is like the heh in the word u-le-dovkah (and to cleave)3Which is also superfluous. in and to cleave unto Him (Deut. 11:22). A great scholar erred in saying that the word le-omdah (it might stand) (Ezek. 17:14) is similar, for the heh in le-omdah has a mappik4A dot. in it.5The heh with a mappik means it. Omed is an intransitive verb.6I.E. comments thus because an intransitive verb does not usually have a heh with a mappik suffixed to it. The heh with a mappik usually indicates the direct object. The meaning of le-omdah (it might stand) is therefore7Since le-omdah is intransitive. to stand by it.8The covenant. In other words, heh with a mappik does not mean to stand it but to stand by it, for omed is intransitive (see note 6). I.E. interprets Ezek. 17:14 as follows: To keep his covenant and to stand (abide) by it.
AND THEY RECEIVED. All the offering which they9The children of Israel. had brought.
AND THEY. The Israelites10Ve-hem (and they) refers to the Israelites. continued to bring free-will offerings to Moses every morning.
AND ALL THE WISE MEN…CAME. To Moses’ tent and said, The people bring much more [than enough for the service of the work] (v. 5).

[MUCH MORE THAN ENOUGH.] The mem of mi-de (much more than enough) means: much more than. It is, in keeping with my interpretation,11In Ps. 119:99. like the mem of mi-kol (more than all) in I have more understanding than all my teachers (Ps. 119:99).12I.E. takes issue with the Rabbinic interpretation that mi-kol in mi-kol melammedai hiskalti (I have more understanding than all my teachers) means: from all. See Abot 4:1: “Ben Zoma said: Who is wise? He who learns from all men; as it is said, From all (mi-kol) my teachers I have gotten understanding.” According to I.E. it means: more than all.

AND THEY CAUSED IT TO BE PROCLAIMED. Va-ya’aviru (and they caused to be proclaimed) is similar to va-ya’avor (and there went)13The root ayin, bet, resh means to pass over. It usually refers to people or objects. Hence I.E. points out that the term is also used in reference to sound. in And there went a cry throughout the host (I Kings 22:36).

FOR THE STUFF. The work which was done.14The Hebrew reads, ve-hamlakhah hayetah. Its literal meaning is: and the work was, which I.E.’s interprets as the work which was done. I.E. disagrees with the definition of melakhah as stuff.
[SUFFICIENT.] The mem of dayyam (sufficient) refers to all of the wise men.15The mem of dayyam is a suffix meaning for them, the reference being to the wise men mentioned in verse 4.
FOR ALL THE WORK. That they had to do.

AND TOO MUCH. Ve-hoter (and too much) is an infinitive. Its meaning is, ho-tirah (and they produced more than enough).16In other words, the infinitive form ve-hoter is here to be interpreted as a feminine perfect, for ve-hoter refers to melakhah, which is feminine. The work which they had done produced more than enough. So Filwarg.
MADE. Scripture begins with the making of the tabernacle.

TWINED. Moshzar (twined) means long in Arabic. Note that the single digit numbers17Literally, the ones, reading ha-achadim (the ones), as in Vat. Ebr. 38. The printed editions read, “Note that the number one (ha-echad) is grammatically irregular.” The problem with this reading is that I.E. nowhere discusses “the number one” in his comment. Weiser suggests that our text is defective. On the other hand, Filwarg and others interpret ha-echad as achadim. are grammatically irregular in Hebrew. This is also the case in Aramaic. They are similarly irregular in Arabic. The heh18That is, a heh preceded by a kamatz. at the end of a word indicates the feminine; the masculine does not have any sign.19The masculine singular does not have any sign indicating that the word is masculine. Now the heh in the number sheloshah (three) indicates the masculine.20In other words, in the single digit numbers the feminine ending indicates that the word is masculine. The same is true of the numbers arba’ah (four), shemonah (eight), asarah (ten).21I.E. is being brief. The same applies to chamishah (five), shishah (six), shivah (seven), and tishah (nine). From there22Ten. through twenty the masculine numbers do not have a heh at the end. We thus say achad asar (eleven),23Rather than achad asarah. shenem asar (twelve),24And similarly from thirteen through eighteen. tishah asar (nineteen). The feminine25The feminine form of the numbers eleven through twenty. is written with a heh.26As is the rule with feminine nouns. We thus say achat esreh (11), shetem esreh (12), shelosh esreh (13), etc. However, its vocalization is changed27It is not vocalized with a kamatz as is usual in the feminine, but with a tzere. See note 19. so that it reads esreh.28Not asarah. This is done so that the word not be confused with the masculine.29Asarah (ten). Hence we say shetem esreh (twelve). The same applies to all of the numbers.30Eleven through nineteen in the feminine. Look. Shalosh (three), arba (four), and eser (ten) are feminine. If their sum is in the construct then it ends in a tav both in the masculine and in the feminine. Compare, sheloshet ha-anashim ha-elleh (these three men) (Ezek. 14:16); and u-sheloshet neshe vanav (and the three wives of his sons) (Gen. 7:13). Now the masculine form for the number eight is shemonah, as the rule says.31The rule stating that numbers 3-10 end in a kamatz heh in the masculine. The feminine is unique in that one says shemoneh (eight)32Segol heh is usually a masculine ending. Compare, moreh (teacher), sadeh (field) (Weiser). in the same way that one says ashte esreh (eleven).33Ashte esreh (eleven), a feminine, is vocalized with a tzere even though the tzere is the construct form of masculine nouns ending in a segol.

[CUBITS.] It is possible that the reason our verse reads ba-ammah (cubits)34The kamatz beneath the bet indicates the definite article. is that it refers to a specific cubit. It possibly refers to the noble cubit of the first temple.35See I.E. on Ex 26:16 and the notes thereto.

[THE LOOPS.] The tav of ha-lula’ot (the loops)36Lula’ot is spelled lamed, vav, lamed, alef, vav, tav. indicates the feminine. The singular form of the word is lulah.37Lulah is spelled lamed, vav, lamed, heh. The heh [in lulah] takes the place of the alef.38There is no alef in lulah (see notes 36 and 37). Hence I.E.’s comment. Some say that the word lalat (near to be delivered) in was with child, near to be delivered (I Sam. 4:19) comes from the same root.39A woman about to deliver experiences labor pains. These pains can metaphorically be described as attaching themselves or looping themselves to the woman. Hence the term lalat. According to I.E. we should render I Sam. 4:19: was with child, seized by labor pains.
FOR THE TENT. La-ohel (for tent) means to serve as a tent.40La-ohel (for tent) literally means to tent. Hence I.E.’s interpretation.

[TO PASS THROUGH.] The word livro’ach (to pass through) is a kal. It has the same meaning as the hifil mavri’ach (pass through).41Mavri’ach is a participle. What I.E. means is that the word livro’ach (to pass through), which is an infinitive in the kal has the same meaning as the word le-havri’ach (to pass through), which is a hifil infinitive. Indeed, this is precisely what I.E. says in his short commentary. We find the same with the words yereh (shoot)42Yereh is a kal. and va-yoreh (and he shot)43Yoreh is a hifil. (II Kings 13:17).44Both of these words have a similar meaning even though they belong to different conjugational forms. There are many such instances.45Where words in different conjugational forms have similar meanings.

AND BEZALEL MADE. Bezalel made the ark because of its importance.1This is why our verse specifies that Bezalel made the ark. Bezalel also made all the holy vessels.2Though Scripture does not specifically say so. However, see Nahmanides, who writes: “Scripture states without elaboration, and he made the table (v. 10), and he made the candelabrum (v. 17). In the opinion of Rabbi Abraham ibn Ezra, this alludes to Bezalel, who made all the sacred vessels. But this is not my opinion, for in the case of the court of the Tabernacle it likewise says, and he made the court (Ex. 38:9), [and it would not be reasonable to say that Bezalel alone made the court]. Rather, this refers back to every wise-hearted man (Ex. 36:8) as mentioned in the making of the Tabernacle” (Nahmanides on Ex. 36:8, Chavel translation). Now Scripture3In chapter 36. mentions the tabernacle,4Ex. 36:8. the tent,5Ex 36:14. the veil,6Ex. 36:35. and the screen,7Ex. 36:37. for they serve a similar purpose.8The first two served as coverings and the latter two as partitions. According to Krinsky, Sarim, and Weiser, I.E.’s point is that Scripture tells us about the making of the sanctuary’s structure before writing about the making of its furniture, because it is the way of the world to first build a house and then to put in the furniture. Scripture then mentions the holy anointing oil with the incense of sweet spices9In verse 39. because there are spices in the anointing oil and also in the sweet incense.10I.E. was bothered by the juxtaposition of the anointing oil and the incense of the sweet spices. These two preparations did not serve a similar purpose. Why, then, list them next to each other?

[OF THE MIRRORS.] Be-marot (of the mirrors) has a bet rather than a mem prefaced to it.1The usual way to say “of the mirrors” is mi-marot, for a mem prefaced to a word means from or of. On the other hand, a bet prefaced to a word means in or with. Hence our verse should have read mi-marot rather than be-marot. It is proper Hebrew to do so.2In other words, the bet may be used in place of a mem. We find the same in the verse ve-ha-notar ba-basar u-va-lachem (and that which remaineth of the flesh and of the bread) (Lev. 8:32).3Here too a bet is used in place of a mem, for we would expect ve-ha-notar me-ha-basar u-me-ha-lachem. It is the same case in Arabic.

[THAT DID SERVICE.] Scripture states this because it is the custom of all women to beautify themselves. They look at their faces in brass or glass mirrors every morning to arrange the head coverings4Hebrew, pe’arim. upon their heads. These head coverings are mentioned in the Book of Isaiah.5Is. 3:20 speaks of the pe’arim (the headtires). The custom of Israel was the same as the Moslem practice unto this very day.6Moslem women in I.E.’s day placed head coverings on their heads. Hence I.E.’s comment. Now there were in Israel women who served God and removed themselves from the pleasures of this world. These women gave their mirrors as a free-will offering because they had no need to beautify themselves. They rather came daily to the door of the tent of meeting to pray and to hear the words of the commandments. Scripture states, that did service (tzave’u)7Tzave’u is in the plural. at the door of the tent of meeting because there were many such women.

[THE LAVER.] Scripture does not mention the dimensions of the laver as it does in the case of the lavers that Solomon made.8Each one of the lavers made by Solomon contained forty baths (I Kings 7:38). The laver9Mentioned in our verse. was rather made out of all the mirrors that were brought.10It had no preconceived measure. It measured whatever size all the brass mirrors came to.

[THE BASE.] The ken,11Referred to in our verse. that is, the base,12Weiser renders: The ken (base), which is the same as the mekhonah (base) mentioned in I Kings 7:38, was in all instances the same size as the laver. was in all instances the same size as the laver13“By the same size” I.E. means that a larger laver had a larger base, a smaller laver had a smaller base. as is normally the case.

AND FOR THE WEST SIDE. Scripture14In Ex. 26:22; 36:27. refers to the west as the hinder part15Hebrew, yerakhim. because the tent’s opening was on the east, which is referred to as the face. Scripture16In verses 14 and 15. refers to the sides which were close to the door17Of the tabernacle. as shoulders,18Verses 14 and 15 refer to each of the sides of the tabernacle as a katef (side), which literally means a shoulder. for they19The sides. are compared to the shoulders of a human being.

Give thanks to God and ascribe power to Him O “Father of a multitude,”20An allusion to Abraham ibn Ezra. See Gen. 17:5, where Abraham is a shortened form for father of a multitude of nations. Now that you have reached the opening of the Torah portion Ellah Pekude.

THESE ARE THE ACCOUNTS OF THE TABERNACLE. Its meaning is: these are the accounts of the vessels of the tabernacle, for the word tabernacle includes everything.21It does not refer only to the sanctuary’s structure; it refers to its contents as well. Scripture goes on to explain why the structure was referred to as a mishkan (tabernacle).22The word mishkan literally means a resting place. It was so called because the tablets of testimony were placed in it.23Hence Scripture reads, even the tabernacle of the testimony. Now Scripture was brief.24Even the tabernacle of the testimony is short for: even the tabernacle of the tablets of testimony. The tablets were truly a testimony, because God’s writing was inscribed upon them.

[THROUGH THE SERVICE OF THE LEVITES.] Its meaning is: through the service of the Levites who carry the tabernacle and all of its vessels which Ithamar appointed to them. For the Gershonites and the Merarites were the Levites under the direction of Ithamar, who listed all the objects they were assigned to carry.25See Num. 4:22-32.

AND BEZALEL. Scripture notes that Bezalel and Oholiab, who were first in rank,26They were the chief workers. “Everything was done through (Bezalel’s) direction, for he acted as instructor to all the wise men, and they did their work in his presence and showed him all that they had done” (Nahmanides). executed all of their tasks properly.

ALL THE GOLD. Saadiah Gaon asks, “Why does Scripture note what was done with the silver but does not mention what the donated gold was used for?”27Scripture, in verses 27 and 28, itemizes what the silver was used for. However, it does not do the same for the gold. He answers, “Look. Scripture notes that the menorah was made out of a talent of gold.28Ex. 25:39. This was also the case with the ark cover29According to Ex. 25:17 the ark cover was made of pure gold. However, it does not state how much gold was used to make it. and the gold utilized for the ark and the altar of incense.”30Saadiah Gaon apparently held that since Scripture tells us that the menorah was made from a talent of gold, the same was true of the ark, the table, and the altar of incense. Thus Scripture does in fact tell us what the gold was utilized for. The remaining gold was then used for various other items. See I.E.’s short commentary on this verse. We thus know what four talents of gold was used for. Now this is incorrect.31That the ark, table, and altar of incense were each made from a talent of gold. Only the menorah was entirely made of gold. This was not the case with the ark. The ark was only overlaid with gold on the inside and on the outside. The same was true of the altar of incense. The table, the staves, the boards, and the bars were all overlaid with gold. The ark cover was made completely of gold.32As noted in Ex. 25:17. According to the tradition passed on to us by our fathers the ark cover was made from a talent of gold because it was very broad and very wide. I believe that Scripture mentions what they did with the silver because the silver was given for atonement.33See Ex. 30:15. Observe. The one who says this127That Scripture never explicitly states that Israel journeyed at night. explains or if it continued by day and by night (Num. 9:21) as referring to one day.128Num. 9:21 states, And sometimes the cloud was from evening until morning; and when the cloud was taken up in the morning, they journeyed; or if it continued by day and by night (o yomam va-laylah), when the cloud was taken up, they journeyed. Now o yomam va-laylah can be translated in two ways: a) Or it continued by day and by night. b) Or it continued for a day or for a night. According to the latter translation our verse reads, “or if it continued by day or by night (o yomam va-laylah) when the cloud was taken up, they journeyed.” Thus the verse teaches that Israel at times traveled at night. Hence those who maintain that Israel did not journey at night interpret o yomam va-laylah as referring to a 24-hour period, that is, a day and a night. This opinion interprets o yomam va-laylah as: or it continued by day and by night, that is, a full day consisting of a day and a night. Now what will they do with the phrase their journeys (v. 38)? Scripture does not read: throughout all their encampments.129If Scripture intended to teach that they journeyed during the day and camped at night, then our verse should have read: For the cloud of the Lord was upon the tabernacle by day, and there was fire therein by night, in the sight of all the house of Israel, throughout all their “encampments,” rather than For the cloud of the Lord was upon the tabernacle by day, and there was fire therein by night, in the sight of all the house of Israel, throughout all their “journeys.” The latter implies that Israel journeyed at night. The correct meaning of or…by day and by night is: or day and night; or: or day or night.130In other words, Israel journeyed at night. Our text literally reads, “Its meaning is (u-pirusho), or day and night, or, or day or night.” This reading is a bit difficult. I.E. is trying to prove that Israel journeyed at night. Hence why mention the interpretation, or day and night (see note 122). Indeed, Vat. Ebr. 38 reads, “Its meaning is (u-pirusho), or day or night.” If we emend pirusho to pirush then our text reads, “The meaning of (u-pirush) Or…by day and by night is: or day or night.” This is probably the reading upon which our text is based, for pirusho seems to be a scribal error for pirush. It is similar to And he that curseth his father and his mother,131Hebrew, aviv ve-immo (his father and his mother). shall surely be put to death (Ex. 21:17).132Translated literally. The meaning of Ex. 21:17 is, And he that curseth his father “or” his mother shall surely be put to death. We thus see that the vav sometimes has the meaning of or. Similarly, yomam va-laylah is not to be rendered day and night but rather day or night. I had to say this because I noticed that the prayer which Moses uttered on the occasion of the scouts states, and thou goest before them, in a pillar of cloud by day, and in a pillar of fire by night (Num. 14:14).133This verse implies that Israel journeyed at night, for prima facie, and Thou goest before them also refers to and in a pillar of fire by night.
